reviews.review: If you like art this is the place to go. A lovely location next to the Botanic Gardens and close to great vistas over stunning Sydney Harbour. Beautiful collection of Australian art and a lovely building. FREE too. Usually has great exhibitions (usually paid). Well worth a visit.

Great mix of the classics with modern. Spending as many hours as you can manage through this magnificent collection is reall rewarding.Of particular note this time for me was Manifesto,which is a must see

Frida Kahlo exhibition well worth the visit!. On a recent visit to Sydney took an opportunity to see the Frida Kahlo exhibition; came away with a better appreciation of her work. Great gallery and plenty to see outside of the exhibition. Two hours really to fully appreciate it all.

Day of Art. I love the art gallery of NSW. I recently was there with a friend and she had never actually been here before. For the size of the building, there did not seem to be as much art as you would expect. And I therefore am sad to say that this will not be a visit I intend for some time from now. The place needs a freshen up and made a little more exciting, romantic and fresh

Frida Kahlo. the reason for our trip to Sydney. met all our expectations. fantastic exhibition and we learnt a lot more about Frida and Diego's life.Also the rest of the Gallery very inpressive, comong from Melbourne it was good to see companion pieces from artists we know so well who are on show at the NGV

Archibald. The Art Gallery hold the Archibald competition every year. You have to pay for this exhibition, but there are many areas of the Art Gallery that are free, and on a wet Sunday - it is a delightful place to spend some time. You can spend many hours walking around admiring the paintings. Other that the Archibald - the Art Gallery of NSW holds many other exhibitions throughout the year and there is always something for everyone's taste. There is also the café for a light meal or coffee. A special place to visit especially if you are a visitor to Sydney.

Keep your eyes out for the current exhibitions. The gallery is always changing its main exhibition. We went to view the Archibald/Sulman Prize entrants - very good this year - and make sure you don't miss the Young Archies section.I strongly suggest you book in at Chiswick for a delicious meal to top off your visit.

What a gem !. I wish my shoes were comfier because I could have spent way longer here ! Such a diverse display . Was wonderful to see originals that I'd never seen in real life . The pop art was probably my favorite this visit .The gallery was very busy with lots of school groups. Guided tours are available.

Fridas Exhibition. Im not an art gallery type person but I adore Frida Kahlo and enjoyed the art that they had there.Had some free time so went and checked out a few of the other galleries they had which I thought were quite nice. Also had fun snapping pictures and sending them as memes to mates. Some of the facial expressions were hilarious!Thanks for the memories

Beautiful art works especially the Archibald Prize entries. The Art Gallery of New South Wales is a short walk from the Botanic Gardens if you walk straight up over the hill. It's a longer walk if you walk around the harbour shore. You'll find a magnificent historic building which has a modern addition. Some exhibitions are not free - for example the Archibald Prize. BUT it's worth the money! You will be surprised by the paintings. Some are huge, some small but all excellent and a little different from the norm. Most of the entries would have taken months maybe years to finish. The Archibald entries have to be or include a portrait. So many of the paintings are of famous people, but not all. I was blown away by the works and I'm very glad we toured the gallery.

Always something to see. If you have time and want to spend it enjoying a variety of art and exhibits, then the Art Gallery will not disappoint. A lovely space to wander around in and soak up history and view engaging exhibits. Nice cafe and space to relax.

Wonderful gallery. Great to visit whatever is on exhibit, but we saw Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera this year, as well as the Archibald, Sulman, and Wynee prize entries, and all of them were worth seeing. It was very busy on the day we visited, so the lunch experience at the main café was crowded, and rather expensive. It's a lovely building and there is a magnificent collection of varied artworks throughout.

2016 Archibald Wynne and Sulman Prize. The NSW Art Gallery is perched on a hill high above the beautiful Sydney Harbour near the Botanical Gardens. It is easy to access by public transport or car parking in the domain or on metres in Lady Macquarie's Drive. We started with a coffee and cake on their outdoor terrace cafe overlooking the harbour. The Archibald is a famous portrait painting competition held every year of well known community figures. This year " Barry" won by Louise Hearman. It is a striking painting of the larger than life actor Barry Humphris famous for his alter ego "Dame Edna Everidge". I also enjoyed the Wynne prize which is landscapes this year won by five aboriginal sisters, the Ken family collaborative from South Australia telling the story of the older women protecting the younger women from attacks from men. It is a beautiful mythological representation in magnificent colours. "Conservatory No 2" by Leah Bullen won the Watercolor Prize. It has the wonderful feel of actually being in a beautiful conservatory. The Sulman Prize for subject, genre or mural painting had a fantastic " Social Climbing " painting of Dalmatians forming a pyramidal hierarchy by Joanna Braithwaite. The exhibition has gone on tour now. It is worth a visit.
Wonderful Art Collectiom. NSW Art Gallery has an amazing collection of Art work, I was lucky to check out the Archibald exerbition while I was in Sydney, very much worth a visit when visiting Sydney

Fabulous Art Fablous Location. I recently took a day trip to Sydney with my art teacher. We were going to go to the Brett Whitley museum but I didn't look at the opening days! Alas we were in Sydney and we had a little hire car so we went to the Art Gallery of New South Wales instead. What a beautiful day! I even got to sit and do a sketch of one of views from the many huge windows. I learnt so much about art and technique that day!

Frida Kahlo exhibit. Lovely gallery. Superb works on display spanning many styles and eras. Free hourly tours are a must do for insight. Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera limited exhibit was a definite highlight.

If you have time to visit only one museum in Sydney visit this one!. The Art Gallery of New South Wales, in my view, is the only museum in Sydney which compares favourably to the famous museums of the world. It's a medium sized gallery which contains pieces of art from different parts of the world and from different time periods. Different sections of the museum are dedicated to different geographies, for e.g.: 19th century European art; Aboriginal art; Asian art. There is a strong focus on Australian art with pieces ranging from the time of early white settlement to present day works.There is also a floor for contemporary art which I thought was a good addition to the mainly traditional paintings and sculptures of other sections.Overall it is a medium sized museum with a good range of varied small collections. Recommend it if you have three hours to spare in the city.

Lovely Australian collection in a pleasant building. As a local I've gone to this gallery every year since I started school, sometimes for specific exhibitions, which I mostly enjoy (though the Masters exhibition was disappointing, the gallery in Canberra generally does better for international art), but also just to wander around my old favourites in the Australian art section. The free sections are plenty to walk around and have some lovely landscapes from federation Australia and before, including some Heidelberg School works and Tom Roberts. I would advise not to eat at the café or go to the gift shop as they are pretty expensive and quite standard fare, pack a picnic lunch and enjoy it in the gardens outside, and there is a café opposite that is a bit more reasonable for lunch. The good thing about the gallery is that is so large you can spend as little or as much time in as you like, I never do the whole thing at once. The design of the building is also lovely, especially the foyer and areas to the right when you first walk in. It is also lovely and cool on hot days.

Fantastic gallery!. We loved the gallery which includes many famous artists and art works, but especially loved the Archibald prize entries which we attended for. I was so excited to be able to come to this as a once in a lifetime event and I travelled from Far North Queensland. I enjoyed the art work, there were some amazing entries and the peoples choice could have been a photo. Other art work was in the eyes of the beholder, it was especially hard to see the works or read the plaques due to the number of people. We could spend days at this gallery!

Wednesday night at the Art Gallery . We went there on a Wednesday night and I must say we had a great time. We walked all the way through from the Rocks, the botanical garden to the Art Gallery of NSW after a day at work; it was really peaceful, relaxing and enjoyable. Once at the AG, we had the chance to assist to an "intimate family style concert" while drinking a glass of sparkling white wine: spot on. Finally we attended the Archibald expo.

So much to explore. Most people aren't aware that the NSW Gallery actually has a really good contemporary art collection. Just head down the series of elevators till you reach the bottom. It's a stunning sombre space under the gallery, and has some really interesting pieces, without the mass of people who crowd the top floors.

Archibald Exhibition 2016 was disappointing. The Art Gallery of NSW is overall a brilliant destination with its own great collection and many interesting special exhibitions. Last year's Archibald Prize exhibition was amazing but 2016 was a big disappointment. There were some brilliantly executed portraits but others mere daubs, seemingly chosen along politically correct lines, rather than artistic skill.
Nice - free entry. free entry (except the exibitions area), lots of galleries with the description. put in list if you have 1-2 hours...

Sydney Lover.. Combine a walk through the Botanical Gardens with a visit to The Art Gallery with dinner at either Cowper Wharf (Finger Wharf) or the Rocks for an amazing day.All these central Sydney attractions are within minutes of each other.Enjoy the art, the harbour, the gardens and the adjacent Opera House.

A great way to spend a few hours. This gallery has an eclectic collection.Something for everyone.There are always changing exhibitions and an excellent collection of indigenous art and artefacts as well as Australian artists.Well worth a visit.It is free for all but select exhibition

Freda exhibition. Went to see the Freda Karlow exhibition which was fantastic but had a good look around the gallery and saw an amazing array of beautiful works of art. The environment was very peaceful and welcoming with plenty of guides there to assist with any question. To actually see and be within centimetres of some of the great works of art from Australia and overseas is truly humbling but also inspiring. It's a place that when you leave you feel like you want to go back as often as you can and leaves you with a feeling that you have really experienced something magical

Frida. Exhibition of Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera. As a Mexican I love these painters and I was a bit disappointed about the amount of paintings. Nevertheless, it was very well organized and friendly staff very helpful because I have a bad foot. The room needs more chairs for disable or impediment people but it was that small that it wasn't a problem.

Gorgeous Gallery. This is a wonderful art gallery that again, is free to the public and has an amazing collection as well as special exhibits that do incur a charge. We were fortunate enough to be able to view the Frieda Kahlo exhibit which was small but wonderful. Well worth a few hours of your time, especially on a rainy day.

Archibald Prize exhibition - well worth a visit. We visitied the Archibald Prize Exhibition and General Collection. Lucky enough to have been there on People Choice Award announcement day. Venue is spectacular heritage venue with modern galleries inside. Just off Botanic Gardens is a lovely walk from the CBD. Spend as long as like - check out exhibitions on website - well priced.
Lovely Gallery. I love visiting here - such a great rainy day activity too. Took a friend who was visiting Sydney as part of the list see tourist attractions. Archibald Prize is currently on too.

Splendour in Art. My seniors tour bus drppoed us early in the Domain for a 10 am opening of the NSW Art Gallery. Beautiful area , harbour views, Pavilion Restaurant handy for refreshments. The Art Gallery was featuring at this visit the Archibald Prize collection ( fee) so a large crowd was present.However one can spend ( no charge) easily 2-3 hours in this magnificent venue admiring the various works/ paintings from famous artists. Bookshop and pleasant leafy indoor / outdoor cafe for purchases.Easy steps/ lift access to different levels.Our tour coach picked group up at Gallery afterwards- not sure of parking. Public transport close by.

Spacious and great exhibits. Recently went for Archibald, Sulman & Wynne exhibits. Enjoyed all three exhibits. I was particularly impressed with the Young Archies, amzing upcoming artists. The NSW Art Gallery is a beautiful old building and inside is very spacious. It houses some very well known and also many lessor known Australian artists. Free entry unless you are attending special exhibits. Pop down to the cafe for a delicious fresh lunch or snack while you are there.

One of Sydney's best Art Galleries. The gallery always has a good selection of free exhibits but also excellent visiting exhibitions that are well worth seeing. Definitely worth a visit. It also has events such as Jazz evening and art classes and the café with water views is great too.

Archibald disappointing but lots of other absorbing things to see. Visited to see the 2016. Archibald, Wynn and Sulman entries. The art was spread across the usual galleries downstairs. The Archibald entries were mostly disappointing - Barry Humphries (the winning Archibald entry) looked like the local butcher. The Wynn and Sulman entries on the whole excellent made up for it. If the $18 entry fee for the Archiblad et al puts you off choose from one or more of the other great galleries. Take time to have a look at the Yoshitoshi exhibition. This is a room of gorgeous Japanese prints. You will while away a lot of time absorbing the divine details to be found in the 100 prints. Give the cafe a miss though. The gallery still has not got this part of its operations working well. The cafeteria feel and general level of grot that staff are not able to manage effectively is quite off putting.
fantastic. Best art gallery i've seen in Australia. We spent a day and a half there seeing three different exhibits.

One day stretched to two and could have been three!. The main purpose of our trip to Sydney on the weekend from across Australia, was to visit the Archibald Prize. Being visual art teachers and artists in our own right meant we had a very hyper sensitive critical eye. The Gallery was full of surprises, our main exhibitions that we'd come to see proved disappointing however the surprises came with the main collection, Manifesto, the early 20th century relief prints, collage and drawing prize which all made up for our disappointment for the main exhibitions that had originally bought us to AGNSW. Sydney-centricity was alive and well in the choice of artists in the Archibald, skills and composition aside the artists seem to have been chosen rather on some sort of social/cultural standing in Sydney society, something i'd been previously unaware of until seeing firsthand. The Archibald gave me a greater understanding of Tina who has singlehandedly championed the Black Swan Prize for Portraiture in the west.Cafe food was fine. One day stretched to two and we could have come back anther but were booked back home.

Frida Kahlo and the Archibald portrait award exhibition. Get there soon for a wonderful exhibition of paintings,drawings and photos Frida Kahlo and her husband. Well laid out and very interesting.also the Archibald prize paintings are very varied and stunning. I joined 2 free tours and found these informative. Good cafe behind the exhibition also.

A world class gallery. We always enjoy visiting this marvellous gallery. Sydney is fortunate to have a gallery of this quality in such a central and attractive location. On this occasion we came for the Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo exhibition as well as the Archibald, Wynne and Sulman Prize exhibition. The former was an excellent exhibition with a wonderful range of paintings by both artists supplemented by stunning photographs. The time-lines and general information provided were informative and accessible. We had previously seen a number of Diego Rivera's murals but had not encountered his paintings. We left feeling far better informed about the lives and works of these important artists. The Archibald, Wynne and Sulman Prize exhibition was well presented and of great interest as always.This experience was similar to our previous visits, whether for a particular exhibition or to look at the expansive permanent collection. We would recommend that anyone with an interest in art visits the gallery while they are in Sydney.

A visit for the Frida & Diego Exhibition and the Archibald Exhibition. It had been a few years since my last visit, but I've vowed to go more often from now on. The gallery is free to enter and see all the permanent exhibits. The special exhibits on at the moment are $18 each for adult tickets. Both special exhibits were wonderful. If you do wish to see a special exhibit - book your tickets online ahead of time, saves waiting in the queue and some of them, like the Frida and Diego exhibition, have timed tickets. The permanent exhibits are also very good, with a wide range to look at. There is a café on the lower floor catering for lunches or a quick snack which was quite nice. There is also a restaurant, but we didn't try that. If you're going on a weekend, parking at the Domain Car Park is easy and a flat $10 for the day.

Great....but be careful!. We came specifically from Perth in WA to see the Archibald and the Frida Kahlo/Rivera exhibition, but made the Rookie error of not checking what exactly was in the Kahlo exhibition, ie practically no paintings of note, displayed in a cramped, corridor-like space with a shuffle along queue. Don't take more than 2 seconds to look at anything or one feels guilty. Not a good chance to see interesting work. Lots of biographical detail and lots of photos of them( repeat cramped shuffling queue) but this is just filler, which you can read anyway in other media. Maybe this is just another example of the antipodes getting the lesser works.The Archibald was inconsistent, but worth seeing and the trick for all shows is to purchase tickets in advance. Save more shuffling in a queue.Downstairs cafe food: roast glazed ham and roast veg for $18 was excellently tasty!The main collection is a delight and a salutary lesson to some of the painters exhibited in the Archibald downstairs. We are coming back tomorrow to spend time with the rest of it!
A bit of Culture. We spent a lovely afternoon at the gallery and also caught a Hitchcock movie. Great atmosphere and especially enjoyed the Archibald exhibition and lunch on the terrace.

Should visit if you love Art. The exhibition is always well curated. A great collection of Australian Art, and showcases some fantastic, changing exhibitions of both local, historical and international art.

Excellent place to spend 3 hours.... After a busy conference in Sydney I had a few hours to spend before flying out. Lovely walk from the CBD to the art gallery via the park walkway. Free entry to a wonderful permanent collection over three floors with an additional Aus$18 to see the Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera exhibition - which was excellent. Didn't use the restaurant but it looked good. Nice museum shop too! Definitely recommended.
Overpriced food. $14 for a meat pie without accompaniments. Really! Take a picnic and sit in the botanic gardens or walk down to Charlies at "The Loo" instead.

The Archibald Prize exhibition is well worth a visit this year. For the first time, we agreed on the winner of the Archibald Prize. The Gallery offers free guided tours. The cafe is good value for a snack.

Artworks and the Archibald - What a Great Visit !. The Art Gallery of NSW is always a wonderful place to visit, with so many famous, exciting and diverse works of art to see - free of charge - in magnificent galleries. Further, for a small charge the Archibald, Sulman and Wynne Prize Exhibitions are well worth seeing. The Archibald winning portrait of Barry Humphries should alone justify a visit. Externally the Gallery is architecturally striking and is fronted by the expansive lawns of the Domain and is adjacent to the Royal Botanical Gardens, another place of natural beauty.. Want a marvellous half day visit In Sydney, then go to them all, you won't be disappointed. A must see.

Fabulous venue on a rainy day. We recently visited the Archibald. The exhibition is always well curated. A pleasant vista with a nice snack awaits at the other end if you go at a time when the gallery is not too crowded

Great permanent collection, lovely building, exciting changing exhibitions. A beautiful building which holds a great collection of Australian Art, and showcases some fantastic, changing exhibitions of both local, historical and international art. The main gallery collection - hung in the original galleries to the right once inside the entry, has a great range of works and there is no charge to enter this area. Changing exhibitions are through the other galleries and you need to purchase tickets for these in the main area once inside the gallery. There is a cafe with an outside deck on the lower level, and the restaurant is on the same level as the entry. Check out the AGNSW website to find out what exhibitions are on during your visit.

Free and Fabulous. This is a wonderful and restful space. It is a mixture of modern and old architecture to house a eclectic collection of art. The exhibitions in clude - old masters, Australian traditional art, modern and pop art, sculpture and asian art and of course indigenous art. There is something for everybody here. There is a cafe serving quick meals and snacks as well as an upmarket restaurant. Take a couple of hours and enjoy the art and the views over the harbour.
Chinese exebision. We visit with friends very nice Ely to axes even will Cher pleases to have rest facilities parking in the street

Always a treat to go to NSW gallery. Went to Frida Kahlo exhibition, loved it. Gallery was very busy but what a great place to visit! Must go if you ever go to Sydney, lots of classic and contemporary free exhibitions and lovely stroll around the gift shop, delightful walk around Domain outside and Hyde Park as well. Use public transport by train or bus is the best option.
Great museum. Spent a few hours here, exploring the many different types of art and exhibits. Was an enjoyable day in a classical styled building near the botanical gardens
Excellent. It has really excellent works. It is worth to see absolutly. Also the main part is free. You can reach to walk down Hyde Park.
beautiful art works and sculpture. This place is amazing and fantastic painting and stone sculpture. educational for any artiest whom whats to do that kinda arts it would be very inspiring
Beautiful Art. My wife and I went here to view the Archibald Prize entries. This was a very interesting visit and well worth the time we spent there.

First visit!!. I have never been to art gallery before. This had been my first and a memorable experience. Loved the paintings and sculptures. They have artifacts from various nationalities. It would have been great if they had provided a guide.

Permanent Collection and more. I live on the outskirts of Sydney but was staying in the CBD for an early morning upgrade next day. That gave a great opportunity to visit this magnificent gallery. Always a pleasure to look at the permanent collection and I also looked at the Yoshitoshi Woodcut ExhibitionEntrance is free, there are usually some exhibitions on that you pay to enter but plenty available for free.Very good bookshop too.

Very impressive gallery. ok so its not the Louvre but it is a very pleasant gallery. There are a great range of art pieces, both local and international, for viewing. Plenty of nice cafes and a great gallery shop.
Archibald visit. First time visit and went to see the Arcibald painting exhibit. Wonderful facilities and fantastic collection of important Australian art.

Frida Kahlo & Diego Rivera exhibition is a must. We were in Sydney for a 2 days stay so thought to see the Frida Kahlo exhibition at the Art Gallery of NSW. The exhibition was excellant and filled in some gaps in our knowledge even though we had visited Casa Azul in Mexico City and seen an exhibition at the Tate Modern in London. The Gallery is well worth a visit and we saw the Archibald Exhibition as well. The Art Galley also has an extensive collection of both old and modern art on permanent display.

Beautiful Gallery. We were there on a weekday morning and it was crowded with two special exhibits going on. The line for tickets was long so we just visited the Archibald Prize winners, as well as some of the regular exhibits. The Archibald exhibit was well worth it as you get to see the top 50 pieces. We had lunch at the cafe which was really busy but the food was fine.

Great gallery with stunning views of harbour. Great gallery with stunning views of harbour. Free entrance, good layout, easy to navigate. Nice collection if paintings. The only downer was the cafe shop / restaurant. Terrible food.

World Class. I have been a regular visitor to this Art Gallery for over a decade. The most recent visit is to attend Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera's exhibition. Due to its popularity, it's highly advisable to book online with a time slot that suits you. At easy pace, you would get to finish up this particular exhibition within thirty minutes. That being said, Art Gallery has an outstanding Oriental Division which holds an exhibition on Calligraphy and Japanese Woodblock Print. On top of that, there are other divisions that focus on Aboriginal art, Contemporary art, early European and Australian art. There's also a superb café that overlooks the Bay and the place buzzes with positive and dynamic energy. You will have an outstanding day outing at this Gallery. Highly recommended!

Wonderful gallery and great Frido Kahlo exhibition!. My friend and I came to Sydney from Melbourne specifically for the Frida Kahlo exhibition and we loved it! Not too many people and a wonderful layout. The rest of the gallery was wonderful too and my new favourite painting is 'And the bridegroom.'Wish we had more time to spend here!
Discovery. i went there to see the Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera exhibition which was spectacular. then i got to see other works of art by Van Gogh, Yoshitoshi,Picasso and others which were for free.

Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera. Visited the gallery to see the exhibition about "Frida Kahio and Diego Rivera" on a week day in August. I enjoyed the exhibition, although some of it was a bit repetitious. However, I still thought it was worth the visit.

Archibald Prize Viewing. The building itself is an architectural icon so that in itself makes it worth seeing. There are many galleries to explore and we fortunate enough to view the Archibald Prize exhibition. There are some older paintings that depict some nude scenes but if you're open-minded with your kids, then the paintings won't be seen as offensive (they are classical paintings after all). It's free to enter except for the major exhibitions and it's something different to do for a day out in Sydney.

A Pleasant Afternoon at the Archibald and Frido Kahlo. I was visiting Sydney so took the opportunity to attend the Gallery to see Frida Kahlo. Great exhibition and good you could get tickets in advance which made the viewing experience easier. The merchandise was not great and did not resale specifically to the exhibition. For example there were no cards relating to the exhibition only postcards. It was great to see the Archibald prize finalists. There were very special. Great afternoon.

Art Gallery of NSW is one of the best. The collection of Australian, European, and Asian art is awesome. The museum is free, with the exception of special exhibitions. We also took advantage of a guided tour on Aboriginal Art which was excellent. They also have a restaurant and cafe. Check the calendar for concerts too.

fantastic pieces. I had seen a lot of museums in the previous 2 weeks, but I'm glad I made time for one more. The place is huge, so I got to see a lot even though I didn't pay for the special exhibits. Fairly comprehensive examples of modern, indigenous, and traditional art.
Frida Kahlo & Diego Rivera Exhibition. We went to the Frida Kahlo exhibition which was excellent. We also had a very nice lunch at the cafe.

Interesting. I went there with my whole family. We didn't know what to expect, but it turned out to be a rich place, with exhibitions suitable to all ages. In one exhibition we got sheets of paper and tried to reproduce the paintings. On another, the kids prepared their own comics books. We also saw other exhibitions, more tuned to adult audience, so the entire family had a lot of fun.

Frida Kahlo. Love the exhibition. We had an informativ privat tour. The huge black and white photos of Frida and Diego are impressive. The Archibald portrait prize was very colourful and I love the packers choice. All exhibition was well visited.

Beauty and serenity. I am not an artist and I don't usually think of art as a first choice for entertainment. However for many years I worked in the Sydney CBD and visiting the art gallery at lunchtime every few months became a habit of mine. I feel at peace in this place with many beautiful pieces of art to watch and occasional special exhibitions. One of the best surprises I ever received happened here. There was a painting which was already a favorite of mine for years because the scene depicted by it was so captivating for me. I had no idea that this painting was actually housed in this gallery. And this was a wonderful surprise in one of my early visits. Many lunch breaks I would visit the gallery to watch this painting alone. The gallery is not fussed about you taking pictures as long as you don't use a flash. But I found my favorite painting was already depicted in high quality on a card that I could Purchase at the gallery's gift shop. And I bought two copies. There is also a cafe at the back of the gallery which offers nice views. Last but not least the gallery is free and just minutes away from the CBD and the Botanic gardens.

Show in Sydney , called in to art gallery. Visited during our family weekend to see a show , swung by the art gallery to see the archibald , gr8!loved it , recommend a visit to all !! Don't agree with the winner but hey , I'm no expert , worth a visit ✔️

There's something for everyone!. Being an art lover myself, I spent more than half a day at the gallery. Free admission (though for featured exhibitions, there would be additional fee). There was also an exhibition where Cate Blanchett (one of my favourites) played 13 characters based on some of the most famous and provocative writings by modern artists, called "Manifesto" directed by Julian Rosefeldt.Works by Van Gogh and Lucian Freud were also on display, as well as (arguably, my own personal favourite), Aborigines collection.There's also guided tours available in the gallery so you may consider checking it out for a better experience ;)

Not sure how I missed it - it is huge. This has a really diverse range of exhibitions. The building itself is huge. Leave your bags with the concierge. Have lunch in the lovely cafe complete with lorikeets and ibis. Near the Botanic Gardens (which I saw first when trying to find the Gallery and thought that was the entrance!). Up the steps from Woolloomooloo. Free general admission but some exhibitions you need to pay for. Popular exhibitions have timed entrances and you need to book in advance for these to guarantee you are able to go on the date you want

Don't miss the Archibalds. As always, the Archibalds create admiration, criticism and plenty of conversation. As an added extra, the Wynne and Sulman artworks are included in the entry fee. To finish off your visit, the cafe is a great place to discuss the paintings viewed. If you arrive before 10 am as we did, pop across the road to the little cafe in the park. Parking at the art gallery is by the hour and can be a little pricey but parking in the Domain Carpark is only $10 all day on weekends.

The art gallery of new south wales is a place to visit while in sydney .. The gallery is situated in the botanical garden tourist / romantic and family place we went there last week seen the exhibition of frida kahlo and diego it was fantastic and today we went to see paintings for the Archibald it was excellent then we went to the restaurant inside the gallery forlunch and had coffee in the members 0nly cafe .Some permanent exhibition are free it's a very nice art gallery to visit and have a day out in the botanical garden.when visiting sydney art gallery is a place visit.

A night out with a difference.. (something for everyone). The art gallery is very popular for a number of key things, one of them is definitely the different exhibition through out the year and the amazing restaurant downstairs which offers great food at great prices the sops are also great . the location means that you right in the heart of the city and close to other amazing places like centre point and Big park ..I love going to the Gallery there is always something to see thats new, its very clean and staff are really friendly.I also love the fact that its open Wednesday until 9 pm

Guess what, we saw the Archibald Exhibition. I was thrilled to see the Archibald Collection and was able to spend plenty of time looking at the artwork. I even took the chance to look at some of the other works housed there. My only complaint would be that the number of guided tours occurring at the same time seemed excessive.You would suddenly find oneself locked in to a group of young people all eyes to the front at the guide. It says much about the Gallery that even with this irritating event it was well worth putting up with to see the works in the Gallery
Art Visit. We went to see the exhibition of Mexican artist Frida Kahlo and her partner Diego Rivera. Great exhibition and wonderful art gallery.

We liked it. The Gallery represents a good collection of Australian art, some pieces very very talented. One of important advantages was the multicultural character of exposition, we have enjoy the beautiful aborigine art too.
checking out Frieda Khalo. We travelled from Tasmania especially to view this exhibition and were not disappointed. Wonderful. Very pleased we booked tickets in advance as there were queues.
Interesting collections. We especially enjoyed the collections of indigenous art. There is also a nice cafe and a well-stocked gift shop.

Interesting and informative for art lovers - hilarious for people who don't care!. I am not an art fanatic but there were things in this museum that were certainly worth seeing! The modern art is hilarious and some of the historic paintings are quite beautiful. It's definitely a #1 for art lovers, but go even if you don't like art galleries! There's plenty of stuff to make fun of there...

Archibald exhibition. I travel to Sydney each year around the time of the Archibald exhibition. Most of the time I don't agree with the judges decision of the winner. This year I did feel the winner was the right painting.the painting that won the packing room prize was probably better , but never wins main prize. Some intersting paintings, but as usual some I can't see why they were included. I also looked through the main galleries, there are some pervious winners of the Archibald including dobles early painting of Margaret olley( to my mind better than the painting by Ben Quilty).There is a good repertory bunny painting and also a Van Gogh ( although this has been centre of some controversy over whether it is by Van Gogh . Pleasent walk down to the gallery.

Great Find.. Gem of a find at the end of the Botanical Gardens.Wear comfy shoes as the place is vast and more than likely you've also found it after a long walk from Circular Quay. Many and varied offerings to take your eye and ponder over or discover. A place where you get separated from your other half as you linger over a display or painting and they are engrossed with something else...
Archibald Exhibtion. It was good to see the painting in real life, my first experience. Queueing for the tickets a pain not many staff operating .

Archibald Surprize. We were pleasantly surprised to discover that there was about a half hour wait to buy tickets to the Archibald Prize exhibition as it is so popular! Even on a Thursday morning... Maybe it is time the Gallery provided timed admission to such exhibitions so as to give each visitor a chance to have a good look at all the artworks. There were so many people that it was hard to see many works. However, in spite of the crowd we did enjoy our visit and chose to have lunch at the Cafe. As it was a lovely day we chose to sit outside but soon discovered this to have been a dangerous choice as the local birds regularly dive bombed diners!!
Frida Kahlo Exhibition. Take the opportunity to see this once in a lifetime exhibition of Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera's work and their life together, just amazing.
Archibald Prize, Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera. Always a great venue with well curated and managed exhibitions. Love the walk across from St James station or up from Circular Quay.

Always a pleasure to spend an afternoon here. We were in Sydney last week. I always like to get to the art gallery. This time I had my young boys with me 6 and 8. We had a lovely afternoon. It was so nice to show them such a great collection. And the gallery itself is a fantastic building. The surrounding park and harbour walk back to the opera house rounded out the afternoon. Make the time to visit the gallery to is worth the time.
Perfect rainy day activity in the city. Great Asian exhibition and always current exhibitions of interest. Also like the permanent Australian displays

Beautiful surrounds and free. This a great walking distance from the opera house or the CBD, walk through the beautiful Botanical gardens.which is also free.An amazing café and restaurant across the road to eat at as well, which is outside in the sun. Some exhibitions you have to pay for but not all, beautiful art and exhibitions and amazing views of the city. The park across the road is also a great place to catch Pokémon.

Rich collection of art pieces. The gallery houses a large collection of art pieces ranging from historical to aboriginal and contemporary. Some sections of the gallery are free to the public while the special exhibits require entry fees. The restaurant in the gallery provide a nice place for a rest with drinks and snacks if you need some recharging during your visit. Worth to spend a few hours if you are an art fanatic. Simply a walk in this gallery is relaxing.

Nice but small. The galleries here were well organised and they have some beautiful and varied pieces. However, the free galleries available are not very big so it doesn't take long to see all they have to offer and we didn't want to may to see the exhibitions as they weren't of interest. Still worth a visit as it is a nice gallery.

Too many people wanted to be there.. We went to see the portrait awards with a limited amount of time available which was a dumb thing to do because lots of other people had the same idea. By the time we had queued up for tickets we took a rapid look at the exhibition which was very good. It was well d.

Beautiful blend of Western and Aboriginal Art. Really beautiful museum blending the usual suspects of Western art with a wonderful array of Aboriginal Art, which I have never seen anywhere else in the world in my travels. I loved the perspective and art of the Aboriginal people and learned a bit more about this ancient culture.

Seems to be promoting paid exhibitions no the free collection. they seemed to have expanded the basement since my last visit giving them a lot more exhibition space which is good because when i vistied two big blockbuster pay lots of money to enter exhibitions had taken over so much of the otherwise free gallery.
A lot to see. As you enjoy a walk around The Domain in Sydney's CBD you will come across this great Art Gallery where you will view some of the World's best Art.

Nice but too crowded. The gallery is a Sydney must see. The setting is lovely, and the art curators make excellent choices. There is good parking for people with disabilities ( phone up to find out about it.) However, exhibitions are often too crowded, especially on Sundays, so go early during the week if you can. Creative attempts to popularise exhibitions are generally noisy and demonstrate lack confidence in the work themselves. The view from gallery eateries and the seating is great, but there is not enough sensitivity to those with food intolerances. I joined the gallery, happy to pay more to view exhibitions in a quieter setting and to spend time in the members lounge. I wont renew my membership, because the member exhibition was even more crowded than those open to the public. The member lounge is delightful, and almost worth the membership fee, but the guy serving the food did not know the ingredients of the offerings, which made it impossible to check if they were suitable. More allergy-aware catering in the members lounge, and less crowded free members exhibitions would make the joining fee worthwhile.

Great art but extremely busy. The art at the NSW Art Gallery is great, and they have a lot of it! We only had the time to explore one floor, sadly - I wish we had more time. The crowds at the Gallery were overwhelming though, it was extremely busy!

One place to visit. The gallery is on the edge of the Domain, one of Sydney's parks and beside the harbour. It houses a fine collection of paintings, both old and moidern and has frequent special exhibitions. There are restaurants and an outside terrrace where one may eat with a view of the harbour.

Beautiful building housing some magnificent art and instructive tours.. Scenically an imposing building, and set up so could view Archibald Prize exhibits, the Frida Khalo and Diego Rivera exhibition and the Tracy Moffatt exhibition within the one building. The outdoor cafe was somewhat unfortunate as it was invaded by a variety of birds, no longer charming as they dived at the heads of people eating there, jumped on tables attempting to eat and drink from the food there and this surely poses some hygiene risks especially for those who are elderly and women who are pregnant.
Art Gallery. Worth a visit, usually has interesting exhibitions. It is close to the Botanical Garden. The gallery is not very large .

Set aside sufficient time to enjoy the exhibitions. Went recently to see the Frida K exhibition and planned to see other exhibitions such as the Archibald but ran out of time. Make sure that you set aside a decent amount of time to enjoy all that the gallery has to offer. Beautiful parkland setting and a decent walk from there down to the rocks for a late lunch,alternatively there is a cafe at the gallery where you can have lunch or stop for a drink and take in the lovely views of the parklands. Definitely worth a visit.

Always has great exhibitions. Every time I visit Sydney a visit to the AGNSW is a must. My last visit was specifically to come and see Manifestos (highly recommend) The Frida & Degao exhibition and the Archibald. There where big line for tickets for the paid exhibitions so but them on line before you arrive. I highly recommend the Aboriginal art collection Yirribana.

Excellent!. The Art Gallery is large so a full morning or afternoon as a minimum for time. There's a great cafe there, lovely as it looks over the parkland. Check their website for special exhibitions and also the annual Archibald Prize Exhibition is definitely worth visiting.

Conference Dinner. Had a conference dinner at this venue last week. The venue was great, and surprisingly warm for a cold wintery night. The food was uninspiring. Not sure if this was arranged by the Gallery or by the conference organisers.

Archibald prize winners visit. Loved seeing the portraits for the Archibald competition, lots to see, some free - some not. Fascinating painting. Quite a busy place too, nice that people are enjoying art.
Frida Khalo exhibition. We flew up from Melb to sydney to go and see the Frida Khalo and Diego Riveras exhibition. It was wonderful a beautiful space and well run
Wonderful place!. Such a beautiful space and incredible collection... set in the botanic gardens which are lovely too !

Archibald Wynne and Sulman prizes. This exhibition is a must see, as the viewer can be the judge. The Packing Room Prize won by Betina Fauvel-Ogden is very commanding and the Archibald Prize Winner by Louise Hearman shows a different softer side of our Barry. Kate Beynon's portrait was my favourite- you can vote for a fave, perhaps the exquisite painting of Wendy Whitely by Natasha Bieniek. Leave at least two hours for your stroll through this exhibition, and time for coffee to discuss the entries. I was pleased to see that Jason Benjamin had another entry in the Wynne Prize. Take time to visit the permanent exhibitions of Australian art.

Great Australian art and special exhibitions. People may come for the high-profile exhibitions (Frida Kahlo and Diego Riveria, plus Archibald and other prize competitions when I visited), but I'd say come for the Australian art and other continuing galleries - and entry is free! It's a nice collection of early 20th century Aussie artists. Plus there's a nice little collection of pre-Raphaelite artworks and a handful of Lucien Freud paintings. Also interesting to see a Colin McCahon piece prominently displayed (THE most well-known Kiwi artist). This is a must-see place!

Worth a look !. We went to see the Archibald Prize ,The Gallery is really well laid out and you can easily spend 2 hours there ! just of word of warning we went at opening time and there were so many school children we just could not get very close to the art work , so choose your time well !

Archibald visit with wheelchair.. This week I visited the Archibald exhibition with three elderly friends and had lunch at the gallery.It was a delightful experience.I booked tickets online to avoid queues and borrowed a wheelchair from the gallery to allow an elderly gentleman to enjoy the exhibition without any difficulty.The staff were super helpful and it was great to see such a wide range of people enjoying the art. Adults and children of all ages and abilities were well catered for. We arrived about 10.30 and although busy we were able to enjoy all parts of the exhibition.We then had a delicious lunch at the Chiswick Restaurant. Despite the torrential rain outside our day was the most fabulous day.

If time permits and your interest is here..... The Archibald Art competition entries are displayed here annually during winter months. Judged by trustees of the gallery, plus a people's choice, interest is keen. Good range of artefacts and works of art.

Frida Kali and Diego Rivera Exhibition - exquisite. I had been warned beforehand that this Exhibition had few of the artists artworks, and that was true. It focuses more on the life of Frida, her eccentricity, quirkiness and incredible view on life. I loved it. The photographic exhibition truly captured her being and that of her life love interest. Well-worth a visit. Bought ticket at the gallery counter and no problem with the crowds on a week day afternoon.

Archibald Prize exhibition a winner. We recently spent a day at the Art Gallery and took in the Archibald, Wynne and Sulman Prize exhibition.There were big crowds so at times it was difficult to get a good view of the works.

Beautifully diverse.. AGNSW is a must when visiting Sydney as it holds one of the most diverse art collections in Australia. The walls dedicated to the Australian masters is just one of the highlights as it's set among beautiful architecture and a view of the harbour. I was here very recently to see the Frida and Diego exhibition, which was beautifully curated (though I wish they had more!). A must see before it closes but a word of advice when seeing a show like this - buy your tickets online. It was mayhem at the ticket booth, the lines were huge, as were the wait times (you don't need to trade in your online tickets either, they just scan the barcode at the exhibition entry and you're right to go in).

Archibald prize is a great reason to go, but any excuse would do. This gallery has lovely exhibits, many free of charge, including classics and Aboriginal sections. The most recent time we went was to enjoy the Archibald Prize exhibition on a weekend. The art component of the experience was great but the organisation of the event left a lot to be desired. Long queues, only two people selling tickets, poor planning. They should know better. The event happens every year and it's very popular among locals and outsiders! They need to lift their game. On the other hand, the cafeteria had great range of soups, salads, main courses...and desserts. Definitely worth a visit at the end of your 4-hour standing at the galleries.

Free entry. Drop by when you visit the Botanical Gardens, it's just a short stroll from the gates. Three floors, amazing indigenous display, cafe and well stocked gift shop. Check their website, there's a lot going on here.Cinema, classes, tours and many kids activities. A nice respite from the weather if it's really hot or rainy out. Kids love this place. Well worth a visit.
Art Gallery of NSW. Very interesting, something for everyone. Easy access for wheelchairs etc. Good cafes within grounds. Loved it.

A must visit if you're into art galleries and great spaces. The NSW Art Gallery is a magnificent space and filled with delightful art. Visit when the famous Archibald Prize is on exhibition - Australia's premier portraiture prize. There is always a major exhibition on (in July Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera for example.) There's a great cafe, gift shop and stunning views. Highly recommend a visit when in Sydney.

A Gallery in the heart of Sydney. There is so much to see within this gallery and there are some rooms where you could spend much more time than others. There was an abundance of Australian art as well as a selection of stunning aboriginal works. Van Gogh, Picasso, Hinder, Cezanne were all to be found within these walls. Some of the rooms were, I felt, overcrowded, and hence the appreciation of the masterpieces lessened, you have to pay to see the specialised exhibitions. Put this on your 'visit' list if you like galleries.

Fantastic exhibitions. Spent morning at gallery it was fantastic.Archibald and Frieda both really good .The downside was the line up to purchase tickets, almost 1 hour, not acceptable as there was only three cash registers operating. Lunch in the cafe was good.

One of the best in Sydney. I love it. I went there 3x in different dates to attend a talk from a historian, see the current exhibition (May 2016) including Biennale. FREE! Look out for some art works painted by Charles Bush on plywoods, statues, aborigin's art, and many more. Tips: 1. Look out for Picasso's paintings. 2. Join the free tour. Check the calendar at its website.3. store your large items and umbrella at the counter. Free of charge!4. it is in city district where you could easily visit Sydney Tower, and more

Stunning art in a superb building. We are very lucky to have such a terrific art gallery to enjoy free of charge for the permanent collection. After seeing the Archibald we took the opportunity to wander the main gallery revisiting Australian favourites by McCubbin, Roberts and Streeton but also dazzled by two iconic large works by Pablo Picasso. Take the time to enjoy all these treasures.

Archi ok but avoid the cafe. Spent a couple of hours looking at amazing paintingsFollowed by a less enjoyable 40 minutes at the cafe waiting for a lukewarm coffee to arriveAdvise: see the art but go somewhere else for food and drink

Beautiful. There is lots of amazing art works to see here, there is an awesome painting of Rorkes Drift. Apart from that there is lots of modern art as well as classic Australian pieces and other exhibits to see an do. I could have spent the whole day here looking around but unfortunatly i was on limited time as i had to get to the airport.

Archibald Prize and Frida Kahlo exhibitions . The Art Gallery of New South Wales is one of the largest public state galleries in Australia. The 2016 Archibald, Wynne and Sulman prizes exhibition is worth a visit (until 9 October 2016). The Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera exhibition (until 9 October 2016) is also popular and interesting though Kahlo works have been to Australia in the past. Sydneysiders look at art differently to folk in the rest of Australia at special exhibitions so be prepared to be patient.

Loved it!. The museum did a very good job of covering different types of art. They had Reubens, Picasso, and Van Gogh. They also had Mitch more contemporary and installation pieces. I'll have to say though, my favorite was their aboriginal collection. It was pretty spectacular.

c u @ the sydney gallery. The Art Gallery of New South Wales (NSW) is the most prominent art gallery in Sydney. Its collection is among the best in Australia, second only perhaps to the National Gallery of Victoria in Melbourne. The Art Gallery of NSW is very strong in colonial and indigenous art. The Gallery is also renowned for awarding the Archibald Prize, Australia's most eminent prize for portraiture, and also the Wynn Prize for religious art, which this year was won by a group of indigenous women. The Gallery is in the Domain, ten minutes' walk from the city centre

Highbrow activity but be prepared to pay for the privillage. I love this museum. The location is easy from Martin Place- thru the olr sydney hospital and a straight walk thru the lovely park. The cafe is wayyy cheaper than the restaurant. There are free exhibits so dont pay out if you are on a limited budget. From the gallery on exit turn right and walk thru the botanical gardens down to the oper pa house. Gorgeous environment.
Excellent. Always enjoy our visit to,the Art Gallery, well worth catching up on all the different exhibitions that they offer.

Nice bulding. but unfortunately too little art pieces too little masterpieces/artwork, they had an exhibition about the world famous Mexican artist Frida Khalo, with nice hardly seen photos from her and her husband, as well as original letters.

Art. A grand old building housing some of Australia's and the world's greatest works of art. It is outstanding in its value. More so as it is free to enter, except for the "temporary" exhibitions which obviously have to be paid for. A wonderful place to spend a few hours or even a whole day and not get tired at all. It is very accessible and easy to get to. You can walk from just about anywhere in the city. It is very close to the city stations, especially Museum station, St James, and Town Hall; only a few minutes walk. You can also take a walk around the outside of the Gallery and admire the excellent views of the city.

Lovely Museum. I love this museum. There is always a special exhibition on show,particularly at the moment when the Archibald portraits are exhibited, and there is a Freda Kahlo and Diego Rivera exhibition Not to be missed. Maybe book on net beforehand

Beautiful gallery. Love this gallery - there are always a good selection of art works to keep you occupied for a few hours. Went for the Archibald collection as well as Frida. The express guided tour of the Archibald was a pleasant addition to provide some additional info to the exhibition. There is a great cafe to rest your feet as well as a well stocked gallery store. It is a beautiful spot to spend a leisurely few hours.
Great Gallery. This is a very good Gallery, loads to see, so much to do, good for teenagers lot's of things to keep you interested.

An Incredible Museum. This museum was a highlight of my time in Sydney. The Manifesto exhibit is phenomenal and certainly worth a visit. There is a collection of art from many different movements, so there is a great deal to view. The eateries in this museum are much better than your average museum cafe.

Sunday at the gallery. Very busy in the main exhibitions often have long queues on a Sunday by 11am to enter the Archibald prize. Wait time of up to 20mins. Pre-buy your tickets online for any of the big shows - the Karhlo exhibition was sold out for the whole of Sunday. Plenty of space in the rest of the gallery - don't miss the the bottom floor and see the Aboriginal collection.

Good place to visit on a rainy day. A respectable collection of Australian art, past and contemporary. The Frida Kahlo exhibition was a bit limited, wished there were more paintings on display of this great Mexican artist, rather than photographs. Admission of $18 a little steep. Comparing this to galleries in other Australian cities, which have free admission. Overall though, a beautiful gallery with some well-known artists. A good place to learn about Australia's history.

So worth a visit!. Does not matter what time of year to visit as it is a stunning venue with even better art! If you visit between July and October you also get to see the Archibald Exhibit which is a stand out!
World Class Gallery. Lovely world class gallery with free entrance, except for temporary exhibitions. I really enjoyed it, but my two teenage sons didn't want to stay too long.

Fascinating collection. This museum is free (except for some portions showing special visiting exhibits). It was busy even on a winter Thursday afternoon. It is conveniently located, near the beautiful Botanical Gardens in downtown Sydney.The large, imposing building is made of orange sandstone, and has a classical Greek Revival look from the outside. Inside, it has high ceilings and a feeling of expansive spaciousness. The collection varies from contemporary art, to European art as far back as the 17th Century, to Aboriginal art of all times. Indeed, the emphasis is on Australian artists. And here we learned a lesson: Australians, be proud, your artists are as good as the world’s best. The highlight, in our opinion, was Australian art post-1900, although we felt that the contempo art at the Museum of Contemporary Art was better. Nonetheless, the Art Gallery of New South Wales was well-worth the time.There is a formal restaurant, and a large and busy cafeteria.As with all of our 5-star reviews, we freely declare that we have no personal or financial connection to this institution.

Sydney art gallery of nsw. Established in 1871,the art gallery of nsw near the royal botanic gardens eastern gate is a leading cultural institutions in Australia.it is open 10-5 daily and on Wednesday till 10pm.it is accesssble on foot from city centre.access is free,

Go during the day...was too busy on Wednesday evening. Have been to gallery many times and usually have a lovely visit but i visited for first time on Wednesday evening and it was just too busy...perhaps there was a special event, but it changed the whole vibe of the visit and did not enjoy as much as usual. Having said that, it is still an awesome gallery with a bit of something for everyone and well worth a visit.

Art in the eye of the beholder. A building with a sense of serenity, broad and fascinating collection, including aboriginal works as well as key Australian artists. Short term display of Tang was interesting and in a peaceful setting.

Great art but overall disappointing experience!. Recently visited the gallery for the Frida Kahlo-Diego Rivera Exhibition and purchased multi-visit passes, very surprised that each pass had to be purchased and paid for separately making it a time-consuming process! Loved the exhibition, taking into account there was only a very small number of works. The permanent collection was well worth the time taken to look around and beautifully organised.Made the mistake of going to the cafe for lunch and it was a nightmare! Massive queues that took forever to move, staff could only serve one thing which contributed to the long waits. I couldn't get a chocolate milkshake for a reason I couldn't understand and the tea was undrinkable. I couldn't find any water and the serving staff were very ordinary. An unpleasant experience I certainly won't repeat!

There isn't enough time to do it justice. I spent an afternoon here viewing a couple of exhibitions. It is a beautiful gallery with friendly, approachable staff. Really enoyed the layout and the works themselves. I just wished i had more time.

Gorgeous interior and exterior is fabulous too. Went to see the Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera exhibition but the gallery has a wonderful layout with its general exhibitions in rooms with high curved plaster ceilings - felt I was in Europe. Lovely place to walk from the city centre too as you enter from the park.

Archibald . Despite the crowds the Art gallery is a wonderful place to visit and meander among the paintings. We went on the first day of the Archibald and yes it was busy but we never felt over crowded. There are always plenty of free exhibitions to see too .

excellent. Sydney art gallery is fantastic. It also offers learn to courses, for both children and adults for those who don't know info of these interests can be found on their website, the food here is also fantastic!

Excellent Gallery with great accessibility . My daughter wanted to visit the Gallery to see the Archibald Prize portraits, so off we set with wife, 6 week old grandson and 16 year old son completing the line up. Disappointingly for us, the queues for the Archibald Exhibition were mammoth and so we elected to visit the standard galleries (free of charge) and come back another day for the portraits.The galleries were a delight and I loved the un-stuffy presentation and accessibility. It was great to see lots of school classes in the galleries and the children seemed to be interested and having a great time. Stand-outs for me were the Aboriginal & Torres Straits Islander exhibits on Lower Level 3, the Australian cubism selection and Alphonse de Neuville's depictions of the 4th Hussars Regiment charging at Tarragona, and the Defence of Rorke's Drift.We had a very nice lunch in the Gallery's cafe and I also noted there is a more up-market restaurant Chiswick, which is an offshoot of the well-known and excellent restaurant of the same name on Ocean Street in Woollahra. The Gallery's shop had a particularly comprehensive selection of art-related textbooks. I think this is a first-class gallery and absolutely worth multiple visits.
Beautiful place to spend a rainy day. Great art gallery. Free entrance. Super place to spend a rainy day. There is a great aboriginal section which is worth a visit.

Archibald 2016. The current Archibald entries including junior Archibald (ages 6-16), and the Wynne and Sulman prize entries are on exhibit till October. So simply stunning portraits, and there's some very talented young artists to keep a close eye on Well worth the visit

For the finer things in life. This is one of Sydney's gems.The art is comprehensive with an excellect Aboriginal Art collection.Under Edmon Capon's direction Asian art collecting flourished.Worth visiting now to see the Archibald prizewinner entries especially Barry Humphrey's portrait.

Well lit with interesting and varies collections.. A visit to the Art Gallery of NSW is highly recommended. Of special interest is the gallery of indigenous art. Bookings essential for any current exhibition. Late night viewings on a Wednesday. NIce restaurant. Attractive location beside thr Botanic Gardens.

Frida AND Archibald/Sulman/Wynne exhibition. This is a beautiful spacious gallery. The Archibald exhibit was amazing. And the Sulman and Wynne finalists all very incredible and such a pleasure to see. Frida and Diego exhibition.. well it was amazing seeing Frida's work up close but a very limited collection. Only about fifteen or sixteen paintings of Frida's I think and maybe three or four of Diegos. Lots of photos that I had already seen and let's face it, you can see photos anywhere. All up great experience and worth the travel from Melbourne to see both exhibitions but not just Frida and Diego.

Kahlo and Rivera - disappointing overall. We are huge fans of Frida Kahlo and were keen to see this exhibition. We were fortunate enough to visit La Casa Azul (Blue House) in Coyacan in Mexico last year but, by far, the best exhibition of her work was at the Scuderie Quirinale in Rome in April 2015 where an extraordinatry collection of Frida's work was on display. If you are a fan of Rivera, which we are not, then you might feel satisfied with the exhibition, but the real drawcard is Kahlo known for work and her sad life story, and the exhibition did not provide some of the fabulous works that were in Rome. Of course, it's all in the eye of the beholder, but I wouldn't recommend or say it is a 'must see'. I know this was curated by AGNSW staff but I feel they 'missed the boat' on this one and concentrated too much on her life story, letters and film, rather than her incredible works of art, even though the two are inextricably intertwined.. Full marks, however, for timed entry, as this is a huge bonus and good to see that we're finally catching up with Germany and many other savvy European countries who've been doing this for a while.

Impressive Art Museum. The Art Gallery of New South Wales is a beautiful museum. Best of all, you can access the museum at no charge for their regular collection. This is a great place to experience Australian, European, and Aboriginal art.When you go...1. Plan to go on foot. When you leave take the walk through the botanical gardens to the opera house (or do this in reverse order). It is a beautiful prelude or postlude to the gallery.2. Note that special collections (such as Frida and Diego on now) cost extra. Also, there are long ticket and entry lines on weekends. Plan to buy tickets in advance or wait for a weekday.3. Don't leave without checking out their contemporary art exhibit downstairs. It is quite a fun and funky display.4. The main galleries are laid out well. They are not cluttered or crowded, making it possible to truly enjoy the art.

Not for me . It's a nice art gallery but we went to the MCA a few days earlier and I think we just expected too much. Besides the exhibitions that were not really in our interest it is a very large and beautiful art gallery.

Excellent. Love going to the major exhibitions, including the Archibalds, and overseas visiting exhibits, informative, delightful and very friendly staff, always something new, even though I always go back and have another glance at the permanent collections

Greag collecitons.. Whenever I am in Sydney I make it a point to reserve atleast one day to spend at the Art Galler. The Gallery has a huge collection of different forms of art most of the exhibitions are free. It also organizes exclusive exhibitions of renowned artists as well as of diffiernt cultures. I had the opportunity to go to the Exbhibition of the Tang Dynasty and it was worth every dollar. I highly recommend Art Gallery of NSW, you wont be dissapointed.

Visit if you are heading to Macquarie's chair. It's at the entrance of Royal Botanic gardens and is surely hard to miss. It is exhibiting art by Australian artists and is nice to take a look if you are curious or a real art enthusiast. Entrance is free though special exhibitions are not.

A must place to visit- see the current Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera exhibition. The Art Gallery of New South Wales should be on every visitor's agenda. Its centrally located, has a try fine collection of Australian, European and Aboriginal art as well as special blockbuster exhibitions every now and then. Two weeks ago we had the pleasure of viewing the new travelling exhibition of Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo paintings from the Gelman Collection. The paintings are accompanied by 50 excellent b & w and colour photographs that convey the sporty and texture of the worlds inhabited by these two great Mexican artists. The exhibition will be on until October 9th so hurry!

Frida Kahlo exhibition. Loved seeing all the art works, a little busy as it was school holidays, but nice to see other exhibitions . Also had lunch at the gallery and it was amazing , try the pull apart lamb.

Must visit. This is a great place to spend a couple of hours if you love art. It has a wonderful collection of local, Aboriginal, European, Asian and contemporary art. Overlooking Sydney Harbour, it took us about 20 minutes to walk from our hotel in Pitt Street. Admission to the permanent exhibits is free unless if you are visiting the special exhibits. Catch the brilliant Manifesto film exhibit starring Cate Blanchett.

you silly not to go. Visiting Sydney? Love art? Want to feel cultured?
This is the place!
so big, so much to see. 100% recommend to splurge on the paid events, have never been disappointed.

Great self guided tour. Was introducing my Asian wife and small kids to western art, so we started in the basement with the modern art, which included installations open to interpretation and using ordinary everyday items so my family could really relate to everything. Good for kids to see an array of brush strokes or dashes of color can mean many things to big people.Then we moved on to Australian tribal art and again this was something everyone could relate to, although all were in awe of the dot paintings and magnitude of dots.Skipping all the pay to view exhibitions, we moved upstairs and wife loved the Monets and statues, while the kids could not believe such life like paintings were possible without cameras.Everything you would expect from a first visit to an art gallery and a what a wonderful setting at the Domain with rolling grass slopes and old trees.Very convenient and reasonably prices parking underground.

Sunday Morning at the Gallery. Beautiful Sunday morning walk from Circular Quay across The Domain to the AGNSW - Art Gallery of New South Wales. Free entry to the gallery with a small fee to enter the exhibitions. This gallery has a wonderful collection of Australian and European art. Fabulous bookshop. Cafés. Great atmosphere.

Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera Exhibition. It's always a joy to visit this wonderful Sydney attraction. We came to see the Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera exhibition and were entranced. It's a small exhibition, but very rich in contact - art, photographs, translated letters and video, as well as in-depth biographical details. Don't miss this one!

Frieda Kahlo. Frieda Khalo........How sad.....The reason you can't see the art is that the paintings are in a way too a small a space for the numbers of people you are catering for.....the captions are also too small for people that are crowded in to read in that tiny space.....people are like sardines to read and see what is before their eyes.....again the greed shows its face....How awfully sad to try to see the Kahlo exhibition....reduced to something like a slot machine arcade. We paid our money and lined up but upon entry found a conger line of art rubber-neckers......we just couldn't do it and so so sad to see art reduced to this level of greed....No we are not coming back to the Art Gallery of NSW until you grow up.

Show me an Art Gallery in a more beautiful setting. A free art gallery that is set in such a beautiful place. The staff are so friendly & helpful and there are always new exhibitions to see, some you have to pay a small fee for but that is understandable.Catch a train to St James Station and walk through Hyde Park to the Art Gallery then look across to the Sydney Opera house from the Botanic Gardens, a magic day out.

Planning is the Key. I went to visit the Frida Kahlo exhibition only to find that it was sold out for the day. My tip for visiting special exhibitions is to go to the Art Gallery website and book your tickets online. I was advised morning visits are best as crowds build on the weekends in the afternoon. Although I couldn't see the Frida Kahlo exhibition I still spent an enjoyable couple of hours wandering through the Gallery. General entry is free.

Some great artwork here!!!. I came here to see the Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera exhibition and it was brilliant. You can view the paintings fairly easy. However there was a queue to view photographs of the pair. I had an online booking for this exhibition at a certain time. It's definitely worth a visit. Some great Australian artwork here also. Going again to see the Archibald exhibit.

At least it's free. Maybe we are spoiled by the galleries in Europe, but this did not impress us at all. Unless you're interested in Australian art there isn't much to see. They did have a nice restaurant though.

An eye on the Prize!. Get ready to see the winner of the Archibald Prize, one of the most prestigious art awards in Australia for Portraiture, the exhibition of works starts on 16 July 2016. What a wonderful art gallery, set on the edge of an escarpment overlooking the Navy Dockyards and Sydney Harbour, on the north east windows and the tree lined Domain at the entrance to the western side. The licensed restaurant and café have large windows facing the north east, too. I love the Australian impressionist paintings in this gallery, represents the best of an era, for me. I also like the European paintings that come and go like unseen gems, in and out of storage. There are usually Asian works, aboriginal art and sculpture exhibitions, in various wings each time you visit. But the Archibald, Wynne and Sulman Prizes always excite me. Hahaha, many years ago even I entered my naïve paintings in the Wynne Prize, 10 years running, and I never had a chance of hanging, but I tried, which gave me great delight. So there is something for everyone at the Art Gallery of NSW. The shop is also quite enjoyable, so make sure you leave some time to visit it. This is a place you spend some quality time, especially on a wet day. Take some comfortable shoes and enjoy the view.

Some great works and a manageable size. I quite enjoy a mix of works from impressionist to contemporary, and particularly Australian like Roberts or Streeton. Here is the perfect place to enjoy viewing such for a couple of hours. Pleasant location a short walk across the park from the CBD and its free!! The parquetry floor has gone horribly wrong but the rest of the place is well worth a visit.

Freda and Diego. Although make an effort to book tickets for this exhibit, the web site wasn't currently selling tickets. Advised to call QTIX direct....eventually got onto sales only to be told I couldn't purchase tickets over the phone and to buy tickets at the Art Gallery as there were plenty! Arrived, queued, tickets all sold....suggested I should have pre purchased on line!!Not impressed.
Worth a stop for anyone. We definitely aren’t art connoisseurs but we really enjoyed walking around the gallery in the free sections. Was made more entertaining by using snapchat to faceswap :)

A great art gallery. Have visited the art gallery a number of times. It has an excellent collection of impression of New South Wales as well as pictures of the building of the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Reasonable cafe

Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera inspire young and old.. These wonderful masterpieces from the collection of Jacques and Natasha Gelman Collection are inspiring.Well worth a visit to see such an amazing collection supported by an noteworthy commentary of events in their lives.Most informative!Marvellous works of art by fascinating people of the Art World.

Varied Collection / Special Exhibitions. Excellent art gallery with a varied collection of Australian and mainly European art as well as several special (ticketed) art exhibitions. Entry is free to all but the special exhibitions. Large cafe/restaurant and museum shop. Something for everyone and well worth a visit if only to see a small area. We covered all but the special collections in a couple of hours. Certainly a good activity for a rainy day.
Treat yourself . What a great way to indulge yourself. Magnificent collections, stunning galleries, and for a limited time the fabulous Frida and Diego exhibition.

Beautiful art gallery. This art gallery is set in lush gardens very close to Hyde Park. On this visit we were blessed to have the Frida Kahla exhibition on and downstairs of the wonderful Cate Blanchett in Manifesto. To top of the exhibit we had the Archibald portraits to look at.

Melbourne Art Lovers - Fly to Sydney!. In Australia it is the way it is. Not every gallery in every state can get a collection of art from overseas to be viewed here. So when Sydney gets an exhibition I go and see it. There are people that fly from Sydney to do the same at Melbourne galleries. The NSW Art Gallery is bright and airey. It has gorgeous views and is in a lovely part of the city - The Domain. The gallery cafe has a range of foods at a reasonable price. The gallery shop has one of the best ranges of products in Australia.

A must see venue in Sydney. We visit this gallery regularly, as members. This time to see '"Treasures of the Silk Road- the Tang Dynasty" and the Frida Kahlo/Diego Rivera exhibitions. The Tang exhibition was superb and fascinating. The Kahlo/Rivera very interesting but , even though visitor numbers were restricted to session times, still very crowded. Maybe because the exhibition had only opened a few days before. Still, very worth while seeing, and of course, the other permanent and temporary exhibitions are always a joy!

Stunning gallery. Saw the excellent Frida Kahlo exhibition. They have a large collection of the Sydney Moderns which are wonderful to see. The shop is good but expensive. The cafe and restaurant are very good too. Well worth it.

Place of Peace. I had my evening wedding photos taken on the steps of the georgeouse NSW Art Gallery so it's a special place for me.
I have seen many exhibition and often just go in for a wander & coffee.

Quick visit. We stumbled onto this beautiful bulding and had a quick visit looking at our favourite artists. Would definitley recommend spending longer and looking at it properly. The building itself is a piece of art. So would love to go again.
