Take in the art and feel good about it.. NSW Art Gallery has a wonderful collection of modern Australian art as well paintings from the iconic painters of early Australian art. Also has a great cafe and restaurant.

A bit disappointed. The Gallery is set in an gorgeous old Sandstone building. That said compared to other world class galleries it needs updating. The location is fabulous but the place feels very old world and stuffy. We traveled here to see the Frida Khalo & Diego Riverea exhibit and found the space to be small and the works crowded into corridor formation which felt claustrophobic. I would have been great to be able to walk around the exhibition in a brighter space like that of the foyer.

Delightful place with free daily guided tours. The Art Gallery is an amazing place with an amazing collection. I was here during the Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera, which was sold out and there were queues with the lucky ones waiting to go in. There is a lot going on at the Art Gallery. Another exhibition focusing on the Tang dynasty.At 11am there are two guided tours: Aboriginal art and collections highlights. At 1pm there is one on contemporary art while at 2pm, one on Australian art. I would recommend breaking the visit in two if one can do it so one is not too overwhelmed with the collection covering all the themes treated in the guided tours.There are two cafés, one self-service at lower level 1 and the other à la carte on ground level, with spectacular views. They both open till late afternoon and on Wednesday till 9pm. You have a place to enjoy a meal and proceed with the second part.There is also a gallery shop with a comprehensive range of art books as well as merchandise like posters, cards, gifts even those made from the exhibitions like the Frida Kahlo bags. Great place to get souvenirs for your loved ones.The gallery opens at 10am daily and is opened everyday including Sundays.A bonus? They also have free WiFi, what more can one ask for? A great place to spend a delightful day!
Our Art Gallery. The NSW Art Gallery is a wonderful place with art exhibitions of all types of art held at different times throughout the year.I would recommend this to any traveller coming to Sydney

Great for Major Exhibitions or just to browse the Collections. The Art Gallery of NSW has regular "Blockbuster" exhibitions which focus on a specific artist, style or period,recent examples include the Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera collection,the Tang from the Silk Road and the Masters form the Scottish collection.The AGNSW is also host to the entries in (and winners of) the Archibald, Wynne and Sulman Prizes in July through October annually. The AGNSW also has wonderful permanent collections, which include Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art, Asian Art, Pacific Island Art, and Australian Art including works by artists such as Brett Whitely, Arthur Streeton, William Boyd, Sydney Nolan, Ellioth Gruner and Grace Cossington-Smith. There are exaples of European masters such as Picasso and Monet as well of course.All of this housed in a beautiful landmark building that mixes the best of classical archiitecture and modern decor.

Fascinating media and Blanchett multi screen art - MANIFESTO. Do not worry about the exact text that drops from overhead, just take in the brilliant visuals and extraordinary performances from Cate Blanchett. I stayed four hours, wished I had ten.Open till November but go now because you will want to go back.

beautiful . Great exhibitions, beautiful Aborigine collection in which you can see the creativity of the Aborigine art evolving over time, nice classical exhibition and also modern Australian art. A lovely building and amazing variety of art Worth going to again and again
Best Way. 30 mins walking from central is the best way and you can enjoy the old architecture of the different building.

A 19th Century gallery but with brave efforts to bring it into the 21st Century. I have been visiting the AGNSW for about 60 years. Living interstate, I now go to Sydney a couple of times a year but always try to fit in a visit to see new exhibitions, as I did a couple of weeks ago. It always feels like visiting the home of an old friend, comfortable and welcoming, but not as stimulating as the experience of visiting the many galleries around the world that have been designed and built in the late 20th or early 21st Centuries. Indeed, all art galleries that were built over a century ago, catered to attitudes to exhibiting (and experiencing) art that were very very different from those today.A number of years ago, the AGNSW undertook a major reconstruction and rearrangement of its facilities, to overcome some of these limitations and make it more suitable for modern needs. These did succeed in a number of ways, particularly in providing large glass walls that opened up vistas to the Botanical Gardens, the sea and the Woolloomooloo area. They also provided outdoor seating in the restaurant with similar views. Most importantly, the lower-ground-floor area used for temporary exhibitions is now very appropriate to displaying the big block-buster exhibitions they frequently stage. But it was always going to be a juggling act, trying to maintain what is unquestionably a beautiful old heritage sandstone building, with modern requirements for lighting, air-conditioning and so on. And the re-design did not make it more sculpture-friendly. Given the nature of the building, it was not possible to have, for instance, a central sculpture court such as the National Gallery of Victoria was able to incorporate into its much more modern 1960s design. As a result, the AGSW leaves one with an impression that it is dedicated almost solely to 2-dimensional art.Given that this houses and must display a large standing collection, it is not dedicated primarily or solely to temporary exhibitions (like the Kunstverein network in Germany). That role is played very well in Sydney by the Museum of Contemporary Art, near Circular Quay, and anyone dedicated to contemporary art may prefer to head there. In the AGNSW, there was always a need to continue displaying the "old favourites" such as the 19th Century European works, and Australia's own painting history such as the Heidelberg School works. A signal policy change during the time I have been visiting, is the decision to display a large and growing collection of Aboriginal art, primarily paintings on canvas but with some earlier bark-paintings, funerary poles etc. In fact, after my recent visit, I was left wondering why one has to go down two levels (by escalator or elevator, admittedly) to see the Aboriginal art. I would think the Gallery administration might well re-think this, and put the historical 19th Century Australian material down there, and bring the Aboriginal work up to the entry level. Not only is much of this work artistically superior, but I believe it is of greater interest to many of the overseas tourists that make up a large percentage of visitors. I have spoken to some of those who, with very limited time available for their visit, never made it down to the Aboriginal galleries, and were very disappointed to see mainly the sort of regional historical work that fill the walls of galleries around the world, with a remarkable sameness. Only Australia has Australian Aboriginal art in large quantity, and we should proudly flaunt it.

A great overview of Australian creative history. From the first European painters arriving to Australia to make a mark to the first Australian-born artists, the museum provides a great overview of the country's cultural history. The recent acquisitions of the earlier (15-17th century) European paintings are a testament to Australians' interest in art and the country's growing prosperity. Highly recommend.

Nice Paintings.. Some nice old paintings of Australia, some Aboriginal Art which were both nice to see, but it was so cold I couldn't really enjoy them. Went to the little cafe for lunch but they didn't serve any hot food. The restaurant didn't seem to have any casual little meals at reasonable cost so we gave up and left.Take some warm clothing. I left my wet rain jacket at the bag check and froze.
Artsy fun. Free of charge for most exhibits. Great Van Goghs and Picassos. Broad range from Renaissance to Baroque to Romantic to Impressionists to Cubism to Socialist Realism. Great collection!
A Sensational Gallery with a Fabulous Collection and Views. I go to the AGNSW every fortnight. A Sensational Gallery with a Fabulous Collection and Views and restaurant.

Tang exhibit was amazing. Fantastic exhibit of artifacts from the Tang dynasty. Well worth the price. Don't miss the virtual exhibit of the Mogao Grottoes at Dunhuang. It's a very creative way to show the Grotto.

Nice collection of Art and Crafts. I visited the Gallery with my two kids. My daughter is loves art work and she had a good time going through the items on display. A good place to visit and most of the art work is accessible free. There is a separate section to which you have to pay to enter.

Excellent place to visit. Free admission and located within the Botanical Gardens so be sure to check them both out. We were in the Art Gallery of New South Wales last week to check out the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander art and it was one of the best exhibits I have seen. We are going to be up in that area in late-September early-October so it’s nice to see some of the culture of the area before we arrive besides what we have researched previously. I really enjoyed it and would recommend to everyone to see. The other collections are great too, the Asia art one is fantastic too and contemporary art if interesting to see what comes out of people’s minds. The Gallery is also spitting distance to Woolloomooloo Bay which is just really fun to say. We may come back at the end of June for the Frida Kahlo exhibit as I have always enjoyed her work.

A Nice Collection of Pieces. The Art Gallery of NSW has a nice collection and range of pieces. It is free to the public. It will not take you more than a few hours to see most of the gallery. There is a park across the street which would make a nice picnic spot before or after your gallery visit. Good for all ages.

Lots of Aboriginal Work. First of all the Domain is a great area of Sydney... and the Art Gallery is a fantastic collection of Aboriginal art as well as work that is international and cutting-edge contemporary. I was delighted to step in an learn more about Australian support of the visual arts.

Always worth dropping by to see what's new. Free to enter (excluding a few temp exhibitions) the Art Gallery of NSW was between major exhibits after I missed the biennial show but the rotating works as well as a few temporary shows (including the quite fascinating Manifesto video installation featuring Cate Blanchett) made this quick visit worth the walk. Easily accessible from the CBD via the adjacent parklands of the Domain, stop by for a peek at Australia's rich art history past and present.
loved it. went to the Tang collection exhibition on till the 10th of June if you are in Sydney don't miss it if not go anyway just for the Australian art
Wonderful Experience. UNIQUE and unusual art pieces. The employees were friendly and knowledgeable, The museum never felt crowded and we were able to get through all exhibits under two hours.

Delightful visit for Australian paintings. I particularly enjoyed the 18th - 19th century art from Australian painters. The gallery also has smattering collection of 16th century Renaissance art to 18th century European art. Admission is free and would be a good place to spend an hour or so.

Well worth it.. What a delightful little "find", upon going to the Art Gallery on our visit to Sydney.Had the most enjoyable lunch in Matt Moran's Restaurant , Chiswick.Food was devine and Staff lovely.It was so cosy sitting by a window watching the rain drizzling down outside which only encouraged us to stay longer lingering over each tasty morsel in front of us.Will definitely be returning here on our next visit and recommending this delightful Restaurant to all our Friends.

A lot to see in a well-layed out museum. Our short visit didn't do it justice ... got there about 90 minutes before closing time, but what we saw was great.Some lovely aboriginal items as well as modern works that were unusual and impressive.Nice café. Art was well-illuminated and varied.
Excellent collection . Really enjoyed our visit. The classical renaissance and historical archives are great and well spaced. Not a huge fan of the more modern ones.

Great art and free (except for special exhibitions). A great collection especially of Australian art. Free entry and in the middle of the Domain so a lovely walk - can do the Botanic Gardens on the way to the Gallery. Well worth a visit.

Excellent. Set in beautiful surroundings and gardens, this open venue that is perfect for the art on display, the natural light makes it a pleasure to walk around all the exhibits. The collection is very good. Manifesto stood out Manifesto, featuring Cate Blanchett is fascinating and worth a visit. The contemporary collection is wonderful as well as our Australian collection.

Top Gallery. Visiting Sydney, we decided to see their special exhibit of TANG DYNASTY, treasures from the Silk Road.Absolutely fascinatingSmall exhibit, but top class items and great explanations of time, history and culture.The refinement and creativity of the period in China is simply amazing, when one thinks that Europe was engulfed by the dark age at the same time, or at least just was struggling to come out of it.Also wanted to see the collection of Aboriginal Art and were directed by the info-desk to go down to the basement, where we are told that it is closed. Internal communication problem?

Lovely gallery. Popped in here for a short visit whilst in Sydney and had a great time. Everything was well laid out and there were some very interesting exhibits, including one by high school students which took my breath away - some of those kids are going to go far!

Excellent!. For art appreciators, they have a good collection!To access some expos you have to pay and some are quiet expansive!I,ve done it after visiting the Royal Botanic Gardens as they are very close!
A must for tourists. Love popping in to the Art Gallery when in Sydney, good location, always enjoy lunch or just a coffee.

THE EYES HAVE IT- USE THEM. We go every year to the Archibald Exhibition & occasionally to a special display.Howeverthere are so many different artistic displays that might suit your own taste.It is certainly worth going & using those gift of sight that not everybody has.Go and SEE.
Great place to escape the rain. Manesfesto, featuring Cate Blanchette and the Sydney Bienalle were the two stand out exhibitions during our visit. Lovely space in the Domain in the heart of Sydney.

I loved the aboriginal art. Great venue, art was wonderful. Nothing "primitive" about the aboriginal art, it was amazing! Entrance free except to special events. Do donate as it is a worthy cause to support Aussie art!
For Art Lovers. This is a free place to visit. Sometimes, they hold special exhibitions which are chargeable. Good place to spend some time for art lovers and to get away from the heat outside.

Really good collection of Art. If you are serious and keen about art, this the place where you can admire the art. A lot of good collections are kept here.Paintings, statues, sculptures coming from different places of the world. It is free admission for general items or rooms, however for special exhibits there is an admission fee. The location is strategic next to Royal Botanic Garden. So you can do all, visit this Gallery, then have a nice walk at the garden then finalize your trip at Sydney Opera House before jump to the commuter trains or ferries at Circular Quay.
An excellent collection. A must see. The main collection is always interesting and there have always been excellent special exhibitions on Currantly the Ming - Chinese art which was superb

Tang 唐: Treasures from the Silk Road capital... [AGNSW] Art Gallery of New South Wales. As a Sydneysider, the AGNSW is one of the "must visit" places for my visiting friends. It has several outstanding collections, particularly Australian Art.From time to time it has a special Exhibition.The current one is Tang 唐: Treasures from the Silk Road capitalI went to see the treasures from the Tang Dynasty, described as the Golden Age of China and stretches over some 300 years. The capital was Chang’an [modern day Xian] the beginning of the legendary Silk Road.Said to be the most progressive open, tolerant [Buddhism and Islam entry] and prosperous period, with the only female Empress in Chinese history.On display are some 135 artefacts..gold/silver/glass/ceramics/sculptures and mural paintings. ..all outstanding and drawn from some 11 "cultural institutions"On of the highlights for me is an extraordinary recreation that modern technologyhas made possible "Pure Land: inside the Mogao Grottoes at Dunhuang". Hold up one of the iPads and the world comes alive because no one is allowed into these caves. No words can adequately describe the sheer beauty of the entire exhibition. A rare opportunity to not only look at the objects but to get an insight into a creative/innovative period of an ancient civilization.

Eclectic variety. Nice free museum representing primarily painted art from different eras and styles. Good representation of Australian painters and a few nice pieces of artists with aboriginal back ground. Well worth a visit and a must do especially on a rainy day.

Great selection of art in a beautiful building. The gallery is a lovely building set within the Domain of Sydney. It has a varied art collection, from 19th century Australian art through to contemporary pieces. I did the guided tour of the Australian art collection, which was friendly, informative and free.

Amazed at the Australian Art on display . A 5 minute walk from the St James Station, the Art Gallery of NSW was a treasure trove of Australian art. It was fascinating to find a continuous stream of Modern Art from the 1800s to 1940s, with explanations on how the international art scene influenced the Australian artists. Sydney Nolan's 'Pretty Polly Mine', Brett Whiteley's 'Women in Bath IV' were exceptional works of interest, as were the Abstract Art of the early 20th century which included Aborigine art.  Lucian Freud's voluptuous paintings displayed alongside Francis Bacon's Portrait of the Pope was truly mindblowing!

Interesting and fun. Went there out of curiosity, not being particularly found of contemporary art I still enjoyed this place and got a good surprise, uncommon art. Special award to the dark room piece.

Beautiful building. Enjoyed the museum on a rainy day during our trip - beautiful building, great aboriginal art, and a delicious cafe. The permanent collection doesn't compare to some of the world's best fine art museums, but a solid choice when in Sydney. Conveniently located when strolling through the botanic gardens or down Macquarie Street.

Could've spent the whole day there!. There was so many interesting art to look at. Aside from the requisite paintings, they also had statues and figurines and "knick knacks." There were also rooms dedicated to works by Australian artists (18th to 21st century, etc.), which was very interesting for me since most of the museums I'd been to in the past feature mostly European works and artifacts.

Escape into the world of Art. Even the walks to & from this Gallery is great but within the walls of this Art Gallery is amazing. A broad range of art & very significant artworks. Exhibitions that rival any other within Australia. Can't be missed by anyone even slightly interest or curious in art.

Tang Exhibition. I always visit the NSW Art Gallery when I come to Sydney. Tang Exhibition was amazing. Some 140 pieces dating back to period 600 - 900 AD, from China, on display in a very well presented exhibition.

Relaxed visit.. I went to the Gallery following the Sydney Biennale and was very pleased I did. They have interesting pieces in the different levels and everything except specific exhibitions is free of charge.Before or after your visit have a coffee in the Pavilion Kiosk across the street...you will not regret it!

One should visit more often. A must see in Sydney. You can lose yourself for hours in the Art Gallery of UNSW. So much to enjoy including Australian art and regularly changing exhibitions. The restaurant is very very good.

** International Artists Before Your Eyes **. Art lovers need to visit this icon when you're in Sydney, it is a place where history walks you back in time through the centuries. It's quality plus, enjoy the experience.

This is one of my favourite place in Sydney!. I live in Sydney and I love to visit the Art Gallery of New South Wales. I get to explore amazing art museums. This is one of the must see attractions in Sydney. Located next to the beautiful Royal Botanic Garden. only 15 minutes walk from the city centre. The main collection here is free, and absolutely stunning. My children enjoyed so much at the last visiting. There’s some free activities for children (my boys are 10 and14years old), they also offer workshops during the holidays but need to book in advance.

have a look at the junior exhibition. down in the basement of the Art Gallery there is a wonderful display of new budding artist picked from all over New South Wales. Fascinating and really worth seeing

Better than I thought!. Hubby had been going to the Art Gallery since he was a kid and always said he would take me 'one day'....well that happened and I am so glad he brought me to this wonderful Art Gallery!...I had never been and always thought I would never be interested but was very surprised that I really enjoyed it.....loved the history and diversity of the art in general. A must visit by all ages!

A fine Art Gallery . This is a fine art gallery with a solid collection of local and international artists. We often visit the gallery for new exhibitions, Pop to Popism was the most notable exhibit. Great transformation of the gallery space to accommodate a large collection of famous international pieces and some lesser known local artworks. Cafe is good to grab a quick bite and make good coffee. Often enjoy sitting outside post exhibition, gallery book shop also boasts a solid collection of art and design books! Well worth the visit, very close to botanical gardens and a pleasant walk to the Opera House.
Great collection for free!. Went on a Saturday in time for free tours. Went on aboriginal art tour which enjoyed. Good location near botanical gardens.

This is a very good gallery. There are many paintings from some of the greats that I have always wanted to see like:Tom Roberts - Bailed up, Albert Tucker - Apocalyptic Horse, Peter Paul Rubins - Self-portrait, Arthur Boyd just to name a few. I'm lucky that I was able to see these greats in real life for free. Unfortunately I wasn't able to take them home.

Art to be enjoyed by all. More than just an art gallery. Yes, it has the Greats, including a fantastic collection of Australian Impressionism as well as collections worldwide. Its special exhibits were well thought out and displayed appropriately. But the lovely part is the Resonant series where performing artists - classical and jazz - are performed in proper concerts with a simple but lovely reception beforehand AND the concert is held often in the hall amongst the Tom Roberts, Frederick McCubbins, etc. - a great spiritual feeling of sound and sight. I love this place.
Nice to visit. It is worth to visit this place. It is adjacent to Royal Botanic Gardens and you can getting there by public bus no. 441. It is free !!!

One of the best galleries in Australia. We visit AGNSW often and love the place. The permanent exhibits offer some of the best Australian and European art you'll ever see, while the special exhibits are always worth a visit.
We went to see Art Express 2016 (art by HSC students from 2015) on this trip; plus the 20th Biennale of Sydney. Some really excellent work!

Great place to visit, so much history within.. There is so much history there, if the walls could talk, they would have ALOT to say.Its absolutely fantastic that there's so many free exhibitions. It is great that you can be having a 'free' day out in the city, and include an exhibition. Some of the exhibits cost, but most are free, and it doesn't really cost that much anyway. Check out the gallery website, or brochure on all exhibition time and cost. My son (12.5) and i went to see the Art Express exhibition, which features a selection of the previous (2015) yr 12 art work for the HSC. This Exhibition runs from Nov / Dec until April /May - check with the gallery for the exact dates. This is an absoluty fantastic exhibition to see. It is great to see so many budding artists in the midst. Any oversized bags/luggage will need to be stored in the cloakroom at the front entrance. Quite convenient considering that the gallery is on 4 levels. There are lifts right throughout, and escallators. There is a restaurant on level 2 that serves all kinds of yummy eats, and gorgeous drinks and its quite reasonably priced, considering where it is located. This is a great place for all ages, because they have hands on areas for the little kids ( only in some exhibits) . There are so many exhibitions going on at once, there's definitely something for everyone. Access to and from the Art Gallery is easy. There are busses that go directly to and from the door.The Royal Botanic Gardens are right opposite the Gallery, and if you are feeling like a nice strole, take a walk through, it's very pretty, and about a 12 minute walk to The Opera House, amongst other places to go. Just follow the signs. The Botanic Gardens is also free. You can have a picnic in there, learn a little bit about Horticulture, or simply just stroll through. If you want to head back in to the city, you can head straight upto Macquarie St, in front, or Hyde Park, off to the left. But which ever way you choose to go, you can be assured that the footh paths are very safe, and suit not only foot traffic, but bikes and scooters also. OHighly recommend this for a fun day out, suitable for all ages!!

Always amazing!. I got to spend time in the company of Monet, Picasso and Van Gogh..... what more needs to be said? We had tea in the cafe and the staff at the info desk were chatty and friendly.... perfect

Nothing Special. We passed this gallery while walking around and decided to go in. It was a bit warm so it was nice to be in an air conditioned building. The main gallery is free but none of the art seemed to wow us. Ok if you are passing by and have about and hour but not recommended for more than that. There are better must places to see in Sydney.
Grand buildings . I had some spare time in Sydney, they say to get a better understanding of a city visit the galleries and museums so I did and was pleasantly surprised, even Pablo was there..

Art is for the Mind and Soul. I enjoy my visits to the NSW Art Gallery, its an oasis in a big city.An opportunity to appreciate art from all corners of the globe,including modern and ancient.The free tours are a must, to get an interpretation and appreciation of the artists thoughts and perspective.Together with the Cafe or Restaurant make it a memorable day for the young and /or not so young to enjoy a visit Centrally located near Botanical Gardens and Domain Car Park
Get your fix. There is an eclectic collection of Art works and I did not enjoy the Bienalle but I love the Pre Raphaelites.

A wide array of art, from ancient to modern.. The more I go, the more I realise how great the art collection and the visiting exhibits are! There's so much to see, and the quality is great. Probably only missing a few great Aussie artists, like Howard Arkley & Norman Lindsay, but still so good!And when you're done, looking at great art, the café has good food and a nice ambience, especially outdoors (but don't leave it too late, as they stop serving lunch too early for those who had a lazy weekend morning)!

A great venue. Whether going for a particular exhibition or just wanting to see the general exhibition there is always something new to see. You can eat in the Bistro and even though always busy you don't have to wait too long. Best to visit on a week day as the weekends are very busy. You can then go for a walk in the Domain afterwards and enjoy seeing the city skyline.

Not suitable for kids. Im old fashioned by nature. I dont think there is a difference between naked people in magazines or painted nudes hanging in art Galleries. I was constantly covering my kids eyes as they are young and have never been exposed to nudity before. If all the nudes were in one area that would be ok but they are spread all over the gallery so unavoidable. Some are quite offensive.Other then that its quite nice. Its free so you cant complain about the price. And its a short walk from the strain station through a lovely grassy oval the kids ca run around on.
My little piece of work was displayed in the AGNSW!. My little piece of art work was displayed at the Art Gallery of New South Wales, I feel honoured and proud of myself!

Pleasantly surprised. The last time, prior to this year, I went to the NSW Art Gallery I was a young adult and aside from a vague feeling of satisfaction at seeing a few paintings I'd studied in high school actually in person, I was left with the impression that this was a very dull place and not one I would feel compelled to visit anytime soon. However 20 years later I attended an exhibition with a friend who is a member, early this year, and after we'd viewed the exhibition we went for a wander - I have to say their collections have vastly improved and the gift shops are a great place for gifts and souvenirs (especially for the hard to buy for people in your life).
19th Century Australian art. Always enjoy the Australian art rooms here. Beautiful buildings house the collections. Easy walk to the gallery and the coffee shop is well located within the building

What a range of pictures to view. It has been a very long time since I last visited the Art Gallery of New South Wales and I promise to go back more often. From old Masters to modern day, the range was enormous and the variety - I don't have enough words to describe it. The building is beautiful and compliments the contents. There is a Spice Road exhibition and a contribution to the 20th Biennale. There is a very interesting Aboriginal exhibition also. I recommend you visit this Gallery - it provides something for everyone, is easily accessed from the beautiful Botanic Gardens and is refreshingly cool on a warm day. The staff were exceptionally polite and helpful.

Very interesting curation. Surrounded by Mrs. Macquarie's Chair and properties of rich and famous, this art gallery is astonishing. Art works from national and international artists are noteworthy. You will see (Asian) Indian connection in three artworks too. Photography was allowed when I visited.
The Biennale is There Now - GO!!. Gorgeous space opposite Hyde Park and next to St. Mary's Cathedral. Amazing art space & the 2016 Biennale is in full bloom there. Eat lunch @ Chiswicks!!

Great collections. This gallery has a very extensive collection of art work and also brings in special displays so even if you have visited it before, it is well worth a return visit. Great display of Aboriginal art as well. With free admission, it is a great place to spend a rainy day (or part of one) in Sydney. However, with the exception of Wednesdays, it is only open during the day.Good gift shop and coffee shop.

Good section of classic Australian art. A walk across the Domain to the Art Gallery of NSW is a pleasant experience in itself. The gallery itself contains a cross section of western art, but the highlight is really the classic Australian art.

One of the Best Art Galleries in Australia. I have visited this gallery numerous times and it has never ceased to amaze me. This is one of my favourite spots in Sydney and if I were a Sydney resident, I would probably visit it more often for its Up Late and films programs.One of the best art galleries in the country along with my other favourites (NGV in Melbourne, QAGOMA in Brisbane and AGSA in Adelaide).

A little bit of culture. My wife and I enjoyed our walk from our CBD hotel through Hyde Park and the Domain to the Art Gallery. The gallery was not huge but had a good cross section of Australian art. We had a light lunch in the cafe and then walked across to Darling Harbor. I think that next time we would allow a bit more time and wander through the botanic gardens. We got to walk through a lovely part of Sydney with huge fig trees and green areas in the middle of the city as well as take in some enjoyable art viewing.

Surprisingly good. Surprisingly interesting collection of European Art, including works of Strozzi, Bronzino, Rubens and Soutine. Also contemporary art is well presented, for example Lucien Freud paintings are quite moving. Great collection of Australian art including aboryginal work. Unfortunately, when I was there Asian art was not on display, nevertheless definitely a place worth visiting.

Celebration dinner for a special birthday. Fabulous dinner for 200 friends of the birthday girl, firstly we had drinks downstairs to view the Archibald Exhibition (which I had viewed the day before) so It was a pleasure to see more. Then upstairs where Matt Moran & his restaurant put on a beautiful dinner, three courses, beautiful flowers on the table. Wines, only the best etc. Speeches & James Morrison himself jazz & dancing. Wonderful evening no-one will forget.
Great museum. A really nice museum displaying a diverse range of Australian art. Most of the museum is free. If you have time head across he road to speakers corner for some great entertainment

Surprisingly it's a very big art gallery. I'm not an art enthusiastic. But since it's free, so I give myself a try to visit. I was surprised with how big the art gallery is. I'm not really remember, I think it has 3 story.They categorized the collection based on type of arts. The placement is very neat. One thing, they allowed to take a photograph!

Call this art gallery?. Creepy old looking, exhibition expensive , hard to get to, no public transport and lack of car park, exhibitions are boring! need to learn something from NGV or NGA in Canberra

An impressive collection and special exhibitions.. Well worth visiting for the art lover. A great range of Australian and global masterpieces on show. Most recently, I savoured over a travelling collection from Scotland, including works by Monet, Titian, Van Gogh and the likes. A Picasso exhibition in recent times was also truly magnificent in range and visual excellence. Nice coffee shop. Perfect for rainy day visits or school holidays!

Fine art and contemporary. Another great free place to visit in Sydney - Fine art on the first floor and more contemporary down below plus a nice cafe. There are usually special exhibits that cost money also. There is a lot of English and some French and good Australian art. It is also just next to the Royal Botanical Garden so in a great setting

A pleasant experience. A great gallery where there is quite a bit you can see for free and you are free to wander at your own pace. I ended up joining for a year which entitles to you to see special exhibits during the year (e.g. Archibald prize) plus a host of other benefits such as discounts at food outlets within the gallery. You can check the website for upcoming events (paid) that you might be interested in seeing prior to joining. They also have a member's lounge on the bottom level with a kids area with toys or drawing activities available where you can sit back and enjoy a coffee/snack while your child is entertained.

Marvelous. A wonderful time I had seeing ancient, statues, and art works that told a tale of past that could pass for the hear and now. I was engrossed in the beauty of the paintings. A must see when in Sydney!

A Great Gallery. It's a great place to visit while you are around the Botanical Gardens it has permanent and temporary exhibitions and I found that both were just as interesting. Entry is free so a great attraction to visit if you are wanting a cheaper day out

Pleasant spot to visit. I am a reasonably regular visitor to the Art Gallery of NSW and the most recent time was for the exhibition of The Greats: Masterpieces from the National Galleries of Scotland.I enjoyed this exhibit and find that I am usually interested in seeing 3/4 of their special exhibits.There are also a number of free galleries that showcase Australian and international art.Recommended.

Excellent lay outs. Visited over the Easter weekend, easy to enjoy all the displays plus the children's art exhibition. Also to be able to enjoy some light refreshments in the building was a welcome site.

Colourful and Entertaining. We stayed there for a whole afternoon with our six-year-old daughter. We ended up forgetting to visit the Royal Botanic Garden (within a stone's throw). Don't miss the gallery at Lower Level 2 where kids can enjoy artworks creation themselves.

Paradise of art lovers. For us it was a shelter to rains to be honest as we are not really interested in arts, but still it manages to wow us with its huge and fantastic collection of artifacts and paintings.Must visit even if u are not much into arts.

Good place to visit if you are visiting sydney. As locals we come here every now and then and our daughter loves the exhibition in the gallery. Free entry and connecting public transport to Town Hall station makes it very convenient even for those who have a pram. It is open all day except Good Friday and Christmas Day

Great and varying collection . I spent 3 hours in the gallery and it was absolutely worthy! They have a very varying collection of Australian and European art. I was lucky to visit during the 20th Biennale of Sydney, those pieces were very interesting. Artexpress (another exhibition) impressed as well! All together I can highly recommend this!
"Artist's That Love Artist's". Its an Artist's must to visit when here in Australia, Sydney at Art Gallery of New South Wales. Free Entry. so much to see..

An eye opener. A very "inclusive" gallery with wonderful works of art. Big Aboriginal display. Also with regard to the art displayed representing the last 150 years, at least 40% was by women artists - as against about 2% in the average GB or US large gallery. Bright and airy, would highly recommend.
Definitely worth a visit. Right next to The Domaine park which is nice to stroll through afterwards.Nice cafe inside.Lots to see.
The Archibull. Great Place to Visit if you Love Looking at ArtEspecially The Sydney Archibald,in Julyfree to enter unless events like the Archibald
Brilliant gallery. Great extensive collection of arts. nicely displayed. Very well supported by organised tours. Well worth making a visit.
Great aboriginal art. Not a huge museum. Lots of great aboriginal art and Australian artists. Surrounded by the Park. Excellent guides.
brillaint guided tour. we thoroughly enjoyed our tour of the gallery collection of Aboriginal art especially as Keith Potton was such a great guide

If you enjoy art this is a great place and FREE (special exhibits not included). Fantastic location being in the Domain and close to the Botanic Gardens. The Gallery has some beautiful works especially Australian artists. It is a lovely place to visit and explore and has multiple levels and different art from around the World. The building itself is a piece of art made of lovely Sydney sandstone and set amongst lovely gardens. If you have time - absolutely worth

great way to spend a couple of hours. Large collection of indigenous peoples art, gallery well spread out and a spaces to quietly sit on couches and reflect on the works,Very expensive cafe with no other food options close by.

Lots to see and Free. Lots of art to see here in a gigantic building. The building is set in the botanic gardens so you have to walk through a lovely area to access it. Visit here and spend the remainder of the day in the botanical gardens. All free....
Great Beach and Amenities. The whole beach scene and atmosphere is both relaxing and adorable with good food and drinks outlets in abundance.
had a wonderful time. I was so moved some works from entrance. Beautiful and elaborate, I never saw. I spend almost all day there, enjoyed some exhibitions and lunch at cafe.

Incredible with something for everyone . I went here on a last minute decision and I had the best time. There is so so much to see and hundreds of unique and different collection- and it was free! However for me the best part was going solo- It meant I could spend as long as I wanted staring and one piece. Give yourself at least 2hr and if possible go either early or late as it gets crowded with can ruin the atmosphere

An outstanding art museum, much more than local art. I know, you read the reviews about doubtful visitors who art not certified art lovers, but do visit here even if it is not a rainy day. From the outside, it looks like a classical museum but inside a modern, flexible new museum has been inserted and it is delightful. The first floor to the right is a restoration of the 19th century museum, with some European classics (Rubens, Canaletto) and local work; but if you take the left side, it is a history of Australian 20th century art. Who knew there was Australian Cubism or Social Realism or Impressionism? Discover local favorite Margaret Preston- those are her woodcut prints on the shopping bags from the excellent museum shop. Downstairs has European modernism (Picasso, Monet) and contemporary Australian art. Overall this is as they say a place for Art and Ideas. If you like to see and consider beautiful things you don't need to be an art expert. It was all free the day we visited, but there may be extra charges for some exhibitions. There is a good cafe and a formal restaurant, but we liked the Pavilion restaurant in the park across the street. The museum is adjacent to the exit from the Botanic Garden and a 30 min walk from Circular Quay

Good collection of Aboriginal art. The Art Gallery is one of Australia's most important galleries -- certainly, the best in NSW. The gallery is in the Domain, near the heart of Sydney. It awards the Archibald Prize, Australia's top prized for portraiture. The Aboriginal and modern Australian collections are good, but I always feel a little let down that some schools of art are not well represented. The National Gallery of Victoria's collection has benefited immensely from the Felton Bequest. I would never bypass a chance to visit the Art Gallery of NSW.

An unbelievably stunning museum!. An unbelievably stunning museum! One of the most interesting and diverse collections that I've ever experienced. I spent over four hours in its vast interior, enjoying every minute learning about unfamiliar pieces and artists. Even if you're not a well-versed fan of art, you're sure to enjoy something from the very different periods, artists, and movements on exhibit. Sydney is quite lucky to have such an institution. What an excellent way to spend an afternoon!

Antique building with modern interior. when see from outside this building looks very old but when you go inside its looks very modern. I like spend my time in this building eventhough I'm not really understand art but just to see alot of art from different era quiet interesting and you also can see alot of original art of aborigin people here.
Must do. The collection is stunning. Hard to justify leaving perfect Sydney weather, but its a perfect way to start a morning before walking through the botanical gardens.
Nice Gallery. Like any Gallery it is hard to judge due to the ever changing exhibitions. I loved one, and disliked the other. Finding direction was difficult, but the variety on offer was good.

Great Australian art and FREE entry!. I went with my kids, we were filling in a spare hour we had in Sydney. This meant we didn't see the whole gallery but we saw a lot of great pieces. I didn't realise it had a fantastic contemporary art display, we really enjoyed it . I was also thrilled to find the picasso's, cezanne, and monet and numerous other famous artists that even I have heard of. The Australian art section was great too, hung in the lofty halls with dramatic frames. Free, quality, educational, what more could you ask for? A must see.

Afternoon at the gallery. Unfortunately, the day I went, a lot of the galleries were closed for the set up of new shows. When I did see however was wonderful. And, I was surprised to see two Picasso paintings.

A Great Activity For A Great Day.. A great collection of Australian and European works of art. You will find Fredrick MCcubbin's On The Wallaby Track here. Australians who are old enough to remember the 1980's may remember that this art work is used as the basis for the Kit Kat advertisement (1982 ) It is a great way to introduce children to Australian art.

Beautiful building with good permanent collection. Just across the road from the Botanical Gardens so easy access and well worth a visit. Even if you have little time to spare there's no charge to see the permanent collection.

Worth a moment of your time.... This is a free art museum, perfect for someone who wants to escape the heat of the day. Most of the exhibits were clearly labeled, lending even the most limited viewer an understanding of the art. Most of the employees were friendly and willing to engage in conversation about the nearby pieces. It lacked a stuffy, clinical atmosphere, and as such would be a great place to take children - or even adults who might be slightly intimidated by other art museums. We saw several school groups, of various ages, present.Paid tickets were required for the featured exhibit -- which looked fascinating -- but it was not necessary to have an enjoyable time. (The gift shop featured a large selection of reproduction and collections of the featured artist, so one can get a good feel to decide if it was worth the price or not.)Quite a bit of space was dedicated to aboriginal art, both traditional and modern, which was appreciated. There even was a remarkable protest piece that really captured and expressed the tone and feeling that most likely many oppressed native peoples share.The cafe served the most wonderful lemonade and provided yet another spectacular view of the harbor. My husband also experienced his first vegemite spread on toast there. A culinary shock he will not soon forget!
Art lovers. Fabulous collection of contemporary and aboriginal art. A must see if in Sydney for all art lovers young and old.
great to spend a few hours and see Australian Art. this amazing gallery is free to visitors and well worth a visit the art is displayed well....and the building is just wonderful old sandstone enjoy
Performance Art. Wide variety for all tastes. Captured the perfect moment when one of the installers lost their head over a new installation.

A wonderful place for art lover. Lots works from different artists from mid-age to contemporary were exhibited here. Only some special exhibitions need tickets. You can spend as long as you like and take as many pictures as you like (remember not to use flash light). There is not much famous works here so there will be no crowds, comparing to the Louvre.

different and disappointing from European perpective. visited as European Art lover of Galleries . This one was small and not very interesting from European perspective. Not much else can say about it

A bit disappointing. Normally I enjoy my visits to the Art Gallery but it seemed like quite a bit was shut for renovations, extensions or new installations. Thus, my visit was a bit disjointed. I did enjoy the Kaldor Gallery and it is always a pleasure to see the iconic Australian paintings. I look forward to returning when more is available.

Beautiful and simple . The building itself is an architect's dream, nestled in the heart of the city right next to the Botanical gardens and the cathedral. The halls inside are absolutely beautiful and display amazing art. It is simple, open spaces, and showcase various types of art from various eras.
A great place to unwind!

Hours passed by and I didn´t even notice!. I love art and this is a great place to go even if you are a begginner you can see interesting and fun pieces. I remember a colorfoul bread stand on the lower stage. It was a different and cool exposition. I went when the michelangelo rembrandt and classical artists exposition was going on. It was a very wonderful experience I loved it. The only negative thing is that in some rooms they put the paintings way too high, no one can really see the pieces.
Lovely gallery and its free. Love this gallery contains some good works,not into the modern art but that's me ,its free but entrance to some art is by fee

On the small side. The museum makes fur a nice stop but it is on the small side. Clearly there is an emphasis on the special exhibits which you have to pay to see. I wandered in right as it opened after spending The morning in the botanical gardens. As an add on I enjoyed it but I would not go just for the museum.

Amazing collection. This gallery is amazing on many levels - literally. Floor to floor, the gallery is filled with excellent free collections as well as pay to visit special shows. The Aboriginal collection is exciting ... and the views from the building are amazing. OF course, most fun is just getting there through the Botanical Gardens.

A Must Visit for a Sydney Visitors. Having visited Sydney many times in the past, we somehow kept missing this gem of a museum. A wonderful collection. I particularly love early Australian paintings of the Heidelberg School and I was not to be disappointed with the collection of Tom Roberts, Arthur Streeton, etc. Fun to see the contemporary collections as well which we enjoyed, too.

Inspiring. I love being a tourist in my own city and I always go on to re-discover for inspiration.The art Gallery of NSW is suitable for everybody, it has a lot of beauitful history and it is a great way to get inspiredIf you are doing the Royal Botanic Gardens walk, it is a great way to relax after by going to the art gallery, it is worth the visit which leaves you wanting more.
Nice to have a walk around to relax. Nice gallery to check out has a mixture of everything for everyones tastes. Nicely laid out and good air conditioning on a hot day
Lovely inside and out. Our tour guide recommended we visit the art gallery after the tour. We did and we loved it! It was beautiful inside and out.

Worth a visit but...... We have visited this gallery before and were quite impressed but this time not so much as it appeared to lack cohesion. Australian scenes were interspersed with European scenes or religious or historical pictures. Perhaps the display needs a rethink.
Always a pleasure to visit. The art gallery is well situated and has excellent permanent and temporary exhibitions, great café too.
Brilliant. Not realy my scene but was passing so thought give it a go and i realy enjoyed most the items on display so guess i may start to take in art galleries

Disappointing given the impression that the exterior gives. When approaching the Gallery of NSW from outside, the building is decorated with names of artistic greats: Titian, Rembrandt, Leonardo, Michaelangelo, etc; so I had the impression that the museum would have some of these artists in their collection.I was disappointed. Overall, the gallery was far more contemporary than I was anticipating and frankly, I was disappointed in the art presented. It's a beautiful museum, but check to see what their special exhibitions are before visiting.

An important and interesting museum. We went first and primarily to look at the indigenous paintings and were pleased to discover Australian art of the twentieth century. The walk through the park to the museum is also a great pleasure.

Very well worth a visit. A beautiful gallery with views over Sydney, interesting collections and roof top cafe with fine views and it's free. We pent on a guided tour of the contemporary collection and the special exhibition, "When Silence falls" was especially moving..
Great show. The exhibition from Edinburgh was great - well presented variety of artists and styles. Pleasant cafeteria to enjoy Sydney's weather.

Great Gallery. This was my first visit to the Gallery in more than 10 years and I was delighted to find this stunning jewel, free to all. It is clean fresh and well laid out with a mix of new and old. I chose to do 2 free tours the 1pm Contemporary Art and the 2pm Australian Collection. I was the only person on the first tour so had my own personal guide, a lovely lady who was both interesting and knowledgeable. The second tour had 12 people, but again the guide was very good. The views at the back of the gallery over Wooloomooloo are excellent and it was a wonderful way to spend a day. Highly recommended and I'll be back again soon.
Absolute must see. huge eclectic range of artists and styles. Beautiful gallery spaces, free to go in, some classic pieces to be seen

Drawing, with cheese, wine and strings playing in the backgroud. The late night drawing workshop with a glass of bubbles and a cheeseboard... Perfect! I brought along my daughter who also thoroughly enjoyed it and plan to bring friends as well next time. I can't draw, but it's still great fun!

It's not the MET but still amazing and owrth seeing. an exytremely eclectic collection of art from old masters to arboriginal to very contamporary works of art in a gorgeous building with magnificent galleries. Should not be missed even if you are not an art lover

A must for the Archibald. A great gallery at any time of year, but especially when the Archibald is on - it's an exhibition that never fails to disappoint (though perhaps international visitors may not know the characters on display.... even so, the portraits are still stunning, ditto the Sulman and Wynn prize exhibits). The gallery restaurant serves great food, quite causal yet good quality. The children's sections are lacking in my opinion, and for kids, the Museum of Contemporary Art is a much better option. Overall - a good stop on a walk around the gardens/Domain, and easily accessible from the city.
Good mixture of art. I am no art expert but very much enjoyed wandering around the art gallery, and in particular the Aboriginal artwork on display

Amazing pictures. Totally blown by that Art Gallery, especially by the ground floor and its big picture. We had a look around and a very nice guard started to tell us a lot about the pictures, such a lovely atmosphere and even a free tour ;) Thanks for the amazing experience, will definitely go back for another visit

A fascinating collection .. We revisited this wonderful museum because we couldn't spend enough time there on a previous visit. Lucky to join a tour and the guide was excellent. I love the contemporary aboriginal art work and the work of the early settlers tells a story of human struggle. Great restaurants too , with wonderful views but watch out for the sneaky Ibis who stole my lunch. The manager kindly replaced it for free!

Location, architecture and exhibition . The AGNSW building itself is a beautiful artifact on it's own. It's location on the midst of all the green of the Domain is a nice break from the concrete jungle of the city which in my opinion doesn't do enough to preserve heritage buildings. The quality of exhibit inside depends on what is on at any given moment. However they do get some great exhibitions, I saw the great European painters here.

The Masters - Scottish Exhibition. Love checking in here to see the travelling exhibitions. Great artists showcased in this exhibition from the National Galleries of Scotland. It also gives me the opportunity to wander around the permanent exhibitions and appreciate the art we have here. Beautiful building, helpful staff and positioned in the Domain - a stones throw from the gardens - make a day of it!

Good!. I planned to visit there with my parents but my parents were too tired to go so I went there myself. It was a great trip since I was so fortune to view the conversation of three of the designers of the Chinese zodiac lanterns. The art works are great and fantastic.

Interesting Mixture of Collections. I spent three very enjoyable hours here and learned a great deal about the country through the exhibits. I recommend leaving another hour or so to walk through the Botanical Gardens nearby, before or after your visit.

Very enjoyable!. I'm slightly biased as I alway like art galleries! Not huge , but some very thought provoking displays . Enjoyed an informative tour of contemporary art . Had a bite to eat at the cafe - tasty ! Interesting gift shop . It's free & a great way to spend a few hours . Just right .

Amazing medley of Australian, Asian, European, and Modern art. Four floors full of varied arts from various places and time periods ranging from buddha heads to local Australian aboriginal creations to contemporary videos. There were even two Picasso paintings. And it is all free too!

The Art Gallery of NSW is a Cultural Icon.. The Art Gallery of NSW offers a treasure-trove of experiences for both tourists and residents of Sydney and beyond. I travel from the Blue Mountains regularly to attend a wide variety of events. Last week I saw the outstanding exhibition: TheGreats -Masterpieces from the National Gallery of Scotland; a travel lecture on Javanese Temples and Textiles and another lecture on the Bauhaus. The Gallery also hosts regular music events, excellent permanent art collections, cafe and restaurant. It is very easy to spend whole days absorbed in it.

A very beautiful gallery with amazing works of art. The gallery its self is beautiful and the art inside it is just amazing. Everyone single painting and piece of art inside has its own unique place! wonderful

One of the best Art Galleries in the world. Always interesting with a marvellous variety of exhibitions. At Present showing Scottish Greats. This Gallery also has a wonderful collection of Aboriginal Art, see the Lower Gallery, European Art as well as some really weird and wonderful stuff. Great cafe serving limited menu but very fresh food.

Every painting has a story behind it. The art gallery is not too big but complete with variety of collections. It's suitable for family activities, they have the art activities for kid which encourage creativity. The display impressed me the most is the shoes stored on wall. It disclosed that kidnapping is common in Columbia, many lost their love one and never see them again. The shoes stored on wall are those missing. The artist approached to the family and bring this issue to public's attention.

Always worth a visit. We were recently in Sydney and had the pleasure of another visit to this excellent Art Gallery.The exhibition "The Greats" from Scotland was on and it was outstanding.
Will visit on every trip to Sydney

Always a visual pleasure!. Enjoying the free admission and so much wonderful art! You can have a relaxed walk around, hide from the rain and never get tired of visiting over and over again. I try to go every few months when I stay in Sydney followed by a Botanical Gardens walk.

The Greats - Masterpieces from the National Galleries of Scotland. The Art Gallery of NSW is the premier art institution in Sydney and the current exhibition is well worth the visit being The Greats - Masterpieces from the National Galleries of Scotland. This is a real treat as the paintings are an excellent survey of different eras and styles - Botticelli, Leonardo, Raphael, Titian, Rubens, Velázquez, Poussin, Rembrandt, Vermeer, Turner, Monet, Degas, Gauguin, and Cézanne to name a few.The Gallery itself is a mix of modern and 18th Century building wiith a wide ranging collection spanning classical art, asian art, Aboriginal Art and photography There is a large cafe and great restaurant with views over to the Harbour. A great way to spend a few hours.

Art indulgence. Entry by donation (if you want) to explore the many leveles and exhibits -amazing displays and lots for young children and old to busy themselves with. When you need a break you can have a bite to eat or walk through the gallery shop.

Definitely worth a visit!!. Amazing exhibition at present 'The Greats'. Masterpieces from the National Galleries of Scotland. Always plenty to see and special exhibitions are very interesting and worthwhile.
Great for a visit. Helpful staff and quiet surroundings. Special exhibitions run all year. Coffee shop could improve their menu - it is very basic.
Interesting exhibitions and great events. The gallery has lots of events throughout the year. Suitable for those who love to spend quiet time and those who has passion in art.

Visiting the Scottish Masters. Wednesday evening opening is always most enjoyable. Excellent guide with most comprehensive coverage of many of the great masterpieces. Extensive information shared on each specific art work that was given attention. It was wonderful to see such an exclusive selection of works normally housed in the Galleries of Scotland. Dinner at the restaurant was efficiently served and appetising to eat.Wonderful opportunity to witness great works of art as well as enjoy a meal!

Decent collection. Considering the place is free, this place has a lot to offer. I love the Australian and Aboriginal Art Collection. I frequent this place and on my free days visit it and enjoy a meal at the Cafe.

Wow the GREATS were exactly that!. I went to the museum and went thru the entire thing. The "GREATS" sections was amazing. I loved being able to see Rembrandt, Renoir, Monet, Divinci, and so many more. It was a feast for the eyes.
Getting better and better!. We are growing the best collection of art given our limited means thanks to some amazingly generaus patrons and benefactorsl

Art Transfusion. Surround yourself with Old Masters and new challenging artists. Eat in one of the most enjoyable restaurants and wander the galleries to your heart's content and it will feel like paradise.

Very nice mix. A very eclectic collection of art with Francis Bacon in one room and some truly wonderful aboriginal art in the next. The Australian art contained in the museum was very interesting and I would never have seen it if not for the museum.
Well done exhibits . Well curated with good notes. Really enjoyed the Aboriginal and other Australian art. Definitely worth a couple of hours.

Short visit for National Galleries of Scotland. WE visited the gallery of the Tuesday (Australia Day) to see the current exhibition of masterpieces from the national galleries of Scotland. The presentation was in the usual location in the downstairs halls and was while slightly busy, we had no issue with taking our time moving through the paintings. Excellent selection of European artists (mostly not Scottish) and even a Canadian painting of the Niagara Falls which has its own hanging place. We enjoyed it especially some of the hand sketching, and preparatory works by the greats. The price was reasonable for the extent of the exhibition and if you enjoy art, then allow more than a hour to make your way through. As part of the fee, you automatically have access to audio guide which worked well and supplemented the information provided on the description cards attached to the paintings.

really fine art in a fabulous setting. The Art Gallery of New South Wales is perfectly situated at the Botanic Gardens. A great variety of paintings and sculpture set in a magnificent Sandstone building. Great to see and exhibition of the Irish Artist Francis Bacon there also.

The Greats. I have been most fortunate, visiting galleries both on Australia and overseas, but I still have the Wow, a Frans Hals, a Rembrandt or a Gaugin. This special exhibition from Edinburgh was excellent. The Botticelli was gorgeous, the Hals...well, that I would like to take home. Good lighting, story boards and 'themed' rooms, each numbered in Roman numerals. Hurry before the exhibition closes. And don't miss other areas of the Gallery.
Masterful Masters . What a great exhibition! Rembrandt, Sargent, Constable, Gauguin, Monet, Cezanne etc. Definitely worth seeing before 14th February.
Nice Respite. I visited this museum while in the Royal Botanic Gardens. Although I hadn't heard of any of the artists, the museum was well laid out and I enjoyed the art I saw.

perfect choice. Perfect choice for a day out. I enjoyed the latest exhibition 'THE GREATS ' its a must see event. It has a superb collection. so much to see and enjoy. Afterwards I walked across to the Botanic gardens for a relaxing afternoon.
Love the old / new building. I don't know how many times I have been there. It's a very nice museum which incorporates the city view through big large windows in the g level.

The Greats: masterpieces from the National Galleries of Scotland. Visited the exhibition from Scotland at the Art Gallery of NSW on Wednesday evening when the gallery was open for extended hours. However, before viewing it, we were treated to a one hour concert in the foyer of the gallery by musicians Monsieur Camembert Quartet, who mainly play Klezmer and gypsy music. It was a fun night doing both these things.

A Pleasurable Experience. We went to see the Scottish Exhibition and loved it. Our art gallery guide was outstanding. Her knowledge of the paintings and artists and her enthusiasm for the exhibition was infectious.
Amazing Scottish Exhibition.. Perusing The AGNSW's permanent collection is always a great way to spend an afternoon, amazing building, great cafe and beautiful restaurant.
Wonderful museum. We thoroughly enjoyed this museum. It was a rainy day, and after walking through the botanical gardens, it was a wonderful stop.

The Greats exhibition. We came to Sydney for the day to see The Greats exhibition. I bought our tickets online the day before and that made it very easy, rather than stand in a long line to purchase on the day. All members of staff we spoke to were very helpful and friendly and it was easy to find our way around. The exhibition was spectacular and I loved how it was presented, we also really liked the audio tour that was included with the ticket, it was really interesting and I was glad they offered it. Not often an opportunity like this comes along to see so many beautiful, historic pieces locally and I think I'll be fitting another visit in before it's gone.

A beautiful building in a most interesting location. This attraction is well worth a visit. There really is something for everyone. It is a large, beautiful building with a great selection of art work from many different types of Artists. The cafe I'd great too for simple food cooked well. Sadly we didn't have nearly enough time to spend there.

What a treasure. The site is perfect for viewing a snapshot of Sydney, the building is grand and imposing, the food is varied - fine dining and more casual, and the artwork is fabulous. Whether there is a special exhibition on or not, it's worth a visit to refresh the senses with the range of art on display

The Greats - Open Late. We visited the exhibition of the Greats on a Friday night as they are open til 10pm on Thursday and Friday nights in January (and Wednesday nights throughout the year). On those nights they also have other entertainment - Friday being the Australian Brandenburg Orchestra.This was a wonderful group of musicians playing Baroque music on traditional instruments which was beautiful and enjoyable. We also had a quick meal in the cafe beforehand and the service and food were both very good and reasonably priced. definitely recommend for a quick bite. The exhibition was very good and the free audio tour was very informative. Once we had seen the exhibit we were able to wander around the main floor enjoying the work of Australian and other artists. The Art Gallery is free however, there may be charges for special exhibitions. As we were leaving it began to rain but this was no problem as there was a courtesy bus to the train stations in the city which ensured we made an early train. Something we would not have done if we'd walked to the closest station. Definitely recommend as it is a short walk from St James Station and also to Lady Macquarie's Chair, the Domain and the the Botanical Gardens.

World Class Free Museum. This was one of my favorite places in Sydney. It is a world class museum that is free. Special exhibits do cost extra. Something I really enjoyed was going on Wednesday during extended hours. They special entertainment and drinks and I found the museum a little quieter to see the art without crowds. Overall, a beautiful spot perfect for rainy days or when you need a break from the sun!
A great place for art lovers. From contemporary to modern to historical art, they have it all. It is also a great rainy day activity. The art gallery also has cafes to simply sit and enjoy.

The best in Australia .. We traveled over from Perth western Australia to see the masters from Scotland exhibition well worth the money.
The gallery itself is so much better than the others as it has
a very over all different range .

Well worth visiting. We have visited several times and always enjoy the free exhibits, which vary from year to year (based on our visit frequency). We are not art buffs but happily fill a couple of hours, usually making our visit when the weather is less favourable.
'The Greats'. See this wonderful exhibition from the Scottish National Gallery if you can. A feast of superb paintings and drawings collected over many years.

Great exhibition. Recently visited the National Galleries of Scotland exhibition. Informative audio tour included in ticket and discount on purchase of Grayson Perry exhibition at MCA which could be used on a different day. Good location for snack at cafe.

Great value and thankyou for staying open late. Thank you to the art gallery for understanding families. We visited after work on Thursday night with the kids. Thank you also for providing a family price that included two adults and three children! Noone does that - family prices are always for two kids. Thankyou for the drawing activity for free. Thank you for a great exhibition. Terrific night out!!

Great art, specially free section! Van Gogh paintings for everyone to see. Great place, friendly staff, awesome free section with classics and my numero 1 Van Gogh!!!! The coffee shop has amazing views and the exhibitions change constantly so you can go back to see more new stuff often!!
We love visiting this gallery. Excellent exhibitions, lovely open space, friendly staff & a great collection of Australian and international works.

Scottish national paintings. This exhibition is well worth visiting. The gallery provides an audio guide, which gives extra information on some paintings besides the written information provided next to each picture. The exhibition is very well laid out and covers a wide range of painters and finished on 14 Feb 2016

Superb Exhibition of Works from National Gallery of Scotland. Already one of the best art galleries in the world for its displays, contents and easy visiting, the NSW has mounted a superb exhibition of some of the best works from the National Gallery of Scotland. Display and audio commentary are excellent but is the opportunity to spend time in uncrowded galleries with some of the greatest paintings in the world which makes this visit so magical. How the National Gallery of Scotland was persuaded to ship these delicate and in some cases very ancient paintings across the world remains a mystery. Unlikely to happen again. enjoy while it is here.

disappointing. Sorry but I just did not get anything from going in here. There was lots of very young artists displaying their work and it showed :( I know this is what contempary is but this was not for me or my partner.

Exhibitions and regular displays worth the visit. We regularly visit the Art gallery, usually drawn by the latest special exhibition. Recently we have seen the Great Masters, the Archibald and Pop to Popism. the building is quite striking sitting opposite the Sydney Botanical Gardens and on the edge of the beautiful Sydney harbour . So easy to make this part of a whole day out.

Welcoming and exciting. Wonderful to reconnect with old favorites and energizing to view new exhibits. Even crowd watching is a delight, young old, ethnically diverse, able bodied and restricted mobility all well catered for. Very proud of the gallery and person ell.

Interesting Art Gallery. I have visited lots of art galleries around different countried and I particularly liked this one. I felt it was quiet, calm and serene in their, but maybe it was compared to the bustling heat of the city outside! I was particularly interested in the Australian art and the Aboriginal art. I thought it was well presented and showcased. I will come back to see more of it if I'm again in Sydney as I couldn't see everything!

Take the opportunity to visit museum, it is great. No queue to pay for the entrance.Very nice display of the pieces so no gatherings in front of one.A fantastic range of items, some very unique and precious from Scotland, England, France.22 dollars to the temporary exhib.3 hours for a nice visit.

A great place to visit. I took both my children 6&10 to the gallery. There were some great school holiday activities that kept them busy for ages on two different floors. These activities were free. You can check out the website before you go and see if there is anything special happening. Plenty of artwork to show them. Only letdown is the cafe. Expensive and lacked variety. It is a great place to take a picnic lunch and have it outside though as it is surrounded by parklands.

amazing place for art. spend half of day walking around and finding very known paints of famous artists. some of the best art paints i have never seen. if you have time go to botanical gardens of sydney

A Great Experience at The Greats Exhibition. We were so very fortunate to experience a conducted tour of this current Exhibition by an enthusiastic and very knowledgeable art curator. It is a one dimensional experience to wander unaccompanied through an art gallery, another dimension when using the optional audio briefing from headphones but the experience to really bring the art works to life is having an interactive experience with the person standing between you and the pictures telling you all about not only the artists but their subjects as well. Absolutely Fabulous!!!

Excellent as always. "The Greats" was certainly one of the best exhibitions i have ever seen. The Gallery was busy as usual but not overcrowded.I am old, and the Gallery lent me a mobility scooter (electric) which made all the difference. I could not have managed this large show without it. The staff all were most kind and efficient.We had an excellent dinner in the restaurant afterwards. Rated 5/5
The Greats Exhibition. Very busy on a rainy day, seemed full of tourists, many international. We saw the 'Greats' exhibition. Spectacular exhibition. From Da Vinci to Gaugin. Great gallery as always.

Great Art Exhibition!!!. Currently showing "The Greats"...one of the best exhibitions I've seen. A great place to spend an afternoon in Sydney...continously changing exhibits. Great to just sit there and take it all in. Nice Cafe as well.
High engaging and interesting place to visit.. A wonderful place to visit if you have an interest in art galleries. I have personal go two to three times a year and it never fails to delight.

Called in for coffee and a quick look around . We were doing an express walking tour of Sydney on New Years Eve so much of it was closed off but the Art Gallery had the queue for the Quay going right across the front door so we broke through that and went in to get a blast of air-con. We had a look at some key pieces of art as we made our way to the cafe. Had a great drink in the cafe and had a look at some of the superb aboriginal art on the way out.

An Impressive Collection in a Beautiful Building. The Art Gallery sits adjacent to the Botanical Gardens and makes a great stop after a long walk through the Gardens. The museum is a well designed structure and features a varied and high quality collection of paintings and sculpture. The Cafe has a comfortable seating area and good food at a reasonable price. Enjoy!
Surprises. Lots of things to see and try and work out..art is a personal thing its not for everyone, but glad we did it
Love an art museum.. The building was a classical old building with very beautiful Ausralian art work. Very impresive. Would recommend.

Best gallery in Australia. I honestly believe this is the best Art gallery in Australia not just NSW. The gallery is a part of history and the gallery includes a range of traditional and contemporary pieces. The works are also varied and includes an The Asian Galleries and Australian based traditional pieces by prominent artists such as Tom Roberts and John Glover. They also host a range of fabulous exhibitions such as Pop To Popism and the annual Art Express Exhibition. If you are a visitor to Sydney, please do not just view the beautiful architecture of this historic building, spend some time walking through the spaces. It is worth it!

Modern/contemporary/aboriginal/Australian art...a visit is worth for everybody!. I visited the main galleries, the exhibition "the greats" about European, modern art and a photographic exhibition. The gallery is wide, peaceful and offers a broad range of styles that can't disappoint anybody. I really would like to come back for the next temporary exhibitions!

Visiting the Greats at night. It was lovely to see that the Art Gallery is a vibrant busy place on a Friday night. Our trip was to visit The Greats but it became so much more. The Australian Brandeburg Orchestra was playing as we arrived and it was very well attended. The Greats had some excellent art from the Scottish National Gallery. The ground floor of the gallery also offered some excellent art. It was well worth a visit and quite novel to go at night. What a great initiative to open the gallery late on Wednesday Thursday and Friday nights throughout January.

Loved it but.... We came to the AGNSW especially to see the exhibition "The Greats". After seeing so many advertisements in newspapers over the last couple of months regarding this exhibition you would expect the signage within the gallery to match the earlier fanfare. No so, we needed to ask for directions. We arrived at the door of the exhibition and were offered a free audio guide [ a plus]. The guide outlined in brief some of the major works and offered some interesting features but it could have been so much better. The small signs beside each painting were in a small font and often gave the name of the artist, year, and the gallery it came from. Other galleries give more information for those who seek to find out that little bit more. The main galleries within the gallery are great but again the signage lets it down. The map could also be improved.
Great show in the indigenous gallery; Murruwaygu. There is a fantastic show of SE indigenous art, tracking from pre-contact shields to a couple of contemporary artists. Amazing drawings.
