Beautiful displays that are changing. There are active as well as mainstay displays ongoing at this art gallery. A busy place for schools and visitors.

Fabulous ad usual. Saw "the greats" exhibition yesterday .. fantastic. Beautifully displayed art works from scottish galleries. Not too crowded. Good flow through. Thank you for hosting these. Shop had great products as usual. Friendly staff throughout. Lunch outside was great .. lovely vego chickpea & beetroot salad. Live the spacopus feel of this gallery. Good luck with proposed expansion.. not too sure about these

Collection and Cafe. 'The Greats' exhibition was a pleasure to indulge in - while it was busy there was still enough room that your could get up close and personal with individual art works. The coffee shop for lunch makes a superb tomato soup.
Wonderful Museum. The building and the installations at this free museum are stunning. Their is something for everyone from contemporary art to the masters. Nice cafeteria too.

Quality work in a stunning venue!. Easy chronological displays with intelligent side notes. Plenty of exquisite surprises and a strong Australian Painting section. The views towards the harbour failed to distract me from the high quality of the work on show. Not convinced that Anish Kapoor belongs in the Asian section: I went to College with him in London! Splendid shop and cool on a hot December day.

Must do's in Sydney. You can't beat a walk around the Opera House/Botanic Gardens for a good coffee/lunch and some culture. Why not take in a art house movie at Dendy's Circular Quay or for a change lunch at the open air cafe at The Museum of Modern Art

One of my favourite galleries in the world. I have visited this gallery several times over the years and there are always new exhibitions to see. The cafe is lovely too, plus it is close t Hyde Park and the Botanical Gardens which are both great.

Sydney-sider enjoying her city. I grew up in Sydney and now live in Singapore. Every time I'm back in that beautiful city by the harbour , I always venture out to the Art Gallery of NSW , both for the art and the surrounds. The walk from the bustle of the city centre (town hall / George street area) , through the hospital on Macquarie street , past the Domain , and then finally to the beautiful gardens and the art gallery is very enjoyable. Always makes me miss Sydney that little bit more.

Cracking gallery. This is a fine gallery; we've visited before but went to see 'the Greats' an exhibition of paintings from the National Gallery of Scotland. It was beautifully presented and there are some lovely works on show-Botticelli, Vermeer, Velasquez. Then we had one of the gallery's own short tours covering their Australian collection. It was terrific-informative and personal. A 5* afternoon in 'the big wet'.

Greats of Scotland Exhibit. Went here for this fabulous exhibit, it was well worth it . The exhibit covered about 400 yrs of art from 3 Scottish Galleries.
When we finished that, we wandered through and saw some old favourites. Wonderful morning spent relaxing.
LOVE THIS PLACE. The contemporary art downstairs is WONDERFUL to see in this kind of gallery!!! The staff are friendly and helpful. Good shop too! <3

Impressive. Although we didn't see the exhibit on at the time, we saw everything else. Starting at the bottom floor with aboriginal art, although skimpy in numbers, these works told a story. Good on you for not diminishing the tragedies. And the good work continued. A great venue, well located in the core of the city. Pleasant security and volunteers working the venue.
Beautiful art collections. The art collection is a must to see and it is free . Good eating place and can buy souviners of art . Could use and iPhone to take photos as long as there no flash .
great. What an interesting collection, not just of Australian art, including Nolan, Preston etc., but an eclectic array of European art too.
Masterful collection. Covered the greatest artists section of the gallery which is at a fee, but it was worth it to appreciate the greatest paintings of the last few centuries.

"The Greats" Exhibition. Tickets for "The Greats" are open re time and date when booking on the internet. I regret that I did not book "multiple entry" as I plan to go again.Make sure you take up the offer of the free audio guide - a wonderful commentary, easy to use and adding much to the viewing.The paintings - so much detail, so much colour and beauty - portraits, landscapes - such a variety of scenes.The AGNSW is to be congratulated for organising this display - it is not to be missed.

Great gallery. Located in the Domain, just beside the Botanical Gardens, the Gallery is a beautiful building. Inside, a great collection of many Australian artists really worthwhile seeing as well as some interesting classic European pieces and a good modern collection.

Good visit . I went to Art gallery of NSW heaps of times and their staff are so friendly. The artworks are a must see. It really shows the different types of cultural history. Each artwork has a history to it which makes it so much more valuable. Definitely going back again soon. Those who haven't been should go. A part of history depicted in art comes to life when we as a society take interest to learn.

Must See When in Sydney. We visit this Gallery every time we are in Sydney. There is so much to see that one day is not enough to take in what's on offer. This time we took in the Masters on loan from the Scottish Art Galleries, and were not disappointed. The café was too crowded, so we went to the restaurant across the road in the Domain, where we had a good lunch.

Cultural . Went to see The Greats Masterpieces from the National Galleries of Scotland.
Very interesting exhibition. Also the permanent exhibitions were very interesting.

Free Art Appreciation. It is a free visit if you happened to walk from Hyde Park to Botanical Garden of Sydney. You will certainly pass by this art gallery. It houses lots of arts which is free for visits.

Don't miss it. I don't intend to repeat what others have mentioned.
Rather, I'd like to add that they have a kids corner at the bottom floor where my 5-year old enjoyed the drawing and paper sculpture.

Always Excellent. Love love love the Art Gallery. A relaxing visit where you can choose to wander the gallery and view the free exhibits or visit one of the paid exhibits on at the time. Visit on your way to the Botanic Gardens or Mrs Macquaries Chair

Great collection. Located in the Domain, the Art Gallery is easily reached by public transportation. It has huge collection of European, Asian, Australian arts, easily lose yourself in the huge building from one section to another. For those art lovers, this is one of the place to visit.

Definitely should go!. Beautiful art gallery that travellers should go, free but some exhibition need tickets.
Pretty relax when walking through there.

Spectacular. We didn't give ourselves enough time to see everything as this is a very large museum. There is no admission unless it's a special exhibit. A lof of beautiful pieces and well worth the time.

One of Sydney's gems. Beautiful! Elegant! Stunning! So many adjectives to describe this phenomenal sydney landmark. Great gallery, wonderful gallery shop, friendly staff!
I recommend walking from the Gallery through the Botanical Gardens and onto the Opera House or Mrs Macquarie's Chair.

Free and huge. This is a free museum but the collection is just OK. Many artists are unknown or not famous. Nonetheless, it is close to St. Mary Church and Barracks Museum. You can see all three within half a day.

Traditional gallery, full of interest. Sadly I didn't have much time for the gallery and was only able to spend around ninety minutes there. Given the chance I will definitely go back. There is a great mix of art from fine art to aboriginal, all fascinating. I managed to find several new artists that I loved. Ironically they had an exhibition on from the national gallery of Scotland which is my local. There appeared to be a nice cafe but I didn't have time to stop.

World class art gallery. As Art gallery members, we visit several times a year, often for special exhibitions, but also to view the permanent exhibitions. The gallery has a fantastic collection of 19th and 20th century Australian art, Indigenous art in the Yiribana gallery and wonderful Asian art, as well as many other excellent parts of the permanent collection. A must see attraction in Sydney!
breathtaking. What an amazing collection of art. Take your time and look again, beautiful art and statues. Will return.

Paintings from the Edinburgh Galleries. Several Paintings from the 3 art galleries in Edinburgh are on display while renovations are being undertaken. There is an extensive collection covering Italian, French and English masters, as well as several from highly regarded Scottish painters. Thoughtfully displayed with extensive explanatory notes. An excellent offering by this state gallery.

Greats Exhibition. Went to see the Greats Exhibition on Sunday currently on at the Art Gallery of New South Wales. Enjoyed the couple of hours spent looking at the wonderful art, free audio guide included in the ticket price and although quite a few people looking at the pieces still able to move around comfortably. A very good exhibition and worth the entry price.
World class gallery. We arrived just in time to tag along with a free, 50 minute tour of the Aboriginal works held in the gallery. Our guide was very informative and friendly.

Always worth a visit. We've always enjoyed visiting the Art Gallery of NSW, whether to see a special exhibition or just for the sake of 'art surprise' - too see or re-visit some of the great collections. We've always refreshed with coffee or light meal in the café. And last visit enjoyed the Asian collection. We also join the tours that are scheduled at specific times - always worth the experience of hearing a guide take you through an exhibit.
Art-solutley Amazing!. Some rare and unique pieces of art. Huge fan of the Archibald prize exhibition (really good for dates) check it out next time you're in Sydney.

Australian art - and it's free! (mostly). The Art Gallery is the place to see some of the great Australian artists. It can be busy on weekends (there is a queue for the cafe), and some of the popular visiting exhibitions can get quite crowded. They have a nice program for kids on the weekends - with craft and a kids trail (though this wasn't operating last visit), and with $10 all day parking at the domain carpark on weekends is a really great cultural and cheap thing to do with the kids. Just pack a picnic to have in the domain or botanical gardens afterwards. You're not allowed to take textas into the musuem.

Fantastic displays for all tastes. When you first step into the gallery you are amazed at the presentation. The format of displays has been done with expert taste. Personally I love the Australian art sector. It is steeped in our history and you cannot think how amazing our history is.

Amazing collection!. Interesting architecture and an amazing collection! Although i couldn't understand some of the artwork at all, it was a unique and different experience. Every art lover should visit this gallery! And it is totally free!

World class collections well worth a visit.. Amazing to think that in its short history from the First Fleet it is possible to view such an impressive collection of Western Art and the extensive collection of aboriginal artifacts. Almost as soon as you enter the building you are faced with major works by Freud and Bacon just for starters. There is plenty here to admire and ponder on for half a day after which you can revive yourself in the excellent café.
Super free guided tour of the Aboriginal art work. Take the free guided tour of the Aboriginal art work to get an appreciation of the depth of this culture.
the greats. friendly staff, the tour of the greats was informative, easy walk to city from here also parking available at domain car park, only pay for special exhibits.

The Centre of Australia's Art Scene. Okay, I have to admit that this place is nowhere near as cool as the NGV International in Melbourne (I hope that I'm not showing any bias here) but it's still a pretty decent art gallery with a pretty extensive European collection (though the NGV has more impressionist works). The major drawcard of this place is that it is where the Australian art scene showcase their best works for the year and are awarded prizes, such as the Archibald Prize for the best portrait. The other thing that annoys me about it is that it can be a little difficult actually getting to, since it is located on the other side of the Domain, which means a decent walk (or a bus ride) from the city centre. Still it is a place that I've really got to come back to some time to spend some more time there.

Wow, what a collection!. There are temporary exhibits from time to time for which there is a charge but the permanent collection is well worth the visit, and that's free. There is a collection of art from early colonial times to modern day with many of Australia's best known artists being represented. There's also a comprehensive and diverse collection of Australian Aboriginal art and also a section on Asian Art.There are free tours that take about an hour. These cover Aboriginal Art, Asian Art and Contemporary Art and the guides are very knowledgeable but also invite the group to contribute thoughts and reactions. This art gallery is challenging to do in one day so, if time is limited, be selective.
Nice to visit. The gallery was free but a special exhibition was $22. Money very well spend. Paintings of most famous ones from the Scotland Museum of Arts.

Worthwhile stop when touring Sydney. Recommended.. A really great venue and a fine collection, but honestly I was much more impressed with Melbourne's National Gallery of Victoria. Definitely worth a stop when you're visiting Sydney's highlights.

Beautiful exhibits and building.. I loved exploring the Art Gallery and the building itself is magnificent. The exhibits were beautifully displayed and there was everything from modern to ancient art to experience. Highly recommend!

Very grand!. I did not have time to go through all the exhibitions in the art gallery as I arrived in the late afternoon, and they close at 5pm. I am in general not a big fan of arts, but I have to say that this art gallery is indeed very grand and beautiful.
Different from anything you can have seen before. A wonderfull world of art, exhibition of Asian culture, aboriginal culture and artist from other part of the world, Scotland when we,ve been there

Wonderful. The paintings are very spaced out, giving you the opportunity to fully experience and absorb the artwork. It's also very clean, so as to maintain respect to the artists and their work. The work themselves are just marvellous and never fail to take my breath away. However, the food is the killer. It's very expensive at the cafe and the line for food is always ridiculously long. My friend waited 45 minutes for a coffee!!

Scottish Masters and then some ........ Spent a couple of enjoyable hours viewing a good range of really interesting and thought provoking works. Exceptionally well laid out which enhanced the whole experience.

3rd Best Gallery in Australia?. There is no doubt that Melbourne hosts Australia's best gallery with the substantial donations made by its residents its collection of Australian art is unrivally even by the National gallery which boasts some great collections of some artists. Sydney on the other hand needs more room even though there was one previous major expansion. It is the home of the best portrait competition in the country which produces the inevitable levels of controversy each year. It is a collection on permanent display that is at best patchy though it has some arears of strength. Ultimately one feels that it has some iconic pieces but that it has collected art almost by chance buying when the price is right. Having said that it does possess my favourite Brett Whitley - of Sydney Harbour a must see.

Great Place To Spend A Few Hours!. The gallery is beautiful, next to the botanic gardens and the domain. On a weekend you can drive and park in the nearby domain car park for a flat fee of $10. The gallery is free although some exhibitions cost money. Currently showing is "The Greats" - masterpieces from the National Gallery of Scotland. This is magnificent and includes some of the greatest European artists. It goes until mid Feb and is a great opportunity to see over 70 works, most of which have never been seen in Australia. There are plenty of other galleries to visit such as Aboriginal art, Asian and Australian. Security guards seemed to be a bit on a power trip but otherwise it was very enjoyable. There is a choice of two places to eat; the cafe, which looked very nice and opens at 10am and then there's Chiswick at the Gallery Restaurant which opens at 12. We dined here and found it to be very very good. The Art Gallery is a wonderful place to visit in Sydney and spend a few hours.

Must See "The Greats". For art lovers, this is a “must see” place to go. Free general admission to most of the exhibits. $22 to see “The Greats” which are masterpieces from the National Galleries of Scotland.
interesting!!. A huge art gallery with paintings and sculptures from all ages. Entry to the museum is free but some specific portions may need a ticket
One of Australia's great public galleries. A perfect day spent wandering the botanical gardens then getting lost in the gallery. The guided tours are great way to learn more about the collection.
Fabulous. Amazing museum to discover many artists from many periods to contemporean.Aboriginal art, european masterpieces in a peaceful atmosphereFree wifi also

'The Greats'. 'The Greats' exhibition was amazing. Paintings and drawings from the Renaissance through to Impressionism. My favourites were Botticelli's 'The Virgin Adoring the sleeping Christ Child' and Vermeer's 'Christ in the House of Martha and Mary', but I was blown away by the size and colours of Church's painting showing the sheer magnificence of Niagara Falls. I'll definitely be back.

A good activity for a very hot or rainy day.. We visited the Gallery with young children on a very hot sunny day and appreciated the A/C. After a quick tour of several art exhibits, the creative activities available in the lower level entertained the youngsters.
The museum to visit in Sydney if you don't have time for other museums. Fine collection with interesting variety of periods and also contemporary shows, just close to the Botanic...

Well worth a visit. For those interested this is a worth while venue. Major works of Art from all the well known Classical Artists of Europe. Interesting to find a painting by the Welsh artist Richard Wilson. So much to see at a gallery where entrance to main areas are free. There was a classical trio playing in the entrance hall adding to the ambience. Spent the afternoon here beforecrossing to the Botanical Gardens for a stroll to the harbour at Central Quays

Just brilliant. I visited the Art gallery on a weekend and was absolutely enthralled. Its very well maintained and has a large number of displays - many free for visitors. Currently its biggest draw is "the Greats" - an exhibition of a brilliant collection of paintings from the Scottish art gallery from many renowned names. Definitely worth a visit to taste the cultural circle of Sydney(P.S: the art gallery is located in the Domain - a green walk-around that makes for long pleasant walks. Dont miss the Royal Botanical Gardens also located very near to this place)
Awesome collection. We had an hour to visit and stayed for over two hours! So much to see. We developed a love of the aboriginal art. A beautiful museum.

The Greats Exhibition. Fabulous exhibition from a selection of Scotish galleries. Extensive range of artists including Botticelli, Leonardo, Cézanne, El Greco, Gauguin, Monet, Poussin, Raphael, Rubens, Titian, Turner and Vermeerand. Works from Renaissance to Impressionism.

Scottish masterpeices. I always enjoy visiting the Gallery and was pleased my visit to Sydney happened to be at the same time as the Scottish Masterpieces. It was well displayed with some lovely works of art from some of the greatest painters. It is also nice to then go to the cafe and have a snack to take in your experience. Well worth the visit and if you have time wander through the other areas to see some more wonderful works of art.
Wow. Fantastic collection of European and Australian art, and it is free! Special shows are not free, but the price was reasonable and the audio tour is included with no extra cost.
Culture Trip. If you want to indulge in some culture whilst in Sydney this Art Gallery is a good introduction....wide selection of local and international art..they also have special exhibitions

Great day of vual arts. Permanent exhibitions are well worth looking at and there are always special exhibitions on as well. Also visit the café/restaurant across the road in the Botanic Gardens for lunch.

An excellent collection of paintings and art work. This gallery has a very broad collection of Australian and European painting as well as hosting occasional exhibitions. On our recent visit we were able to see the visiting exhibition from the National Gallery of Scotland. But equally interesting was the well displayed collection of modern Australian art, We found the work by Grace Cossington Smith and Margaret Preston particularly striking. There is plenty of space to move around the gallery, and altogether a great place to go on a hot day.

LOVE LOVE LOVE this place.. I have spent three days of my Sydney visit here. There is so much to do and daily free tours which are very worthwhile. I found it good to wander around the different exhibitions by myself then joining a tour and finishing off by wandering around again by myself. I found this a great way to get the most out of what I was seeing. Entry is free for most of the gallery. I also paid $22 to see the current exhibition , The Greats , and that too was really worthwhile. I can't say enough good things about this art gallery.

Many great works !. We don't have this kind of Museum in Indonesia, especially Surabaya city. To enter this museum for free is a very good experience. We can see many great works from famous artist. Since this place located 10 minutes from Botanical Garden, we decided to visit and very pleased !

Best Museum em Sydney. The visit can take one or fours hours, there's so much to see! Best museum em Sydney, IMO. Perfect to go after a walk on the Botanic Gardens. Super organised, friendly staff, amazing collection.

Art Gallery of NSW in Sydney. This museum holds a great collection of works with some very interesting pieces of European, Asian and Aboriginal art. The entrance is free and donation is encouraged. We visited it on a Monday at the end of October and it was not crowded. Definitely worth a (thorough) visit.

Great way to get your culture fix. We drop in to the Art Gallery whenever we get some spare time while in Sydney. The permanent displays are worth revisiting from time to time. There have been some fantastic exhibitions over the years and the Archibald is always worth seeing.

Gallery and Gardens. Right on the edge or the Royal Botanic Gardens this art gallery is in a magnificent position on the edge of a park overlooking the harbour. There are works here by Monet, Rubens, Van Gough and many lesser know masters. Good restaurant and gift shop. Really loved this place.

Great Scottish Masters Exhibition. Visited the Gallery last Monday to view the superb collection of Scottish Masters in all their glory. A great exhibition facility which provides excellent internal lighting and audio presentation for self-guiding. The displays are very carefully placed which allow a reasonable group of visitors to view at the same time unlike some known European Galleries which make things very tight.A most comfortable and entertaining visit.Note: It seems the exhibition will be limited to Sydney alone!

A Great Gallery. The Art Gallery of New South Wales is wonderful, in truth we are still to explore it all and we are planning on going back soon, but we went to the Scottish exhibition and had a guided tour. It was definitely worth doing and I suggest going if you have the chance to. But there is so much more and the building, setting and even the cafe is just great. Looking forward to going again.

Works of European Masters as well as Australian Artists!. This lovely gallery is located on the edge of the Royal Botanical Gardens. Admission is free. The building itself is beautiful, as is the extensive collection of European art, including pieces by Peter Paul Rubens, Claude Monet, Camille Pissarro and Vincent Van Gogh. Another room features beautiful works by Australian artists. There's a nice gift shop and a restaurant. Well worth a stop!

Beautiful art collection; stunning building and location. If you can, go on one of the docent tours of the gallery's collection. I did the indigenous art collection tour, and learned so much about aboriginal art. It has really increased my appreciation of the styles and differences between different nations. The gallery cafe is also very good.

Great range of art works. Started by visiting the cafe to rehydrate with a pot of tea. Seats are both indoor and out. The special exhibition was from the Scottish National Gallery, we've been there in Edinburgh several times so went with the permanent displays. International works, wide range of Australian including aborigine art, contemporary and traditional work, some lovely sculptures and all in very spacious galleries. First class pleasure, lovely to see everyone from little kids to old timers!

Wonderful Museum with Wide Array of European, & Australian Art. This wonderful museum located at the end of the Botanical Gardens is worth spending a couple of hours to tour and enjoy the exhibits. The gallety. Includes a large section of European art and an Australian art as well. close by is the Library and St Mary's Cathedral which are also worth a stop
Great Artists exhibition. We spent a wonderful morning visiting the Art Gallery of NSW's exhibition of Great Artists. This exhibition on loan from Scotland is not to be missed.

Nice space & jangong. Overlooking the docks this pleasant gallery has a good albeit small collection representing native, Australian and European art. The restaurant looked enticing, but sadly it was doing a Melbourne cup do, so closed to public!
Beautiful gallery. There are lots of old paintings in display, and the higher floor is mainly for modern arts. There is a nice and lovely lawn in front of it and it is close to the botanic garden.

Great gallery and getting better, a great quite space. Specialty exhibitions vary in quality from time to time. Mostly they are good to very good & often educational. You can spend 2-3 hours there before you suffer overload. A pleasant walk form the city centre to a wonderfully quite space.Good food at reasonable prices.

A mix of australian and international. Being an old gallery (for Australia) it has a good collection of australian and international art. Good Australian collection from late 1700s to today. regular travelling exhibitions.
Great gallery. A great, free gallery with a fascinating and extensive selection of Australian artists. Easy access through Botanic Gardens from Circular Quay

Excellent art collections. The entry to the art gallery for most of the regular exhibits is free and NSW Art gallery has a very good collection of classic, contemporary and Australian art. When I was there, I managed to catch the Greats: Masterpieces from the National Galleries of Scotland (showing till Feb 16), and paid AUD$22 for this special exhibition. This comes with a free audio guide for the key pieces as well as a free 1 hr guided tour by a very knowledgeable guide around the exhibition area. They also provided free guided tour for their free exhibits at regular intervals as well which was wonderful. Would strongly recommend a visit to the NSW gallery after taking a walk along Sydney Opera house and botanic gardens, as they are all within walking distance.
Great gallery. This gallery is spacious, ecclecticand in a wonderful location. It also has a great gallery bookstore

Terrific varied collection. I loved the contemporary collection on the lower floor (the guided tour by Mary was excellent). It was very easy to spend most of a damp Sydney day here exploring the Australian art, having lunch and browsing in the shop.

My Favourite Place in Sydney. Here again for the Archibald's in 2015 I really admire the gallery. It looks fantastic inside and out and has free entry to the permanent works. As well as fantastic paintings and Sculptures the gallery also offers free music concerts (typically AIM students) on a Sunday and often offers free films in the Cinema which normally relate to one of the temporary exhibitions (normally a charge) on at the time.When I lived in Milsons Point I came here most weekends, now I live further out and my trips are less frequent, but no less enjoyable.

Varied art with old and new pieces. The museum is in The Domain, which is a large park area with some nice floral borders.There was a good mixture of old and new artwork on display here spread over a few floors. There was a good selection of aboriginal art on the lower floor as well which was really interesting. :)

Interesting Art Gallery of New South Wales. Admission is free and is definitely worth a visit. Not only are there pieces from some of the masters like Picasso and Matisse, there are also interesting modern pieces of art and an Asian collection of art. There is also an extensive display of Australian aboriginal art.The art gallery is spacious and is well laid out. Not all the pieces were to my taste but I still really enjoyed my visit.

Art Through the Ages. This gallery provides a good summary of all art with a particular focus on early Australian art. This gallery hosts the Archibald Prize yearly and is always a great exhibition to check out (it does cost though), great Indigenous art section. Good stroll through the Domain to get here. Closest train station would be Martin Place with a 5-10 minute walk.

A beautiful gallery. During a recent visit, we spent a few hours one day wandering around this art gallery. It is indeed a relaxed experience, and a relatively uncrowded one at that. There were plenty of people visiting, but it wasn't too many. We liked how well laid out the gallery is, and we especially enjoyed the Aborigine art exhibit.
A good learning place. Different period and style of drawings can be found there. A good place to know more about different style artists.
Fantastic. One of the best Art Galleries in Australia. Has a wide variety of European artists which I love to view. Just go check it out. It's in the gardens. Just a nice day out and view culture
Excellent. whats good is that this is a relaxed experienceThe guards aren't over the top..you can take photos,great school holiday programme for kids and a great collectionCafe is good too

A little bit dissappointing. I spent around a hour browsing some of the permanent collection. There are some lovely pieces but I came away feeling I'd seen better elsewhere. The lighting is badly placed or not quite right in some spots - reflecting off the surface of the painting and distorting the view.
A regular favourite. I adore visiting the Australian Classic Gallery. There are favouites I simply adore to see regularly that make my heart sing to see them.
Yep! This ever evolving gallery is worth multiple visits. Great place for the art lover and close to the city and some fine restaurants - so you can make a day of it!

A great introduction to Australian art, and much more. I'm a frequent visitor to the Gallery. It usually has a current exhibition of international interest, and several rooms of Australian artists both old masters and new. The ceramics exhibition is mainly Asian and exquisite, and there is usually a good display of aboriginal art in the lower levels of the gallery. I always recommend visitors to Sydney include it in their explorations.It has a lovely cafe, and a slightly more expensive restaurant.
Just go there. Really good museum and there is always a new exhibition or something to do in .. It's not expensive and the shop is nice.
Always have grea exhibitions. It's free unless you go into special exhibitions! I love the Asian art exhibit and many of the old Australian art!

A Place to be Inspired. This gallery is not to be missed. If you are feeling lacklustre and in need of a creative injection, this is the place to visit. On entering the building, on the ground floor, you will find a permanent collection of Australian & European paintings hung in a historic part of the gallery. The main entrance hall is hung with contemporary paintings, which are very large and eye-catching, often by indigenous artists. To the left, is the gallery Shop containing many covet-able items, from art to postcards, books and more. There are many other galleries on the entrance floor containing well known Australian artists or a permanent collection of Asian art. Head downstairs for special exhibitions, like the yearly Archibald, Wynne and Sulman prizes for portraits, landscape etc, very popular with the locals. A couple of floors down the escalators are the location of exhibitions of contemporary art, and installations. And the gallery cafe. And if you are a Friend of the Gallery (or a friend of a Friend!) you can avail yourself of the members lounge and cafe - a very comfortable location with an excellent smaller cafe, and stocked with shelves of Art books.I go several times a year to recharge.

Always something Interesting. We have visited several times before and we can always be sure to find something interesting. Most of it is free but special exhibitions will cost you.We were delighted with the Julia Cameron Photographic exhibition which was on loan from The Victoria and Albert in London.It is not just for oldies like us but anyone can find something to interest them here.

Great Sydney Attraction for Art Lovers!. Starting with a great walking around Domain Park, Woolloomooloo Bay, Botanic Garden and a free tour to the Art Gallery of New South Wales (only some exhibition you have to pay). If you want to try the Australian Modern Cuisine you can book lunch at the delicious CHISWICK at the Gallery (great views) owned by renowned chef Matt Moran, there is also a cafe (more casual) on level 1. Highly recommended!
Beautiful Gallery. Beautiful Gallery with a very diverse and in depth collection. Vary varied collection as well. Not to big a gallery that you get lost in and set in a stunning location.
Stunning Australian art. Always a highlight of a Sydney visit, this fascinating gallery showcases Australian art with temporary shows by artists all over the world.

A plethora of beautiful art. Wonderful place to visit and (mostly) free. Lots of security keep a sharp eye on things to the point you know multiple eyes are on you all the time and are never far away but they are professional and exceptionally friendly and won't actually bother anyone (unless, I assume, some one does something stupid). The art is magnificent and I could have spent hours upon hours just gazing on multiple days because of the sheer quality on offer. the pay for exhibitions are well laid out and well worth the price of admission. All in all, a must see for anyone visiting Sydney.

A different kind of fun. We went to the Gallery on the weekend and found cool 'kids' interactive things to do. Even though I'm not a kid anymore, I still enjoyed participating in the activities, e.g. currently the Colourwheel exhibition hosts colouring-in and build your own creative masterpieces. It's great to see free and paid exhibitions.

Must see attraction in Sydney. Always something inspiring to see at the AGNSW. Plan to spend at least 2 hours there - which will enable one to go through all aspects of the Gallery. The shop is also pretty interesting, with books on both Australian and International art - worth while checking out

No Botticelli but the AGNSW should pride itself on its aboriginal art!. Let me explain the title of my review: as I walked up to the Gallery there were names of Renaissance Masters including Botticelli all around the outside walls. This naturally made me think that they had a big Renaissance collection. So I asked at the counter if they indeed had any Botticellis, at which point the gentleman noted that it was more an aspiration rather than fact. And that they hoped to get one in a few months time. He pointed me to their Renaissance gallery (more on that later). This somewhat puzzled me. Yes, Renaissance art is lovely (I am personally a huge admirer) but the museum has such an amazing collection of aboriginal art. Why not celebrate that more visibly? Don't get me wrong, the museum does seem to pride itself on its aboriginal collection. I joined the free tour and our guide was most informative and it was clear that aboriginal art has come to be regarded highly in Australian history and culture. I just found the contrast between the outside and inside rather puzzling and somewhat implicit reflection of how aboriginal culture is still treated compared to European art. Regardless, I thoroughly enjoyed my visit to the gallery. The aboriginal art pieces are absolutely wonderful and do join the guided tour. You learn a lot and our guide was excellent. When I visited there was also a "Body Parts" exhibit which was excellent too and right next to it you could see Moderns by Matisse, Cezanne and Picasso. Absolutely worth the visit in themselves. I did visit the Renaissance gallery too. There were some nice pieces of Renaissance art there and off in a smaller room there was a lovely painting by Constable (after Claude) which was itself worthwhile. And don't be afraid to head downstairs towards the study library ... you get to see some wonder Australian Majolica in the cases. There is also some nice 19th century Australian art. But you need more than 3 hours to fully enjoy this place (and I didn't have that much time). But then if you have the chance, you can go again and again. It is that kind of place. You won't tire of it.

Great aboriginal art section and nice coffee shop. Best aboriginal art section in sydney, i guess. Take your time, as there is not so much of it in the contemporary art museum next to the harbour. Donation only, so entrance is free. Cool coffee shop but also a pricey restaurant in the museum. Both worth a stop.

Could be great.... Not really anyone available to help if you have any questions. Cafe seems to take up an awful lot of space for what it is. It wasn't clear where everything was, and it seemed a bit empty, for the free-access art.

Wonderful gallery. Fabulous collection from all over the world. We visit this gallery every time we are in Sydney and always find something new to look at. The regular collection is outstanding as are the changing exhibitions.

Audio Described Tour. I've been a few times as a carer for my friend who is blind, Daniela is excellent, she is so caring and knowledgeable about all of the exhibitions and gives you such a different insight into the power of art

Wonderful art gallery. Wonderful collection of art from around the world! Of course not like the galleries of the US and Europe but fabulous collection for what it is. Some great examples of great artists. Easy to get through and not too overwhelming. Always good exhibitions running.

Fabulous place. One of my favs here in Sydney .... Fabulous place. One of my favs here in Sydney ... Prefer to go there Sunday afternoons. Great place for first dates and also just to hang out with friends and visitors. Many of their temporary exhibitions are very well curated and the standing exhibitions (these free!) are really worth repeated trips. Also, the cafe downstairs is good ...
Art on your mind. Very interesting with a good contribution from various sources. Modern and 19th Century Australian 'bush artists' well represented. Lots of great exhibitions as well. Worth a visit

Great exhibitions in optimal location. The museum itself is quite nice, the location is great, right by the Botanical Gardens, and they often have an interesting exhibition in place (Monet, Australian photographers, etc), besides their own collection.
amazing stuff. another place i love visiting every time im here.so many beautiful painting and lovely exhibitions on all the time.one can spend the whole day here without getting bored

Fantastic position, fantastic gallery. Give yourself a treat, walk through the Domain and visit the Art Gallery of NSW. Spend a good couple of hours browsing and in fact sit on one of the many lounges and just look out the windows and enjoy the Views

Well worth a visit. Beautiful art but I have to say the building itself is also stunning. Well worth the visit.
Enjoy a nice coffee downstairs and a visit to the book shop too.

One of the best museus I have even been. You will see the classics (like Picasso and Monet), but do not miss the contemporary art session in the first level. There is an amazing mural that you can stay hours trying to understand it. Free and good for all the family.
A great way to spend a rainy day in Sydney. If you enjoy art, it's one of the highlights in Sydney, especially during winter for the Archibald prize.
Art at its best. Some of Australia's best art available to see at this gallery.Have travelled there several times to spend time here

Tons of beautiful pieces from across the centuries!. The gallery has a huge variety of primarily paintings and sculpture from about the 15th to the 20th centuries from several different continents. If you have any interest in art or art history you won't be disappointed! Free general admission but you can also pay extra to enter the special exhibits, but even without that, it's a very fulfilling experience. Great way to spend an afternoon.

interesting. Interesting exhibits from the old time, amazing work on modern contemporary art, it's a mixed collections. You will never get bored while roaming around. I believe people who do not fancy art will also love this place. bring your kids here, they can participate in some activities. one of interesting art gallery I've been so far.

Excellent day out. With great expectation we all went to the Archibold Prize exhibition a few weeks ago.It was awesome , with a broad range of portraits that highlight the diversity of talent we have in this country.We also enjoyed a lovely meal at the Restaurant , fairly pricey , although quality that is worth paying $20 for a glass of wine and $55 for a steak.An all round nice city of Sydney treat.

A great gallery.. We came here with the kids on a wet visit to sydney. It was a shame the 441 bus stop for the gallery is so far away...we hit drenched! Thank goodness for the click room! The kids enjoyed the holiday craft that was put on by the gallery and enjoyed the paintings of Ned Kelly the best!

Great variety of works. I love this gallery. There are a number of Australian 19th & 20th century pieces, and then other sections for indigenous, Asian & modern works. There is a really nice cafe and a great store selling books, jewellery and other items related to the various artists / exhibitions in the gallery.
Interesting Visit. Nice museum, good mix of old and new artwork. Really liked the focus on Aussie and Kiwi artists, inspired me to travel to NZ and visit Milford Sound

Worth a visit if you're interested in art. Only visited the aboriginal art section but found it very well arranged and the art was excellent. It gave me a good perspective on this type of work. The art gallery is really a museum and covers all different types of artists. It also has a cafe that, though we didn't try it, looked quite nice.

Visiting Art Gallery of New South Wales. Visiting tha Art Gallery a delightful experience, whilst visiting were able to view the Archibald exhibition. Followed by lunch in the restaurant and then wandered back via the Gardens to the city

Brillant Collection of Australian and International art….. I have been to many a gallery in numerous countries but I am always drawn back to the Art Gallery of NSW. It is located in a brilliant place over looking the harbour with most gallery spaces open free to the public except for visiting exhibits or specific shows. Either way if art interests you or even if you are just little curious about seeing what there is to offer in Australia from early days till present then this should not be missed.

Beautiful, a must if you visit Sydney. This museum exceeded all my expectations. Picasso, Leighton, Reuben, Matisse... beautiful collection. I particularly like their modernist and prerafaelite art. I could stare to Leighton's Cymon and Iphigenia for hours, the light within her body is truly unbelievable. Loved it!!!

Best collection of Colonial paintings 1820s to 1880. Sample of everything that has been valued as ahving cultural significance to Australians - colonial painting 1820-1880s; paintings by Australian women 1940s- 1970s; posters; its na interesting gallery. Mixed collection that shoudl suit all tastes. Gluten free food int he restaruant - nice garden where kids can sit outside.
Free and great. Incredible setting, close to the Botanic Gardens. FREE and the artwork is world class! Wonderful for a rainy or hot day.
Something of interest... A wonderful gallery,right in the middle of the gardens! great walking distance to everything..Good prices..Very welcoming

Be surprised by European art as well as Australian. Such an easy art gallery to navigate and see in an afternoon!
I went for the Archibald exhibition. $15 entry.
But this gallery changes exhibits regularly and is easy to visit regularly.

OK exhibitions but nothing extraordinary. Great building, and beautiful location next to the Botanic Gardens and facing The Domain, but the permanent exhibitions are a bit ordinary, besides a few outstanding pieces. I've found the last few ticketed exhibitions a bit ho-hum, too.
Visit to see the Archibald Prize paintings. Went to see the paintings in the Archibald Prize. Well organised at the desk and right through the whole art gallery. Staff were very helpful and pleasant

Very good collection and exhibitions, a nice shop and a good restaurant. Very good collection and exhibitions, a nice shop and a good restaurant, so this is a safe place to spend a morning or one afternoon with culture and a nice meal. If you are a few days in Sydney this is a museum you can not go without, if you want to learn a bit more about Australia culture.

More than the Art!. Visit the Art Gallery for the art, but also visit for the experience. Set behind the Botanic Gardens and within walking distance to the city centre, the Art Gallery is a lovely destination for afternoon tea or a coffee. Beautiful building and ever changing art. The Archibold Prize exhibition is exceptional viewing and the HSC Art Express displays Sydney students' many artistic talents.

Beautiful Art Gallery. This is a world class art gallery. Never disappointed. In the heart of Sydney. Its a wonderful way to spend a relaxing Sunday or week day. Staff are very attentive. It has many great artists. One of my favourites
Australian masterpieces. Finest collection of Australian masterpieces, from our earliest colonial artists through until today. Always excellent exhibitions in the spacious halls.

Well Worth a Visit. Beautiful Art Gallery. We were pleased to be able to see the Archibald exhibition and participate in a portraiture appreciation workshop put on by a number of volunteers. Also had a lovely lunch in the Art Gallery's cafe

Lots to see. This is much larger than it looks. We made the mistake of visiting on Sunday when it was totally packed. Lines of people buying tickets for the Archibald prize show, and then lining through the galleries to get to the show. I missed several galleries since the people in line took up most of the space. The café and restaurant had hour waiting lines. Actually, it is great to see an art gallery this popular, and I like the Australian landscapes.

AGNSW is fun. A fun visit to see the Archibald last week. Crowded but accessible. A chance to visit the front galleries of Australian art, always a treat. Good little cafe with cheap optios and a glass of wine.

Archibald Prize as good as ever. I have been a member of the Art Gallery of New South Wales for many years and am never disappointed. In August, I primarily went to view the Archibald Prize, and though it was crowded, viewing was adequate. A plus on this visit was the meal we had at the restaurant.

Amazing Archibald. My friend and I went to see the 2015 Archibald paintings in August 2015. There was a fairly long queue and we were a little daunted, but it moved quickly and we purchased our tickets from a particularly lovely and friendly young man. The gallery has many rooms that are free to visit and one could spend a whole day there without it costing a thing. Because we wanted to see the Archibald paintings we did need to pay, but the price was very reasonable. There was plenty of viewing space and the whole experience was very pleasant. Afterwards we took a stroll through the lovely Botanic Gardens and had a thoroughly enjoyable day.
Arts lovers!. Most work of arts in the gallery were from local artists. They also have a small restaurant and next to it is Sydney botanical garden.

Great building plus wonderful art. It's always worth a visit - wonderful permanent exhibitions but the special exhibitions make it even more special - saw the Archibald entrants and there was much of interest but little in common with past concepts of portraits - art has changed so much over the years and the exhibitions certainly highlight this.

Clean and spacious . Nice clean and spacious with friendly staff, art work clearly labelled, works going on in the Asian art work department but still plenty to see, would recommend plus they have a Monet piece
Beautiful building with wonderful works. A great gallery with interesting permanent and visiting exhibitions. The Archibald exhibition was great.

Beautiful Building and Gallery. Friendly staff greeted us - had no idea there was so much to see - loved seeing the guides taking tours and inspiring our younger generations! Need to allow at least 1/2 my day next time.

Escape the hustle and bustle of the city. I went here because a friend had recently visited. Lovely old building. Across the domain park about ten minute walk from Martin place. You can cut through the parliament buildings. There are a couple of walkways that take you through to the domain from Macquarie street. Nice and quite location. Coffee shop in the park open before the museum opens at 10am. Museum also has a coffee shop and restaurant. Free entry but there is a fee to see the main exhibits. $15.00 for the famous Archibald and for $25.00 you can see that plus another exhibit. Bag storage available for free at the front door. A great place to escape the city but tip is to get there at opening buy ticket and go straight to exhibit. Gets busy by 10.30 with all the group tours and school kids. Guided tours at certain times. If your into art or not this is worth a visit especially when the Archibald paintings are on display.
I'd go back next time I'm in Sydney.. I loved this gallery. A beautiful space with some fantastic (and iconic) works. Spent a few hours here by myself and enjoyed tea in the cafè.

Art and lunch . My favourite spot in town after opera house... Always great exhibitions and an extraordinary permanent collection.
Try CHISWICK at the Gallery is the perfect spot for lunch, a quick bite, a drink at the bar, or dinner on a Wednesday.
They always have special dining packages. But you need to book on line.
Good day. Not a big fan of museum but love this place. Very relaxing and amazing coffee shop. I will certainly will be back.

Nice lunchtime venue after viewing art. A very pleasant lunch spot. My wife and I had lunch after viewing The Archibald. Menu is nicely varied and easy to find an appealing dish.. The cooking is of a good quality and presentation very good as is the service.The ravioli was really good with the pasta perfect in texture and flavour very good also .

Not often you get something this good for free. Wonderful location near Domain park and Sydney Harbour foreshore so take time for a nice walk to and from. Also very good restaurant and cafe inside....plus stunning view.Small by overseas standards but has some lovely pieces.The guided tours are very interesting and generally the special exhibitions (you must pay for) are first class.Plenty of places to rest if required and disabled friendly.Also find staff and volunteers some of the most pleasant you will deal with.

Gorgeous collection, free entry and live music!. I went on a Wednesday night (the gallery is open late!) to listen to some live music and had a great time! The artwork on display is also very impressive. I especially enjoyed the large collection of old European paintings and sculpture.

Touch of class. Sad to say it wad 29 years ago that i was last here. So I paid a visit and I loved it. Normally not my cup of tea but always good to do things outside your comfort. Next time i woll go back and finish tour

A gem of an art gallery. The Art Gallery of NSW, is one of the top three art galleries in Australia. It is small by international standards, but has a solid collection that can easily occupy half a day. The front of the building is 19th century Greek style, with modern extensions at the rear. As you'd expect, there is a decent cafe, and a restaurant. And, yes of course, they have harbour views.This Gallery delivers serenity and beauty. Art ranges from medieval to modern, with a focus on Australian works, Asia art, and some European works.

Lovely atmosphere and super cafe. It was crowded during the Archibald exhibition but it all runs smoothly at the Art Gallery. I love the ladies who do the tours, it makes the paintings come alive and so much more interesting. The lower Café is fabulous, the staff are friendly and the food quick and easy. So glad it's open through the afternoon for a glass of wine after the exhibition. The Cloak Room is wonderful too as I'm always there in winter and it's warm inside so dropping my coat off is a great help.

Delightful Location. Thoroughly enjoy the whole outing. We were there for the Archibald Prize and the service was polite, pleasant and the food simple but sophisticated and appropriate for the night. Excellent job and we will be back again.
A must see for art lovers. There are some very interesting pieces of art on the entrance level. The modern art was ok but I could have spent a few hours just on the ground floor.

A touch of culture and art. We visited the Archibald exhibit which was great fun and very interesting. The exhibits were well presented with very helpful information on the wall beside each painting. It was a great opportunity to appreciate some grey and some less great works of art. The operation was well organised, policed (by unobtrusive security) and run staff. Well worth a visit.

Good collection of Australian art. We stopped here after wandering through the Royal Botanical Gardens. This museum has a wide range of art, but we were most interested in seeing Australian art, both aboriginal and contemporary. Several galleries branch off from the main lobby. An information booth provided maps and advice on where to go. Although most of the museum is free, special exhibits may have an entrance fee. We saw several examples of aboriginal art with explanations of its form and function. We browsed through a gallery of contemporary art and sculptures as well as a collection of European art. We enjoyed our visit and recommend this museum.

Archibald. What a wonderful exhibition. As a visitor to Sydney, this was one of the highlights of my stay. It wasn't as crowded as some galleries I've visited which meant I could really look at the exhibits in my own time.
love this place. every time i visit i go to the gallery as my visit would not be complete at all without it. beautiful paintings and great exhibition .the park stroll is good

A Wonderful Look at Australian art. Not only are most exhibits free of charge, but there are some surprisingly interesting exhibits including a film archive that shows older films. Always worth a visit when in Sydney.

Interesting artwork. The gallery was established in 1871 and is located adjacent to the Royal Botanic Gardens. There are collections from Australia, European, Aboriginal and Asian artists. My son really enjoyed the Matisse collection. There were a few Impressionists such as Pisarro and Monet represented. Ruben had a self portrait and a few other paintings. I enjoyed seeing paintings from Australia which were new to me. On the lower level was the contemporary/modern art section which was hard for me to appreciate.No flash photography was allowed. The gift shop had an interesting selection of books.I am not sure the museum is free every day but the day we went there was no fee.
A Place for Art Lovers. Great place for art lovers....lots of pictures, sculptures etc for you to see and enjoy the beautiful moments.

Wonderful, free,art gallery in the heart of the city. This is one of my usual haunts. I love it here. The art is always changing, so much care goes into the presentation of exhibitions. A good starting point for visitors to Sydney is the intersection of Market and Elizabeth Streets;( St James Train Station or the bus stop close by in Elizabeth St). Walk across Hyde Park, past the Archibald Fountain and across College St. From here a pleasant stroll along Art Gallery Rd. The gallery is free to enter, leave your coats and bags at the cloakroom (also free) and get a map at the information desk. There is a charge if you want to visit one of the special exhibitions but there is so much to see if you just want to wander around. Go and see the amazing collection of indigenous art. The coffee shop is good for drinks and wraps and the gift shops for souvenirs. Wear your walking shoes and extend your trip by walking through the Botanic Gardens and down on to Circular Quay when you have finished.

An interesting historical perspective through art. The main collections were interesting to view and the gallery was relatively quiet, despite it being the school holidays. I enjoyed the photographic exhibition which traced European settlement and the relationship with the Aboriginal people.

A Fantastic Meal and Meander Gallery. We loved everything about the Gallery. The location, architecture, the design inside. We also had a lovely lunch at the cafe downstairs where the staff and food was fantastic. The Gallery shop was also well stocked. A must visit.

Go and see the Archibald Prize artwork. We went here this afternoon to look at the Archibald Prize artwork. Some of the pictures are moving and the reality of others is unbelievable. The sole objective of our visit was to see the Archibald Prize, however after looking around what we had been to see we found the rest of the art gallery interesting also.
A pleasurable afternoon. off to see the exhibitions some great some so so overall a great time lunch at the cafe excellent staff very helpful
Good collection of painting and sculptures. we followed a guided tour. The tour guide was very knowledgeable. She was very enthusiastic in guiding us thru' painting in different periods.

Ever changing art work at no cost!. Love this place and get down here when I can, especialy for special exhibitions like the Archibald prize showing. This year was an especialy good exhibition. You will need several hours to enjoy all of the galleries. Dont miss the shop, lovely gift ideas.It is not necessary to visit a special show, you can enjoy the permanent features free of charge and stay for a nice lunch in the cafe.

Conference in the Art Gallery !. The Art Gallery is situated near Parliament House . They have displayed many different type of painting in varies time. We have attend many functions in the gallery . Very relaxing atmosphere with displace historical painting .

Historical structure, excellent library and art exhibitions.. There was perfect library and several exhibitions, there was great art pieces exhibited so I enjoyed at there for more than 1 hours. I must come when I visit Sydney next time.

Amazing pieces of australian landscape history. My partner and i went to check out the archibald prize exhibition. We meandered through the galleries and saw the early australian landscapes. They were amazing and well presented. Several other competitions were on display which made the $15 entry to the archibald cheap. Great views from the cafe. Cheap entertainment. Relax, wander and enjoy.

Aussie Art. Its free to enter. Once a week the museum is open late. When I was there it was open til 10 pm. The museum has quite few pieces from aboriginals and Australians artists as well. The museum does have a cafe, but it is a little out of the way from the rest of Sydney. Just about a kilometer or two from Hyde Park
Worth a visit. We once again visited so see the Archibald Prize. It is easily accessible and worth a visit as there is always something interesting to see.

Highly recommended!. Great museum- I spent an entire day there.I really enjoyed the "See you at the barricades" exhibit (free) and the 2015 Archibald exhibition (entry fee required). The guide who gave the free guided tour was very informative and interesting. I also watched a free movie "Germinal" at its theatre.Highly recommended for anyone who enjoys art. I will suggest going to their website and see all the events available, and plan your day before going.
Art lovers rejoice. What a way to spend the day!!! Beautiful works of art, and welcoming environment. I have been here twice now, and each time, i see new stuff.

the best in Sydney. Excellent, the main exhibition is free and they have also temporary exhibit of very good quality.
By favorite museum in Sydney
Modern and contemporary arts

Very Good and its Free. We were lucky enough to se the 2015 Archibald exhibition. You do pay for this and it was worth the money. The gallery is well laid out and spacious - you don't have to be an art lover to enjoy this exprience

Really enjoyed the Archibald. I don't go often, but the Arhcibald, the Wynne and the Sulamn exhibitions are always worth a visit. Well curated and often provocative. Amongst many, this is a highlight. Worth a visit.

Went to see the archibald and the photography exhibition.. Have been to the NSW Art Gallery many times. Excellent facility. Always nice displays of interesting works. I find some of the displays a bit overwhelming due to the scale of them but that is typical of all major galleries in the world. My only disappointment is the cafe is becoming more like pub food than restaurant food. It is still not bad but not up to the standard of the gallery though.

Art lovers paradise. The Art Gallery of NSW is a magnificent building set in the grounds of the Domain. It has easy access by public transport or there is loads of paid parking in the nearby Domain carpark. Entry is free to the gallery with some of the special exhibitions at an extra charge (we paid for the Archibald, Wynne and Sulman which was $15). The gallery is well laid out and has a very spacious and light atmosphere. To cover the whole gallery, you would need to dedicate the whole day. You could have a picnic lunch in the grounds of the Domain or nearby Botanical Gardens. There is also a Chiswick restaurant on site as well as a cafe. Recommended

Great gallery with easy access. This gallery is within easy access to the centre of Sydney and close to the City loop train station at Museum. Located in beautiful parkland it's a nice walk to get there, and is also close to other museums and the Parliament building. There's usually a special exhibition being held and there's a great selection of Australian art, Aboriginal artefacts and Asian art as well as a great collection of world art. There's a very nice cafe available also. Well worth a visit for all ages.

First time to visit the Archibald Prize Exhibition 2015. Had a great time taking in the inspiring Archibald Prize, Wynn, Sulman Prize and other wonderful examples of Australian art. No matter if you agree on the ultimate winning entries there is so much to do and see plus it offers the opportunity to walk no matter what the weather is like outside. What a wonderful afternoon it just kept getting better with the sunshine outside offering us spectacular scenes of the harbour nearby we roamed around the gardens and enjoyed afternoon tea at the Pavilion in the Park just opposite as we watched the world go by. It would be a lovely spot for a long lunch if we'd been just a little earlier, children played hide and seek, parents sat on blankets on the lawns watching and chatting, others stretched out on deck chairs finishing off wines as the restaurant staff busied themselves clearing tables the occasional local bird descended to steal food scrapes. Winter is mild in Sydney most years and with the exception of a few days it is very pleasant to be in this city and see the sights. This is a highly recommended place to visit for locals and visitors alike, you will pay is $15 for adults with concessions for pension card holders, children and family passes for two adults and up to 3 children are $40 so it does make it affordable to provide a great day out. Sometimes to view your own city as a visitor would makes you feel so proud, we drove and parked easily at the meter parking in the Domain, however watch the time as we did see a few people being booked for overstaying. Public transport by bus or train (St James Station or Circular Quay are only a short walk away and you can relax completely.
GOOD FOR FREE. Sadly not many museums are free in Sydney. It is!. Located in front of Botanic Garden fit perfectly in any tour plan. The shop and coffee/restaurant inside are good value
Brilliant Archibald Exhibition. A friend and I flew from Brisbane to Sydney to visit the gallery to view the current Archibald art exhibition. We were certainly not disappointed.

Great Australian Art and surprisingly Pre-Raphaelites too. i love this art gallery. It has a fantastic collection of Australian art, which in case you didn't know is very very good. Brett Whiteley is awesome and his studio is another gallery affiliated with AGNSW. Regular exhibitions are always good but the permanent collection is the jewel in the crown. The Shaeffer collection of pre-raphaelite art is also a treat. Go and spend the day - the cafe is good and the location in the Domain beautiful.

Loads to see and plenty of help available. It was not too crowded and plenty of help was available to have us complete a walk though in limited time. This is worth the walk and it has a wonderful café and restaurant as well should you wish to stop a while.
A Must For Art Lovers.. See some of Australia's Art in this well laid out Gallery. There is often Art from overseas as well and always a feature exhibition.
Well worth the visit. Went to see "Pop to Popism" earlier this year. Well curated, interesting and a great selection of permanent works. Plus the restaurant has amazing views!
Arcibald Prize. We attend every year & the complimentary tours they provide are fantastic & informative.It is also esy to access from train stations with a short walk
Archibald show not to be missed. ARCHIBALD show not to be missed. As usual, controversial and thought provoking, the painting always look so much better in the flesh rather than just viewing on line

Archibald Exhibition. First time here. Wonderful huge spaces, views from the many windows are spectacular. Old on the outside yet contemporary inside. The old Australian Classics area was awesome. A wonderful and leisurely activity to fit into a visit to Sydney. August to September a good time to view the many portraits submitted for the Archibald Prize.
Great!. Great way to spend an afternoon, particularly in summer to get out of the heat. They also run great free programs and workshops for kids. Plus there's some amazing art too!

Be Inspired. Yes, the galleries of Europe are impressive but this is a showcase of art that matters to Australia. The Art Gallery of NSW is situated in the Botanical Gardens and easily accessible from the CBD or by ferry to Circular Quay. Take the opportunity to stroll through the Gardens which make a nice contrast to the art on display. The spaces in the Gallery are airy and uncluttered and the new additions work well with the original sandstone building. For children there are dedicated activities, especially on weekends and during holidays. Entrance is free, except for special exhibitions.At the moment, the Archibald portrait exhibition (Fee is charged) is the main draw card. I found the standard this year to be very high. Please don't forget to look at the Young Archies, which are portraits by children. Some of the explanations for their choice of subject make for interesting reading. There is a warmth, fondness and playfulness to these portraits. There are rooms dedicated to Asian and Aboriginal Art and once you have finished, or perhaps in between browsing, the cafe offers a tranquil view over park lands and the harbour, as well as good modern Australian light meals.

Impressive. We visited the Archibald Prize Exhibition recently and enjoyed the experience immensely despite there being a large crowd in attendance. I was impressed by the exhibition and the management around it.

Excellent!. Some fantastic works in a stunning building.Not only does the artistry take your breath away, but the architecture too. I have been to the Gallery on many a school trip but have not been able to fully appreciate it.The annual Archibald prize is a must see. I would definitely recommend a trip to the Art Gallery of NSW to any tourist and/or local. Pieces to appreciate for all age/art appreciation levels. Pop to Popism is a 5/5.
Rainy Day things to do. Great to see the paintings of Tom Roberts, Arthur Streeton and other Australian greats of art and sculptor.

A must vist for Sydney!. Wonderful gallery to visit and we were fortunate that the Achibald Prize exhibition was on.Always a highlight.Wonderful portraits....Cafe is great spot after the art to enjoy a coffee or light snack.Excellent collection of Australian art over the ages.
Worth spending some quiet time in the building.. I used the wifi at the library and then started wondering around. It has heaps of historic displays and the actual building is amazing.

Does Sydney proud. Nice to be able to visit a local art gallery, one which we can have pride in. The main building is elegant both from the outside and once inside, plus the more modern extensions blend in well. The main gallery is free to enter with charges for exhibitions, currently the very popular and well presented Archibald Prize selection. Some notable artworks and sculptures throughout and generally not too crowded. Often changing and also free short term exhibits. Both the cafe and more upmarket restaurant are commendable options for lunch with the cafe also good for coffee and snacks. I always recommend at least walking to and/or from the Art Gallery and the city centre by traversing either Hyde Park, The Domain or Botanical Gardens.

Sydney's Art Gallery and park. Excellent art gallery, with a resident collection of Australian art and occasional "block buster" type shows from (usually) overseas. There are annual competitions, such as the always controversial Archibald portrait. I like especially the annual display of high school student art, often called "Art Express". Check out their website for what's on: http://www.artgallery.nsw.gov.au/. Unfortunately, in the middle of a large city park, "The Domain", it is poorly served by public transport, but there is paid, garage parking sort of near by. The walk through The Domain is pleasant as is a stroll through the Botanic Gardens <http://www.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/>.
Wonderful Exhibitions make this Gallery a big drawcard.. Always love to visit this building and exhibitions when we come to Sydney. The Archibald is a big drawcard and well worth the visit.

Dynamic Exhibitions & Great Day Out. I really enjoyed my recent trip to the gallery to see the Archibald, Wynne & Sulman Prizes. There is a fee for this exhibition, however everything else is free to view. The gallery is not very big, but they creatively pack many exhibits into the spaces. I really liked how the artworks were presented - some hanging from the roof in the foyer, to a large installation of mirrors you can view whilst going down the stairs, to Jitish Kallat's Public notice 2 in the Entrance Court (http://www.artgallery.nsw.gov.au/exhibitions/jitish-kallat/). The exhibition named Colourwheel (http://www.artgallery.nsw.gov.au/exhibitions/colourwheel/ ) was another one of my favourites. There are places for the public to make their own artworks, inspired by ones currently on display. This is fantastic - making art next to masterpieces! Their online resources are also wonderful. The coffee shop inside the gallery makes great coffees and it is a nice way to finish the visit.

Love this Gallery. My favourite Sydney gallery. Always has interesting exhibitions. Recently saw the Archibald Portrait Prize. Permanent exhibitions are great as well. Nice cafe overlooking Wooloomooloo Wharf.

Don't miss this.. This is one of my favourite destinations in Sydney. This art space is something to be proud of if you are a Sydneysider and well worth visiting if you are a tourist. There are a couple of great eating options and an exceptional gift shop. Love it!

Lovely Museum with unusual display of old and new.. I loved the mix of old and new at this museum. This is an outing for 1-2 hours as the display is not huge. The coffee shop has beautiful viewing point over Woolloomooloo.

Never tire of this gallery. Every time I visit Sydney I visit the NSW Art Gallery and enjoy it. I regularly go to the Archibald / Wynne / Sulman annual exhibition if I don't see an Archibald selection in a regional gallery close to home. This year I thoroughly enjoyed the Archibald and Wynne exhibitions in particular.The ambience and presentation of the gallery is welcoming and attractive. Staff are pleasant and helpful.You can do much better than to dine at the in house conveniently located cafe which has disappointing food.

Explore Australian Art History from different angles. Massive collection from domestic artist and European artists. The most impressive collection is the aboriginal section, different from the traditional art pieces we've seen, the wildness and the power behind the art work is worth seeing.
Love it!. Great gallery! I loved the exhibitions and had a fantastic time exploring the gallery! I definitely recommend it!

Free Museum. Another freebie in a beautiful part of the city centre; walk through the Botanical Gardens or the Domain to get to it. Lots of Australian history and art as well as European and Asian. Take the time to go to the bottom level for the native Australian artwork.

Wonderful paintings!. If you like and appreciate art, this is the place for you. Managed to catch a sneak peek of the Archibald competition this year. Free admission. Just enjoy the arts and other exhibits.

Another year of Archibald, Wynne and Sulman. We have been lucky enough to get to see these 3 prizes most years recently. As usual, so many brilliant paintings in the Archibald. A hard job for the judges. And, as usual, even picking one for the People's Choice was difficult. Some portraits didn't press our buttons, but that's only personal choice. Likewise the Wynn and Sulman- some brilliance, some not appealing at all. But ALWAYS, a fantastic exposure to so many different styles in portraiture, landscapes and genre painting. Shouldn't be missed! And the Junior Archies-childrens' portrait painting etc- charming and amazingly good ! And the Members Lounge a haven on what was an incredibly busy day. Fantastic to see so many people appreciating art. Who said Australia is a cultural wasteland? Exhilarating, stimulating and inspiring.

Relax and Enjoy the Art . I enjoyed my day at the museum. My favorite pieces were Sidney Nolan. There many genres of art. The gallery is organized , spacious with scenic views. It's a great place to relax and enjoy the art

Archibald Prize. A very high standard Archibald this year and for once the judges have got it right! The Charles Waterstreet portrait is the real standout. A beautiful painting! The Wynne entries are again brilliant and well worth a detailed look. As usual, give the Sulman a miss.

We all enjoyed the Gallery.. Fun for all of our family. Our grandsons ages 7 and 10 enjoyed the Gallery as did the adults in the party. A nice selection of paintings reminded me of the National Gallery in London on a smaller scale..
Well organised. Went the see the Archibald finalists, well worth the visit and also check out standard exhibits, very interesting and pieces had explanatory notes, very cultured.
The Archibald is a great exhibition. We love the art gallery and would highly recommend the Archibald prize. The cafe is good to sit and relax and enjoy something to eat.

Wednesday night at the gallery. Last night visited the Gallery during their special Wednesday evening extended hours. They put on a special event for the Archibald entries, which was an interview with the winner and subject. It was a class ly evening and staged so well by the staff of the Gallery. My hats off to them. One the best Wednesday nights I've had in a long time. Will be doing it again soon.

It was rainy and this was the rescue . We couldn't do much in the city as the rain was too heavy. I have nothing to do with art but the collection was easy to understand and still interesting for me. No entrance. Will last for about 1.5 hrs.

Fantastic exhibitions, Archibald is the best. We had the best day in the gallery, thoroughly enjoyed all the exhibitions especially the Picasso Matisse and the Archibald. So worth the trip then a walk through the botanical gardens to the opera house is a great way to finish the day

Archibald 2015. I went to the Archibald exhibition tonight. Excellent collection and the portrait of Charles Waterstreet is a worthy winner. However I liked the painting by Kim Leutwyler. I recommend seeing them all and choose your own favourite.

Archibald was a well put-together exhibition. Went for opening day of the Archibald Prize (heard some people in the queue complaining about the crowds - c'mon people, it's OPENING DAY of course it's packed)!Lovely exhibition of portraits, landscapes and "other." While I didn't agree with *any* of the winners of the 3 prizes on offer, it was definitely money well spent.My favourites are attached :)

Enjoyed it. Good diverse selection. Had a mix of old and new, Australian, European and Asian. A very balanced gallery. In a nice location too. Far superior to the Contemporary Art Gallery at Circular Quay

Wonderful Art. I always like to see some of my favourite artists' work and I am never disappointed when I go to this art gallery. Great picture windows as well as many genres of art.
