Great female painters like Grace Cossington-Smith and Margaret Preston, along with more modern and Indigenous art. My husband really loves the painting of the Queen of Sheba meeting King Solomon - a very art piece.

Archibald exhibition . Whilst I can't say I'm an art lover I really appreciated the level of effort and quality of the portraits. The photos I've put here on TripAdvisor seriously don't do them justice. It was cheap too, only $15 to enter. A good couple of hours spent. Recommended.
Wonderful aboriginal art. The gallery was undergoing refurbishment so some of the rooms were closed but the collection is worth seeing for the aboriginal art alone.

One of My Favourites. This wonderful gallery has changing exhibitions and there is always something exciting to see. It is really well set out, accessible and free. The permanent collection has many important enjoyable pieces and is regularly changed.
Must-see Sydney attraction. Highly recommended part of your Bot Gardens walk. Great collection of Victorian high art and Pre-Raphaelites. Stunning view from the top floor cafe.

Australian art. The NSW art gallery is free to the public, has a variety of Australian art and visiting exhibitions. Lovely walk from here through the botanical gardens to the opera house or easy walk to the city. Lovely way to spend some peaceful time

One of the best collections in the southern hemisphere. Check out the visiting exhibitions - there are usually one or two on, usually of very high standard. Asian exhibitions are paticularly expertly curated. The permanent collection has some high quality Ruropean and American pieces. The collection is unsurprisingly strong in Australian art. From the back, there is astunning view of Woolloomoloo harbour, particularly in the evening sun.

Art is the emotional Heart of the People. The Art Gallery of NSW always has an important exhibition, Right now it is the Archibald, Sulman and Wynne prize winners, so hurry so you don't miss this. The Gallery offers an excellent indigenous art section, as well as early European settlement Australian works. It is reasonably easy to park on Gallery Road, there are many restaurant and café options both within the gallery and nearby. Children are always welcomed and have special events during school holidays. You can join a guided tour, or hire commentary on MP3 players for special exhibitions. Staff are helpful, mostly you can take photos, there are plenty of toilets and there is a great book and souvenir shop. Leave yourself plenty of t ime and then maybe finish off with an amble through the Botanic Gardens across the road to reflect on your experience.

While away a couple of hours. Combine a trip to the Art Gallery with a wander through the botanic gardens. The contemporary Australian art is well worth a visit and a must do if you are an Australian citizen.

Disappointing. I was disappointed in the Matisse exhibition and the war artists exhibition -was expending more works. The cafe food is pretty ordinary, but service is good and the atmosphere is good. This gallery very second best when you consider the State and the International Galleries in Melbourne.

Loved It!. This is an amazing museum. Loved the collection, a large array of works. We spent several hours and we still rushed through some rooms.P.S. They had free wi-fi and I was able to check my email for free. :)

Art Gallery of World Standard. They have a changing routine of World Class Exhibitions, bringing works from overseas for those of us who cant travel often. A great collection of Early Autralian to Modern with Asian and Indigenous Art. Well worth a visit then wander across town to th MCA or Museum of Contemporary Art near the Rocks area for the rest of the times.

Impressive. Loved the fact that the Gallery has such fantastic displays of Australian art. Also hard to get your head around paintings that are hundreds of years old! A great way to spend a few hours.

Great to see and do. Very informative and educational. Liked the Asian art tour very much. I will go back and do more tours next time we visit. Food is a bit restricted in choice and high in price if you need to eat there.

Wonderful. I never fail to come to this magnificent gallery every time I'm in Sydney. It has a marvellous collection of Australian artist that I love to see plus there is always a visiting exhibition af high quality. The Resturant on the entrance is favourite spot to sit enjoy the views and eat really good food. There is cafe on the lower level

Nothing more to say, MUST GO. This Art Gallery locates near the Botanic Garden of Sydney. Reacheable by public transport or even on foot. If you have no sense in direction, just take a taxi, the fare is minimum.I suggest to allow 1 to 2 hours exploring this gallery and the collections of master pieces. Check the official website before you go, there is special exhibition happening regularly.This gallery has not been occupied by nasty visitors yet. You can relax and find some peace. Enjoy
Great Gallery. One of my favourite Australian Galleries. Wide range of paintings and exhibitions. Great setting and very spacious.
Wonderful exhibition of Photography in Australia. Easy to walk around and we had lunch in the outdoor restaurant. Very good. What more can I say? Very good.
always wonderful. little snippets of harbour views from various gallery spaces and beautiful gardens to walk in nearby

A great snapshot of the history of Australian art and its free. A visit here gives you an insight into the history of art in Australia. The gallery is set in parklands and is well worth a visit if you enjoy art.
A must see. A great free day out for all. A large gallery with many sections, e.g. Australian, contemporary, Asian, traditional European. Pick up a free kids guide at the desk. Well stocked shop.

Always terrific. The Art Gallery of NSW is beautifully situated in the Domain and close to the Botanic Gardens. They always have special exhibitions but I just love the Australian Masters - they never fail to delight and I think they're a must for tourists to see.
Fabulous Museum. This museum is one of the best in Australia. It has a fabulous collection. The aboriginal exhibition is wonderful.
Good. Not a massive art gallery. The perfect size really. Some great varieties of artwork to take in. Worth a visit when in Sydney.

Whirlwind visit. We did a whirlwind visit to the Art Gallery which we've also visited on past trips....their indigenous art is excellent. This time we went to see an exhibition of old photographs which was fascinating. a it was entitled "the photograph and Australia" and featured some iconic images. I was a little disappointed that it was biased to certain states more than others.

Great collection. I never get tired of visiting this museum. The collection is quite impressive, ranging from aboriginal art to contemporary Australian artists. Free entry, well thought distribution of art pieces, and for the ones who can't live without their coffee there's a superb view from the coffee shop if you want to take a break from art and digest what you watched.
something lovers of art.. There's alway something to see but I prefer it when there is a special exhibition in town. Being local I wouldn't go out of my way otherwise.

Diverse collection, great museum to visit!. Really enjoyed it! This gallery offers a diverse collection of Modern, Classical and Aboriginal art. Numerous areas of the gallery are free to enter but they do offer other paid events and displays. So many amazing artists have called this place home from Andy Warhol to Penelope Seidler. If you are feeling peckish you can also visit one of their cafe's for a bite to eat and then pop into the shop for a memento of your trip!
Surprisingly Good. I did not think the Art Gallery would contain such a big collection and display them in such a lovely old building. It is worth a few hours to visit.

Can satisfy every taste. The Gallery was housed in a spectacular, historical building located in a lovely environment. It is only a 15 to 20 minutes walk from the city centre. Unless at times of bad weather, the walk itself is already an enjoyable one. The collection in the Gallery is diverse, ranging from Old Masters to Modern Arts. There is something to satisfy every taste. Try to take advantage of the free guided tour provided by the Gallery. It makes the visit more informative and interesting. I was lucky enough to arrive at the Gallery in time just to join such a guided tour, conducted by ( believe it or not, fellow Hongkongers) Cantonese! Quite a pleasant way to spend two hours even if you are not an arts enthusiat.
Amazing architecture,. Along with the architecture, was an amazing selection of history, contemporary art, sculpture and photography. We had 2 reluctant teenagers in tow and they really enjoyed it,

Art Gallery of New South Wales. This free museum provides an excellent array of largely Australian art. By definition it is recent, 19th century on. There is an impressive collection of impressionists and many displays of Asian and other art.

Great place to visit. The outside of the building commands attention across from the Botanical gardens. We spent several hours browsing the exhibitions then stopped at the cafe for lunch, fabulous place to visit with a variety of displays.

Always a great pleasure. I always enjoy visiting here. I arrived here after a bit of a long walk from the rocks, around the harbour and past the Botanical Gardens, so I was sweating a bit. But I unloaded my backpack and coat at the front desk and then spent the next hour or so strolling around, delightfully exploring the art. Although there were a few school groups there, I managed to avoid them for the most part, although I was impressed that these children were being encouraged to examine and respond to what they were seeing. I really like this gallery with it's wonderful mix of art styles - something for everyone. And free!

Great gallery. Lovely gallery set in beautiful surroundings. Wonderful exhibitions, great gift shop. Good cafe - you could spend most of the day here! From there you can visit the Botanic Gardens and walk into town. Well located.
A visit is worth the walk. We walked in and wandered around and found this a very impressive building on its own without the artwork. Staff are very friendly and there is lots to see.

Good for rainy days!. I had no intention of going when I got to Sydney...my hostel was right beside it and during a rainy day staff suggested it was worth doing. I thought it was pretty decent...I'm no art lover but managed to spend a few hours in here. It's worth a thought if the weather takes a turn for the worst!
a gem. great place to go - huge place with incredible range, great presentation. from kids to the great masters, aboriginal, humor...

Beautiful building with a great collection to suit every taste. The Art Gallery of NSW is a must see for art lovers. The building itself is quite stunning, blending the old with the new. The art collections are also really good. I appreciate Modern art and was not disappointed.

Beautiful building and Diverse Collection. Take a free guided tour of the permanent exhibition. Worth it for the great stories that make the art come alive. Entry is free and takes in most of the gallery. Special exhibitions will attract a fee so if you're interested enjoy but there is plenty to see for free if this is your first time. If you do pay for an exhibition the audio tour guide is worth the expense or tag onto a guided tour free with admission at set times. Food court tends to be very busy and a bit pricey for what it is. Restaurant is also a bit pricey but great service. Walk across the Domain into the city for more choice and cheaper eats. You can check your bags in at the Entrance to the Art Gallery for safe storage and enjoy your wander without the load. A great piece of culture in a beautiful setting.

Lunch break with art. For all folks working around the Art Gallery it is a must visit. The lunch food selection is very simple but utterly delicious. For those of us who like to get some wine with the food - you will not be disappointed. So, what are you waiting for - come along and say hello to the "arty lunch' in the big metropolis of Sydney. You may even venture out and check out the free to browse exhibition. Free inspiration for the next part of the day.

Must visit on a Wednesday evening!. Went on a Wednesday evening, when the museum opens late till 10. There was live music, and I had dinner at the cafe too (which was alright).There's something about walking around an art gallery at night that's simply magical. It wasn't crowded at all, and I had the pleasure of taking my own time exploring the museum. There was even transport (a bus) back to Town Hall station and a couple of other stations running every 15 minutes till 10pm - a very thoughtful service by the museum. Highly recommended if you love art.

BRILLIANT - EXCEEDED ALL EXPECTATIONS.. If you ever have time in Sydney do visit this terrific gallery FREE! Wonderful and always good to get some 'culture' experience.
BRILLIANT - EXCEEDED ALL EXPECTATIONS.
For last century artwork, a must.. If you enjoy artwork from the last few centuries I encourage you to visit this place. Their collections are truly incredible.

Take a tour. We spent a couple of hours visiting this gallery and struck it lucky on arrival as a free tour explaining aboriginal art was just about to start (left at 11 am but the schedule changes daily). We were the only people on the tour and found it to be very informative as the guide was very knowledgeable. What we learnt was put to good use the next day when we purchased an artwork. This was a great introduction to the history of aboriginal art up until today. We then quickly viewed the remainder of the contemporary section. Loved the Matisse works.
Check it out. General exhibit is free which is a plus...good range of art movements to view and occasionally exhibits special shows. Check their program.

Must visit in Sydney. The AGNSW is a must see when visiting Sydney. I love wandering through the halls from contemporary to the classics. Be sure the check out the aboriginal section. The café is pretty good to for lunch or a snack.

Lovely art gallery, free entry!. Art Gallery of NSW is free entry with special exhibitions that has entry fee, most of the major exhibitions you can buy online with timed entry. the rest are free. so if you just want to look at some free art if you have time and not too fuss about what you see. you can just walk in and wander around. if you want to see a specific advertised major exhib, then its best to buy online in advance to avoid long queue. even with the free stuff, they have a huge variety, from 18th Century European to Asian to Aboriginal to modern to Art by year 12 students for their HSC exam.. the exhib change all the time. So u can visit this place over & over and not see the same thing. they also have free film screenings sometimes. check their website for details. and they open til late Wed nights. if you want to go after work.

A well presented gallery. I had hoped to take in Aboriginal art as part of my visit to Australia and the NSW gallery did not disapoint. It's a very attractive building and the collections are excellently curated. A few hours extremely well spent.And free, of course, as galleries should be.

Limited art gallery in a lovely building. If you are used to the art galleries of London and New York then this will disappoint, it does not have the depth or breadth of art that they have. However for a gentle excursion at the end of a visit to the botanical gardens which are near by it shouldn't be dismissed. The space is lovely and there is a reasonable cafe on the lower ground floor, plus a much smarter looking restaurant on the ground floor.

Went with a group of 100 Kindergarten Children - awesome. Went with a large group including 100 5 year old children. What a lovely way to spend a Friday Morning excursion. The staff were helpful and on hand and while diligent in protecting their fine Art works, did not restrict the children's enjoyment of this Gallery. A lovely way to spend a morning in this fine building

Wonderful place. this has long been a lovely peaceful place to visit with exhibitions cultivated from within Australia and from around the world, you can go for a specific viewing or wander about for hours inside. there is even a yummy restaurant with a gorgeous view of Sydney not often seen.
beautiful. great collection of paintings and sculptures, even the Australian Art was I impressive (I'm not normally an Australian art fan)

A great addition to the Gallery. More of a fine dining experience than the service it replaces. Chiswick at the Gallery is as good as the other members of this brand. Lovely food. Lots of share plates which make it more affordable. Great staff. Love the experiments with out of hours opening

A LAZY AFTERNOON.. I ended up in Watson's Bay after walking around Double Bay, Rose Bay and visiting Vaucluse House. A bus ran from Vaucluse House to Watson's Bay which has a great view of the bay and a several fine eating and/or drink spots.

Plenty to see. I always visits the Gallery when I'm in NSW and although the Gallery allows tourist guides the OK to use microphones (only place in the world I have experienced a gallery allowing this annoying habit) don't let it turn you off. While the collection pales in comparison to Melbournes National Gallery it is still worth a vist

An excellent central city Art Gallery. This gallery is such an easy walk through Hyde Park and the Domain and a beautiful building architecturally. Some excellent collections on while we visited - a great way to spend half a day and the gallery shop is packed full of interesting things to look at and buy. We relaxed in the cafe for lunch at the end and meandered back to the city centre finally.

Lovely building, collection uninspiring. The setting and architecture of the building are worth the visit which is free. The collection however is not inspiring and lacks imagination in the way it is presented

Wonderful,gallery. You can easily spend all day here looking at different parts of the collection, sitting outside with a coffee or lunching.We took a free tour of highlights of the collection with an excellent guide, and the gallery also offers free guided tours of the Aboriginal art collection at 11am and one in early afternoon - check the time. It's a fair walk fron Circular Quay or the train stations, so if you're not sure about walking consider a cab.

Very interesting. I found the art gallery of New South Wales a good few hours to spend there's always a great variety of art to look at which explains a lot of Australian history the staff have always been very nice and helpful and they always have amazing art from lots of different talented artists

An excellent collection. The gallery holds an excellent collection, which ranges from aboriginal art to oriental exhibits. At the time we visited, there was major work underway installing a forthcoming visiting exhibition but this did not detract from our enjoyment. The venue also provided a good respite in the heat of the day, being air conditioned and having good refreshment options.

Lovely, well rounded Gallery in a magical location. Good, if not blockbuster, range of temporary exhibitions and a large collection of Australian modern and colonial art. Lovely exhibition spaces, a little annoying for the disabled as only one set of elevators, but nicely resolved for other guests.

Great Art Gallery and free!. This is a huge art gallery that I had limited time to explore. I focused mostly on the Yiribana Gallery which is the Aboriginal gallery. I enjoyed my visit here and was amazed that such a huge art gallery would be free of charge. That was very nice and probably encourages more folks to visit. I highly recommend a visit here if you enjoy art galleries.

Great Landmark to visit. If you enjoy art and expositions, this is a great place to visit. I quite enjoyed the display of the paintings (mostly the european art). The architecture of the place is quite enjoyable and welcoming. Allow a good couple of hours to go around the place, maybe more if you go to the main exhibition
A gem. Light airy gallery with great displays. We spent a couple of hours browsing, and didn't see all the gallery had to offer. Good to see classes of school children there.
OK.. It was OK. Plenty to see. Nothing really I over enjoyed. Good quality for what it is tho. It was part of a day of museums so enjoyed it.

Great art gallery in nice setting. Came here for a few hours before catching the plane home. I was able to store my luggage in the cloakroom and also have an excellent lunch at the one of 2 cafe/restaurants in the gallery.The collection is well spaced out and themed, and I did a free guided tour of Australian Art at 2pm which was very informative. Definitely go and see the Matisse and other Impressionist art which is on display free during May/June. It was a real treat to see and read the information. There is also an exhibition of Australian Photography at the moment.It is a good 10 minute walk from St James Railway station so you need a map to get you started as when you come out of the station it is unclear in which direction to go. I walked towards the park (Hyde Park) and saw the sign to the Art Gallery which is in another large park called the Domain. You can come and go freely as entrance to Gallery is free so I took a break and had a cup of tea in the Domain and sat in the sun for a while before going back inside the gallery.I also brought my mother here last year and there are wheelchairs you can borrow for free. Plenty of lifts and good bathroom facilities. There are 2 cafe/restaurants but I would recommend the cafe as the food is cheaper and you get larger serves. The restaurant's menu has a few light meals but they are quite small. I had the cured salmon trout which was delicious but without any salad with it, I found it too rich to eat on its own and there wasn't that much anyway. I have eaten in the other cafe and there was more choice for lighter meals.

Lots to see.. The gallery is larger that it looks from the outside. There are numerous floors showing all sorts of art. There are a couple of eateries inside and another across the road. The majority of the gallery is free of charge.

I visit two or three times a year when in Sydney for work.. One of the best ways to spend a few hours in Sydney if you have time. I have some personal favourites to visit. Great location, easy to walk to, interesting range of hangings.

Excellent art. This gallery has some superb examples of Australian art and Asian art. My favourite exhibition is the famous portrait painting competition know as the Archibald which is on in July along with the Wynne and Sulman Prizes - always worth a look.

High Caliber Art on Show. Housing great art from diverse cultures and exhibitions on all through the year, located adjacent to Domain Park and Botanical Gardens, we go at least twice a year, and good food available on lower floor.

Great Australian art collection. Cant say enough about this place- have been many times but still find it stimulating and fresh. Lunch in the main restaurant (new, and looks great!) is a little extravagance, but has a terrific view. Free to get into the Gallery, so factor that into a good meal!

Raining in Sydney? Free indoor entertainment and education. Fees apply to some major temporary exhibitions but otherwise this is one of the best free sources of indoor entertainment and education in the city and worth visiting whatever the weather. It is worth noting however that the gallery opens late on Wednesdays to 10.00pm.There is so much to see, and the facilities are very good. I am interested in the settlement period but the collection encompasses aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander art, contemporary, European and Asian art.

Great for guests and rainy days. Free entry (certain exhibits require entry fee) with plenty to see. Aboriginal section really worthwhile. Visited with older family members and they really loved it. Situated in parkland with a cafe across the road so makes a nice break after a busy day sightseeing!
Art experience. I really enjoyed walking through the halls of this place. I would go back if I have a chance and its free:)

well worth a visit. This free gallery has many highlights, though the permanent collection itself is perhaps not one of them - the Sidney Nolan collection, smaller than I expected was my main reason to visit and there are some excellent and representative works by him and the other Angry Penguins. Good Aboriginal works too, especially the sculptural pieces. There was a superb temporary exhibition of Australian photography on when I visited, and the Asian collection has some wonderful objects, interestingly interspersed with contemporary responses. The building itself is fantastic with an open and airy feel, though the new galleries do seem to go on and on rather relentlessly - by the time you get to the lowest basement there seem to be more staff than visitors around. The restaurant looked great, though I didn't try it. Located close to the Botanic Gardens (but bizarrely signposted) so a great end point to a stroll from the harbour, though as elsewhere in Sydney, the disastrous land-based public transport system makes moving on (in the rain) inconvenient.
Art Gallery. We enjoyed our trip to the gallery. The beautiful paintings are always a pleasure to see and the staff were very polite and helpful.
Australian landscapes. It was very interesting to see the 19th and early 20th century landscape paintings depicting typical Australian scenes.

Tours, culture and a nice cafe. Check to see what is currently showing, these special exhbitions require a ticket.However, the rest of the gallery is lovely and has some famous Aboriginal and Australian artworks, which shows the progression of art and culture in Australia.Being across the road from the Botanical gardens and the domain makes for a lovely days outing. The cafe indoors in nice with good sandwiches and coffee with views over Woolloomooloo and the wharfs.

Visited dozens if times -love it. I have been to this amazing gallery many times over the past 30 years. Always a new and interesting collection, plus favourites from Australian history. Highly recommend.

A lovely few hours. We're not big art buffs but we duked in here for a quick look around and ended up enjoying it much, much more than we thought we would. It's expansive, well set our and the way finding was helpful. There was a fab display of artwork by local school kids which had us very entertained and the eating and drinking families where of a high standard (we had a coffee outside). I'd like to have seen more indigenous artwork but having said that we ran out of time and needed to move on. I'd recommend. Worth it.
Free and worth an afternoon.. A lot of indigenous art that was lovely, unique and well displayed. They are under renovations right now so will be even better by Oct.

Excellent venue. The museum building(s) and their setting are outstanding. The cafe is quite good for a museum. The aboriginal art is very engaging, especially for those with slight familiarity with such art. The European art collection is what one might expect for a colonial outpost. Australian art seemed quite good. Certainly worth a visit especially since there is no admission charge
A fine collection. Well worth a visit if you have any interest in 18th and 19th century European art, and some Australian work over the past century.

Perfect for a rainy day. From the outside, this building reminds me a bit from my home country, France. When you enter the building, it's a mix of Renaissance and Modern inspiration.The levels I truly recommend you to do are:- The Aboriginal Art (one of the lower level)- The Modern Asian Art- The Australian Art — not the European one, if you're coming from Europe, it's will be pretty much the same as we have (just less impressive).- The upper level, which was hosting an exhibition made by talented High School students. This level is often changing, so you'll have to be up-to-date with the gallery's program.We went there on a rainy day and made the most out of it.

Rainy day Excellence!. The Museum was more than i expected. It had some very amazing art to show off but I ran into a couple of bumpy people while in there but I do not hold that all to be their fault. Maybe I just take more time to look at art? ;-) I have been to 4 museums in Sydney and this was my second favorite besides the museum of Modern Art.

Great alternate activity. I went on a Sunday afternoon when the weather outside was a little wet and gloomy. The gallery was pretty full of both local people and tourists. Most of the exhibitions are free and it was a really great way to spend a few hours on a wet, Sunday afternoon. There isn't an extensvie collection of art and sculptures at the gallery but there is a good feel of the different styles and modes ready to view. The guides and staff are really friendly and helpful. They have a lot of information that they are happy to pass on. I really liked that there were free activities for kids of all ages to do. They were even able to take home some of their creations and continue some of their artworks at home. I thought that this was a great way of engaging the next generation in art. I would really recommend a visit on the odd occasion.

Rainy day reward. Visited the gallery on a rainy afternoon during a recent visit to Sydney. Really enjoyed the gallery and all it had to offer. Quite a comprehensive collection and well worth a visit. We saw a fascinating photographic exhibition tracing the history of photography, but the permanent exhibitions were worthy seeing as well.

Australia in a Photograph. For anyone interested in history or in photography or better still in both the exhibition currently on view at the Art Gallery of New South Wales is a treat. The photographs on display show Australia as a place and Australians as a people. For any Australians in Sydney until 10 May this is worth seeing and for tourists who have an interest in photography you will be impressed with what these early photographers were able to create. Take a break in the delightful Gallery cafe and move on to any of the other wonderful collections.
Good selection.. Plenty of famous artworks to see and the old sandstone building is in good condition. The cafe is good for lunch. Also see some native artworks. Easy to access across from the city.

Lunchtime bonus. Great little gallery. Manageable in a morning and one or two nice surprises including a free Sunday lunchtime concert in the middle of the C19th Australian gallery.Followed up by an lovely lunch at the Pavilion on the Park right outside the gallery - tasty fish and pasta.

Art lovers visit. On a wet day this was a great spot to stop and have a look at some great art. The children enjoyed wandering through and admiring the pieces on display. We spent a couple of hours moving through and just soaking up the atmosphere.

Pleasant gallery but needs reorganising/refurbishment. The building itself is lovely, but the interior tends to be arranged in an awkward way, with some of the hangings/instalments and long vistas obstructed. At times, queues for temporary exhibitions lead into the permanent galleries, which is sloppy. The permanent collections are certainly worth seeing.

Visiting the Art Galley of New South Wales is fantastic. Situated on the edge of Botanic Gardens, the Art Gallery of New South Wales is located in a grand historic building featuring classic architecture. I visited the art gallery twice and really appreciated each experience. The first visit was to view the various art collections ranging from traditional masterpieces to contemporary abstract works and the Aboriginal art section. My second visit was as part of a social group, where we enjoyed a wine and snacks before watching one of the free films regularly on offer at the art gallery. The film was none other than the classic Rocky Horror Picture Show. The Art Gallery of New South Wales certainly has something for everyone, including tourists and locals.

Art Gallery of NSW. A four star gallery in my view, this collection contains many priceless gems. It is well laid out with special exhibitions featuring regularly. The eating options are good and varied but expensive and better value is obtainable elsewhere. But if money is not an issue for you, they are enjoyable. Entrance is free. Highly recommended.
Surprise. I didn't expect such an interesting collection, Australian art as well as European. Really nice surprise during my visit to the Royal Gardens. Must do!

Wonderful Museum - Free and open late on Wednesday night. We ended up our Australian trip back in Sydney on a Wednesday after a flight from Melbourne, and after we checked into our hotel, we still had plenty of time to have a meal and then visit this museum since they stayed open late until 10 p.m. They had an interesting jazz band performing in the atrium area, and there were nice dining options at the museum as well. Most importantly, is that they had a wonderful floor that featured various exhibits by Aboriginal artists, some historical and some contemporary. They also had good info on the displays as well as a nice film featuring many of the artists. The museum also has a wealth of other pieces, from Francis Bacon to VanGogh. The Lucien Freud painting that features Leigh Bowery is incredible, and there are many other pieces of historical importance, many of which we had discovered for the first time. They also had a temporary exhibit that incorporated ancient asian pieces along with contemporary artists like Ai Wei Wei and Nam June Paik. It was very well done, and it wasn't crowded. It was a perfect evening as we strolled through the botanical gardens to get there.

great collection of Aborigional art. Loved the wide collection of australian art. The videos were very informative and helped promote some understanding of the story of the first Australians. Very powerful exhonsibit
Love it. great place to enjoy art in a relaxed atmosphere. Always changing and great for kids to wonder and explore without feeling like you have to keep them silent.

The Photograph and Australia. Went to this exhibition with high expectations which were not realised. Many very small photographs in dim light with explanations brief or missing entirely (or, listed to the side of a collection of photographs making it almost impossible to match the details to a photograph). A better development of themes and enlargement of smaller images would have been preferred by me (put the original photo to one side of the enlargement, if necessary). I would suggest just buying the exhibition book from the gift shop and missing the exhibition itself. Underwhelming.

Grand and modern. This is one of my favourite galleries in the world to visit. It is full of a good balance of the classics and modern pieces. The layout is easy for new comers to navigate their way around.

Tranquil culture. Always worth a visit,Great exhibits,easy to view at aleisurely pace.Like the Asiatic section particularly. Not very crowded & has good restaurants for when the legs tire. Probably not true at lunch time!

A bit of Kulture Mate.. Great CBD institution. Had nothing to do at lunchtime yesterday and went to the Art Gallery of NSW and saw "The Photograph and Australia" which was very impressive. Didn't know Australia had so many great photographers. After that had a general look around the gallery. Very impressed with the great artwork we have at the NSW Gallery.Staff are always very good there and they all seem happy and are very accommodating.Yes, I enjoyed a bit of Kulture at lunchtime.Thanks Mate.

Well presented. We decided to go to the Art Gallery to see the most recent exhibition. It was worth the long walk from our hotel on the corner of College and Oxford Streets. I did find some of the exhibition a little confusing because all the information about the photos was to one side. However the photos that we saw were amazing and it was great to see how some of our earliest days of Australia have been recorded/

Great Art Treat. Visiting the Art Gallery of New South Wales is a joy we look forward to most times we visit Sydney. From Circular Quay we walk past the Opera House, through the Botanic Gardens, around Mrs Macquarie's Chair and into the gallery. For no cost you can browse the free collections housed in an open, light, sandstone building with wonderful views from large floor to ceiling windows on the entrance level. There is a restaurant on this level which is pricey, but well worth a special treat ! The cafe downstairs has a terrace and inside seating and for the cost of a very good coffee you can enjoy the ambience and views in comfort. The gallery contains paintings and sculptures from the early colonial times through to the 1960s and 1970s and some contemporary paintings. There are also Asian art galleries that are free to enter. Exhibitions change regularly and most times we attempt to go as they are uniformly good. Sometimes they are 'block-busters' and there are queues to get in, but last weekend we went and there was an excellent Australian photography exhibition which was well attended with lots of knowledgeable photography buffs. There is parking along the roads leading to Mrs Macquarie's Chair, with meters. Be careful they are patrolled frequently! However with the lovely gardens right across the road I'd encourage you to walk if you're able, and make a good day of it with a picnic in the Botanic Gardens.

mostly closed down. Free to enter and lots to offer - but most of it was closed when we visited in April! This is a big disappointment for a public gallery - no wonder the MCA is so packed and popular by comparison!!!

Not for European art lovers. I went here because it was a "top choice" in the lonely planet book. I love Louvre in Paris, National Gallery in London, I love Renaissance and Impressionism paintings, so I thought I might go here as well but there are just a few paintings by Monet, Van Gogh, and the others are by Australian artists and less famous European ones. It's just not my cup of tea, and luckily it is free for admission.

Excellent Art Museum. A very nice collection including a number of Impressionist and Post Impressionist pieces. The Van Gogh may be of some interest as it seems to be a bridge between the earlier and final works. No admission fee so see what you want for as long as you want.

Beautiful Building located in stunning setting. Great to give the kids some culture. Located just off the cbd of Sydney adjacent to the botanical gardens and the magnificent ladies macquarie chair, you find the delightful Art Gallery of NSW. It is an attractive building with a wonderful feeling inside as you enter. Much of the gallery is free. It offers two dining options to cater for budgets. The gallery shop is worth a visit on your way out. There is enough to interest children even for 20 mins. It might lead to an interest of their own in time. Sydney has much to offer so if you have 3 days or more it should be on your itinerary.

Range of interesting exhibitions and solid permanent collection.. We've been regular visitors to the gallery for a number of years and highly recommend visiting. They have had superb exhibitions as diverse as China's first Emperor, japanese wood block prints and more recently Popism. We've also joined the gallery to take better advantage of all the regular and special events. Hope they keep up the fine work!

Disappointing Photographic Exhibiion. This exhibition is large and numerous but weirdly presented so that one is looking for where the information about the photographs is presented (in some of the galleries)

Perhaps the best Art Gallery in Australia?. We have visited the AGNSW over the years and it keeps getting better. If you include the Australian Museum, just down the road; the Hyde park Barracks; and the Power House Museum next to Darling Harbour, you will have a pretty good handle on the history of the State, its fauna and flora and its amazing art both Aboriginal and post-settlement, plus wider collections and decorative arts. Go to the Art Gallery first, though, and view the way people living in this remarkable continent have seen it and their societies.
Fabulous food with great views. Loved the food, the mouth watering menu and all the helpful staff who made the whole experience of lunching with friends so much more enjoyable

Great to see Australian artists. This is a great place to spend half a day. The Australian artists, both indigenous and non indigenous are well represented. The current exhibition of year12 artwork from NSW schools is lovely to see. We have some thoughtful young people coming along. The activities for children during the school holidays were well attended and the cafe provided a welcome cup of coffee and a sit down.

Art Gallery of New South Wales. Always a delight to visit - mostly free except for a few special exhibits, but if you're a member, then you have reduced rates to shows (catch the great Resonate program of classical and jazz performed surrounded by the great Australian Impressionists and a guest lounge with free beverages and art library for your relaxation. Also free concerts on Wednesday evenings and so on. Love this place!

Lower level 2 was closed. Very busy museum with an excellent cafe and a fantastic museum shop. I was looking forward to seeing contemporary art in the modern gallery but ended up disappointed to find that practically the entire lower level 2 was closed and under construction. The rest of the collection in other levels were interesting enough but left me wanting more.
Beautiful venue. Easy walk from the city through beautiful parkland. Don't expect a European quality collection but a great place to spend half a day in Sydney.

Rainy Day!. What a great way to spend a rainy day. I hadn't been to a Art Gallery in years. Walking around & looking at all the beautiful art made me realise I must do this more often. An amazing place to visit.

A favourite stop in Sydney . I can sympathise and to an extent, agree, with the criticisms of this gallery but I am very find of it. I usually incorporate it into a wander through the botanic gardens and I am very fond of its collection of 1700's through to 1900's classic art. I also love the building. I do NOT love the refreshment options ; try to plan your day so you are taking coffee and lunch elsewhere.

Very nice gallery with diverse artwork. I went on a Thursday evening when the Gallery was open late which was a great find. It had a nice collection including an Aboriginal gallery and even a Pop Art gallery, although that was closed for the evening. A very pleasant evening.

MORE BEAUTY APPRECIATION AT THE ART GALLERY!. After visiting the Royal Botanic Garden where I appreciated the beauties created by Mother Nature, I went out to visit the Art Gallery where beauties created by Persons are on display. Note that there is an exit from the Garden located near this attraction. This FREE Art Gallery has several floors of exhibits. The Ground Floor has beautiful paintings and art works on display. Located outside this area is the Cafe where one can buy refreshments and snacks.One floor down is the gallery where Asian arts are on display such as paintings,wall hangings, potteries/ceramics, Japanese walls, kimonos and samurais, sculptures, pictures of Jesus Christ and Buddha, etc. Another floor below the Asian Arts Exhibits is the Yaribana Gallery where art works of the aborigines are available for one's appreciation. They include wall hangings made of cloths, poles with paintings, etc.Tips: After visiting the arts on display, take a break at the Cafe. Enjoy their delicious refreshments and foods as well as the views outside of the Cafe Area. Remember to retrieve your backpack and big items (left near the entrance for temporary safekeeping) before leaving this attraction.

The Photograph and Australia Exhibition. We specifically went to the Art Gallery of NSW to see thePhtograph and Australia exhibition, which we found very interesting.It was well set up, with a huge variety of styles and artists represented. Particularly interesting to me was the very early photographs from the 1800's.We also had a wander around the free sections of the Gallery, and the Asian arts were beautiful, and worth a look, as were the main rooms to the right of the entrance.We spent a couple of hours there in total which was more than enough time.A criticism I do have (which is quite minor) is that the placards describing the art were such small writing, you had to stand so close to them to read them, no one else could read them at the same time.

Slightly underwhelmed. I have to say I was slightly disappointed by this art gallery. We didn't want to pay to see the Photography exhibition so just went in the free areas. We enjoyed the indigenous Australian section, and the Asian art, but neither area was very big. The European and other Australian art I thought was not particularly exciting, and a whole floor was closed for renovation. Maybe our experience at the cafe at the start of the visit put us in a bad mood. Having waited 20 minutes for them to deliver two cups of coffee I went up to the counter and asked the staff member to make my coffee so I could take it back to the table myself. The waiters were wasting so much time wandering around looking for the table numbers. To cap it all, the ladies toilet floors were filthy and covered with pieces of toilet paper. All rather off-putting I'm afraid.

Disappointment Again.. As an interstate visitor this Gallery is always on the top of my list as """MUST DO ""I have now visited 3 times in the last 18 months .Each of those times the Gallery's large Impressionist Australian art area has been closed for preparation work or other. . The display of artwork in the 3 or 4 main rooms on the right of the entry was again the only area open , other than a Asia display .I travel to Sydney to see local artist on display. Each time missing out.I suggest visitors contact the gallery, before any future visits, to check what is on display in every area. This question is not fully answered on the web sight.

Awesome stylish museum. I love how this one is put together. There is at least one work from many masters represented. There is a great section on Australian artists as you'd imagine. there was a photo exhibit the day I went that was very nice. It is very walkable and the rooms meander around without being confusing.

Unique Experience, Unique Collection. We visited this Art Gallery 2 time. It has a unique collection of master Art works. Some of the paintings are very huge. It displays Australian art of different periods. There was a display of Asian art.The entry is free.
Wonderful Gallery. This is a modest gallery by world standards, but if you are in Sydney and enjoy art please make the effort as it is well laid out and has a marvellous collection.
Of course very dependent on showings. Great gallery with fantastic viewing facilities. Located in heart of the city amongst gardens and historical building precinct.
Excellent collection.. Excellent collection of art work. Must visit place for art lovers. General area has a free entry, some exhibitions are paid

Very Nice Collection. Since we were in Australia, we wanted to see offerings from Australian artists. We were not disappointed. Although it is a small gallery, as compared to the Met, it has a wide variety of Australian works from different periods and a very interesting Asian display. We enjoyed ourselves thoroughly.

A day of culture, food and sightseeing. Always worth a visit to the Art Gallery of NSW. Especially when a prominent display of art is showing or just to recharge the batteries.My fav section is always the traditional gallery with works form the OLD MASTERS.

Masterpieces.. You do not expect such old artworks in a modern city. A nice walk across the park from the city. The building is attractive sandstone. They have a good café for lunch too. Good pieces of art to view from all mover the world.

I never miss this in my Sydney visits. This is a brilliant art gallery. The paintings are wonderful as well as the layout. The gallery has an enormous collection and they rotate a lot of paintings so that every time you visit, there is something new to see. There are various collections such as Asian, Aboriginal etc. If you feel the need for some refreshments as a break, there is an excellent resturant at very reasonable prices. I love their sandwiches! The museum is also situated in a beautiful spot and you can walk through very green open parks to get there. Public transport is excellent and after visiting the museum, I would suggest a walk through the Botanical gardens to the Opera House and then to Circular Quay.

Interesting. The gallery is free entry. Depending on your interest the gallery is good for an hour plus. Cafe on site, toilets. We went mid week, mid day and there were several school parties present. If you want a quieter visit maybe visit after school times. Near the Botanical gardens for a lovely strol afterwards.

The old girl's looking pretty fresh.... I love the Art Gallery. The collection is broad and I go all the time. If you are working in Sydney it is open on Wednesday nights which is always fun. A snack at the cafe, a quick vino and a gentle meander around is a great evening. There are constantly rotating exhibitions coming through which have entry fees sometimes, however general admission is free. There has been a refresh and swap about in the more traditional part of the gallery so even if you are local and have not been recently it's worth another peek!
Wonderful Memories. We began our lunch by taking a leisurely stroll through the Botanical Gardens which was delightful. Enjoyed a delicious lunch with friends. Recommend the Barramundi.

A home away from home. The AGNSW is like a second home to me if the frequency of visits and my attendance at the many activities are a guide. In addition to their weekly art history lectures on Western European Art, I am also thoroughly enjoying the series of lectures which are currently being given by Susannah Fullerton on English literature. I enjoyed the incomparable views and the attention of the waitering staff when lunching with friends at Chiswick today although I thought that my fish and chips were over-cooked.

Excellent Gallery and Great special displays. Went to the photography in Australia members viewing last night and it was excellent. A bit overwhelming with so many photos from 1800s and early 1900s but all very interesting and nicely displayed. The special exhibitions at the gallery are always nice.
Fabulous. Lovely walk through the park to arrive,spent a whole day wandering around the Gallery. Beautiful works, nice light lunch in the cafe. One of my favourite days to remember.

Good although would like to have seen more made of the indigenous art. A nice environment in which to look at local art. The indigenous section is good but not huge and most is quite modern....I somehow suspect that a great deal of older indigenous art might be available but the overall emphasis seemed to be on European or more classical stuff

Excellent free attraction. The Art Gallery of NSW was my favourite free attraction in Sydney so its no surprise it attracts over 1 million visitors a year. The gallery has a diverse collection including European, Australian, Aboriginal and Asian art. I was surprised to see Picasso, Monet, Freud and Cezanne all rubbing shoulders in the European Art gallery. While we meandered through the galleries at our own pace you can catch various free tours and events.We paid to see the "Pop to Popism" exhibition which was really interesting and worth the $20 entrance fee. Well worth a visit if you are in the area.

Popism. A visit to the Art Gallery of NSW should always be on any tourist's must do list.Now that Chiswick at the Gallery has opened not only do you see great exhibitions but you also enjoy some of Sydney's best food.

A Tentative Appraisal. The art gallery is housed in a magnificent building in the park area of Sydney. As a Yorkshireman, I am very pleased to say that entrance is FREE (certain special exhibitions excepted). The internal space was enormous and we never felt that anyone encroached on our space as we perused the art.The exhibitions that were available, Asian, European, Australian (settler) and Australian (indigenous) were very enjoyable. However, we have seen better displays of indigenous art at other Australian museums. We do not believe that the gallery has any very famous works, although it does have works by famous artists. The most noticeable piece in the European section was an enormous canvas of a French Napoleonic cavalry charge, although the central figure brandished an impossibly-shaped sabre. We noticed that many of the acquisitions of the art gallery were obtained a very long time ago. Perhaps this harks back to some previous Golden Age when the art gallery was awash with money.This review is entitled "A Tentative Appraisal" due to the fact that so many areas and floors of the gallery were closed for refurbishment. It felt that only around half to two thirds was actually open. Thus, although we score this establishment as "Very Good" we are only really assessing a part of its potential.

Art!. Wonderful Art to see from all styles of Artists, the building is also in a wonderful part of the City, particularly if you sit outside weather permitting, very pleasant to have lunch there, the Cafe is wonderful, the restaurant is nice too but the Cafe has a wonderful choice of food etc.

Amazing refresh on teh ground floor. We have been going to the art gallery on-and-off for many years and had grown very bored with the same-old same-old pictures "glued to the walls" (so it seemed) on the right hand side as you go in.We usually go every 3-4 weeks and spend an hour; not too long and we can focus on one section. Have a coffee and snack then off we go. Reasonably happy.We were simply delighted to find a week ago that they have significantly redone this whole area, and pulled out of storage a plethora of amazing works (both paintings and sculptures) that we had never seen before. Some of these had plagues indicating they had been bought around 1880 and I swear I have never seen them out on show!Well laid out, simply fascinating.Our heads were full after walking around this area, and could not do another section - quite frankly, we did not want 'the buzz' to be diluted, so we had our usual coffee and left; but very pleased this time.If you have not seen this latest set-up, you simply MUST go.
Great art. Very well laid out exhibition. Friendly staff. Great art, learnt some stuff too. I love art gallery's as they have such ambiance and this one was lovely.

Great collection of indigenous art.. Located amongst beautiful parklands in the heart of Sydney, it is very relaxing to stroll through the domain or along Lady Maquarie's Chair Park and call into the Art gallery. Great collection of Australian Art and interesting exhibitions. Pleasant café and shop.

Art Beats Footy!. I've volunteered at the gallery for 6yrs and every time I go to the NSW Art Gallery I feel that my soul is enriched by seeing various art works. Current exhibit of "Art Express", the works of HSC students on display is amazing and bodes well for the future of Australian Artists. More people vist the gallery in a year than go to the sports events.

Excellent Gallery. The gallery is close to the CBD and was an easy walk from Hyde park area. It has an excellent collection of 19th Century Australian paintings. There was an interesting exhibition called Asian Converstations which I found interesting.

A small, delightful gallery. A nice variety in this lovely collection, displayed in naturally-lit, airy galleries. Permanent collection rooms are free, but there is a charge for some of the special exhibits. Large bags and backpacks must be checked. My fav works: Sea Hath Its Pearls by Margetson, Queen of Sheba Visiting Solomon by Poynter, My Crown and Sceptre by Gotch, and some gems by Monet and Cezanne. Plus a nice selection of marbles and bronzes.

"A thing of beauty is a joy for ever". We visited The Art Gallery of NSW in Sydney in early March.We much enjoyed the exhibitions of Australian and European artists from the past,and they were displayed in a lovely cool building,a magnificent building actually. There were several further displays too,namely one of Japanese art and ceramics,and a very interesting one of Aboriginal art.there was good information on all exhibits and the facilities throughout the gallery were very good,likewise the cafeteria. Altogether a good visit and well worth it!

The very best art gallery. Have been the art gallery many time this year and are anticipating the Scotland national gallery's exhibition here later this year. The membership is very valuable and the armchair travel is awesome.

Improving. Recently visited when in Sydney to see the Pop to Popism exhibition which was excellent. Understand plans to extend the gallery which will allow for more of its vast collection to be shown. An easy walk from the CBD.

Small but perfectly formed.. This is a very good gallery with a "must die For view". the art is a good mix of Foreign and Australian art. It is well presented and clearly explained and a visit should not be missed when in Sydney.

An interesting couple of hours. At the moment they have a collection of Australian Pulp Fiction for the 40's & 50's. That together with the long term exhibits mak s for a good browse, especially if it is very sunny outside.

Respite from the hot weather, great collection of works. A nice break from the heat if nothing else! A short walk from the Botanic Gardens, so go there first and in the way out visit this free gallery. The gallery surprisingly houses a few works from Francis Bacon, Picasso and others, even a Van Gogh! The aboriginal work was fascinating.

Its not the Met or Tate but.... Its ok. Not exceptional.
For a tourist, it is wise to check what exhibition is running before going.
If you want to get a really good dose of high quality Australian art go to Canberra.

Gems in our Australian Art collection. We thoroughly enjoyed our time here. The environment is peaceful (except the school groups but they were all well behaved!). Even through the more modern PopArt display was in the lower galleries, we wished we had left more time for the collection on display in the upper galleries. If you are an artist or art lover, give yourself plenty of time. We visited the Cafe twice during our day here and sat in an outside patio area which was like a little oasis of quiet in amongst the buzz of the city. There are some memorable and iconic paintings on display here. Delightful.

Too bad security guy wrecks entrance with his attitude.... This is a terrific museum. I came too late for the pop art exhibit, but found lots to see anyways.Best part of this outstanding museum is the Free cost! (There was a cost for the pop exhibition.)Loved the older and established artists and their art as well as Asian & aboriginal art, but really enjoyed the (third floor art) from the older art students in Australia. The artists gave insight into their thinking and approach--- way cool.I woulda given 5 stars except the rude blond-pudgy security guy at front door demanding all to give up packs. Tone of voice, glare and attitude woulda been appropriate at a prison, not a gallery. Perhaps he would be better with a remedial public relations class or maybe just working at night when no public is around. I watched him offend several other people besides myself. 4 stars.Yes, yes

Pop Art Was Great. I went here specifically for the Pop Art exhibit. Seeing that exhibition does require an admission fee, but its well worth it. I've seen works by Lichtenstein before at the Art Institute of Chicago, but I've never seen Warhol or the other artists on display here. The exhibition was well set up, taking you through different locations and time periods in pop art history. You could not take pictures, and I understand why, but I wish I could have b/c there were a few artists works I would have loved to remember. They didn't have postcards for them in the gift shop either so maybe someday I will remember the ones I really liked.

Pop Art exhibition is well worth seeing. just saw this exhibition, but have toured the gallery for other exhibitions previously. The current exhibition hosts works by Australian and global icons, including Warhol and Lichtenstein. The gallery is worth touring just for the building.
Very Good Free Museum. We enjoyed our visit to this museum. It is free and has guided tours at 11am, 12pm and 2pm. It is much like a British Museum except it has Australian / Aboriginal art.
BRILLIANT. GREAT PLACE TO VISIT restaurant/café when busy not enough food ie running out just a very small complaint other wise EXCELLENT

Great art work. They provided free lock up. This is ticket free place. You will find so many great art work there. They keep updating recent art performances and work shows. Some of the art session are paid to entry. Inside, you can find toilet, restaurant where you can have a short break.

For Art Lovers. If one likes art do not refrain from visiting the Art Gallery of New South Wales . Stimulating beautiful & inspirational .Sadly there are Limited hours at cafe - restaurant Nevertheless . very nice experience . Afterwards if one is still energized cross over to Royal Botanical Gardens and take a refreshing stroll through the greenery.

Must visit. A must visit for art lovers. Wonderful permanent exhibition, particularly the aboriginal display. Watch out for the visiting exhibitions, currently Pop and Popism. Park down near Lady Macquries cahir and have a stroll along the harbour front or a picnic in the Botanical gardens. Free except for the temporary exhibitions. A donation is appreciated.

Lovers of Art will love it. The Art Gallery of New South Wales will not disappoint art lovers. There a magnificent collection of artwork throughout. Old Masters through to modern art. There are also sculptures. There are the Wynne Prize Exhibition paintings to see and also the Sulman and the Archibald at the times these competitions are held each year. There are also temporary exhibitions from time to time.

Good collection. The AGNSW is one of Australia's premier galleries and houses many works by both Australian and international artists.The gallery includes both a permanent collection of artwork and temporary exhibitions (generally of well-known international artists). The period of work housed includes everything from Renaissance to the Contemporary. Largely purpose built as an art gallery, the building itself is light and airy and provides a wonderful space to exhibit the works (especially when you compare it to many European galleries that have been converted from other uses and struggle with dim narrow spaces and very limited opportunity for use of natural light. The gallery sits within the Domain parkland and the two restaurant spaces have spectacular views of the harbour through floor-to-ceiling windows. A particular highlight for me was the Brett Whitely works.

Lovely museum. The love art musume is a place to hide away from the heat, stay in the place and view the exibitions which chances every few months. The building is a nice subject for painting, be sure to bring along a drawing block and painting tools to capture this

A feast of Aussie art. Let's face it, any Australian gallery is going to pale into insignificance against the likes of Musee D'Orsay and similar great European galleries, but nevertheless, it houses a terrific collection of Australian art classics and is definitely worth a visit.

Great gallery. Love this gallery - a great space to wander around and has some wonderful temporary exhibitions - check to see what's on. Located next to The Domain park, next to the Botanical Gardens and combines well with a walk through the gardens and visit to the Sydney Opera House. Has a good cafe/bar for a bite to eat. If you are in Sydney on a Wednesday evening they are open later for Art After Hours and on these evenings as well as Sundays they usually have free screenings of films which are themed to current temporary exhibitions. Check their website for details.

Truly worth a visit!. A first rate art gallery which is beautifully positioned, well run and most importantly has a great collection. The level of this and other Australian cultural centres improves every time we visit. A real credit ti Sydney and Australia. Carry on the great work, and the dining facilities are also excellent,well priced and served with a smile.

I love this place.. This a wonderful place to spend the afternoon Have a coffee and a nice lunch and then go and study the fantastic art works on display. Even a novice will find this place interesting. So much to see and learn.

A good day out. I saw the Pop Art show here while it was on tour and it was simply wonderful. They had great iconic works by Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein and David Hockney amongst others. It was an amazing show and I enjoyed the Campbell soup can's immensely having wanted to see them for a long time. The main gallery is also full of worthwhile paintings and sculptures

Not Just an Art Gallery - FREE EXCEPT FOR SPECIAL EXHIBITIONS!. There is an excellent café as well as a very good restaurant. An excellent book shop which also carries art supplies. The Aboriginal Section is on the very lowest floor but is well worth a visit. The Asian Section is also very good. I love the Archibald and associated exhibitions which carry a small charge.It is nice to walk back to the centre of the City across the lawns of the Domain but if you are stuck for time you can catch a bus from outside the Art Gallery back to the Queen Victoria Building in the central CBD

The Art Gallery of New South Wales. One of the best art galleries I have visited. It is large so there issomething for everyone to look at whatever their taste in art.There are always special exhibitions too.Its setting is beautiful. There are restaurants where people canget snacks or more if they wish.

Something for everyone. Great gallery with a good range of styles to suit most tastes. Check their website for special exhibitions which can be excellent. The food venues are expensive and disappointing and in my view should be avoided.

Well worth a visit even if its not a rainy day. The special exhibitions are always worth a look, the recent Pop Art was fantastic. The cafes and restaurant are always busy but the food is good if not a bit expensive.Some beautiful art in a beautiful building.
Lost in art. What a great place fora quick "art fix" or spend a leisurely day absorbing the atmosphere. Great for couples, families and students alike.

teach your kids to use their "inside voice". I went to the gallery for a quiet time to reflect and view the artwork, however I was constantly bombarded by children whose parents thought it was okay to let them run around yelling in the building. I understand that children need an outlet, however I don't think the art gallery was the place. If not for the noise I would have had a much more enjoyable time. I felt rushed as I was trying to get away from the rowdiness, so I think I may have missed a bunch of pieces. What I did manage to see and enjoy was truly beautiful.

Pop to Popism. If you are a fan of Pop Art, this is something you will devour! There are works from all the greats and not just a few. I was thrilled to see so many of Andy Warhols work personally. I found very few of them not worth a good look and reading of it's rundown. There is also a guided tour, the recorded tour or just wander through yourself. Very enjoyable!

Great attraction. This has a little bit of something for everyone. Good value for the money, and a lot of very interesting rocks, birds, and local history rolled under one roof. Definitely one of the top attractions of Sydney.

Small but excellent collection. We especially enjoyed the temporary exhibition about Pop art that was on at the time of our visit. The main collection is a lot smaller than we were expecting and this was compounded by most of the Australian collection of pictures being withdrawn because of ongoing building works. What we were able to see though was worth going for and it's free to view too.We lunched in the cafe on the basement level and it was an excellent lunch at a reasonable price. It gets very busy at peak times, so might be worth eating a bit earlier or later to avoid the queues.

An amazing collection. I went here not expecting too much and I was greeted with a very fine exhibition of art from around the world.The Asian collection is magnificent and I spent a lot of time looking at each piece from Ming vases, Buddha's and beautifully made Samurai Swords to name a few.The European and Australian collections are also very fine, with pieces by Picasso, Bacon, Cezanne and Freud. Also watch out for a piece called 'The visit of the Queen of Sheba to King Solomon' by Sir Edward John Poynter, which I personally found inspiring.There was also an exhibition on Pop art on, which I fully recommend going to see; it was incredibly interesting.Definitely one of my Sydney highlights.
lovely paintings. spent the whole day almost at the gallery.loved all the displays and very piece of work was exquisite.look forward to going again next time i visit sydney

Always good. I always enjoy wandering around the AGNSW, and this time was no exception.My favourite painting is Sydney Heads 1865 by Eugene von Guerard. It shows the view across Vaucluse to the heads, before the area was urbanised. Very interesting, and well worth looking up, in the first or second gallery on the right as you come in.Hope you like it.

Pop to popism exhibition. If you get a chance go and see this art exhibition it is excellent. The works by Roy Lichtenstein and Andy Warhol are fantastic but so are those by much lesser known Australian, UK and America artists.

A nice cultural input during the walk in the Gardens... The Gallery offers a big exibition of different arts, and you find this as a pleasent interruption, and need a little air conditioning, then this is a nice place to spend an hour or more.There is no admission fee,

Sydney Saturdays. An island of cool serenity in the Heart of Sydney........if you have a liking for Art of any type then this is a MUST ! The impressive building houses a rich permanent collection of Australian and Indigenous art , a Café and Restaurant with excellent food, and frequent Special Exhibitions ( Picasso, Monet and Warhol have featured ) and the annual Archibald and related Prize showings to boot. Entry is free but Specials are not .Tip (1) Join the Friends of AGNSW for priority access to exhibitions, a Members Only Library and Rest Area and many enjoyable Friends events throughout the year including Preview Evenings of shows.Tip (2) Park at the Domain Parking Station ( Flat Rate at weekends) and stroll up ;Tip (3) The Botanical Gardens are just across the road - a day out in themselves ! My most favourite place in Sydney and a wonderful place to meet up with friends.

Indigenous Art. Attendants were knowledgeable about the works. Some eye opening and thought provoking exhibits. Well hung on the whole but sometimes light glare spoiled appreciation. Adequate labelling but more info would be helpful. Cafe good and Chiswick's restaurant serves excellent food over looking the river. Service is excellent. Plan 2 trips. You can't see all of the collection in one go so plan for 2 trips

Gallery and Gardens. A fantastic collection of Australian and International art, for my visit Pop to Popism . Fantastic afternoon. Staff excellent knowledge and the guided tour made to experience all the more interesting. Relaxed feel topped off by lunch at the Gallery Café next time we will try Chiswick at the Gallery.....Classy !

Fabulous art gallery with plenty to see. The Art Gallery of NSW is situated on one side of Sydney's botanical gardens, not far from Hyde Park, so it is very central and easy to get to.The gallery itself is free to enter and contains a large sets of exhibits set over a number of floors. There is plenty of variety in the artwork so there is bound to be something to interest most tastes.There is also a nice café/restaurant and gift shop.Wonderful that this is a free exhibition to enjoy and definitely recommended as a place to visit and enjoy for a few hours.
Beautiful. This is one of the best Art Galleries in the world. Very good collection of Australian fine arts and displays.

Don't miss this - it's a must-do!. I've been to Sydney a few times, but somehow had missed a visit to the gallery. No more - this will definitely be on my 'must do' list when I next return. The European art collection is world class, and the Australian 19th century collection provided a fascinating insight into the history of the nation. Whilst the 20th century Australain collection was not on view when we visited, it'll be on my list for next time. The gallery is comparable with leading international counterparts. Although the collection isn't large,it also enables you to really concentrate on each piece. Very nice cafe too!
Lovely. Very find museum of important artwork. The wife and I visited along and had a great time. High-quality museum, high-quality art. Would definitely recommend if you enjoy artwork.

Fine collection of 19th century Australian art . I visited at the end of January 2015 and was looking forward to seeing the collection of 19th and 20th century Australian art. The 19th century collection was fabulous being especially strong in Tom Roberts, Arthur Streeton and Charles Conder. Unfortunately for me the 20th century Australian works were not on view, and won't be for another three months, due to large refurbishment of the building. Instead I spent some time looking at their fine selection of art books and bought one on the modern Sydney artists. Had the modern Australian paintings been on view this great gallery would no doubt merit a five star rating.
Pop to popism. The current attraction is on Pop Art. On Warhol, Litchenstein andso more, its worth to give it a try. Really nice.

A wonderful look at Australian Art. The gallery has a wonderful display of Aboriginal artwork. Skip most of the exhibits upstairs if you are close to a European (London, Paris) or American Gallery (LA, Chicago, NY) as there is better stuff elsewhere. Head downstairs and see the innovative and clever aboriginal art.
world-class art gallery- a must see. always visit whenever I'm in Sydney as their exhibitions are very classy, and they have some of the best Aust paintings

Well laid out and pleasant to visit. It is good to see that the Art Gallery attracts many visitors. However, the number of people did not detract from the tranquility of the place and enjoyment of the wide range of art on display.

Always worth a visit!. This Gallery always has something to look at whether it is its permanent collection of Australian art and various collections or its touring exhibitions.We recently visited again to view the "Pop to Popism" which was outstanding.From Andy Warhol to Roy Lichtensteins comic style painting there was something for everyone.If you have time, lunch at Chiswick is wonderful.Great view of Woolloomooloo wharf and the Harbour.We will return

Some great exhibits...... There are some stunning works here both modern and traditional... It is a very manageable gallery... Not too overwhelming.... Well lit..large airy spaces..... Well mounted... With some refreshing write ups on exhibits...an uplifting experience ...some essential soul food....it is all free too...The shop carries an amazingly good/interesting range of books....Excellent place to spend an hour or two.....

Australian aboriginal Asian and European art. Maybe best in Australia on par with national gallery in Canberra.
You find European paintings from the 15th century, statues, and much more.
Very good section on Asian art, it is a pity the Australian modern art section is now closed,
reopening in April 2015.
a must see. the art gallery is very interesting to visit. Lots of history in the paintings and best of all its free

pleasure. It is such a pity that all the GREAT shows are only in Canberra, but this place really tries to please different tastes in Art. Well laid out,easy to walk, well indicated all good. Pity the "restaurant" on the top floor is so bad.

Surprisingly good. Did not expect to see such a strong European coverage including strong representations from 20th century artists such as Freud and Bacon. There is an extensive section of local and Aboriginal art and the whole atmosphere of the gallery is very relaxed. Very thoughtful and well presented.

"Pop to Popism" Exhibition. The "Pop to Popism" Exhibition was not what I had expected - it was so many times better! I was amazed at the wide variety of artworks on display, covering works from the 1950's to the 1980's. We did not use the audio guide, but I feel it would have added much information to my viewing, making it even more interesting. This exhibition covers a whole floor of the Art Gallery, so it is not an exhibition that you can move quickly through. There were a few couches where you could sit and consider what was on display, but they were too widely spaced through the exhibition. However, so much to see, so much to take in - the colours, ideas, the contrasts - and all of it enjoyable.

Million Dollar Views for Free. Easily connects to the Bourke St bicycle path, with bicycle parking available out the front. I went back twice in my week in Sydney, once to a free exhibition, and one to a paid. I enjoyed both. How lucky to be able to view artistic treasures for free, and I'm not even a rate payer in this city! There was plenty more to see as I barely scratched the surface. You could spend as much time as you wanted here, and if looking at art is your thing, a visit here is recommended!

Depends what is on. The Art Gallery of NSW hosts some great visiting exhibitions as well as housing some fine local and indigenous art. As part of a day in and around the harbour, this is worth a visit. And the cafe is a good place for lunch.

Stunning. This is a world-standard gallery with a wonderful range of art, often housing excellent temporary exhibitions. The atmosphere is relaxed and there is a very good informal restaurant downstairs - an absolute delight. In addition there is a formal dining room which is very popular.
pop art. pop art exhibition very good and the gallery shop always a good place to pick up gifts; Free exhibitions always good too

My Favourite Place in Sydney. I cannot visit Sydney and not go here, twice in the last 6 months and I am already anticipating my next visit. On this occassion we were drawn to the Pop into Popism Exhibition and it did not disappoint. Beautiful venue showcasing the most stunning of works, the galleries themselves are breath taking, the detailed architecture and the creaky wooden floors are delightful. We also enjoy coffee outside overlooking Woolloomoolloo.
The Sydney Art Gallery!. The AGNSW is "the" Sydney Art Gallery - let your feet do the talking and your eyes will be delighted!
