Loved the effort out into kids activities. We visited the Pop to Popism exhibition which was very interesting even though we are not particular fans. We were really appreciative of the effort that had gone into the kids trail through the gallery so adults can enjoy the paintings without being accompanied by a wringer! There is also a kids activity corner with templates to complete that we all enjoyed doing. Well done

Fantastic Gallery. Not particularly an "art" person, but I really enjoyed this gallery. Some of the paintings were incredible and it was amazing to see some original Picasso's and Van Gough's in real life, which even I could appreciate.While here we also visited the Pop Art exhibition which is a paid extra in the gallery, I wasn't fussed but my partner insisted we checked it out and again it was surprisingly enjoyable I would definitely recommend checking out the exhibition with original works by Andy Warhol etc, but even if you don't know any of the artists (which I didn't) it was still a cool exhibition to look around and I think even kids would enjoy it as it was very colourful.Overall, I'd definitely recommend visiting here, even if it's just for the air-con to get out of the heat of the park!

A must visit. We are a family of art lovers and so this was an essential visit for us, but even if you are more ambivalent, I can recommend this as a lovely experience, especially if you are in Sydney on a rainy day.

Pop art currently quite spectacular. Im no art critic and I like what I like. The current exhibition at the AGNSW is very well worth a look at. I always find it exciting to see works of art in the flesh that you have seen many times in print, and this exhibition will tick many of those boxes. Great gallery as well, my second visit, and the last time there we saw the Warriors exhibit with the Chinese soldiers.

Best cafe in Sydney. Great gallery. Beautiful building. Lovely surrounds, so can enjoy the sights & scenery inside & out. Also has the best family-friendly cafe in Sydney - worth the trip alone. Fabulous peaceful setting overlooking water, innovative, healthy accommodating, accessible and friendly!

Awesome Gallery!. I really enjoyed my visit to the gallery. It is walking distance of the Royal Botanical Gardens and St. Mary's Cathedral, so this was convenient. The gallery offered some amazing pieces. I really enjoyed the Asian pieces and Aboriginal pieces. The eatery was very nice as well. I feel this is a must see while visiting Sydney.

Great Selection of Arts on Display. We like the varieties of arts on display. There are works from the older "classical" period and also from the modern periods. There is also a gallery on Asian Arts. There is a guided tour at 2pm while we were there. The curator is very knowledgeable.

fine edifice - mixed ceremony -great value. from aboriginal or Papuan to transitional romance and australiana - it offers a remarkable set of collections some with a ticket- occupying an area and located within a fine exploratory promenade path

Still outstanding, on sixth visit from the UK. I come to Sydney regularly, and this is always one of my stops. Again, not disappointed on seeing the current collection on pop art, which is the largest I've come across anywhere in the world (52 countries, that is). Artists both internationally well known and local/NZ talent make it a true representative show, with over 200 exhibits. As to others' comments, a) this particular show is not free (the permanent halls are) and b) this one has a terrific kids' section where they can both play and experiment with creating pop art for themselves. Deserves every praise!

Well worth a visit.. Although it had a Pop Art exhibition on which I had recently seen we really enjoyed the aboriginal art section and the 20th century including some works by Freud, bacon and Picasso hitherto not seen by us.

Pop to popism worth a look. This exhibition gets the thumbs up from us and will appeal to amateur fans of pop art. We were surprised that we were familiar with quite a number of the works from the NGA. The exhibition is well set out and features famous and lesser known (to us) pieces. The biggest highlight was the Lichtenstein pieces and we also discovered Peter Blake. We had never visited the NSW art gallery before. We will return.
Pop Art is great in the flesh. Cafe was great, staff helpful. GREAT venue. NSW does itself proud with the Arts and this is a good place to start.

Great selection of art works. Such a great selection of works, there's something for everyone and it's free to get in. In a city where everything is so expensive, it's nice to have a wander round away from the sun without it costing anything. There is a paid section of the gallery which I believe changes exhibitions, so there is always the option to see something new.
Always a delight!. I love our wonderful Art Gallery. Whether it is to see a particular exhibition or to just stroll around the permanent collection - this is a great way to spend a few hours.

Excellent gallery - but they need activities for kids!. This is a beautiful art gallery - and is a popular spot for tourists. Some besutiful pieces of art from various periods. I was disappointed that there was nothing from Pro Hart or William Dobell on display despite their significant position in Australian History. I also find it unusual that an Art Gallery this size does not have a hands-on activity area for kids. Most regional art galleries have an interactive area for children to draw/create/engage. I asked at the information desk, and was told by the lady that there was nothing at all for children. Disappointed. You can, however, take photos inside. Entry is free. Parking will cost $7 per hour outside on the street (metered parking).

Great Australian art, and maybe a taste for more?. It was disappointing that the 20th and 21st Century Australian Art section was closed for renovation during our recent visit, but this gallery is always worth a visit. Whatever your preference is among the Australian artists or genres, you will find some great works to enjoy and ponder. A free phone app helps your visit (once you master it's rather complex structure) and you can even use their free wireless access to download it!For Australians who have not travelled, it provides a small taste of great historic and international artworks, and hopefully it will I still in you a desire to visit the great European and American galleries, as it did for me.
Pop to popism. Highly recommended, it was very nice to see the display of these very famous pieces of art. Nice staff.

Great but in unexpected way. This museum has a surprisingly outstanding European collection. We came to mainly see the aboriginal art but that was barely better then a tourist gift shop. The European collection is well worth the stop, even if for a little bit. The Asian collection was unusual and very interesting, with a great modern twist. I would have gladly spent more time there but it was violently cold inside!

At times it can be great.. Everything about the AGNSW is classy. It is a beautiful gallery. I just widh the exhibitions in the contemporary galleries would change more regularly. Surely there is much more in storage that the art that is displayed for 12 months or more at a time. I would come back more often if the Collection was featured more widely.

Culture in the Colony. Set it the perfect surrounds of the Botanic Gardens it offers a great chance to view masterful works ant no costs.
Whilst you are able to have a meal withing the building I am not sure the cost warrant the venue.

Popped in for some art. The Pop to Popism Exhibition was by far one of the best exhibits I have been to. This was a large exhibition and was well worth the visit. The layout and flow were excellent and I would recommend the exhibit to both young and old. When you have finished in the Pop to Popism exhibit you can browse all of the other terrific art on display at this fabulous venue. Plenty of choice to catch a bite to eat and access for the disabled is also well taken care of. Perhaps the NSW government could provide a few more disable parking places at the front of the gallery.

Contemporary art, Asian art and iconic Australian art witha great restaurant and cafe. This is a much-loved gallery with locals returning regularly to enjoy both the changing exhibitions as well as the collection of iconic Australian images. It is a large open gallery space that is incredibly welcoming.There are some absolute treasures in the Asian section which I recommend you visit first for its intimacy before then visiting the Australian galleries.The new restaurant is worth every cent, but for something less expensive the cafe has a great menu.The gift shop is a great place for presents I could bang on about the artists represented here but visit their website if you want to see your favourite artist or ones you studied at scool.There are some lesser international works but as you will have seen better overseas I suggested you spend your time in works you don't know that will bring you more pleasure and less disappointment. Enjoy.
An important institution. Beautiful setting next to the Domain. One of the cultural hotspots of Sydney. There are usually excellent exhibitions showing here.

Great tour . Entered the gallery just before one of the tours started fortunately.We had a lovely tour guide which was extremely informative. Well curated pieces of art. Nice eclectic variety as well.Excellent cafe.Highly recommended.

It's pretty ok , one timevisit. It's a nice place to visit when u r bored with city traffic and rush. It's free entry so u can go have relaxed view of the art. It has some pretty awesome paintings. The aboriginal and the modern art where pretty cool . There is botanical gardens as well opposite to it as well. In all an hour should be enough
varied collection. Explore the out-of- the-way basement and top floor exhibits to get away from the modern tripe. Ceramic collection worth a look.

Always enjoy coming here. I have been going to the Art Gallery regularly for over 40 years now, and just love to go to be inspired and to take me out of the world for a while. Late night openings on Wednesday night have a lovely atmosphere, and it is great to see their guest speakers. You can become a member of the Gallery, and there is an area set aside downstairs with a library and cups of tea etc. for members. My last visit to the Gallery was during the Corroborree Festival in Sydney,where there was an enjoyable full program of interesting guided tours around some of the indigenous gallery, and artist talks. The cafe at the gallery has a nice atmosphere out on the verandah and quite a buzz inside, but I prefer to go elsewhere after some very ordinary experiences there recently.

Successful Function for Archibald Prize. We held a corporate function here during the Archibald Prize and it was a huge success. Staff were friendly, attentive and we appreciate their hard work.Venue is beautiful.

Makes you wonder where your money goes.... Art – by its very nature subjective – inevitably makes many judgements of a gallery just someone's personal view. You might hate Warhol, I might love his work. Neither of us, I'm sure, would claim to be 'right'.What is probably less subjective is the way a gallery's run. So, if you turn up to what is supposed to be the premier art gallery in a country's largest and most visited city and the 'current' brochure lists twelve highlights and exhibitions, of which only three are open, you start to ask questions...You would have thought that the gallery's curators would be overrun with artists enthusiastic to design up to date guides, but maybe that's just too hard and not 'arty' enough for them to tap into? I couldn't possibly know, but when the printed materials accompanying Kay Rosen's wall pieces include amazingly vacuous lines such as: “before you created this work, I don't think anyone had noticed that the word blurred has two colours in it – 'blue' at the start and 'red' at the end. And certainly no-one had blurred those two colours on the wall to make the 'r' in the middle purple ...”you really start to wonder...For more joyous nonsense and a good laugh visit this gallery. If you want to look at some less pretentious and much more (in my humble opinion only, of course...) interesting pieces visit the State library instead where there's not only beautiful architecture, up to date guides, and a complete absence of celebrity artists but, more often than not, some wonderful, thought provoking and original work on display.

Great collection. This gallery has a great permanent collection. Also have a pop-art exhibition at the moment. It's in a beautiful old classical sandstone building set in parkland near the botanical gardens and the harbour. Always worth a visit

Best Aboriginal art collection. The Australian and Aboriginal collections are the highlight. The Asian is good, and the European is not much. If you can, take an Aboriginal Art tour, and learn more about the intentions and culture behind the art.
great classic art. I loved the sculptures, set in the middle of gorgeous victorian rooms surrounded by Australian and european art of superb quality

Australia's history visually!. The Art Gallery is located a short walk from St James Station and for anyone interested in our history it is a must see! You will see painting from the earliest settlers depicting their struggle right through to modern day. It is a great way to take in just what Australia is about. The exhibitions are easy to access and there is a lovely restaurant and a cafe for those who just want to have a coffee. The cafe has a good view of Woolloomooloo and you can walk down to the wharf for a fabulous lunch at the Finger Wharf. Aboriginal art and Chinese art are also beautifully displayed which completes the whole picture of Australia and its evolution.

A real insight. An interesting mix of works from European and indigenous cultures.Do make sure you see the paintings by the Australian Impressionists - Charles Conder, Arthur Streeton and Tom Roberts. The heat just shimmers off their canvases.

Well worth a visit when visiting Sydney. The art gallery is situated in the domain, just a short walk from the CBD. We visited the Pop to Popism exhibition but also took a look at the indigenous art section which was very interesting. The cafe is a nice quiet place to relax with a coffee or lunch and there is a restaurant also with fabulous food.

Pop art exhibition. Really enjoyed getting close to Warhols and Liechtensteins. Took the whole family-a few of the exhibits are a bit racy consistent with avant garde work for its time. Beautiful building in lovely part of Sydney

Go see Pop to Popism on thru March 2015!!. A must for any pop culture appreciation-ist. The museum is impeccably clean, friendly, affordable and accessible. Definitely on your to-do list when staying in Sydney.

One of the best galleries in Sydney. I love to visit the Art Gallery of Sydney regularly! It has so much depth and variety. I alternate from doing a tour to wandering around alone. It is a very nice place to have lunch too!

Huge FREE Museum. My wife works at a museum and couldn't believe the quality of this museum that was FREE. Great way to spend a few hours while it was cloudy / rainy outside. There's some really good / unique art that I enjoyed, and I'm not an artsy person by any means.

Wide range of paintings. This gallery has paintings form Europe as well as Australia. Naturally not all artists can be found here but Joshua Reynolds, Gainsboro' , Picasso and Braque are represented. To my mind breadth is more important than depth: I have found the Uffizi in Florence rather hard work!
An Oasis of Calm and Culture. We really enjoyed this Gallery with its mix of European and Australian Art. Well worth a look and a good way to spend a few hours.

Popped into popism and had a ball.. The latest exhibition, Pop to Popism, was much more thought provoking than I had expected. All the icons are there and a few pleasant surprises. The Australian section showed how well artists here incorporated the concepts on pop art into our culture. Well worth a visit, and make a booking for lunch, walk ins are treated like unwelcome guests.
Always worth a visit. With free entry, a beautiful building, varied exhibitions and surrounded by parkland - why would you not??

Fantastic - don't miss the Pop exhibition. Apart from the great exhibition, for which i was lucky enough to join a great free guided tour by a very knowledgable and friendly guide, i can also highly recommend the lunch venue out on the balcony. And be sure to see the portraits of Margaret Olley (ground floor), absolute standouts.

Pop to Popism. Excellent giant survey of International and Australian POP art from the 60s onwards....what I like was the opportunity to be able to compare well know australians with all the famous international superstars - and one of my paintings is in the show!

History and beauty. We go every year to see the Archibald as well as any exhibitions they hold during the year. It has great restaurants as well as cafe and you can spend hours wandering around the gallery looking at all the incredible art works

Excellent. This was our first port of call in the city on this particular trip, and yet again it did not disappoint. We had a free guided tour of the Pop to Popism exhibition, which was fascinating. It is well worth going on these tours, the guides are very knowledgeable, and you can then return to whichever artwork you like to look in more depth and spend as much time as you wish.We always find this gallery friendly and helpful, a delight to visit. It is not dauntingly large as some galleries can be. Will return to dip in again soon.

So many classics. See so many original classics you've only seen in magazines.Free and air-conditioned.Take as many photos (without a flash) as you like.Shame the Modern Australia collection (eg Sidney Nolan's Ned Kelly series) is taken down at the moment for renovations.

Disappointing - poor visitor care. I have previously visited and really enjoyed the gallery. However, this time I was really disappointed. I go to an Australian gallery primarily to see Australian art. The C20th gallery was being refurbished but most of the gallery staff seemed unable to explain this. When asking for directions to C20th Australian art I was directed to C18th European (where, of course, the gallery cannot compete with the galleries of Europe). This suggests a very poor training of staff and lack of commitment to the visitor experience. Check before you visit if you want to see particular paintings.
Wonderful museum. I visited museum all around the world, and this one is really great, you can find a lot of artists from everywhere, which makes your visit really interesting

Art Gallery - a must see. I enjoyed just looking at all the different art, we had lunch there at a nice cafe and the food was good and not to expensive. Service good. The day we went they had a person playing the harp and someone playing flute so that was very nice to see and hear. The art works are so amazing to see and such talent. Dislike well nothing I could say as enjoyed the whole experience.

Go! :). This is a beautiful museum, even if you are not interested in art. You get a good view over Sydney from the restaurant or cafe, it is cool (almost too cool) and has free wifi. The art collection is very impreesive and there is something for every taste.

Pop to Popism. Visited the current recent exhibition and was blown away by the size of the exhibition. Artworks from the 1960 and forward showing how art and popualrism of the 1960 emergy in cartoon, billboards and signages generally. The major piece was Brett Whitely's Amercian Dream. An enormous piece ot say the least.

Worth the visit if you enjoy a dabble in art. The art gallery had different levels of some very interesting art and some not so interesting, however worth the visit also for the airconditioning to relieve yourself from the heat waves Sydney endure.

Art lovers paradise. Well worth a visit, especially at art show events. Enjoyed my visits there, have been a few times and will love to go again next time something special is featured. Beautiful old building in the heart of Sydney - time out there from hustle and bustle well worth it!

Fabulous Gallery. Free exhibitions are fantastic in the range, quantity and quality of the artwork. Easy to find your way around. Excellent modern and traditional art. Special exhibitions change throughout the year and bring variety and interest for all. Fabulous location, walk from the the city. Fantastic restaurant and cafe.

Unexpectedy great. Today I went to see the Pop Art Exhibition and was so surprised with this exhibition. It was great to go during the week as there were few people there so seeing the art works was soo much better without 10 plus people in front of the art work. It was well presented with a great variety of works. The American and European works are in separate rooms then you step into the Australian room. The difference is amazing. These paintings are full of light. It was wonderful to see fantastic works by Any Warhol et al. I loved the huge work by Brett Whitely. A must see
Great Pop exhibition!. An amazing exhibition of modern art.Nothing to not like.Wonderful walk through the gardens to get there.

True Art. Those who loves art.. this is a place you shall not miss.Been there in 2009 so i'm sure at the point of writing this review there are many upgrading going on.I'm not an art person but going to the art gallery is a MUST in Sydney!!!

Two enjoyable Sundays spent here. my partner and I so enjoyed two Sundays at the art gallery. The first was to take in the general exhibitions and to also stumble upon a free music concert with a brother and sister playing the harp and piccolo/flute....so enjoyable. The following fortnight was to attend the new exhibition of POP ART (charge for this but well worth it). This is on until March 2015 so well worth the time. We also returned to enjoy another concert of 3 young ladies playing woodwind instruments. These concerts are free and you will certainly be entertained and enthralled. Enjoy yourselves, we certainly did.

An iconic place to visit in Sydney. We try to visit this wonderful gallery several times a year, usually for the special exhibitions, because we don't live in Sydney,and it gives us a good excuse to visit the "big smoke". This time it was the "Pop to Popism"- a fascinating look at some of the very different art of the 60's to 80's- Warhol, Lichtenstein etc. Brilliant! But the permanent galleries are also a must see, with a wide range of styles, periods and genres. Anybody who wants to see 19th century Australian art should make this gallery a must see! The Indigenous and Asian art galleries are also amazing! A good cafe and shop with wide range of merchandise make it a compulsory place for all art lovers to visit!

Practically Educational.... I just went for an enjoyable walk around the gallery and got to see some incredible modern art some graffiti pieces and some controversial stuff too. It was the third Sunday of the month so there were Art teachers supplying pencil and paper chairs and boards and giving tips and pointers on how to sketch or improve your drawing technique as we sketched the sculptures in the gallery. I stayed until it closed. The POP-ART gallery was also there at the time, its a little pricey so I decided I should go and look at that another time instead of rushing through it and missing out on the free art lesson. :)
Travelling exhibits excellent. Make an art museum a part of every city you visit. The travelling exhibits make it well worth it. Once we discovered a post-Impressionist exhibition.

Framed History and Perspective : A Trip To The Art Gallery of NSW. If you're keen to introduce your children to Australian art, or just looking for an opportunity to expose them to some creative culture, this venue is a must stop. It is free and relatively easy to get to either by public transport or private car. Each gallery is spacious and easily accessible making them a good gallery to take children to. Check out the Kid Bucket List for more details.

Inspiring permanent collections.. This gallery is one of the best, it boasts a beautiful building which houses some of the best permanent collection artworks I have seen. There is regularly world class exhibitions on show. If you appreciate fine art then you must include this gallery on your list of places to visit.
Pretty rated!. Went to Pop to Popism at the Art Gallery of NSW, was very impressed with the range they had. Some amazing art!!

Lovely Gallery. We visited to see the Pop to Popism show, and thoroughly enjoyed it. The "Popism" means the range is wider than one usually sees in this sort of show. Then after a delicious soda in the cafe, we toured the rest of the gallery. The general collection included two Freuds & 5 Bacons, Gormley & Moore (my UKcentric comfort zone) and some really interesting 19th century Australian artists - including a lot of fabulous women artists. The Asian section was also fascinating - sitting ancient & modern side by side, including works by Kapoor & Ai Weiwei. We spent the whole afternoon here, and thoroughly recommend it.

More than just an Art Gallery. A must for travellers or locals alike. This art gallery houses some of Australias iconic artists as well as some of the European masters. Regular changing exhibitions make for regular visits. The mix of old masters, classic, modern and sculptures along with a good selection of dining options make this an enjoyable outing that shouldnt be missed.

a really good gallery. a great gallery as far as the galleries in Australia go.The Aboriginal art section is great.They have re done the Asian art section in a very interesting way. Also recommend going on their free tours of the collections, very informative friendly staff
Pop and Popism. This is a world class exhibition based on international and Australian Pop Art. It is the summer blockbuster and shouldn't be missed.

Beautiful gallery - must visit in SYD. Visited on my first day in Sydney. Beautiful artworks. Best of all, staff is lovely. Museum staff or guards tend to be really intimidating and sometimes u dont enjoy the experience, but the staff here make you feel really welcome. They also have weekend activities for kids which is awesome.

Quick lunch with art. Love to visit this place for a quick lunch in between my business appointments. Always fresh, always well prepared and served with a smile. The ambience of this place is supporting of wide thinking and bright ideas. Come along and try for yourself....

Giving this a 5 star rating based on the current exhibition .... Pop to Popism is a great little snapshot of this 1960+ art movement. This gallery is pretty lazy and doesn't try and do anything different but this is still worth visiting. They are some really great Warhols and more. On the ground floor, at the moment, there's a really nice photograhy exhibition of three photographers on the road, both in Australia and overseas in the 70s and 80s - I particularly enjoyed the narrative of the Indian trip ...

Priceless Art for free!. Rodin, Gaugin, Van Gough, Francis Bacon, Andy Warhol and Picasso all for free! It is opposite the Domain and The Pavillion restaurant. If you're in Sydney you need to go here! A wonderful expeience in a lovely setting.

Plenty of variety for every taste. Whether you're a fan of wacky modern art or prefer traditional sculpture, portraits and landscapes, you'll enjoy a visit to this free-admission museum on your way to the Botanic Garden.
Pop exhibition and more. Always worth a visit for fine art collection. The POP Art exhibition was of greater interest than we thought it would be

Good for non ART Lovers TOO. Spend two or more hours here to ponder around the great diversity of exhibits of this gallery. From Asian culture, to European paintings, and of course plenty Australian unique. My only disappointment was that their aboriginal art and culture section was closed during my visit for maintenance, so do check beforehand (even that won't change the reality). However, the small groups of young kids led by their teachers sitting before selected paintings for briefing, quiz...add so much live to the gallery.
Just delightful. Such history lovely large gallery, stunning forms of Art at every corner! Must see, must do, will entertain all taste

Loved the Pop expo. We went to the Pop expo last week. It was an excellent collection. As well as a wide range of international items (US, UK, Europe, etc) it had a good set of Australian pop art from the 60s and 70s. The tour we joined was informative too. There was certainly enough to make us want to go again.
Sydney Art Gallery. Interesting exhibitions a little cramped but the regular gallery rooms are light filled and spacious. A very good cafe on site with a variety of food and drinks selections.

Wow! A treasure of a place.. This mus tbe the most gorgeous place to visit. You do not need to hurry, just staunter, enjoy, go into the world of the artists and be taken over by the charms of the Art Gallery. I have been to many special shows, they were well curated and stunning but I also enjoy the other galleries where Australian art is on show and it is so good to have access to such treasures. A wonderful place to visit again and again.
Admission was free here. I enjoyed the different variety of the pictures by different painters here, but it can be a long walk for elderly or adults with children

One of my favourite places to visit in Sydney. The AGNSW is set near the Domain and the Royal Botanic Gardens, so a visit there to take in the art work can be accompanied by a visit to either of these lovely outdoor attractions.

Art Gallery NSW Great ON A Hot Day. The art gallery of NSW may not bet the grandest of art galleries, on the outside entrance , there are panels that where never completed. What it does have is a wonderful collection of Australian artists, from Whitley to Nolans. After you have walked to Mrs Macquarie Chair, It nice to pop in for some lunch or a cuppa, As it an Art gallery it has the best air conditioning in Sydney, on a hot day it is so good to cool down before you continue to explore this wonderful city.

Sydney Art Gallery. Basic art collection, often they have a special collection of art-works from a great artist. Great coffee & food in the Gallery, and also in the restaurant just outside. Situated in a great setting (not surrounded by a lot of other buildings). A short walk the the Botanical Gardens

Stacks of variety & good coffee - and FREE!. A beautiful art space, classic facade with beautiful modern interiors. And FREE! Next to Botanic Gardens, worth combining the two. The cafes (more than one!) is far better than the Gatdens. A mix of classic & modern art with changing exhibitions. If in Sydney for a while, they run art classes and tours. Very well liked and supported by locals. Child friendly with a regular kids participation programme.

Art Gallery of NSW. As I live in Sydney, this is one of my favourite places to go. I catch a train to Circular Quay, check out the MCA (Modern Art Museum) before walking around by the Opera House and through the Royal Botanical Gardens to the Art Gallery. There is a bus from there back to the QVB (Queen Victoria Building) in the centre of the city.The Gallery is excellent and often has several exhibitions running concurrently - both free and some for a small charge.

Art, food, wine, vistas - all intriguing. The Art Gallery of NSW contains manysmall galleries and usually I prefer to focus on one type of art or one exhibition and give it all my attention. However, occasionally, I wander generally through all the exhibition spaces. The extent of my looking at art always depends on how much energy I have and whether all that looking becomes too exhausting. However it is possible to spend a whole day at the Gallery by balancing the looking at art with wining and dining at the cafes or restaurants, or simply staring out picture windows and enjoying the view. The exhibitions are constantly changing and so there is always an array of art works which are Australian, American, European, Asian, and African. Some are historical and some are contemporary, so depending on my interest on any particular day there is always something I will enjoy looking at.
Fish abd Chips at the Hotel. Brilliant. Value for money. The salt & Pepper squid was fantastic, and on a hot day, the bottle of wine also well enjoyed.
Lovely view & great food. Great, light innovative food for lunch. Lovely elevated outlook over Woollomooloo Bay & Botanical Gardens.
Amazing. .. spent many hours in this - with The Sea Hath its Pearls by English artist Margetson as my favourite - there is also a Frank Brangwyn there - Welsh artist! fabulous place

Take your time , lots to see..... I went for the POP ART special exhibition , then spent half a day wandering through my favourite sections. The collection of Asian Art is impressive and well displayed , I REALLY liked the Infinite Landscape video by Yang Yangliang ; can I buy it anywhere ? The Australian art is well displayed with a real sense of light and space around it. Walk to the Gallery through the gardens , theay are very appealing. Stay for a meal ( food choice good and tasty) and dive into the Gallery shop. There are 6 or so books I would like but too heavy for the hand luggage ; perhaps next time. In the interim , I consoled myself with postcards. Gallery is free , except there is a charge for special exhibitions.

Dobells lot's of them & wonderful food. this is a great spot for any very special occasion on hand to enhance our experience were gallery guides as well as Dobells Drysdale & Streeton I know I enjoyed a meal & had some very nice wine top speeches good company however it was eclipsed by the art what a magnificent collection if you are in the vicinity any time soon don't miss this exhibition something for everyone.

Spectacular Venues under one roof!. Awesome spot for sightseeing, cultured and elegant galleries! When feeling peckish, have a glass of wine with classy and tasty meals at the restaurant. I'm in love with this place.

Nice gallery. The Art Gallery is free to get in to unless you are going for a special exhibition. It is an easy walk from St. Mary's Cathedral and wynyard railway station in the center of the city. Lovely walk in good weather as you walk through parks that have huge gorgeous trees to marvel at. When you get to the gallery the facilities there are nice and the restaurant makes good coffee and meals at reasonable prices. Try and get an outdoor table if the weather is good. I have been to the gallery quite a few times and really like the special exhibits when they are on most. the art is usually provocative in nature (but not always).

Great Gallery.. Had a lovely time viewing the many paintings/art work on show. It was great to see so many painting by Australian artists as well as the great European masters. I also loved the fact that the Gallery was right by the Botanical gardens which meant a very pleasant afternoon taking in art and nature.

The Archibald. We visit Sydney each year and fro almost 20 years we have delighted in the Archibald exhibition. Lucky for us the change in dates worked, although we missed the vote this year. We have attended the special Amex viewing twice before & have enjoyed seeing some of the artists. Keep it up.

It's an art gallery just go. Ok so compared to art galleries around the world, the art gallery of NSW is small fry. And it doesn't get the big exhibitions like the national gallery in Canberra. Still it's on the harbour. It's beautiful and has some good works by Australian artists. It's one of those places I go to to relax have a coffee and stare at beautiful works of art. Again this is a space it's hard to not stay happy in. Just have a wander

Sophisticated, powerful, worth visiting. The Art Gallery of New South Wales in Sydney [free admission] is a refreshing relief from the tourist attractions in the city. It's an easy walk from almost anywhere, as it's several blocks from the back of St. Mary's Cathedral in the center of the city.Don't expect to see Old European Master paintings. Instead, go there to enjoy the Aboriginal Art downstairs and the colorful modern art. My visit will be memorable, and I returned home with wonderful pictures.

This is a cultural institution which ticks many boxes. I have regularly visiting the Gallery for nearly 15 years, attending weekly art history lectures and other lectures which cover a wide range of interest areas, including, philosophy, psychology, literature, civilisation, music etc as well as having the pleasure of viewing some wonderful works of arts. I feel very fortunate that one institution fulfils so many of my aesthetic and intellectual needs, so I never tire of visiting the Gallery

nice location and interesting painting. located in the botanic garden, it is a nice walk from Hyde park, the trees are majestic. the gallery at the ground floor is worth a look , with many Australian and European painters from the 19th and 20 th centuries. I also enjoyed the aboriginal gallery at the -2 level. Is it not big but there are some wonderful piece of art. and remember that the entrance to the museum is free.

Amazing. I went here to see the Archibald Exhibition but I also ended up visiting the other parts of the galleries. It's really a fascnating place. I was really surprised when I ran into the Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott inside the gallery. He was standing next to me and viewing the exhibitions as well.
Archibald Exhibition. Travelled to Sydney to see this exhibition...didn't dissapoint. Very busy as it was the last weekend. Amazing talent.

Much of it closed. Was bitterly disappointed with the art gallery. I had looked forward to showing my son, but was disappointed at how much was closed. Wish I had gone to the museum in my last morning instead. Not how I remembered it at all

It was way better than I expected. Walking through the gardens to find a classical building for the art gallery (the brisbane art gallery is an atrocious cement block), it was lovely for an Australian attraction, very grand looking. Inside was wonderful. I mainly went into the European section to find Monet and there were Constable, Cezanne and Degas, I was a very happy girl. There was also a European drawings - a free exhibit - that had Turner and Blake (no Dore), but I was very happy. Our art gallery (Brisbane) has only one or two important paintings, so this was heaven in comparison to Brisbane and even the National Gallery in Canberra.
Art Gallery of NSW. Is located within beautiful parklands overlooking Sydney harbour. With a fine collection of Australian,European,Asian and contemporary works.

Worth a visit. We discovered the art gallery after a walk in the Botanic Gardens. Great place to spend a couple of hours. I really enjoyed it and would recommend a visit. Leave the teenagers somewhere else for some peace and quiet.

Art in Australia. This is probably a better option than the trip to Canberra to see the gallery there. The art is a collection of European work from the renaissance onwards, to a wall of Lucian Freuds and Francis Bacons. The early art by European Australians and - the best part - modern Australian art is the thing to see though A few Sidney Nolans, John Brack, Brett Whitely, Russell Drysdale, Margaret Olley, and the portraits of Olley by William Dobell and Ben Quilty - these made the visit worthwhile.

Great place if you have a few spare hours Sydney CBD... or half a day.. The Art Gallery of NSW has always a good variety of permanent and temporary exhibitions on display and if you have a few hours in the Sydney CBD, this place never disappoints.

Take your time!. Huge gallery with both permanent and currant exhibitions, located just a short walk from the Opera House and city centrum. Take your time, this is a huge place, with alot of paintings, installatins etc. Perfect for a rainy day, or just when you need a break from the sun!

Yes, it is!. Yes, it's an Art Gallery and it does it's job very well. Both permanent collections and curated exhibitions are always world class. Excellent facilities in terms of cafeteria and food choice. Worth a visit by those travelling to Sydney as you can couple a visit with a stroll through the Botanic gardens to get there. Also has an excellent Asian Art collection.

Archibald visit. During a quick visit to the gallery I had a small meal before entry to the exhibition. I ordered a simple tea and snack at the large cafe downstairs. The tea and one scone was over priced and took ages to order and we waited ages at the table. What happened to the old cafe they used to have. It was so expensive and so ordinary!

Great place to experience. Being from the outback, we don't get to see many Art Galleries on a regular basis so visiting the NSW Art Gallery in the Sydney Domain was a treat. We had been there before. We were fortunate to visit when the Archibald Prize was exhibited. What a wonderful experience. The entry is free but special exhibitions have an admission fee. We walked around for a few hours and then had a lovely stop at the café. It's a wonderful treasure and well worth a visit.
Looking. Always something interesting to see at the Art Gallery & it's free.You will pay a fee for special exhibits

Domain Park Cafe across the street. Cafe in the park snack lunch and ginger beer. Great setting after having spent a glorious 2 hours in two sections of the gallery. Reasonable cost cozy atmosphere and quality fish and chips for a snack lunch.

Always worth a visit. When planning a visit to Sydney I automatically think of including a visit to the Art Gallery. It's in a glorious location by international standards. There's always a new exhibition. And if I don't fancy seeing the latest one then there are all my old favourites in the permanent collection to say hello to. The Gallery's shop is good, and so are the temporary shops that pop up alongside special exhibits. The canteen-style restaurant on the lowest level is busy whenever I visit and I don't like it greatly, but since it's on-site I usually end up there. The Gallery's volunteers do fine work and deserve visitors' appreciation.

A Must see in Sydney. I'm now a proud member of the art gallery. Love it and everything about it. Great exhibitions, talks and cultural events. beautiful space. Excellent location for a stroll in the Botanical Gardens after or before. Go there!

wonderful place to lose yourself for a day. Recently I attended a "highlights of the Aboriginal collection" at the gallery. I have wandered through this gallery on many occasions but attending the most informative guided tour gave me a whole new way of appreciating this extensive collection of our first people. I am intending to do these tours more often as they broaden my understanding of the wonderful art we have on our doorstep.

Archibald Trip. Make sure you get a free trip from one of the guides as it greatly enhances the enjoyment as you learn so many background details of the paintings. I did the 2pm after having lunch with a super view.

Quite a bit of the gallery is closed for a new exhibition. Recently visited the gallery and found most of the lower floor gallery spaces to be closed at the gallery gears up for a new exhibition or revitalising the rooms. So was a bit underwhelmed by this visit. Having said that, the gallery is normally a great place to visit where you can spend half a day wandering through a pretty collection of art from various time periods. When the lower floor spaces reopen, we'll be back again.

Wonderful and free!. Sydney is not a cheap place to visit, so it was refreshing to find that a visit to this fabulous gallery was free. There's some great works to check out here including contemporary and Aboriginal works of art. The restaurant is very popular too and it's no enigma to see why. Definitely a great place to refuel.you could spend a day here easily, as there is so much to look at.
Very Interesting. I think it was worth a visit. Very beautiful space, and interesting collection.

For art enthusiasts and not so enthusiasts. Houses a vast collection of art works - paintings & sculptures.Works are divided into galleries: Australian art, aboriginals, classic and contemporary. Famous Van Gogh and Picasso and others can be seen here. And the best part: Admission is FREE. You may want to check other featured exhibitions on the date of your visit: http://www.artgallery.nsw.gov.au/collection/Conveniently situated inside Royal Botanical Garden. Worth the visit.

Who doesn't love art?. Despite the weekend crowds the Art Gallery of NSW is always worth a visit. We were here about a year ago and there has been a good rotation of art with only a couple of major installations remaining as they were from our last visit. And its free! Take the kids, take visitors to Sydney, take a break from the daily grind and immerse yourself in the art.

Australian collection. Worth ducking in for an hour for an overview of Australian art. Check on line in advance to see about docent ours. The Royal Botanical Gardens are adjacent and well worth a visit.
Definitely worth a visit!. The Art Gallery of NSW was an real eye opener.The Australian & European art pieces were well selected and suited the atmosphere of the whole art gallery.

a legendary site. The Gallery is a marvel. So much to see. So beautifully displayed. A visit to the Gallery is very special. As well I had sat through the lecture series each Thursday for 2 years. It's a magical insight into art through the ages and very, very informative.

Archibaldness. Father's Day at the Archibald exhibition - what a great way to spend a Sunday! Great portraits by local artists - Anh Do's portrait of his father and Adam Goodes stood out to me as really great pieces of work. The kids were kept entertained with a really clever guide that encouraged them to interact with the work (not literally, of course). Also saw some beautiful pieces by artists such as Monet in the main collection. Definitely worth your time and a visit, and if you can get a seat in the cafe, the food and coffee are worth the wait.

Second visit and still AWESOME!. This was my second visit to the Art Gallery of NSW during another short visit to Sydney. The gallery was busy this time with the infamous Archibald Prize exhibit. Lucky enough I was there early enough in the mid-morning to get in before the line ups got too long. I purchased a double ticket for the Archibald Prize Exhibit and the Theatre of Dreams Exhibition. My visit was during a weekday so there was lots and lots of school tours which got a little loud at times. If you can time it right get in for some free tours in each exhibit, the extra information on the background of each piece of an exhibition is fascinating.

A NSW Icon. You can easily loose a full day in this art gallery. I love it here. The only negative for me is the parking. The ticketing rangers are always out and find it very lucrative. With the park across the road, you could take a picnic lunch and really enjoy. (just solve the transport issue first).
Different. We loved visiting the Art Gallery of Sydney, because it was our first contact with the Australian artists.

Nice to visit but not as good as the QLD art gallery. The building was the main delight but the art display wasn't specular. The art display obviously changes from time to time so it is worth the visit for the building alone

Great art library. So travel through the old paintings and find your way down the wonderful blood red marble stairs. Ahead is the art gallery library. A perfect place to catch up with the latest journals or research your favourite painter. Free!

Satisfying culture and meal. It is a great attraction to visit with both the permanent exhibits and the visiting ones, and then to be able to sit outside eating a well prepared meal while overlooking the gardens etc is well worth a visit

A real glorious temple to the gods of the art!. Designed by the same architect who built Central Station, W Vernon, the Art Gallery not only looks like a Greco-Roman Temple, but is indeed a sacred space for the arts. Every time I step inside it, I get a spiritually uplifting experience and I can't help but tread with care and respect. It is an awe inspiring place.
wow. this place is free to visit and huge!!!! I loved it finding it can be difficult but fun the native collection of art fill two floors

A fantstic visit. It's a great museum with combination of old and modern art collection where you'll love visiting. It is located in the beautiful Royal Botanic gardens and you can spend a lovely and memorable day at Royal Botanic gardens while visiting this museum.

unexpectedly sophisticated. A wonderful selection of artists - but have you tried the National Art Gallery in Canberra for a knock-out? Both art galleries have excellent international exhibitions and encourage local artists.

Great Space. combining both the modern and the old, this gallery is a most relaxing space to wander through. We actually had a guide show us through the modern art sections and she was so knowledgeable and interesting. Recommend highly. We wandered through the whole gallery ourselves after the tour and explored seeing some brilliant artwork. There are also some lovely views out over the harbour from the generous seating areas also. Dont miss it.

Archibald Prize exhibition 2014. I have not visited the Art Gallery for many years. This year I made a point of squeezing in a short visit during a three-day stay in the city. The Archibald Prize exhibition is currently on display. I must say I was a little disappointed. I expected to see a huge selection of over-sized, extraordinary entries but the number of items on display was quite limited. Also on display was a Japanese collection of kimonos, artworks, masks, etc. Excellent.I had time for a quick stroll through the permanent galleries. Lots of old masterpieces, sculptures, etc. The Art Gallery is situated on the edge of the The Domain, a huge park extending down to the Harbour edge. I took a taxi to and from the Gallery but if you have time, why not walk through Hyde Park, to the Doman and to the Art Gallery. I paid $15 to see the Archibald and Japanese exhibitions. All other levels of the gallery offered free entry. A good way to spend a few hours.

Great way to spend a day. Have never made the time to visit this Art Gallery and was not disappointed when i did. Easy walk across the park from St James Station. Great collection of Australian Artist and Aboriginal Art, as well as special exhibitions. I will make a point of returning to this gallery as there is much to see.
Love the display. I had never realised just how big the Art Gallery The displays were different from my expectations, but I enjoy the 4 hours it took me to view it all.

A great collection. Although there were 2 special exhibitions on, I was able to view the rest of the permanent collection of art, mainly by Australian artists, for free. I particularly liked the works by Aboriginal artists on the bottom floor.

Well worth a visit. Interesting permanent collection, especially the Asian art section which is free. Also has regular major paid exhibitions such as the Archibald, Wynne & Sulman prize exhibitions on currently $12 adult entry. Have included photos of my favourite from each of the three exhibitions. Transport tip. Parking is very expensive in the area and walking is a little further than you think. Get the 441 bus which leaves outside QVB building in York St and drops you outside the front door of the gallery. This bus runs every 20 minutes weekdays during gallery opening hours.
Boring. boring collection, i think that in europe we have more and more and more better collection than here but here is more curated. <better go in other parts

Lovely Aboriginal Art. We visited the art gallery with my family(2kids) and we really enjoyed our visit. The kids usually get bored looking at art, but they loved the Aboriginal art section. The gallery is much bigger than it looks and there's lots to look at. The cafe at the gallery is a bit expensive, and not very special, so it's better to get lunch somewhere else, other than that everything is great. We went on Thursday, but found out that it's open late on wednesdays. So if you want to go there in the evening make sure you go on Wednesday, it closes at 10pm.
Great way to spend an afternoon,. Free and full of culture. Worth the visit and it is located in beautiful gardens. They also have a yummy coffee shop.

Beautiful and interesting exhibits. We were fortunate enough to see the Archibald Prize exhibit which was an amazing showcase of Australian talent. The Sol Lewitt exhibit was fascinating as my first experience with conceptual art. We were fortunate to have the exhibit explained and unpacked for us by Alexandra Gregg, a staff member at the gallery. She was very gracious, knowledgable and clearly wanted to help us understand the work before us.

Best art gallery in Australia. Well, I only really stayed in Melbourne and Sydney. I definitely thought AGNSW did a better job of establishing a truly unique canon of Australian art. I definitely walked away with a better taste of what makes Australian art unique.

Great Australian Art. This is a fantastic Gallery and is full of classic Australian Art
The Gallery is well set out and always has interesting special exhibitions
The restaurant is also very good
Interesting collection. Really enjoyed the works by Australian artists. Good mix of different types of art in collection. Entry is free which is fantastic for a museum of this quality.
Amazing. What a beautiful Art Gallery. Fantastic exhibitions of beautiful paintings.This visit I loved the exhibition of New guinean tribal art

take it from a member. AGNSW is awake to locals and visitors alike. Stroll through the Botanical Gardens to find a home among the world's best exhibitions and enjoy food and drinks in convivial and calm surroundings. Thoroughly recommended to overseas' visitors.

Visit for the Archibald Prize Exhibition. Excellent exhibition, even though there was a lineup progress through the queue was quick. Restaurant was very good even though very busy we did not have to wait very long for the food to be served and the food was good.
don't miss it.. General exhibitions are for free. Very nice walk through the botanic garden. nice cafe. and then take the stairs down to Wooloomooloo
Very well constructed. Brillant, well set out loved most of the Art, very Clean, well priced, easy to get too, take comfortable shoes, be prepared to rake a few hours too

It's all about the art.. Great collections, beautifully curated and well worth a visit. Really enjoyed the C20 Australian Artists. Make sure you see Balcony (2). Free entry and late opening on Wednesdays.

Archibald Exhibit. We make a special trip to the Archibald Exhibit every year and were not disappointed by this year at all. The Gallery is always relaxed, lunch was good and reasonably priced, and the exhibits are always well lit with interesting narratives. The Art Gallery staff are very pleasant and helpful. This is a "must" stop for us on every visit.

Wonderful. We visited the Art Gallery of NSW to see the 2014 Archibald prize finalists - fantastic! It was our first visit to the gallery and we will definitely be visiting again for future exhibitions.

One of my favourite places in Sydney. Lovel this place Well set out always good exhibitions. Great staff and a lovely cafe to eat at with an excellent view of a park in Sydney. A must visit venue for arty enthusiasts.

Sydney's only major art collection. Great permanent collection. Asian galleries are awesome. The Aboriginal gallery a treat for visitors to Australia. The temporary exhibits are usually world class. The cafe is very good with nice views from outside terrace on a warm day. On weekends there is organised kids activities and entertainment. Check website for times. Plus it's great to combine visit with a walk through botanical gardens which are next door.
Awesome. Diverse and wide ranging art from Monet, Picasso to modern Australian artists. The Cafe is very reasonable and has excellent food.

Fantastic Gallery. Our second visit. Unlike many reviews, we were there for the permanent exhibition rather than the Archibald. We love the Margaret Preston, Drysdales & the Pre-Raphaelites among others. The collection prior to 19th century is limited but the quality is first class. There is also an excellent cafe - see separate review!

Must see site in Sydney. My wife and i have visited the Art Gallery many times, but this is my first review for it. Today we visited the Archibald, Wynne and Sulman prizes- must see events on any art lovers calendar. As usual , an amazing diversity in presentation of portraiture, landscape etc. Always an absolute pleasure to see. And the Young Archies-portraits by artists aged 5 to 16 was also amazing. The gallery is a magnificent place to explore. In many visits, we still haven't seen all it has to offer, as the special exhibitions are so overwhelmingly good in themselves, but the magnificent 19th century Aussie art( Streeton, Roberts et al) is a stand out, and the huge range of genres, from traditional Asian and Indigenous art to the most abstract of modern art, with many great masters, makes the gallery what we consider to be one of the most important sites for visitors to Sydney. Don't miss it if you love and appreciate art!
Beautiful . I really appreciate this museum, was no fee tour and one floor was for 2 exhibitions 10$ each, but you could pay 15$ for both.
Great. Fantastic. heaps to see.. This was outstanding. It has heaps to see, and it is really well laid out. You must visit this place, even if you are in Sydney for a few days.
Always great exhibitions. It is a great place to explore in all styles of arts. The tickets and front desk service is far from ideal though.

Great things come in small packages. Sydney's art gallery is not huge, however it packs a punch in terms of stunning and relevant art pieces. This gallery has done wonders in making the art accessible and its not unusual to see people walk right up to the paintings, all but breathing on them! This is Art up close and personal. Sydney's Archibald exhibition in July / Aug each year is an incredibly creative representation of contemporary Australian art. The Archibald is a 'must see'. Given its location on the border of the Domain and near the beautiful Sydney harbour, tourists would do well to head to the gallery in the midst of a day walk through the Botanical Gardens and Sydney harbour

The Packing Room. A simple building......with an awesome collection of art from 19th-20th cent.......a few too many late life art loves for me..but it did truly kick back and remind me just how much I love art....thanks Mum!

Always something new to see. Our most recent visit to the AGNSW was to see the opening of the Archibalds. The exhibition is always interesting, sometimes controversial. But the joy is that you can leave those rooms and move through many, MANY other levels of art, from the super-modern to historical Australian artworks. Lovely cafe, too, with beautiful views. A nice place to spend a couple of hours, with expensive parking in the Domain a quick walk away.

Art Gallery Needs Time To Appreciate!. The NSW Art Gallery in Sydney Australia needs the person visiting to take time and to plan the visit. Limited paid parking is nearby but it is within walking distance of the CBD via the beautiful Botanical Gardens or from nearby streets close to Hyde Park.

Best Archibald exhibition. Worth getting in line at 10 a.m. to see 2014 Archibald prize-winning portraits at leisure before the crowds. Great variety and always controversial. Added bonus to wander out amongst the permanent collections.

Archibald Prize. The queue was massive for the exhibition so we decided to view the rest of the gallery - well worth it, so many extraordinary paintings to see, a day is not enough finish up with a cool drink in the cafe and check out the Art Gallery Souvenir Shop.

Archibald Prize. We travel to Sydney every year to visit the Art Gallery to view the Archibald Prize exhibition. This year was equal to past exhibitions that all are presented in a most professional manner.

Must be supported to be at its best. An excellent gallery. I would love to see a book covering the entire collection or easier still online.Over decades I have visited, at first reluctantly, my tastes have changed but I do enjoy reacquainting with long standing exhibits.The programs, educational, performance, archibald, biennial are always exceptional. This is a Sydney icon to be embraced, criticised, but always supported to be its best.

Wonderful art, bad cheesecake. We approached this gallery walking from the opera house through the domain. A nice, walkable distance from the Rocks and coming upon this beautiful, majestic building as we emerged from the park made the experience even more engaging. Wonderfully laid out, the rooms large enough to impress but small enough not to be overwhelming and the stories and explanations beside the pieces being very informative, this Gallery rated a second visit three months later upon our preparation for departure. The pre-Raphaelites were an absolute thrill to see. It was also my introduction to Australian artist Sydney Long, whose work I fell in love with.We returned the next day to take in the temporary exhibit, "America, Painting a Nation," which was an enjoyable, if brief, overview of American art with the usual suspects; Copley, Hopper, Whistler, etc. The gallery shop was excellent, however we found the café to be quite mediocre, with possibly the worst cheesecake I've ever had in my life. Gave the café a second chance upon our return visit and was equally disappointed. Then again, I don't go to museums for cheesecake.Professional photos 181 traveler photosEnter dates for best pricesCheck Inmm/dd/yyyyCheck Outmm/dd/yyyy83% Ranked #78 of 284 Barcelona B&B and Inns636 Reviews Certificate of Excellence 2013A recent review“Great hotel in Barcelona”reviewed 4 weeks agoSim132 Basel

A real Sydney highlight - don't miss it. The Art Gallery of NSW has many things going for it. A stunning location, a stately and beautiful building, amazing exhibits all year round and a loyal clientele of Australians and visitors every day of the year. There's also a fine gallery shop. We were there to see this year's entries for the Archibald Prize for portrait painting and were not disappointed. 54 varied and evocative portraits in every imaginable style, with helpful comments on each one. The entries for the Wynne Prize for landscape painting of figurative sculpture were also worth a look but, with few exceptions, were rather less impressive. Stephen Pong's 'Broken Well' was a highlight and great fun, however. The Sulman Prize entries were, as always, unsettling, fascinating and full of imagination - this prize really encourages fresh creativity.We found the Lost Prince and the Winter Queen exhibition from London's National Portrait Gallery educational and well worth a visit, as was the Plumes and Pearlshells exhibition on the art of the New Guinea highlands - comprehensive and fascinating. By this time, we had reached sensory overload, which is often the case in this wonderful gallery. But we'll be back soon!

Never been there before. We looked for things to do whilst on a weekend in Sydney. We have been a few times before to Sydney but this time the gallery had the Archibald prize and landscape artworks on show. Very much worth a look. I liked the way they (the Artists and Judges) added their story on what the work meant...it helped visualise what they portrayed..The gallery is a good thing to do!
I like the traditional art there. There're other museum which has greater western art to show us. But the unique traditional art here makes it special.

Sydney - I am impressed. In Sydney for a few days holiday with friends. We decided to walk through Hyde Park and Botanic Gardens to the Art Gallery of NSW on Wednesday at dusk. We chose Wednesday as it is open Wednesday night and has a schedule of free events. We had a lovely time and thought the place had a lively and fun feeling to it. The schedule of free activities were diverse and interesting and it was the best experience I gave had in an art gallery ever. Plus there is a free courtesy bus back to the city every 15 minutes! Highly recommend anyone in Sydney on Wednesday night please head up the hill to the Art Gallery and a bag full of surprises is waiting for you.
A little bit of culture. Brilliant art gallery with variety and diversity. The terrance restaurant has awesome views of the Opera House and is a welcomed place to sit, eat and have a drink

Limited range, but free entry. Nice museum, but not a huge range of artworks, although I was only there on a fleeting visit so perhaps didn't get the "full experience". Free entry though so overall worth a visit.

Complimentary Tour and Archibald Display. Visiting Sydney we went to the gallery to view the Archibald art display, on arriving there was a complimentary tour about to start so we joined in and had a very informative tour of the highlights of the gallery. Dale, our guide, was very passionate and we were so much more appreciative of what the gallery had on offer. The Archibald display, along with two other competitions, was well presented and we spent an hour viewing the talent and interesting art in this display.

Emphasis on Australian artists is very good. The is a very enjoyable art museum and with its emphasis on Australian artists it is surprising (to me at least) with the significant Australian impressionist work. Lots of interesting modern artistic works too.
Archibald prize. Great - got there early; beat the crowds. The staff were very helpful. The exhibition was good value, I thought.

Love the Lucian Freud. Interesting mix of paintings across several eras. Beautiful heritage building - ceilings are amazing! Great to be able to examine paintings close up . And all for free- aren't we lucky

One of the few free Galleries in the city. Whilst the exhibits from Papua New Guinea and the movie filmed in the late fifties or early sixties of the people of the Highlands and the famous Mt. Hagan festival was very interesting, personally I found the gallery of aboriginal art somewhat limited. It was primarily for these two exhibits that I visited the Gallery. There were other sections, among them Japanese and Contemporary, which I did not visit. Overall however, the Gallery appeared very popular.

We went to see the Archibald Prize entries. It is a long time since I visited the art gallery of NSW...not since I was a young girl in fact, so on a visit to my hometown we took the opportunity to see 2014's Archibald entries. I wasn't disappointed. The gallery is perched on the edge of the Domain in a fabulous position overlooking Woolloomooloo and Sydney Harbour and so a joy to visit because of its prime location. The Archibald paintings were well displayed and even though it was busy, we were able to take our time and look at all the paintings at our leisure. The 2014 winner was unusual but a worthy choice. We didn't have a lot of time to spare and so didn't get a chance to visit the many of the other galleries/rooms almost all of which are free. I will be back for another visit and I won't leave it so long between visits next time.
Art. they say art is the expression of emotion body soul and mind, so here at the art gallery of NSW, what's not to like?
Must-see in Sydney. I visited the Gallery almost every week. So many to see and most of them are free. Just a place you must visit in Sydney.

bueatiful. i loved seeing all the australian art work, it was a very fun day. i had lunch at the gallery then walked arounf the park that surrounded the gallery. and it was right across from my backpacker that i stayed in! very handy!

Something different. The modern art was something I'm not used to - it's not just about the paintings, the sculptures were unique in the own way.
Pretty interesting, but if art isn't your thing and you're the type who likes adventure, this place may not be for you.

Interesting art. Although I am not an art expert, I really enjoyed my visit to the art gallery. The place is clean, has free wifi, and interesting pieces of art all around. There even were a couple of Picasso pieces on display while I was there, so that was pretty cool.

Worth to visit. Spends a Sunday afternoon in the art gallery. This is my first visit and the kids enjoy looking at all the pictures/ crafts work on display; esp. those done by high school students.
Definitely worth a visit.

Worth a visit for sure!. The exterior of the art gallery is magnificent, reminiscent of the Pantheon. I went in to see 2 pieces by Robert Peake (royal portrait artist in the 17th century) – Winter Queen and the Lost Prince. These portraits were from London’s National Portrait Gallery. I took the opportunity to have a walk around to look at other pieces and there were certainly some impressive pieces and some minimalist ones which I don’t get. I would say that it’s a good place to spend an hour or two in as it can be quite enlightening. Very well curated.

Stately Art. Well worth a visit for an hour or 2, organise to join one of the guided tours conducted by one of the many brilliant volunteers, they add an extra dimension to your visit with background info and interesting facts.

Iconic Art. From the Heidelberg School to Contemporary Artists this is a wonderful current display. Lots of early colonial landscapes building to the oh - so - familiar Streetons and McCubbins. If you are an International visitor this is the best introduction to Australian Art.Hints: Try NOT to go on the weekend, go early on week days to avoid the initial rush of School students. And try to scones in the restaurant..

Art tastic. The Art Gallery is in some lovely grounds and we have a sunny winters day to find it. The exhibits were compelling and there was something for everyone, modern and traditional. All for free - a real jewel in Sydney's tourist treasure box.

Nice but not special. My husband and I visited the Art Gallery on our first day in Australia. It was a nice museum but nothing special. There is a good mix of art styles and time periods. We visited the Pacific Islander exhibit and took the Australia Art tour. The tour guide was very nice but she seemed not to have the greatest grasp on the material she was presenting. I particularly liked the more modern Australian art - but I like modern art in general. The presentation on early 1900s paintings and their context in Australian history was quite nice.I must admit that my husband and I were suffering from jet lag as we had just arrived in Australia. This colored my experience of the museum and I probably didn't get as much out of the visit as I could have. I'd definitely recommend visiting the museum if you have time but it wouldn't be high on my list if my time was limited.
Will be back. It has so much to see in there, a lot of interesting art pieces, and it's open to everyone! It definitely give people ideas just to see those cool art.
Special day. We came here for the Monet viewing and had a great time . Had cake and coffee and it was great price.

Worth a Visit. Good to get an insight into a range of art styles - easy walk from central business area of Sydney.
But do not expect a massive range of art pieces here.
The free admission is a big plus!

Contemprary Art and Music. I was amazed at the beautiful 3 D presentations and how well the Art gallery had arranged exhibits on each floor. Great views of the harbour can be had from level floor where there is a modern style café which appears to be very busy no matter what the time or day. There is a good interactive display on level 3 especially for children and would be of interest to educators as well. It has a neat shop on ground level where some interesting souvenirs can be discovered.

For those who like 19th century Australian art, it is a must.. This gallery has one of the best collections of 19th century Australian art (although it's loans to London in 2013 brought together pictures from here, Melbourne and Adelaide).

Quality ,a most enjoyable experience. Set in a area of green the sandstone building is already a treat. The art is well hung in open an easily accessible areas. The art itself gives a good insight into Australian artists both indigenous and European. Many times there are special exhibitions which are well worth the visit. Free entrance to general museum.Perhaps a slight downside is the bistro/restaurant where one has to wait a bit too long in lines to order one's drinks,etc.Also a bit pricey.

Good place to wander on a weekend. Great pieces - just needs more to fill the empty spaces. Great Archibald exhibit. We were lucky to see 2 young finalists for the 2014 Archibald prize - it would have been good to have seen something like these on display.

brilliant gallery. This is one of the most comprehensive australian state art galleries. It has a large variety of arts on show and its collection includes famous works that are wellknown and easily recognisable for all. There is a lot of gallery space and many artworks are on display. I would go back here.

Wonderful way to spend the afternoon in Sydney. We had lunch at Circular Quay and then walked through the Botanical Gardens to the art a Gallery. This gallery has something for everyone, and such an excellent range of Australian art from Tom Roberts to Ben Quilty. The cafe and the shop are worth a visit too.

Always great displays. Well known for the variation of different types of art and artists, there is something for everyone from very young and the elderly. Leave yourself at least a half day to wander around and see special exhibitions which can be found on their website. Not to be missed
Well Worth A Visit. A great display of historical and contemporary art. Entry is free and as such all you invest is a little time. The Gallery is in Hyde Park

Lunch with a view. My friends and I enjoy this venue for out get together lunches as the food is good and the view ensures a very pleasant dining experience. Moreover, we can also look at the wonderful exhibitions that are current at the same time.

Afghanistan Treasures. How fortunate are we that the curators had the foresight to protect and save these treasures from being destroyed. We were amazed at the intricate detail and beauty of the jewelry and other precious artefacts made back in 1,500 -100 BC. What incredible eyesight they must have had with no magnifying glasses to assist them! It was interesting to learn more about the history of Afghanistan.

Classic and Modern Art. The staff were friendly and did engage in conversation. You were always aware of their job being security but did not feel like a potential crook. I loved seeing well known pieces of art close up. Some of the modern art is not to my taste.

Brilliant gallery. Right on the edge of Sydney's CBD, just a short walk through Hyde Park or the Botanical Gardens, the NSW Art Gallery is alive with stunning exhibitions. Large light viewing rooms are set with seating enabling the space and time to fully appreciate the wonderful installations. A great rainy day option.

Love this gallery. I've been visiting this gallery for almost 20 years now. I love it, they have amazing exhibitions always changing, a great restaurant inside & outdoors. Staff are always helpful & even if you don't go for an exhibition you could still end up spending your whole day there, so much to appreciate & see.

Well worth a visit. Set next to the botanical gardens and the harbour, Sydney's art gallery is a lovely way to spend a few hours. Try Wednesday evenings when the gallery holds different events themed to the major exhibition on at the time. Mid morning to lunchtime can be full of school kids but the gallery is big enough for you to avoid them. Cafe facilities also good.

Much to see. You won't be disappointed with a visit to AGNSW. A stroll through the gardens (or catch the 441 bus from the QVB building) will bring to the impressive building. Taking a free guided tour is well worth it to get a better understanding of the paintings particularly the Australian ones. Lots of different themed rooms and finishing with a coffee or meal in the cafe is a nice way to end the visit.

Great Australian collection and great views. This is a lovely space and better than its Canberra cousin. Some really important Australian artwork - vale Margaret Olley - and wonderful views over the gardens and Woolloomoolloo. Best avoided on wet weekends when it's a bit crowded!
Just wandered in because I had time. I didnt expect to go to the museum while walking around the city, but I'm glad I did. Very nice museum with amazing pieces of art work.

Great secret spot in Sydney. Not well known but worth a visit - especially if you have visitors on a blustery, cold or wet day in Sydney. The cafe offers a good selection of coffee, cake or lunch options and sensational views down the harbour but can get busy if an exhibition is on. I like to wander among the art collections (some appeal and some not so).The staff are helpful, informative and sometimes amusing without being patronising

Favourite Australian Gallery. One of the best Gallery's in Australia. Located close to the Domain and Botanical Gardens. Fabulous mix of contemporary and classical art. A favourite place and one I take interstate and overseas visitors to regularly. You will be pleasantly surprised by the various art on display. Free entertainment on Wednesday evenings and free films on Sundays. Something for every taste.

Great Collection. My mum and I visited the gallery to see the Afghani Treasures exhibition and check out the permanent installations on our trip away. Both were really good and captivating. While my mum is an artist and will enjoy almost any gallery, i am not a big art buff- but even I enjoyed the first 2 hours or so (after which my feet got tired!) Well worth a visit to check out some big names- there were works by Picasso, Monet and Van Gough when we visited.

Depends on your tolerance to art.... but its free and central. Located not far from the CBD, Hyde Park and the Domain this art gallery is convenient to get to and given it is free (exhibitions cost however) is a very good attraction to put one your wish list. You can saunter about the place for as long as you like and there is a cloak room to store your pack if you so wish. There is a café and a reasonably well stocked shop.There are a range of galleries on display and while I can't claim any grand knowledge of such things there seems to be a fair array of styles. The building itself is somewhat of an attraction, built in the days when such huge edifices were the thing to build as opposed to yet another sports arena to satiate the masses.A good attraction and great as part of a cheap day out (combine it with a free guided tour of the Botanic Gardens nearby etc).

Beautiful!. I did not know about this place until one day we went to the Botanical Garden and passed through this wonderful looking place. We went in and we were surprised.
