The place was beautifully decorated and the art pieces were great. I love the atmosphere so much, it gave me the classic comfortable feeling. I definitely recommend this to all of you, sophisticated travelers!

"How Great Thou Art!". We thoroughly enjoyed our pleasant, peaceful visit to the Art Gallery again. The calibre and antiquity of some of the paintings was remarkable indeed. The many volunteers were pleasant and helpful. All in all it was a most enjoyable escape from the hustle and bustle from the CBD!

A Must See - and FREE. A really glorious museum, full of a wide range of art. Very helpful staff, and several options for food. A great place to spend half a day, if not more! And its location is very close to several other things of interest, too, so it's a lovely place to walk around. Combine this and the Royal Botanic Gardens for a really amazing day in Sydney!
Impressive. Great Gallery and location. You can spend a full day visiting all the different Galleries. Offers varied eating options.Best of all it's free!

Brilliant. I loved this place. The space is amazing. A great range of art - in various mediums. Spent half an hour in front of a Picaso while one of the curators gave a talk about it. Very informative and accessible. Third Sunday of the month is extra special for kids

Lunch at the Art Gallery. Three of us met at the Art Gallery for lunch and a look at the current exhibition. The menu choice was good and varied and the food excellent. We sat outside in the garden, the lorikeets insisted on sharing ( stealing) any food left unattended and drinking from our water glasses which was amusing for the onlookers because they (the birds) picked me for an easy mark. I eventually threatened to smack their tails. All in all a fun day, oh by the way the paintings were fun, some gorgeous some quite odd.

Great and free!. The location is fantastic set in parklands and the gallery is worth visiting. It's free entry except for any special exhibitions. Give yourself an hour to wander and check out some great international and Australian art.

Old and New. Every month we enjoy visiting this outstanding Gallery. It is filled with beautiful art works from Australia and practically everywhere else in the world. I especially love the Impressionists from Australia and France. Then the Oriental gallery is also fascinating. So is much more. My favourite painting of all is of a farmer and his cows on a frosty morning painted by Elioth Gruner. Enjoy a light meal at the cafe or indulge yourself in the fine dining restaurant that overlooks the Domain and Finger Wharf. Now I've given away all my secrets of this lovely Gallery. Oh! I forgot to mention my favourite bronze sculpture of a man and a horse by Mario Marini.

Visit to the Art Gallery of NSW. Brilliant gallery. We visited the lost treasures of Afghanistan and it was amazing. The works from the early European era were wonderful as were the exhibitions of early Australian works.

didn't realise. Never realised how wonderful this place is. Spent a couple of happy hours entranced with the photography and some of the wonderful iconic Australian works that I just didn't expect to see. Moving.

Not to be missed. This is a wonderful museum that is a "must see" for any visitor to Sidney. The collection is diverse and varied in terms of European and Australian artists and classic and contemporary. The building is worth a visit on its own. Very friendly staff.

Not Just An Art Gallery. You can spend hours walking around oogling and getting lost in the wonderful art works. When you get bored you can walk around the windows and look at the amazing views of Sydney Harbour and the city. The restaurant is good yet pricy, the gift shop is extensive.

Wonderful collections. Stunning harbour views. Saw the Afghanistan exhibition here last week. A remarkable collection of artefacts on loan. Then wandered through a couple of other galleries. Loved Ben Quitlty's prize winning portrait of Margaret Olley. Finished the visit with a glass of wine in the restaurant overlooking the harbour which was sparkling below. Hard to beat.

Well worth a visit. This gallery belongs in a list of the top 100 galleries internationally. An exhabition of saved Afghan art was on when we visited.They have an interesting collection of Australian Art alongside art from Rodin and Monet etc.Located an easy walk from the CBD and surrounded by parks, it is a very pleasant place to spend a few hours. It is about 1/2 downhill to the harbour and Opera house afterwards

Very good collection of Australian Art as well as some of the Masters.. The Australians state’s flagship art gallery boasts an impressive collection of Australian and International Art. Did I mention it was free?  It did charge a $10 fee for the special exhibit on Afganistan Hidden Treasures (which I paid and could have probably skipped). After inquiring at the front desk and being helped by a very friendly young man, I was able to download an application that allowed me to be pointed to the highlights as described by the Museum’s director. Each piece had a audio file that could be listened to while examining the painting/object, etc. I find that this is a very good way for someone like me who really enjoys/appreciates art but does not have any training in what to look at/for to get a much deeper appreciation of the piece. It needs to be updated a little (some of the noted paintings did not have a current audio file and perhaps a little more work on the layout of the audio portions) - I was absorbed in the Museum for the better part of two hours, and allowed me to get off my feet at times to sit down and listen to the review. It is obvious why so many Australians are so proud of their Museums. Good facilities, good price. Very good experience.

Brilliant display of art and a good cafe too. We have to admit to admiring Arthur Streeton's work but found plenty of other things of interest too. The aboriginal display was excellent. We also enjoyed a very good lunch in the cafe.

Good early sunday morning culture. We went for the afghan treasures exhibit, but spent a good time exploring the Mid to late 20C permanent exhibition.
Good place to visit early on a Sunday morning before the it gets busy.

Wonderful art gallery in a beautiful spot in the city.. The art gallery is just on the edge of the Botanic Gardens, so in a very pretty spot. There is always lots to see. The bookshop is very good. Go to the cafe and if the weather is good sit outside.
Fantastic. Walk across the Domain to the Art Gallery of NSW to discover a comprehensive collection of Asian, Australian and modern art.

Fascinating... and free!. We were on our way to the Botanic Gardens when we chanced upon this Art Gallery, so we went inside and were awestruck with the exhibits inside. Unfortunately, we arrived at around 4:15pm, so we only had 45minutes to view the exhibits, as the Art Gallery closes at 5pm. Wish we had more time to view the exhibits on display
ART lovers stop here. Yes, a great place to spend an afternoon if you love contemporary art. Some great Aboriginal contemporary is usually on display also.

Worth a look. Went to the exhibition "Afghanistan: hidden treasures from the National Museum, Kabul", which was enlightening and humbling and reiterated again what a strategic section of land this country has been over the ages.The European galleries aren't a patch on those hanging at the National Gallery of Victoria in Melbourne but there are some lovely works nonetheless.Cafe serves good coffee!

Wonderful art display. After a walk through the Botanic Gardens with my UK visitors, I introduced them to one of my favourite Sydney spots - the Art Gallery of NSW. We enjoyed a delightful lunch - tasty and well-priced in the café, before wandering around the gallery, enjoying the wide variety of art on display. They were particularly impressed by the Australian art, the range of subjects and the construction of the gallery with its contrasts between the original section and the newer section with the glimpses of Sydney Harbour. For me, it was a visit again to a place I had been coming to regularly since my childhood.

Great Art Gallery to visit for the latest exhibitions. This a beautiful art gallery. It is designed beautifully on the outside and is right next door to the domain. The Art Gallery of NSW has acquired many beautiful works of art over the years. It also does some beautiful exhibitions one of my favourites in recent years was the Picasso exhibition.

The finest art available for free.. It's stunning.. I love paintings.. I enjoy visiting galleries and this is one of the finest in the world... The best of Australian art is on display... So very easy to spend three relaxing hours here... The restaurant is excellent too.... There is no charge for entry either , it's FREE... First class.

great art, mostly free!. Unlike most galleries in big cities, the NSW Art Gallery has free admission to its permanent collection, and for visitors, this is a great way to get a sense of Australian history, both European and Aboriginal. The café has a lovely outdoor patio - but watch out for lorikeets! Special exhibits have a price tag, but most are well worth the money. Avoid weekdays at the start of new shows - when school trips tend to take over the space.
Amazing museum and it is free!. I really enjoyed seeing the artwork done by Australian artists. It really exuded Australian pride and was different than what is exhibited in other museums.

Oasis in the Desert. Whilst Sydney lays pretensions to being an international city I am one of the locals that does not find this to be the case. Sydney can be a bit of a cultural wasteland. Thankfully, the NSW Art Gallery is one oasis in the cultural desert. The collection of works on display is quite large and covers major local and international art movements. If you come expecting the Tate or the Guggenheim you will, however, be sorely disappointed - keep some perspective!!I would especially recommend a visit for those trying to develop a better understanding of Indigenous art. The works on display are breathtaking in their use of form & colour. It is significant to note that the works display Indigenous art as a living and progressive movement; not something to be assigned to history books. Those seeking to explore the roots of Western culture in Australia will not be disappointed. Numerous oils grace the walls that trace the artistic journey made by the first Europeans as they endeavored to interpret this harsh and forbidding environment. You see before your eyes the shift from a European perspective to a new "Australian" perspective where the light and colour of the landscape are portrayed more realistically. Where the "English" perspective has given way to the perspective of the 'new' Australians. In addition the collection of Pre-Raphaelite works is of a quality rarely found outside of Europe. The Modernist movement is well represented too, with works by Roy de Maistre, Grace Cossington Smith and Margaret Preston. And on and on it goes.In its parkland setting the NSW Art Gallery is a wonderful insight into some of the best of Australian art. By the way, like all good art galleries, the cafe is predictably ordinary. I do however recommend the High Tea in the restaurant. A great way to spend an afternoon or, for the art tragic, a couple of days!!

Diverse collection makes this Gallery suitable for everyone. This Art Gallery is TARDIS-like in its size - it houses deceptively large exhibitions on European, Contemporary, Modern and Asian art. There's even Pottery for those who like a good plate.It's well set out and there's enough novelty and hands-on activities to bring kids (though not for as long). For those who haven't been exposed to much Australian or Aboriginal art (like myself) it's a good environment to see Oceanic art for the first time.PRO-TIP: Give yourself PLENTY of time look round. I got through the exhibits in an hour due to a deadline, but I certainly didn't give some pieces the time they deserved (and my start-stop sprinting wasn't appreciated).I'm sorry, Art Gallery of NSW - I wronged you.

Always wonderful. Enjoy it here any time - whether it be local artists or special exhibitions, always a treat. Saw the American history of art and it was fascinating to see the development and changes in art in another country. Exhibitions are always well curated and interesting.Easy to get whether by public transport or nearby parking at Domain.

Great Australian art and more!. Great place to see Australian art. I was not familiar with this at all and got to learn a lot. There is of course the usual European and Asian art as well. The lowest floor had nice aboriginal art. One depicting Captain Cook as a pirate was particularly moving. You could spend a whole day here. Indeed, we cam back a second day to follow a guided tour that we had missed the previous day.There is a restaurant on an upper floor and a cafe on the lower floor. We ate at the cafe and it was very good.Tip: download the gallery's app and follow an audio guide on your smart phone. There is also a gallery wifi that you can use.

Must See Museum of Sydney. I was very impressed with the thought put into arranging the various collections. The post modern section and the Australian sections were my favorite - but overall everything was worthwhile. This is hands down the choice art museum over the contemporary art museum.Pro tip- check out the cafe downstairs for lunch, food is excellent at a decent price

amazing gallery. An amazing place for art lovers ,a mixture of old and modern art .Nice collection of Australian works which depict the history of Australia,loved the place.Nice cafe and play area for the little ones

Worth a visit. I've been here for many of their special showings and thoroughly enjoyed them, beware if its one of their short ones as the crowds get to be quite large and the lines even worse. On a normal visit its lovely and peaceful, you are able to sit and admire your favourites. There is also a nice café with reasonably priced food.

Wonderful way to spend a Sunday morning. Went with a girlfriend for a late brunch, walk to the art gallery and viewed the current works. The art gallery is surrounded by wonderful parklands and the view to the harbour is amazing. The exhibitions and layout of the gallery is world class with a well stocked shop that has a great range of art and architecture books.

Up with the best. Some excellent art, and we from the Northern hemisphere will not see Australian landscape painting unless we come somewhere like this. Some interesting contemporary art, and an excellent collection of Asian art and pottery/porcelain. We went on a Sunday and the place was packed. Great to see families enjoying art together!

worth the stop. I can't believe this place was free of charge (with the exception of some special exhibits)And for those of you who are needing Wi-Fi access, they had it free of charge. It was a very open and quiet with a wide variety of exhibits. If you are an art enthusiast - this is a MUST see and you could spend hours here.Even if you are not, it is still worth the stop for a quick look around.

Discover who discovered australia. Great place to visit. full of art and history. Amazing layout, easy to walk around, very quite, great place to share learning time about things that are unique to australian culture.
MUST SEE. I really enjoyed the art they had here. nice assortment! laid out very well. If you go to one museum in Sydney, this is the one i would go to.
Great gallery. Beautiful building set in the park. It doesn't disappoint inside with some iconic Australian art from masters such as Nolan and Boyd amongst many others.

In the Botanical Gardens is a treasure!! Free entry. Great café or more formal restaurant with Harbour Views if you want to impress your visitors. The Art Gallery is ever changing with free entry it is a magnificent building on several levels with lifts or escalators to access. There is a charge for visiting exhibitions which you can choose to visit or not - well worth a visit

Excellent!. Great location in The Domain park, next to the Botanic Gdns.! Looks like an old building from the outside but is mostly very modern inside , with great collections of Aussie art, both old and modern, including Aboriginal art. Good cafe.

Always Interesting. The beautiful old building housing the Art Gallery of NSW welcomes one with the open arms of the stone steps. With very tall ceilings and vast walls over several floors, there is something for everyone, interactive exhibits for the kids, sculpture, a wonderful collection of Old Masters and world class travelling exhibits. Mark the gallery on your browser and sign up for the newsletter to mark special events in your calendar - rain, hail or shine there is always something fascinating to see.

Excellent gallery. Had never been before and especially was interested in the Afghanistan exhibition. Spend several ours and nearly saw everything and the variety of art form is fantastic. Had lunch in the restaurant which was surprisingly good!

ecclectic collection. We loved this art museum! Contemporary collection had wonderful variety of imaginative art. Numerous Maori bark paintings plus modern paintings highly influenced by Maori paintings. Special exhibit was extensive Sol LeWitt artworks. Even museum shop was way above par.

Quality Art. This museum can take up an afternoon easily. There is European and Australian art some of which is Aboriginal. It's a lovely walk to get there through the Botanic Gardens. The space is large so we never felt crowded. There is an Afghanistan special exhibit there currently which was fascinating.

Imagine What You Desire. Simply fantastic, 19th Bienale is happening right now. I'm blown away by the creativity of the Art Express exhibition taking place. Walk thru the Royal Botanic Gardens from Circular Quay to get there. you will not be disappointed.

Nice visit. Compared to the Smithsonian or European capitols this is an ok collection. Certainly worth visiting when in Sydney for some of the historical perspective presented. The cafeteria provided a nice atmosphere and good food.

Disappointing. I love museums -- they are must-sees on my vacations, however I found the Art Gallery of NSW to be disappointing. The gallery had interesting pieces, but there wasn't much "life" to the place. The displays lack thought and creativity and can feel very cold. I tried attending the late night activities, but there was lack of enthusiasm from the staff and the attendees did not add to the fun of the evening. Lovely art work, but disappointing gallery.

Three Hours Was Not Enough. I only had three hours to spend in the Gallery. That enabled me to look at the permanent collection which includes several galleries of works depicting Australian life in the 19th/early 20th centuries. Obviously few of us like all art but the mix of many periods and genres and styles meant that it would be difficult to spend time there and not enjoy a significant part of the collection. Even if art galleries are not 'your thing' but you are interested in seeing early Australian life then I would suggest that there are several galleries which you would thoroughly enjoy. Go see. You won't be disappointed.

Great exhibitions and nice permanent collection. Love going through the permanent art collection when you walk in from the main entrance its on the first door to the right - the old beautiful works of art are so worth going to see, I myself dont like the contemporary exhibitions but there are plenty of those here as well
Art Gallery. Just a quick look into the Art Gallery. Had a very restful time looking at the painting of the past.

Art Gallery NSW. I liked the modern art and of course all the other paintings and the gift shop, I wasn't there for too long because of a lack of time, but everything was fine, including the restaurant

A must visit place in Sydney!. The Art Gallery of NSW is one of Australia's leading museums of art with five levels presenting a diverse range of art. You can easily spend few hours in the museum as there are too many things to see and you'll be impressed with the art work. The best thing is the entrance is free!

Excellent Australian collections!. We very much enjoyed this art gallery, particularly Australian galleries (both 19th century galleries and the 20th-21st centuries gallery) on the ground level, and the Yiribana (aboriginal) gallery on lower level 3. The café was also very nice.

Lovely gallery.. This is a beautiful, classical building, situated in lovely parkland, close to the centre of Sydney. A reasonable collection of European works and old masters, together with an important collection of work by Australian artists.
Remarkable !. Surprised at the content of this gallery -really fabulous art-work and so diverse ,well worth a visit and the cafe is good too !
Girls' lunch. Always enjoy lunch here with its superb views and fine food. Service can sometimes be a little slow.

Amazingly!. We were lucky enough to go the evening opening of the gallery...every Wednesday 5-9pm. We were doubly lucky as they were showcasing their year 12 students work (17-18yrs). How wonderful that these fledgling artists are given a major space in a renowned gallery...what a motivational tool. We enjoyed listening to the successful artists and then viewing their work, so much so, that in a crowded schedule of only five days in this city, we are taking another morning to revisit. Rest of the world take note!!

Love it. Not as good as in Melbourne,in my opinion,but you can find some pictures that you fall in love on them.It's pretty close to the Royal Botanic gardens which make it +1 immediately.Make sure you take same photos but without flash.
Great variety. If you like art you'll be blown away by the variety and quality of the paintings and exhibits here. From Aboriginal art to European Masters - well worth a visit.

Lovely Gallery in lovely surroundings. Where the majority of note worthy art exhibitions happen in Sydney. No exhibition you want to see? Visit anyway and see for free the permanent collection of the Gallery.

Very interesting approach to art. I almost got a scare when I entered. Staff jumped at me and started to dance around me and sing....I never seen anything like that. Interesting approach! Made me smile.

Up there at the top. With several special exhibitions held every year and a vast range of art work on display in several dedicated galleries- not to be missed venue in Sydney. The Asian collection is amazing.

One of the most interesting spots to visit in Sydney!. One of the most interesting spots to visit in Sydney. Adjacent to the beautiful Royal Botanical Gardens, this free venue is full of historic art. There are also paid exhibits from time to time. In fact, this would be a fantastic place to visit during the summer, if only for the air conditioning! The place is huge and offers wide variety of ways to have a nice time. Also, you don't have to be an art expert to enjoy yourself. There's always some new exhibition available.

Great museum. We were wondering what to do in a rainy sunday in Sydney and decided to the Art Gallery of NSW. What a great surprise, huge exhibition space, Australian artists and Aboriginal art are the spotlights and a lot more for free.

A Terrific Stop. Not large but interesting and free. Spent about 2 hours , not including lunch.The Aboriginal art on the lower floor was the highlight for me.
Had a very pleasant lunch in the cafeteria.

An interesting 'arty' stroll. We visited the Art Gallery of NSW today, wandering around the gallery for a little more than one hour to see only the exhibits on the ground floor (free of charge). There is much more for people with more time and/or more energy to see and enjoy.We walked to the gallery from our hotel, enjoying some of Sydney's lovely parks and gardens on the way and, after leaving the gallery, walked through the botanic gardens to the opera house. A lovely way to spend time on a sunny Sunday.I'm not an art buff. Would I walk over broken glass to get to the Art Gallery of NSW? No. Would I recommend a walk through the gallery and, on a nice sunny day, its adjoining gardens as part of an overall look around Sydney? Yes, absolutely. You can't go wrong.

Currently exhibiting the Hidden Jewels of Afghanistan - should be Sydney Art Gallery. A excellent place to visit for the day with a short stroll from the CBD (across the parklands) Plenty of choices in the art world to appreciate Favorite would be the contemporary artists BUT worth a walk to all sections Small featured exhibit "Hidden jewels of Afghanistan" was worth it

World-class collections in a beautiful setting. While exploring the Domain,I was caught in a storm and the Gallery provided at first a great refuge.Then I was impressed by the quality of the exhibitions and the cleverness of the display. Especially the Aboriginal collection in the lower floors,and the contemporary Australian pieces. There is also a good selection of Asian art,early XXth. century Australian masters...and last but not least the cafe is quite welcoming after hours of exploration,with a great view over Woolloomooloo wharf and the eastern Suburbs. Overall a great destination for all visitors to Sydney...and locals as well.And the entry is free :-)
Good selection of artwork. Great tour provided by the docent. She was able to hit the highlights in short amount of time -from the Masters to aborigines.

An excellent museum with a beautiful restaurant. We found this to be a lovely art museum -- especially given the price (free). The exhibits were quite decent but the lunch at its fine dining restaurant (we've forgotten its one-word name) was OUTSTANDING. Excellent food, albeit it a bit pricey, and a lovely ambiance. Great view, great food, good wine. It really enhanced the entire museum-going experience. We recommend this place.
arty farty. art is a reflection of a society so reflect for a few hours - its wirth it for the views of the battles ships outside x

Good variety. The gallery had a good mix of art from different countries and from different periods. There were several sections of Australian art that I really enjoyed. Well worth the visit.There was some kind of "performance art" going on at the entrance that was a little amusing. The museum guards/guides/(?) at the entrance would surround selected individuals as they entered the museum and start dancing around the visitor while shouting "this is so contemporary." I must admit that I don't understand that type of "art" . . . but the reaction from the visitors that were caught in the "art" was priceless. But don't try to take a photograph of it. I raised my camera to take a photo and was promptly asked not to. Apparently the artist doesn't want any photos of his work.

Well worth the visit. I went into the art gallery after walking around the Botanic gardens and I really enjoyed my visit. There is a wide range of art on the different floors and there is plenty of space to walk about and take everything in; it was also pleasing that staff were relaxed about the photo opportunities. I went on a busy Sunday afternoon but it didn't feel noisy or overcrowded, and was in fact a very pleasant experience.

Probably one of my best trips to art an gallery - ever!. It's not totally 'my scene' but thoroughly enjoyed afternoon at the Art Gallery. With a family of six, free entry is always a good starting point and the Gallery is pleasantly situated on the edge of the Botanical Gardens. The layout is open and 'airy' and it does make it easier to appreciate the art. A fairly diverse range of art that found interesting (even if 'grazed' a tad in certain areas).There seems to be a reasonable cycle of ongoing events and the kids enjoyed being involved in a didgeridoo/aboriginal music event where they learned about the history/background of the didgeridoo/got involved/made music etc. They all thoroughly enjoyed it.For myself, the highlight was the three 'museum guards' performing Tino Sehgal's "This is so Contemporary" in the entrance foyer on unsuspecting visitors. It was absolutely fabulous and whilst maybe would be considered a little 'on the fringes' was incredibly interesting art. Seriously it made my day. Whilst this event may have now ended, I am sure that such an open-minded gallery would have other equally as interesting activities.Normally, after a couple of hours in an art gallery/museum I am chomping at the bit to escape. This visit was completely different. Full marks all round.

Very nice exhibits. The Gallery of New South Wales was a very nice museum. They had a lot of galleries with a lot of Australian art. I did get a bit lost when trying to find other exhibits, because the special exhibit is on a floor in between the free galleries. It was somewhat quiet, for some reason at the entrance of the gallery attendants were screaming some loud saying that could be heard throughout the galleries, I could do without that.

IF YOU LIKE ART. I was a member for years and enjoyed it very much, I'm not into Modern art so unable to comment on that gallery, but it is an nice walk across the Domain or you can use the hop on hop off bus

First class museum worth a visit. Don't miss the Aboriginal art here. Beautiful galleries and all but the special exhibits are free. There are numerous bathrooms and an interesting gift shop. The cafeteria looked good too, although I didn't eat there.

A must do when in Sydney. This is a must see for pverseas travellers - even if only to view some fabulous Australian art, and they have wonderful special exhibitions as well. It's truly a world-class institution

Go early on Wednesdays. We enjoyed the night out at the museum very much. It has a very relaxed feel and we were able to visit all the exhibits leisurely in 2 hours. The best thing is that it's free entry! That's a huge relief to our pockets.

For all art lovers. For all art lovers, the Art Gallery of NSW is like a kid in a candy store. I was there to see Renaissence to Goya exhibition but saw so much more that didn't require purchasing a ticket. Spent a good 3+hrs on a rainy day inside being amazed with the vision, skill and eye of paintings from the 1700s to contemporary modern sculpture pieces.The best time to go is during lunch time to late afternoon which will ensure the place isn't crowded.

The treasure of Sydney. If you are a fan of paintings, this is your best destination that you must go when visiting Sydney. There are some masterpieces such as Monet, Vincent Van Gogh, etc. Check their website before visiting because they offer free tour everyday and sometimes on weekend they have free concerts. This time when I visited, I enjoyed a very very good concert holding by ABC. The location may not be super convenient, it took me a while to get on the bus, but after visiting, I'd suggest walking alongside the waterfront, which is the best spot to take photos with both Opera House and Harbour Bridge. And then going thoughout the Botanic Park, you are back to the town. A wonderful itinerary.

A lovely, manageable sized gallery. Small enough to see in a few hours without getting exhausted or overwhelmed, with some important Australian and international pieces. Lovely views over to east Sydney from the windows are worth seeing also. Good cake and coffee in the cafe on the lower floors.

A must see in Sydney!. Although not a huge gallery, the collection is quite extensive and very good. I was pleasantly surprised.A Sydneysider we met on the plane from Perth said we should not miss it, and I am glad that we had the time to go. The admission is free, which is a great bargain. You can, of course, make a donation at a couple of boxes near the door, but there is no pressure or coercion.Don't miss it!
Some very nice paintings. Some masters, many artists new to us. Not crowded. Easily accessed across the street from the botanical gardens. Free unless you attend the special exhibit which we skipped.

a great introduction to Australian art. this wonderful building in the domain of Sydney has a huge collection of Australian art, modern and from the settlement of Australia, as well as touting exhibitions. you will see iconic pieces of Australian art in a fantastic location. have lunch at the café, and sit on the terrace for view of Woolloomooloo

A Great Docent Makes All the Difference. We timed our visit to join the free tour with a volunteer docent. It was an amazing introduction to the history of Australia as well as its people. Our docent was outstanding, as good as any you might find in the Arts Dept of a great university. She started with the19th century landscapes of the new continent, by the Europeans reflecting the romantic style of the day. She took us through the aborigine works explaining the deeper meanings of what looks like modern "dot" art as well as the carved and painted funerial posts. And she was equally enthusiastic about the modern art, pointing out the installation of river rocks suspended in an array of cables, casting interesting shadows. I would highly recommend this as one of the first stops as an introduction to Australia. I only wished that our docent had more than the hour she spent with us. We stopped at the lovely cafe for tea and biscuits.

Cultural Overload. We were amazed that such a great gallery is free to enter. We loved the Aboriginal Art works exhibit, such rich textures and colours. The rest of the work are well displayed and the cafe is reasonably priced for a drink and lunch.

Compact but worthwhile collection. I will mention the art first as that is what it should be all about: the collection is not massive on a world scale but does contain some real gems. The Aboriginal art and some of the early 20th century works are a highlight for me. Just as jaw dropping, however, is the setting and we managed to visit on one of those blue, sparkly Sydney Summer days so the views from the windows were sometimes a distraction from the artwork. The food outlets are dependable and the facilities are fine, especially considering there is no charge for general entry. Special exhibitions will usually have an entry fee. Definitely worth a visit but do allow time to wander around the Royal Botanic Gardens and take in the view from Mrs Macquarie's Chair while you are in the area.

Good Overview of Aussie Art. My favourite part was the contempory art and the old Australian traditional scenes which give you a glimpse into history. The gallery is open late on Wednesday evening and often has special events for Art After Hours. General admission is free although there may be a charge for some special shows.

Art Gallery of NSW.Sydney. The Art Gallery of NSW is an art museum-one of the most popular and significant in Australia.Over numerous floors this art gallery has interesting pieces to look at It is not particularly large but there are some nice paintings and a lot of Australian Art:http://www.artgallery.nsw.gov.au/discover-art/learn-more/australian-art/ The tribal artifacts from aborigines are impressive Open every day 10am until 5pm.Recommended

Always a special place. I visit the gallery at least twice a year, sometimes for the big exhibitions like America or the Archibald and sometimes just to see the permanent exhibitions. It is always worthwhile. The location is beautiful, the gallery small and intimate and the facilities world class.

Enjoyable. I can hardly believe that this gallery is free! There is a good selection of art to explore and it is refreshing to not be looking at the same religious paintings that you find at most others galleries. Of course, you won't find a lot of paintings by the "Greats" but you will find plenty of art to enjoy and you can't complain, because it is free.
Free Art Gallery. The art gallery is not particularly large but there is some nice paintings to look at and the building is lovely. It is free to get in which is great if you are on a budget.

Great Art .... I walked through the park from Circular Quay which is a great way to approach the Gallery. Worth reserving a ticket for the big shows but when you get there it is very well organised. Nice cafe as well.

Great Gallery & great guided tours!. This is a great Gallery set in the Domain and is well worth visiting on your trip to Sydney. If you are walking from the City shops, head for McQuarie Street and the Sydney Hospital to take a short cut through the grounds, stopping for a great coffee - then head across the Domain. The staff on the desk are really helpful and friendly - the guided tours which are held most days are led by enthusiastic guides. Just turn up and they appear! Website gives you information about subjects and times.The cafe/restaurant is well worth a visit too - great food, (licensed too!) reasonable prices and a lovely terrace overlooking the Botanic Gardens.

Some interesting exhibitions and pieces. The Art Gallery NSW has a great location, a nice stroll through the gardens to reach it, and the multi level building means that collections are grouped together in a meaningful way. Free for the standard collection including so,e good Australian paintings as you enter (in galleries on the right). Temporary Exhibitions are usually of high quality too. Don't miss Art Express which is also free.

Went Back for a Second Look. Located in the Domain amid the Royal Botanical Gardens in Sydney, the Art Gallery of New South Wales was an unexpected delight. The collections included a rich display of vintage and contemporary pieces from Aboriginal artists as well as space dedicated to contemporary, Asian, and Australian art. During our visits there was a special exhibition of American art and a collection of crayon drawings made by Aboriginal elders in 1947. The classic exterior of the gallery opens into a spacious, open, and easy to navigate interior with both a cafe and a restaurant with lovely views and a children's area for hands-on activities. All but the special exhibition was free. We enjoyed our time there so much on the first visit that we returned a second day to have another look.
Good Collection. It's free, air-conditioned and has some interesting artworks, both modern and old. A nice and pleasant way to spend a 1-2 hours. Cafe is a bit expensive though.
America- Painting a Nation Exhibition. Another outstanding special exhibition for the AGNSW - a real treat for local and overseas visitors alike!

A Sydney Highlight. I absolutely adore the Art Gallery Of NSW, with its large collection of diverse works and intelligent layout. It also offers some fantastic views of Sydney and just captures a great part of Sydneys culture. One of my favourite places to visit

beautiful, classy museum with a great collection. I went to see especially their Pre Raphaelite collection, which is exquisite. Museum is fantastic, spacious, great collection, including Maori art, Their Bronzino is gorgeous.Next to beautiful park. Totally recommended

An interesting permanent collection. A gallery such as this is dependent on a combination of 'local' items and ad hoc purchases of foreign ( mainly European) works.The exhibits are well grouped together-both the local (Sidney Nolan, Arthur Streeton et al) and the European (Constable, Gainsborough, Momet and Picasso).I was less impressed by the Asian collection.
worth an hour or two to wander round. we found it worth an hour or two to wander round, but our son and his mate did not find it attractive - too much old stuff and not enough modern art for them

Great, go!. Fantastic art, including guest exhibitions such as American art. They have a very pricey restaurant there, where my face was nearly burned off with chilli. Another restaurant with coffee, good stuff to stop and absorb all that brilliant Australian art you've seen. Absolutely lovely man at the coat check made up for a few uppity front desk staff. Still, fabulous and famous art. Go!

Art after Hours. Recommend vsiting the Art Gallery on a wednesday night at about 5 pm until 9 pm. This is when the locals go ( as we learnt when we went on a private tour of Sydney) and it was a good way to see the gallery but also a great night out. The evening we went there was a band playing

Great australian art. We went to see Australian art rather than a general art gallery and were not disappointed. We skipped the special exhibition (fee payable) of American art and concentrated on the Aboriginal drawings and the 19th & 20th century Australian art. There is an amazing still life sculpture of a table with fish and seafood on - great movement in the carving of the wood. And the staff were very helpful in suggesting which parts to visit. There was a great kids session on during our visit with lots of interaction and noise. They all loved it.

An oasis. Tranquil environment, quite a substantial collection (we’re in Australia, not Europe), beautiful architecture, polite staff, great restaurant and cafeteria.What else do you need? If you’re in Sydney, possibly this is the best oasis you might find in the CBD!

Art Gallery. There is something for everyone at the Art Gallery. An enjoyable day with costs nothing unless you are seeing a special exhibition. The meals at the coffee shop are a little expensive but the view is great. Good day out for young and old.

Wonderful Australian Art. The Art Gallery is a beautiful building in lovely grounds. The art is of the highest quality. It's great to see so much Australian art in one place. The coffee shop and restaurant are excellent.

Worth a look-see. The building and the views of Wolloomoolloo Bay (sp?) are worth the trek. There is a nice collection of European masters as well as modern, but the Aboriginal art is what really struck me. They also have some really nice contemporary home-grown art that I found made the whole day. There was a wonderful photography exhibit. Be sure to take one of the free tours.

Terrific collection of Australian artists. The Art Gallery of NSW doesn't have an outstanding European collection, but it's 19th century and contemporary Australian art collection is outstanding. Its galleries are also well designed with many large windows strategically placed throughout to let in good light and frame Sydney itself as a portrait.

Bigger than it looks. This building is deceiving as to view all the exhibits you go down rather than up. High ceilings from the original museum and a lovely parquet flooring leading into the modern section. Australian, European & Asian art from contemporary to modern. Their are various free tours found the "Collection Highlight" tour very informative was taken over the whole gallery with lots of extra info. Can also recommend the cafe plenty of seating, good selection of food and excellent service.

Vast and Informative. The museum is free and has a lot of artifacts that are related to aborigines and various other sections. The museum overlooks the Woolloomooloo Bay and is a spectacular view in itself. The museum also doubles as an art institution as well. The museum has so much to offer that you will easily end up spending half a day here. They along with aboriginal works also carry 20th century art collections. The museum also has a nice restaurant that serves good quality food and seating space where you can relax and refresh yourself. The museum is a nice place where you can come face to face with the Australian history and art culture. I loved the place and the wide variety of artifacts they have here. One has to have enough time in hand for this place.

Worth a visit!. The building is stunning! You can see European impressionists such as Monet, Manet and as well some aboriginal art without being overwhelmed. Stop at their cafe with a magnificent view to sip some cmpagne.
Very nice museum/gallery. A mix of both European and Australian art. Walkable from the downtouwn area. If you are into gallaries, don't miss this one

Every changing collection to enjoy. We often stop off to visit the Art Gallery when we are in Sydney as they are continually changing some of the exhibits so there is always something new and interesting to see.

Beautiful gallery next to Botanic Gardens. Nice place to visit on a hot summer day, especially after a walk through the notanic gardens . Gallery has a nice collection of Australian art in addition to international att. We enjoyed the free guided tour at 2pm introducing Australian art. Other free tours are available at different times.
Free wifi is available in the gallery.

Loads to see. This is a great place to visit with a huge range of conceptual and traditional art. There is loads to see and something for everyone, even kids were enjoyong it. Plus its free so you cant go wrong!

It's Worth the Effort. Being tourist in Sydney, getting to the Art Gallery of NSWtook some effort in getting there, but It's worth it. It takessome walking to get there. The gallery opened later thanwhat was listed on the web. It was very clean, the ceilingswere quite high so one has to stand back to really enjoythe paintings. There was a section including modern and aboriginal works. We spent about 3 hours in the gallery.We stop for lunch at the café and ordered a kangaroo lasagna. It was very tasty like lamb. The portion was generous. You gotta to try eating a kangaroo dish while you in Australia. Since we got caught in the rain storm, we took a cab back to our hotel. Thecharges added up quite quickly as we pay $24.00.

Dream location and gorgeous museum. The America exhibition is well worth seeing, with a superb collection of American artists from Colonialism to Abstract Expressionism and really well curated. The restaurant serves lovely food both indoors and outdoors. The Domain is beautiful to walk through with delightful plantings. Many thousands had gathered today early in order to view the New years Eve fireworks spectacular.

Not just for special blockbusters -- so easy to visit. We regularly visit the Gallery from interstate. Access is so easy, with the train taking you right from the airport to Museum Station which is a pleasant walk in the park to the Gallery. Although we usually time our visits for blockbusters we always take time to look at the other exhibitions as well, which are free (although there are charges for temporary exhibitions). The collection is diverse and well displayed. The special exhibitions are usually excellent and if crowded you can book tickets and entry times in advance. Amenities including the cafe and shop are very good. We were there for the American Art exhibition which runs until February. Well worth a visit although I was disappointed at the range of postcards available. The shop for this exhibition includes an impressive collection of books about cooking, quilting and crafts.

Good selection of art work. Over numerous floors this art gallery has interesting pieces to look at. While the European classical collection doesn't stand up to those on display in large museums in Europe, they are still quality pieces.The lower ground floor houses some aboriginal art, strangely under visited while I was there. My favourite was the modern work, the "basement" walk through exhibit the security guard standing her by points out, and the glass mosaic wall.Definately worth a visit. Leave all back packs and day packs with the staff at the front door.

Good way to kill your time. Nice gallery with very well laid out. I always enjoy sightseeing of the pictures or artifacts displayed there. Most of them from European and Australian arts. However don't expect to see the most famous painters's work of art such as Picasso etc since they have none of that I know. But for me, I am very pleased with the collection since I am not an art person. They look incredible good works. I like to stop by there on the way to circular quay during my day off. Relaxing and admire the beauty of art. They do have some exhibition sometimes and the museum admission is free.

A wonderful gallery worth a visit at any time. Don't come often enough - it is a wonderful building in an extraordinary area - but often just come for major events like the Archibald Trophy etc. It is though far more than that and the beautiful array of art treasures is worth a visit at any time of year.

Always a pleasure to visit. The gallery is terrific and it is also a great place to have lunch , morning or afternoon tea. The view from the restaurant is pleasant, the food and service excellent. Make the most of the visit by having a walk in the Botanical gardens afterwards.
Great Gallery. A well laid out gallery with some great views over the harbour. Well worth a visit if you are interested in Australian art.

Plenty to look at and take in. I always enjoy taking time out at galleries. The NSW Art Gallery was no exception. I loved the spacious rooms with a rich array of art to take in. A great collection of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island art, along with international and contemporary works. Best of all, its free to get in!

Best Art Museum in Sydney. One of the best museums in Sydney is the Art Gallery Of New South Wales. It is located in the beautiful parklands (That is how Australians refer to parks. It makes it sound further away then ten minutes of walking). The museum is five levels down – a lot bigger than that neo classical building looks. There are huge modern gallery installations. The Modern Australian Art and Aboriginal Art galleries are worth seeing. For more info and photos go to http://travelwellflysafe.com/2013/11/17/things-i-have-learned-in-sydney-australia/
Over and over again. I never fail to find interesting work on view here. The aboriginal collections are not to be missed. Lunch in the restaurant, with its view out over the harbour is nice too.

Very good art gallery. We loved how the art gallery was quite spacious so you could enjoy everything at your own pace and not get in every-ones way. The set up was a little confusing and we might have missed a few sections but what we did wander through was very nice and the info cards often had some very interesting additions that enriched the experience.

More than an afternoon required..... Did not see the feature American art for a fee. Was however very appreciative of the display of European, Australian as well as modern art for free. Very well laid out and not crowded at all. Lots of goodies in the art gallery shop.

Recommendable. I am not an art person, but I like this art gallery. There are many interesting installations as well as paintings. I visited the art gallery just because the admission was free, but it was worth visiting even if it was not free.
One of the great galleries. It's a superb collection of national and international artists that can be visited and re-visited. The collection is remarkable in its diversity and range.

Whitely outside and treasures inside. This is a great gallery. It's easy to get to - just a short and easy walk through the Sydney Domain, and the famous "Matchsticks" art piece by Brett Whiteley is in the grounds. Fabulous.

A visit to the NSW Art Gallery is unique and memorable.. A visit to the NSW Art Gallery is unique and memorable. Parking is conveniently nearby in the Domain parking. A beautifully situated restaurant with views to the Harbour, indoor or outdoor is very enjoyable. The variety of galleries to see - from Rennaisance, Federation, Oriental, Aboriginal and so many more, will keep you intrigued for the whole day. A short walk to the Botanical Gardens and up to the steps of the Opera House as well as Government House is nothing short of remarkable. From there along Macquarie Street seeing the historic buildings of the Mitchell Library, Parliament House, Sydney Hospital, The MInt, and The Barracks, all side by side. And then right in front of you is St Mary's Cathedral, opposite Hyde park and the Australian Museum - fantastic!!! AND you are back at the Domain carpark, all within a kilometre of each other.
Art to suit all tastes and a great cafe too. Many galleries covering Aboriginal, European and Australian art ranging from way back to very recent. The Cafe serves good coffee too.

Well worth a visit. I enjoyed my visit to the gallery. The Australian collection especially has many famous works I had previously only seen in photos and prints, also a lot of less well known works by Australian and International artists.
Great way to culture vulture in Sydney. AGNSW has a great static collection and fantastic touring exhibits. The cafe is a little so-so, but great views!

Great Collection in a Great Setting. Visited the Gallery following a glorious walk through the Botanic Gardens. The Gallery itself is impressively spacious and we were able to enjoy the permanent collection without charge. On an early summer Sunday the place was nicely buzzing with visitors enjoying all the exhibits and it created a very good ambience. There are additional specialised visiting exhibitions that change on a regular basis. Added to all this is a superb cafe with, on the Sunday, live music. The staff at the Gallery reception were very welcoming and we could not believe the efficiency of the Cafe team.

Beautiful art gallery in a beautiful spot. Right opposite the Botanic Gardens the gallery is a must see place when in Sydney. There are many types of art on display. a really lovely restaurant and cafe, You could spend a lot of time here so much to see. I never tire of goung there.

Oasis in downtown. A great place to escape downtown and the heat. Great collection of pre-European and early European Australian art. Some of the paintings really bring out the experience of the sublime that the Australian landscape inspired in early European occupants. Nice 20th C Australian collection. Interesting exhibitions - often free. Nice little Asian art (Chinese, Korean, Japanese) collection.
Enjoyable Sunday. A wonderful way to spend the day, followed by lunch or dinner in their restaurant and a stroll through the park.

Tour. Excellent collection of contempoary art. Happened to be in the museum when a tour was offered. It was a highlight of our trip. The woman was knowledgeable, opinionated and gave us other art sites to visit.

American Exhibition. Went to see the new American Exhibition and came away wanting more. The exhibition was well laid out and for the most part of quality but was underwhelmed with the modern section.Looked in on the free Australian galleries on the way out and was as impressed if not more with the quality of the local artwork. Have to go back again for the local free exhibitions more often.

Always fantastic at the Art Gallery. The Art Gallery of NSW is our Sydney Icon and a place we are proud of. The surrounds are wonderful and the gallery itself is majestic. Just go there you'll love it

Busy, Exciting Oasis. I love this gallery and was thrilled to see the new exhibition 'Painting a Nation' with its informative commentaries on the wall and in the guide. Such a civilised gallery. It was full of visitors but neither crowded nor noisy and all seemed absorbed and entertained. Link between art and nation-building intelligently explained but surely more contrast between early and later periods could have been made? Absence of anything from the early period a disappointment.The cafe is as good as ever; not cheap but food is sustaining and pleasant variety available. Service excellent.After that, sufficiently restored to visit the splendid Australian art upstairs. The Russell Drysdale collection is amazing.Only disappointment was the Gift Shop. Postcard images tiny and poorly reproduced so the Drysdales, McCubbins et al will have to be remembered rather than continue to be enjoyed. Even the range of small prints was very narrow. Most other galleries of this size and reputation do far better.

Special night showing with presntation dinner. We were at a work function and they held the awards dinner at the museum, it was a very nice location and the dinner and surrounding museum were fantastic.

Worth the trip. Living in Wash DC. I have access to the smithsonian that has AMAZING pieces of art. and although I did like a lot of the artwork and the performance I was able to see... I wasn't something I'm dying to see again on my next trip back. but it's in the middle of an incredible park

Eclectic Blend of art. well the admission is free--Yippy! The collection is very diverse. It ranges from exquisite aboriginal art, to some of the masters, some modern and contemporary and things in between. It is not far from the opera house and is even open to 10 on Wed. nights.

Collection of Aussie artists. I spent time in the Aboriginal art exhibit, renaissance exhibit, and learning about history though the paintings. Nice collections, layout, and location. (And it's free!)

Plan on spending ALL day!!. Spent the day cruising through the Art Gallery. There was a lot to see, and there is food available for lunch to eat. It was a wonderful day, but bring good walking shoes, there are multiple floors and lots to see and explore.

Left quickly. Free entry is great. Place is modern and clean. Left early due to all the nudity. I would prefer paintings with nude people or exposed breasts to be all in one area as not to expose them to young children. Art or not I dont like my young kids seeing images like that and they were quite embarrassed and were constantly covering their eyes. Im not fond of those images either. Ill buy playboy if I want to look at stuff like that. I expected that kind of thing to be there but not so spread out. I enjoyed it otherwise.

Great gallery. The gallery is well set out with a varied selection of exhibits, and it's free! well worth an hour or two to visit and stay for lunch as the restaurant serves up some great food at a very reasonable price.

Hidden gem. It is slightly out of the way for a lot of visitors as it isn't right on the Harbour - only went myself for the first time this year. I was very pleasantly surprised - not only has it some great exhibits and events but the building itself it a fantastic blend of traditional and modern. My children loved it - we caught one of the lunchtime puppet shows with them. The restaurant boasts an amazing view of Sydney from the windows; I had no idea this was all there! Will definitely be back more often from now on.
alright. the art gallery is pretty good - if you're a fan of art galleries this is average. If you're not - it's not really worth the trip. The art is ok. There is a variety of art to look at.

An Australian Icon. The Art Gallery Of NSW is a bit like the Tardis - bigger on the inside! Once you walk through the neo-classical entrance, you are inside a truly modern gallery. The European collection is interesting, but it is the extensive collection of Australian art that makes this gallery a stand out. The Indigenous art exhibition is amazing! I think the best aspect of the gallery's collection is its eclectic nature. You will see works from all over Asia and this helps to contextualise the modern Australian art as well as that by those original Australians whse ancestors have been making representations of the world for over 40 000 years. Visiting this gallery is an emotional and intellectual experience that, for any visitor to Sydney who wishes to understand the essence of Australian artistic thought, is an absolute must.

Very much worth the visit. The Art Gallery of NSW is not just a place to take the kids on a rainy day, but a place where visitors can find out about the hopes and beliefs of (some) Australians.I won't pretend that we Aussies are a cultivated bunch, but we don't do too badly in the Kulture department. We've got a lot of galleries, public and private, and other cultural institutions, such as our national broadcaster, ABC Radio National and other affiliates.But, back to AGNSW, as most of us know it.Have a look around the top of the building before you enter. You will see the names of those artists considered "the best" in the 19th century, when the institution was built. Some you will know and others have faded into obscurity.The collection has some of the classics, but also newer works.Of interest to visitor and resident alike are the changing exhibitions of various sorts and sizes.One perennial is the art works of the New South Wales high school finishing examination. Here you can see the artists of the future.For other shows, either check the paper or the AGNSW website.
wonderful places. we were told to go here by my cousins and so glad we did the the whole place has some great art work to be seen and the shop is good too

Worth the visit. We got lucky--10 minutes after we entered this free-admission museum, a tour was announced, also free of charge. A lovely Sydney lady took our small group on a viewing and history lesson re Australian art, including some fantastic aboriginal pieces. If you like art, this is a great place to visit.

ARt galoRE. Brilliant location to wander about & looose yourself...always something different to find & enjoy at the NSW ART Gallery. I love the traditional art works along with the exhibitions & then there are things for the kids..all found in a hugely impressive historic building
Excellent art gallery. This is a beautiful art gallery with an extensive collection of Australian art. Nicely laid out and the staff is very helpful. Highly recommended for a visit.

Not to be missed. You would expect a gallery like this in a great Capital city like London or Paris. There are many works and pieces of exceptional quality, and rarity and while we were there the exhibitions had some extremely interesting artefacts, plates, sculptures, paintings, all set in an atmosphere which felt more relaxed than most. It did not have the stuffy feel of a museum, there was something going on most of the time, we were inspired. It is a complete contrast to the fabulous Botanic gardens which are literally opposite. If you spent one whole day in the gardens and the Gallery, with perhaps a walk around the Opera house as well, you would have a very memorable day. You would also be completley worn out !

Great!. Lovely setting by the park. The entry is free and very well curated collection of art painted by a mix of European immigrants / visitors to Australia as well as older European art. There is an aboriginal art section as well as modern / contemporary collections. There is a gallery with female artists such as Tracey Emin also. You will need a few hours to view all the works properly I would expect.

An amazing building!!. Worth visiting for the amazing building the art is housed in. The exhibits are always good and varied and great place to spend a few hours. The coffee shop/restaurant is always a favourite and serves good food & coffee. A stroll to lady Macquarie's chair from the art gallery is also worth visiting

Viewing the artworks and eating lunch at the Gallery. It is a pleasant walk from Town Hall Station to the Art Gallery. The Gallery has wonderful ambiance and the restaurant there is well worth a visit - great food IMO and a good view. I would recommend having a browse of the artwork and lunch at their restaurant afterwards - a nice way to spend a few hours.

A great day out on a rainy day!. I visited this gallery afew times either when i was broke or on a rainy day! Its a great gallery with a great gift shop.
They have new pieces in often and at one stage has one or 2 of the terracotta warriors.

Sydney Moderns Exhibition is outstanding. The exhibition showing at the time was The Sydney Moderns Exhibition which was outstanding. Not being from Sydney I found it very interesting to see the different images of the city over the years. I also viewed the other collections of the gallery and found many pieces that I had seen over the years in photographs. I must also recommend the Korean/Asian exhibition of pottery.

Sydney Moderns exhibition is brilliant. I traveled to Sydney just to see the Sydney Moderns exhibition. I was well worth the time and expense. And the books available in the shop - never seen such a comprehensive collection of books on bookmaking.

Not an art connoisseur, but I thoroughly enjoyed it all. Art galleries are as much about the spaces the art is housed in as the art itself, to me. This was light, airy, spacious, and covered a good variety of art pieces for a newb like me. I really enjoyed my stroll around the museum. I saw some inspiring pieces and massive canvases than made me wonder at man's persistence to create something with so much detail and skill. There's a great view of the bay from one the museum's corners. The grounds are just as pretty and I loved taking photos of the columns and statue at the front - spent a good 20 mins doing just that and to marvel at the architecture.Perfect way to end a walk around the Royal Botanic gardens round Mrs. Macquarie's corner.

Interesting collection of Australian and world art.. Amazed to find the original of a print I have owned for the last 35 years, wonderful.Good selection of art with a great informative selection of Sydney Artists

Well worth a visit. The current special exhibition on the Silk road tomb gives a superb insight into the culture of the time. Other permanent exhibitions such as the Asian, Australian and European are well worth a visit with some truly special works on display.

A regular must do. Aside touring exhibitions, visits to the gallery are free. With several wings featuring New guinea, Japanese, Asian, modern and colonial art of Australian artists.Great views over harbour from cafe.

Best collection of Australia's earliest European artists. This place never ceases to impress. It's location surrounded by Hyde Park, The Domain and The Botanical Gardens is par excellence.While I go to the odd paying block buster exhibition, I love to wander into the gallery and view the early depictions of Sydney and Australia by artists Frederick McCubbin, Tom Roberts, Charles Conder and as well as 20th century Australians like Loyd Rees, Sidney Nolan, Arthur Boyd, William Dobell , Russell Drysdale and Norman Lindsay. They've also got fantastic collections of Aboiginal ad Torres Straight Islander Art, Asian Art, Contemporary Art, PacificArt, European Art, Photography, Western Art.The cafe is a nice place lunch or just have a cuppa.

Wonderful aboriginal art exhibition. The main reason we went to the gallery was to see aboriginal art. We were delighted to discover the work of Brenda L Croft whose thoughtful and reflective art was beautiful and insightful. It's on until October. Sad that the shop had no information on her or her work - though there is a website. Didn't have a great deal of time after this but we also noted some fun modern pieces. Also a lovely building, and entry is free.

Every visit has been worth it. They always have a few good exhibitions concurrently. A major exhibition from overseas, usually old masters and sometimes contemporary. Also have permanent collections -an extensive Australian gallery and an Asian gallery. A recent addition is the ever changing collection of contemporary art.

How Good Is This?. Having a couple of hours to kill in Sydney, we found ourselves in this great art gallery. Wow! Apart from the soothing atmosphere, the architecture and the live music, the one element that stood out for me? The people. Visitors of all ages, genders and backgrounds, mingling through the exhibitions really make this building what it is ... The Art Gallery of NSW. Spend a little bit of time or a lot, the choice is yours. Stop for a cuppa and remember to take your camera. Close to public transport, it's a winner!

Moderns Exhibition. Traveled to Sydney to see the Moderns Exhibition (there was a modest fee). Access to the exhibition was great and layout of the work was very good. Information was plentiful and the lighting was good. We started with a coffee in the cafe and access to all areas was great for my husband who was in a wheelchair. After the Moderns we then perused the beautiful display of Australian and European art from the 18th and 19th centuries. It was a great morning and look forward to future exhibitions.

Love our Art Gallery. My favourite place in all of Sydney. Late night visits on Wednesday are just magical for me. The night lights, the music echoing from the restauran and even hush voices of visitors are all in harmony to make the Gallery much more special to me

Nice museum with nice collection + restaurant with live music. Nice architecture, nice museum and nice collection. You can reach the NSW Gallery with a short walk from the National Library or the Cathedral.Museum collection spans from Antique works of art to Contemporary paintings.There is a restaurant on the basement and they often play live music.

Don't pay for the museum everything you need is at this one for free.. Excellent way to learn about Sydney for free. Great museum. Highly recommend and it's free. They have it all sculpture Australian artists aboriginal art etc.

Sydney Modern Exhib.
Till 7th October 2013. This is a very interesting exhibition & one I really enjoyed. If you are visiting the Gallery in Sydney then also include this extra delight. The Art Gallery is free but this is an extra cost and well worth it.

Beautiful, calm spot in central Sydney. Wonderful building, amazingly quiet when I was there. Take the free tour at 11am of the Aboriginal collection. There's also a highlights tour that should be interesting. After that walk through the Botanical Gardens back to the Opera House.

Make it you must-visit in Sydney. The permanent gallery collection was amazing. It has a very good collection of the western masters works such as Picasso, Van Gogh,Monet etc. The permanent gallery is free however there's entrance fee for current exhibition. I paid AUD$15 to enter the exhibition of 'Sydney Moderns' never regretted.
Fantastic!!!. Love and support my local Gallery. A joy to visit each month as they have something new on offer each time. Favourite visit of the Year is the Archibald Prize time.
New and Old. The modern exhibition is worth a visit. Centrally located in the centre of the city, and also adjacent to the botanical gardens

The mothership of gourmand art. This is the mother -ship of art in sydney. The colonial facade is solid and imposing with two equestrian bronzes to greet you. the gallery houses some of the finest works of art in Australia,including Aboriginal, European,Asian and Contemporary art. Its got to be the world's longest gallery exclusively exhibiting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander art and culture. Take a free guided tour. It will enhance your experience. There are five levels where the icon names of Sydney Nolan,Margret Preston,William Dobell , Russell Drysdale and Brett Whitely European Art morphs into Asian art which releases you into Photography,Prints and Drawings and finally into Contemporary art There is a first class eatery downstairs,for light refreshments or gourmand meal. This gallery is astounding and very pleasing to the senses.
Free and worth the visit. The free part of the Gallery is wonderful if you enjoy art. There are usually special exhibits that have a fee, if you have additional time to view.

A LOVELY ART MUSEUM. The building that the art work is housed in is beautiful. It was built in the later 1800's and includes modern and contemporary works, as well as older European works. They currently are showing the Sydney Moderns display, which is quite nice. Entrance to the museum is free, but does cost $15AUS to enter the Sydney Moderns area. My favorite was the Aboriginal art located on the lower floor in the Yiribana Gallery.The cafe located inside the museum has excellent salads and a place to relax and think about everything you've just seen. The walk through The Domain park area is a treat. Enjoy watching all the healthy people working out at lunch time.
Great Art Sydney. Art at its finest Large very spacious galleryBeautiful paintingsLovely park outside for picnic,relaxing something to do
Art for enjoyment. Had a wonderful morning at the Gallery followed by a very nice lunch.Great walk through the park to get there.
Good place to visit. A great place to visit, whole gallery covering across 4 floors with arts abd paints in all sections. Admission is free and would spend around 1-2 hours if not doing it in rush

Great place to view the Australian Masters. On a hot day the Art Gallery is a great place to visit. After a walk from the Opera House or City through the parks you can cool off as soon as you enter the Gallery. I have always loved the Australian landscapes but one can see other great exhibitions throughout the year. If you have a little time to spare then a visit to the Art Gallery is a highly recommended option.

A frequent visitor. I love this gallery and have visited so many times I became a member. Located across the road from the Domain, it's a good starting point for a walk around some of Sydney's best sights (State Library, Botanic Gardens, Mrs Macquarie's Chair). It has wonderful permanent collections as well as many exciting exhibitions. With a restaurant, cafe and gallery shop and only 15 minutes walk to the city centre, well worth a visit. Plus it's FREE.

A Nice Way To Advoid The Rain. The Aboriginal Art on the lower section is a must, the detail of the cross hatching is amazing. Just to look at this is worth the visit. The Cafe serves good meals at reasonable prices and has a very pleasant out door section.Have a look around the sections when you first walk in the front door. Especially the modern sections and you would be amazed that somebody paid money for a couple of pieces, I won't say which as you will see. I'm off to the scrap yard to buy a couple of doors to stick on a wall and sell them.But do have a look at the parts of an old grand piano and other wooden bits which is quite interesting to look at as well the the Bugatti shown at speed.

Ok, and some interesting attractions. I thought this place was ok, but I might be slightly spoilt due to better Art galleries I have been too. The paintings were ok but there was nothing really special. Some of the Modern art was really interesting though.
Don't think I would visit again.

Definitely worth a visit. I was there on a Wednesday evening, when they're open till 9PM. They have a very interesting collection of Aboriginal art that's worth checking out. Plus other artwork from Australians from the 19th and 20th centuries. They have a few paintings from famous international artists also. Admission is free.

Good cafe menu. Easy to order and convenient to the Art Gallery of NSW.
Casual atmosphere and good coffee
Has a pleasant outdoor area.

Something for all the family.. On a recent visit we were treated to a free piano concert and later in the afternoon they put on a childrens show. There are paintings and artworks from around the world, you can even find a Van Gogh amongst the impressionists. Don't miss the aboriginal and torres straight islanders exhibition.

Great, Smallish Museum/Gallery. A visit to the Art Gallery of NSW not only introduces some wonderful art but it gives visitors a chance to explore an amazing collection of Aboriginal art and enables a sense of early Australia through some of the first artists. It is home to traditional and contemporary art and has a regular program of activities and talks.Its a beautiful walk through the Botanic Gardens to the Gallery so the setting alone makes it worth a trip. There is also a good cafe and restaurant so lunch here is a good option. And if you don't have a pool in your hotel, just nearby is the most fantastic swimming pool, AB Charlton so you can combine two great activities.

Art Gallery of NSW. This art gallery was very large and had a wide variety of in terms of genres, mediums, time periods and subjects. The were classical paintings from the 1700 and 1800's, a collection of Buddhist sculptures and ornaments, and modern art installations that were thought provoking and poignant. My favorite exhibitions included the Korean, Chinese and Japanese pottery exhibit and the modern art. There was even an unexpected delight, a Monet in the middle of it all. I ate lunch at the restaurant there and it was delicious. Wear comfortable shoes and bring your imagination and a camera.
Amazing Gallery. The galerry that has a touch of class and elegant. The paintings are beutifully done, the craftmanships are very expressive , so much history.
A world-class gallery in Sydney. This is a wonderful gallery to visit at any time but it also has special shows from time to time. The restaurant, overlooking the harbour is fantastic.

In the Eye of the Beholder!!!. Sydney's National Art Museum is not only a treasure trove of beautiful art works inside, it is also lucky to sit at the edge of the Sydney's Botanical Gardens which offers spectacular views of Sydney Harbour. The art museum has many of the most famous artworks in the world, and at times also offers special exhibitions of world famous artist's works. Closest train station is St James (on city circle link), parking is nearby (10 mins walk), and museum has all conveniences for all visitors including lifts to all floors. Lockers are available to check in your bags, so that you don't have to walk with them.

A Sydney must.. There is always something different to see at the Gallery. Special exhibitions can be expensive but there is plenty to enjoy without seeing them Exhibitions change regularly and entry is free.

Very Enjoyable Gallery. Here one will see a variety of fine art. From Australian artists to Old Worled and European artists works. There also is an entire section of Asian art as well. Afterward, one can walk through the Royal Botanical Gardens which continue right up to the Sydney Opera House.

You can never have too much Bacon!. I've been travelling up to the Art Gallery of NSW for sheer pleasure and a good art fix for years. It has a fabulous collection of Australian and international works and a stroll back through the Botanic Gardens to Circular Quay is another of Sydney's delights afterwards.This time the draw card was the Kevin Bacon Exhibition. Wow!Imagine standing amongst room after room of hallowed canvases, biographical materials, including his ripped up photographs, seeing his foci and style shift as he moved through different phases and relationships of his life.It was too much to absorb in a single visit and we were lured back a second time to simply absorb more.The exhibition was highly moving and his life experiences were exposed via his paintings as if under a microscope; revealing the confinement of post war England and calling upon the world to reflect and change!Well, even if you missed Bacon I can only egg you on to enjoy The Gallery of NSW's fine collection of indigenous art, the wonderful Australian Impressionists, Geoffery Smart's shrunken portrait of Clive James. Margaret Preston's woodblocks, portraits of and paintings by Margaret Olly and much, much, much more.I'd recommend setting aside a day or two, if you love art and have not been there before!

One of the best cultural attractions in Sydney. Located adjacent to the magnificent Royal Botanical Gardens with easy access to relatively affordable parking at the Domain parking station, and with no entry fees for general admission, a visit to Sydney's principal art museum is well worth repeat visitation. The Galleries feature a well rounded mix of contemporary and 20th century Australian art accompanied by an excellent collection of masterpieces by the well known Australian and colonial artists.The Museum features both a cafe (with outdoor seating) and an excellent fine dining restaurant.
