don't miss the Aboriginal contributions. you likely didn't come to Sydney for its museums, but this Art Gallery of NSW is actually fairly impressive. Easily reached after alighting at Circular Quay it is across the Botanical Gardens, itslef a delightful stroll. There are both Australian and European galleries, as well as the downstairs Aboriginal contributions that you would not see in New York, London, or Paris. Two-three hours.

Take the Guided tour. So good was the guide in the morning as she introduced us to Australian artists that we went back for more after lunch. Dilys, originally from London, really knew her stuff and we were pleased that we had already spotted some of the best that she returned to to discuss in greater detail. Particular artists that impressed were Stratton, Lambert and Pingouet of the 19th century in NSW. The European tour was equally revealing and we learned a lot about artists from the Renaissance to Picasso and beyond. More than a good intro to the gallery but then return at your leisure to see more of ones that catch your eye. The modern art was fascinating - especially the Bugatti with everything at 20 degrees (see pic).
A good day out. Very impressive art work from all genres. It takes some time to goaround all the exhibits but it is worth ttaking your time over.

Free and Non-flash Photography Permitted. Any museum that allows non-flash photography and is free usually is deserving of an Excellent rating. This is an Excellent museum even without the above. Went on a weekend and it wasn't crowded at all and I got to be part of an art exercise.

A Must. This gallery contains the best of Australian art. Fabulous indigenous work and a wonderful collection of work that depicts early life for those who came from 1788 onwards. A great display of abstract works and some very significant European traditional paintings and sculptures.

A Great Experience. This is a great experience for locals and visitors to Sydney alike. So much to see and the whole building is amazingly set up. Plenty of thought provoking exhibits. Some you will admire, some you will dislike. Whether you think you enjoy "art" or not, it is certainly well worth a visit. And as a free attraction, it is even more impressive. There were plenty of young school children being shown around the gallery during our visit by fabulous guides (presumably art-loving volunteers) - it was wonderful to see 5 and 6 years olds in awe of many of the works. Well done !!

Interesting collection and nice cafe. The free collection is really interesting and diverse, everything from 19th century and Asian to Aboriginal and modern art. You could spend hours wandering here even without ever visiting the paid exhibitions. The café has a nice terrace outside in the sun and does good lunch and reasonable coffee. Also, it's very close to the Botanic Gardens. So you can combine your visit to the Art Gallery with a lovely stroll in the gardens while admiring the view of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge.
A must for those who appreciate art and architecture. The building is amazing, so many styles blending seamlessly together. Many hours spent exploring the vast range of art.

Sydney vacation. I took my 10 and 12 year old to look at the new exhibition. It was fantastic. Whilst we visited during the school holidays it was not overly crowded and it was great to see some of the development that has happened in Sydney over the last 50plus years
In a beautiful location. The walk through the Domain to get to the Gallery is beautiful in itself. It's quite an unpretentious gallery also, and a beautiful building. A must see for any visitor :-)

Diverse old/new, local/international art. Located in the grounds of the Botanical Gardens, the Art Gallery of NSW is an open and bright museum showcasing a diverse collection of old and new art from Australia and abroad. Of particular interest was the considerable contemporary gallery (lower level) that impressed with many interactive pieces and New Media displays, in addition to further new media displays located on the upper levels. It's focus on Australian artists is also notable, providing for a unique collection of paintings, sculpture and mixed media that provide an insight into the two century old city's inspiration upon local artists. Western art is housed in the breathtaking, original 19th century wing, so don't forget to look up. The gallery houses multiple food & drink options (untried) and an OK shop, providing for about 2 to 4 hours hours of sightseeing, depending on your interest in the subject.

Stay for hours. Go for the last Australian Art tour of the day, then stay on for an Art After Dark evening. When we went there was jazz in the cafe, chamber music in the gallery, lecturers in two spots and a very odd, but interesting performance piece. The "We Give Evidence" installation is one of the most powerful art works I've seen.

The art gallery............ This art museum is a very interesting museum. Last time when I went it didn't deliver but it had potential. Now the museum is great with amazing paintings and this museum is huge. Definitely worth a visit if you haven't already.

not very good, but at least it's free. I came to see the Bill Henson exhibition, which turned out to be 10-odd photos with no captions and with (as is unfortunately usually the case with photography exhibitions in mainstream galleries) no EXIF data.I didn't find anything else of interest in the gallery, largely because the staff were really unfriendly when I asked for simple directions, so I really wasn't inclined to ask them about the collection.Entry is free so it doesn't hurt to drop by if you're in the area, but I don't think it's worth going out of your way to visit.
Fantastic Experience. This is a must see if you are a tourist to Sydney. Get there early and have lunch at the cafe. Wonderful atmosphere.

Archibald Prize first rate. I visited Sydney for the weekend and saw the Archibald Prize collection. It was very thought provoking and a great couple of hours. The gallery has loads of other good stuff worth seeing and lunch at the cafe rounded it off nicely.
It's free entry and inspirational. Take the time to spend an hour at agnsw. Always lots to see and a mixture of Australian and international art. Some amazing pieces by Smart and Whiteley on show

Always see fabulous work. It doesn't matter how many times you visit here, you're bound to see something you've never seen before. Exhibitions come and go, paintings get regularly moved and changed. And the new John Kaldor Family Gallery regularly change their exhibits - what a find this is! Even glimpsing Sydney Harbour through the large windows is a treat! The cafe food is good and the shop has lots of fabulous souvenirs, children's books, etc. If you have the chance, also see a film in their theatre. They get their hands on some rare prints and it's the last place in Sydney to view films from film (not digital prints).

Good place if you're an artsy sort of person.. I happen to chance by this area while walking along the botanic garden. Entrance fee was free and the gallery occupies quite a large area. Not sure why, but security seems to be pretty tight. For every 10 portraits there seem to be 1 guard. Seem to be quite an overkill, not too sure why though. Throughout my viewing, I did not manage to see any portraits that i am familiar with despite the wide collection available. Perhaps thats why i didn't find the place very interesting after all.

Place to visit for modern art. The venue combines old and new. The art is striking. Make sure you go to the 4th floor, have a coffee and enjoy the view. The staff scattered around the museum wear "Ask Me" buttons and they truly are there's to help answer questions. Currently this venue is free to the public, take advantage.
I could go back again and again. A beautiful building in a beautiful part of the world. The surroundings are gorgeous, the artworks sensational. A wonderful place to visit

Wonderful place to visit... High Tea is a must!. My husband and I went there with my mother, we wandered through the art gallery before having an exquisite High Tea. I had not expected the food to be such great quality. We will definitely be visiting again!
Just Beautiful. Really lovely place to visit and enjoy all the beautiful paintings and other forms of art. My favourite is the picture of a woman with a budgie in her mouth, weird and wonderful.
Art and More. Most of the art is Australian, which is to be expected, but there are few nice surprises. The building itself is a work of art, and you can easily see what you want in an hour.

A beautiful, serene space in the heart of Sydney. Any visitor to Sydney should pay a visit to the gallery! The collection is substantial and includes European, Asian, and Australian colonial, indigenous and contemporary works. Admission to the permanent exhibition is free. Weekdays are the best time to go, as the exhibition spaces are much less crowded.The gallery also hosts fantastic special exhibitions, which are well worth the admission cost. I saw the Francis Bacon exhibition in February, and it was amazing!

Both content and location are splendid. The art is of very good quality. The best European paintings are from the 19th Century and include some fine Pre-Raphaelite works, notably Madox-Brown's original large painting of Chaucer at the court of the King. The more modern Australian works are striking, especilly those by Drysdale and Nolan. The aboriginal art is fantastic and it is worth going just to see that. Do try the Restaurant, which has wonderful views and good food.

Do a free tour. We go often and are never disappointed, especially with the exhibitions but try and take one of their free tours. The tours give you a bit of insight into this delightful gallery. The cafe is also worth a visit and quite reasonable. Also the gift shop has interesting items to purchase as gifts.

Great intro to Aboriginal Art. This FREE gallery in the Domain has a nice variety of paintings from Europe and Australia as well as sculptures from Asia. Some beautiful Aboriginal Art. The modern art is a nice contrast. There is a lovely restaurant on site.
Archibald Prize. Well worth seeing and only $10.00, the Art Gallery is good value. It is an easy walk through the park from the railway station too.

A great place to visit in Sydney with lots of atmosphere.. The Art Gallery of NSW is housed in a beautiful building with lots of atmosphere. Over the years I have enjoyed The Archibald Exhibitions and Terracotta Warriors and much more. It is a lovely place to vist for a couple of hours and view classic Australian and Overseas Art. I like to have a coffee in the cafe at the Gallery and soak up the vibes. There is metered parking available and the gallery is close to public transport and within walking distance of the centre of the city.

Such an Asset for Sydney. As Sydneysiders, our family looks on the Art Gallery as somewhere to visit guite regularly. Whether to view an outstanding travelling exhibition or to wander amongst the permanent collection, there is always something interesting to see. But it is the atmosphere which attracts me most. It is a light, airy, welcoming, almost informal space with an enthusiastic vibe. It is in a wonderful location with such easy access to the Botanical Gardens, the harbour and the CBD. A great spot to take visitors, or just to meet a friend for a coffee or lunch.

Best museum in Sydney. There are a great number of museums and galleries in Sydney, but the Art Gallery tops my list of favorites for its vast collections of Asian and European art, sculptures, contemporary items, and always lively ambience. It was late in the afternoon the day I went, and I was much enchanted by the live jazz performance at the museum cafe, with the harbor as the backdrop. Would definitely come again.
Art gallery at Sydney. What a wonderful experience. We spent half a day at the Art Gallery and thoroughly enjoyed the exhibitions.

Always worth a visit. Whilst this gallery may not have the commanding presence as the National Gallery in Canberra or the collection of the Melbourne Gallery it is always worth a visit.Found 2013 Archibald VERY average..time for the Trustees to include some NEW artists....thoroughly enjoyed the Children's Archibald and the Helmut Newton photographs.

if you're into art - get in here.. Not the best state gallery in Australia but still worth a visit. Traditional and contemporary Aboriginal art downstairs; Don't be seduced by the old galleries to the right - it's mostly hyper-art from the Victorian period. The galleries to the left have a good selection from Australia's best-loved artists. Avoid the turgid tours - use your own judgement.

Always a great place to visit. I’ve always been visiting the Art Gallery as part of school excursions or on outings with family and friends! It's never boring with such a wide collection available to see whether it be oriental art, renaissance, high school works or modern sculpture!

Archibald and more! After hours surprise.. We visited the gallery to view the Archibald Portrait exhibition. Walking through the Botanical Gardens was a lovely prelude to our visit. The gallery is spacious, bright and quite impressive. The permanent collection was so interesting with many pieces by well known Australian artists set out in time periods. The Korean porcelain display was thought provoking and the Korean prints delightful. The Archibald, Wynne and Sulman Prizes were amazing exhibitions and to see these pieces in situ was a terrific experience. The highlight was discovering the Gallery has an After Hours program on a Wednesday night. The Gallery is open to the public with the restaurant open and access to all exhibitions available. A three piece Jazz Trio was performing for diners creating a friendly warm atmosphere. To top it off, the After Hours program was the free, just turn up and join in art classes run by the Education Officers. We spent 2 hours in the 19th century gallery drawing statues and pieces from pictures with over the shoulder tuition from the well qualified, supportive instructors. What a great initiative by the gallery providing us with a remarkable unplanned experience.

Archibald exhibition. We went to the gallery mainly because the Archibald prize nominations were on show. The paintings were well displayed in a few rooms.
While there we also had a wander around the rest of the gallery which was also well displayed.

Archibald time. The art galley is a great place the spend the mornings, it has the additional advantage of enjoying a morning walk through the botanical gardens at its door steps. The best time to visit is during the Archibald prize to view the offerings of best in Australia art on offer.
a great collection. Some really great shows come through the gallery, as well they have a great permanent collection of Australian and international art.

Visited the permanent exhibitions. We go there every trip and just look at a small part of what is on offer. The main gallery is free, with charges for special exhibitions. They have an ipad app which gives you a good feel for the place.

Worth a visit. Went for the Bacon exhibition but enjoyed some of the Australian artwork that I studied many moons ago. A nice walk through the park to get to and a lovely building. They open late on a Wednesday.

Archibald heaven. Love visiting the Archibald's every year and the gallery certainly does this well. Always enjoy a wander around the free areas and really like being able to sit and just look at paintings and sculptures without feeling hurried.
browsing. they always have interesting shows displayed, easy to get to and the members area is excellent. just walking around is amazing

stumbled on a gem. Stopped in, just to take a break from walking... found really exciting art in what seemed to be permanent installations as well as couple of great special exhibits of photography. Really, it is worth a look.

archibald prize visit. exhibition was interesting,however my husband and i became Separated while viewing the paintings and an overzealous attendant wouldnt allow my husband back into the exhibition to find me. Hope she never becomes separated from anyone and needs help!

An excellent regional gallery. The gallery has a fine collection of aboriginal art and art of Australian artists both in classic and modern styles. And, it has a nice little collection of European art. Definitely worth and hour or two of your time, if you enjoy visiting art museums.A fascination for me is a Degas bronze dancer. The bronze just sits out on a pedestal. And, we watched for several minutes as any number of people walked by the statue and just ignored it. I asked the guard on duty. And she confirmed my observation that most people never even bother to look at. A piece to me that is one of the most valuable pieces in that hall.
archibald. Too crowded could not read the write ups about the artists. the pictures I could see were as to be expected varied and lots of talent, sometimes very hard to find the portrait
Francis Bacon. Went to see the Bacons. A great show. The permenant exhibition is interesting but patchy. Also an exhibition of new work for an annual prise which was very interesting.

Free viewing but Staff watched you like a hawk. A lot of staff walking around watching every move you made. If you seemed to get too close to the painting they came from all directions to make sure you were not going to do anything. Just my own option.

GOOD SMALL TOWN ART GALLERY. Don't expect too much and you won't be disappointed. Limited collection that doesn't compare with the collections in European capitals. At least it's free and the cafe has a pleasant environment.

Great free art. FREE general admission. Most of the gallery is modern and contemporary art which I don't always understand but there were a few cool pieces. There's also art from Asian as well as 15-19th century European and Australian art. Photos without flash are allowed and everything but small purses must be checked (for free) and the door.

Hidden treasure. Free entry to the museum with its many collections to view - Modern, Contemporary, Aboriginal, Classics, Australian ... The cafe overlooks a quite section of the Domain/Botanical Gardens with glimpses over the rooftops of the suburb below, you know the harbour is there ... The cafe has a selection of meals and snacks, with coffee and other refreshments. Well worth a visit. This is a space to relax and enjoy the talents of others.

The best.. Great Australian artists and a good selection of Modern Art / Classic art. Like Tate Modern and Britain all in one building. Restaurant worth going to too. The café did some good coffee and teas.
Art at its best. Most wonderful collection of art worth seeing even on a warm autumn day especially after coffee and picnic in the gardens.

Time for new judges.. The Archibald had 4 very good works (not including the winner), the Sullman was much more interesting but the work judged the winner certainly wasn't among the best 5 and the Sullman is best avoided altogether. I don't know whether it is a lack of taste, ignorance or poor eyesight but we need some new judges for next year!
Archibald prize exhibition.. The gallery itself is always worth a visit. The Archibald Prize Exhibition is a highlight! Portraits are very interesting and some great new approaches are evident!

The Archies well worth a visit. I now live out of state but try to coincide visits back to Sydney to visit family with the annual Archibald, Wynne and Sulman prizes exhibitions.The staff at the AGNSW are unfailingly polite and helpful. The indigenous exhibitions are always worthwhile, and I would go there just to look at Brett Whiteley's masterpiece, The Balcony 2, which remains my favourite Sydney painting.

Who says art is dead. Went to an annual art event called the Archibald Prize - its for portraits. It was amazing. So, so diverse and good work. Then I went to the Bald Archies, which is a send up of the establishments Archibald Prize. These guys have a great sense of humor. Really enjoyed both. As no one takes anything too seriously here. Not stress. "No worries mate" They'll make an aussie of me yet.

Wonderful gallery but ruined by crush at Archibald Prize and school children!. We were visiting from the UK, and have been to the Gallery on many occasions. It is a fantastic collection, with an excellent range of art styles, to suit all interests. However, our main gripe from our last visit was the Archibald Prize showing. For these really popular shows, I think the gallery should consider 'timed' tickets as you get at other venues - when we visited the gallery was so packed, we could hardly see any of the pictures and certainly had no quiet time to stand, observe and contemplate the art. Also, the description cards by each picture were so small and in such tiny font, that people were having to crowd around them to read, thus blocking the paintings even more. Our other issue that day (a school day !) was the huge crowds of school children - it was packed with pre-schoolers up to older teenagers (is it some sort of Aussie School art appreciation day?) - while I fully support children being exposed to art at an early age, the main galleries were also packed and extremely noisy - definitely not my idea of the ideal environment for art appreciation ! Perhaps the schools should be given a day to themselves once a month, when the gallery is shut to the public. We came away feeling pretty disappointed this time. However, on a positive note, this is truly a lovely gallery in a beautiful setting, and should be on any visitors itinerary.
Archibald exhibition. As usual, I can't agree with the winning choice, but at least it was a portrait of someone other than another artist.

Stumbled upon it while walking the botanical gardens. Very clean and clear art displays. Spacious and seemingly endless rooms to visit and pieces to admire. Plenty of communication/information handouts and tours available. I wandered for about 45 minutes with no guide or pre-destined plans. Saw a beautiful wedding party outside... the architecture of the building is as captivating as it's show pieces. Cool gift shop for that hard-to-buy-for person in your life. Extra bonus... it's only about 5 minutes walk from Harry's Cafe de Wheels and their famous meat pies!

So difficult to leave!. So it's embarrassing when all the security guards know you by name because you've been to a gallery every day for the last week- yet take a look at this infinite collection of art with a variety beyond your imagination, and you'll understand why. Now I'm not sure if I prefer the Brisbane Modern Art one or this- it's a tough contest. Go with PLENTY of time.

Worthy place to visit. If you have sufficient time it is worthy to visit art gallery which is free.Only one bus 441 will take you direct to the gallery,other wise you get down at Hyde park and walk for 10 mts.beides st.Mary cathedral.

Archibald Prize. At the gallery annually in April are the Archibald (protrait), Wynn (landscape) and Suleman (subject) art prizes (short list and winners). Always worth a look, but don't overlook the permanent collection which is good and well displayed, or the orignal historical parts of the beautiful building.

Bacon exhibition. we were there to see bacon which was a very good and interesting exhibition. we strolled around some sections that looked really nice but were a bit tired. we loooved the café! amazingly good food, friendly service and nice tables, in and out; worth the money althoug reasonable. very nice museum shop too.

It's far from the MET or the Louvre but it is still a gem in Sydney & worth a visit. The more traditional artworks when you first walk in are hang too clustered together with lots of them above eye level. It is one of the most awful placements I have ever seen at a museum. Probably the curators do not have enough room. The Asian section's and more contemporary section's installations are done much better. And The special exhibitions are always great and not to be missed when they do come around such as francis beacon, picasso and etc. The first night events are awesome and the different festivities and activities that they have there are wonderful as well

Performance Arts Sucks in Sydney. I went to this very beautiful gallery yesterday and while at the bag check a group of middle aged employees of the gallery surrounded me, started jumping up and down and recited the mantra "Isn't this contempory (sic).It was puerile and pointless and really pathetic. The dramaturg or artist provocateur kept calling these aged art attack terrorists into a huddle to redirect their performance. The response seemed to be exactly the same as before each time and his earnest intensity baffling in relation to the activity.I teach performing arts and it makes me shudder to think that people will judge my art form based on this kind of piffle. I also think they should have said 'contemporary' if they were going to do he activity.I enjoyed most of the gallery which is huge and very attractive. I found the Pre Raphealite section most impressive and was surprised to see so many Bacons there. The one Picasso in the collection was pretty unpleasant sadly and doesn't hold a candle to most of the Picasso's in MOMA.Some of the exhibits in the modern exhibitions were repulsive e.g. The tiny naked shrivelled old women, and others creepy and horrible like the dead clowns. I sometimes struggled to work out which were exhibits and which we're storage covers but there seems to be something in this gallery for everyone.One unexpected exhibit was Paul McGann the actor who was there. Of course he may have been there to view the art instead of being the art.

Archibald Prize Exhibit and much more. Spent a very enjoyable visit to the Art Gallery of NSW firstly at the Archibald Prize Exhibit which was really amazing. The gallery has cafes where you can enjoy a light lunch & continue with your visit to the permanent exhibits which are Free. Thoroughly recommend the Asian section guided tour & the Australian section guided tour. Headsets with recorded self guided tour are also available Free.

This art gallery is one of the best. The layout is particularly user friendly, nice and open with wonderful views out over the botanical gardens. I particularly enjoyed the works of Grace Cossington Smith and Arthur Streeton. We took a ferry to Mossman Bay and walked around to Sirrius Cover where he painted. No downsides here.

Archibald plus. Great time of year to visit the Art Gallery as the annual Archibald , Wynne and Sulman prizes are on display in six rooms ( to correct previous poster). $10 entry is not expensive especially when you consider how much it costs to put on the display and that the present government is cutting funds . 2013 Archibald entries particularly good. Very, very popular. My advice go either late in afternoon about 4 pm when crowds dissipate or Wednesday evening when the Gallery is open for Art after Hours. BUT make sure you also see the artists of the future the ARTEXPRESS display of 2012 HSC major works. Sometimes better than the "professionals".

What you would expect -art!. Went here over easter - wanted to see the Archibald exhibition. 10 bucks was probably a bit rich for 30 paintings in three rooms but I guess that is what you pay these days. The rest of the galleries were great.
archibald prize. As always worth a trip to Sydney to see this and hang out in such a wonderful space. Art express is also worth seeing. Amazing talent for such young people.

Take one of the free tours if you can. I was lucky enough to be in Sydney when the Archibald finalists were on display which was really great, but the rest of the gallery was fantastic too. I went on two of the free tours run by volunteers and they were great. I find I get a lot more appreciation for the modern art collections once someone explains the concept behind it!They also do free movie showing on Sunday afternoons, so if you want a cheap day in Sydney, you could spend a bit of time here!

Step back in time. The Art Gallery is perfectly situated to visit in combination with a coastal walk from the Opera House, or a stroll through the Botanical Gardens, or across the park from the CBD. I have never been to one of the special exhibits, but there are lovely permanent ones. I especially like the 19th century Australian and the Aboriginal exhibits.because they afford a glimpse of Australian history and culture simply not available elsewhere.

Archibald Prize and Art Express, a must see!. This was a great afternoon spent looking at the chosen best portraits painted for 2013 Archibald Prize. These exhibitions are a great way to experience NOW art, to keep up with Australian contemporary work, it is varied both in the subjects and the media, size and technique. There is something for everyone and you can vote for your own favourite at the end. The Wynn Prize exhibition is certainly less interesting and frankly boring this year however the Sulman Prize entries were certainly more exciting. The cost is reasonable at $10 entry. Combine your hour or so and go upstairs to see budding artists, year 12 student works submitted for their HSC...brilliant, exciting, talented students. This is FREE. You can then do a quick look around the ret of the Gallery which is compact. The cafes are great, indoor and outdoor.
Archibald 2013. Great exhibition once again but make sure you buy your tickets online before hand to avoid the line ups. I'd recommend going early in the day as it gets busier by about late morning.

An international standard art museum. The Art Gallery of NSW is a must-see for visitors to Sydney remotely interested in art. Excellent Australian and international permanent collections, both contemporary and historic are on display.Excellent "blockbuster" exhibitions feature regularly, such as the large Picasso exhibition in 2011.The Art Gallery has a cafe with a beautiful view of the Sydney Harbour and is set in the lovely grounds of The Domain.

Free Art. Great gallery spaces and great artwork and the price is perfect, FREE. A must do for the whole family, not only is there an outstanding collection of Australian Art there are also European collections as well as contemporary work on display, there is something for everyone.

It's OK. There are many respected Australian art works on display. Not much else of interest. Spent an hour or two looking for something to challenge artistic interest, and didn't find it!More interesting were the speakers outside the front of the Gallery, on the other side of the street. Reminiscent of Speaker's Corner in Hyde Park, London, they had lots to say about almost everything.
Unexpected. Surprised yet again by the city. The last thing we expected was such a quality facility, with some seriously famous paintings on display.

Visit on a Wednesday. Whether it's on your cultural hit list or you just need to cool down in an air-conditioned sanctuary for a while, this gallery ticks all the boxes. Aside from the special exhibition (which depending on your tastes may be well worth the ticket price) entry is free. And there's plenty to look at, from aboriginal art to old masters and much more besides - including some very contemporary works. But if you can, visit mid week. Not only is it late night opening there are likely to be extra attractions going on too. We stumbled upon live music in the cafe, a curator's tour and a discussion forum. The whole building is a bit of a tardis and first impressions from the outside can be misleading as there's lots is space to easily swallow up the hoards of visitors.
A bit of serendipity. We stumbled upon the Art Gallery of NSW while we were out walking thru the botanic gardens and it is really nice. I loved looking thru the eclectic art selection!

Bacon Art Exhibition. A truly elegant and beautiful building set in the magnificent surrounds of the Domain. A short walk to the Botanic Gardens, and on to the Opera House and Harbour Bridge. Great art as well

Always worth a visit. This is one of our favorite places to visit whenever we come to Sydney. We know there will be a remarkable, well-curated exhibition (this time it was Francis Bacon). We make sure to plan our visit so we can have lunch or afternoon tea at the Restaurant, with its lovely views and excellent food.
I like it!. Besides all the coming exhibitions the gallery has a pretty good stationery exhibition. Having a European heritage i was pleased with that. I've been several times over the years

Wednesday nights at the Gallery are a treat. On my own for an evening in Sydney, I went for a walk through Hyde Park and the Domain and ended up at the Gallery on dusk. I was warmly welcomed inside and spent an hour or two wandering the exhibits, catching parts of presentations, and strains of music playing live in the Cafe. A lovely (free) bonus to a business trip.
Nice Museum. Easy to do in a short period of time, this is a nice museum. The building is beautiful from the outside and implies a much more extensive collection than what is actually in the museum.

Francis Bacon exhibition-great afternoon out. Fantastic dressing to the building for the exhibition. Great drama in the works. Great to see Bacons relationship with Brett Whiteley.
Love the Gallery of NSW, its cafe, views, the light and space.

It is okay. I don't know too much about art but when I get into the gallery I know it very arrangement, you can either walk around the floors or you can seat on the sofa and have look all products through ipad... very modern

Such a great space. It is easy to spend the day here. The exhibitions are excellent and the cafe has a terrific range of well priced food and drinks. The Francis Bacon exhibition was superb. Always worth a trip to Sydney to visit here.

The best gallery I saw in Sydney. Well laid out, with different galleries including European art, 19th century Australian art, modern Australian art etc. Great to trace the work of Australian artists through the years by comparing it to the trends of Europe. Spent about two hours. There are some classic pieces of iconic Australian art to, such as the work by Sidney Nolan.

Do not expect the Louvre or the Metropolitan !. We went for the Francis Bacon exhibit and it was FANTASTIC. But other than that, do not expect to see art works from the masters (may be a couple). This is NOT the Louvre, or the musee d'Orsay, the Metropolitan, or Chicago: it is just NOT. So, if you expect to see Picasso, Matisse, Modigliani, Van Gogh: you will be disappointed.

I like this museum so much been here many many times. I like this museum so much been here many many times there is so much beautiful paintings from all parts of the world and is a facinating and enlightening place to be visit also the location is awesome

Good Art, Bad Layout but Free. While there is some great Art and the building itself is beautiful, the layout is terrible, i ended up missing a section because i couldnt find it and had to go asking people. Plus i find it hard to call something an Art Gallery when they have the name of a world famous artist spelled wrong on the front of the building. See if you can find it. I'll give a clue, it should be only one word or used the correct last name. I do argree with them with having Art being free for everyone and believe that all national galleries should be.

Free and Great. Im not a art maverick but i loved my visit to the Art Gallery of NSW. Free tours are conducted regularly and entrance is free. The variety of art work is amazing- from Impressionist to scuptures to modern art and aboriginal art. Note that pictures arent allowed in the aboriginal art section.

Brilliant! A must when you are in Sydney. Rain today in Sydney so popped into the art gallery, so pleased it rained! Had checked out what was on via the Internet and it looked very interesting, I wasn't disappointed. Fantastically set out with several floors of exhibits. The art was amazing, you must go and visit when in Sydney whether the weather is bad or not! Free entry and free wifi.

A big part of Sydney. The NSW Art Gallery is a very worthwhile visit. There is an extensive mix of interest art and some updated interesting architecture to the rear of the gallery. It looks over The Domain. A very worthwhile visit.

State of the Art. Here you can find all sorts of interesting photos, paintings and sculptures. Things to expand your mind and your field of vision. Lots of people around on weekends so it's best to go on a weekday in my opinion.

excellent visit - well curated museum. Loved the museum enjoyed the exhibitions and permanent collection. The whimsical broken bust sculpture in the entrance was really great. Walked through the gardens to get here which was quite nice.

and its mostly free. sydneys temple of art with many of the early famous painters displayed and with frequent block buster displays great coffee shop with harbour views and nice food good asian gallery
Wonderful. One walks through the beautiful Botanic Gardens to get to this beautifully situated building, and again, it's free except for special exhibits. Another Sydney treasure.

Definitely worth the visit!. There was a huge range of art, from Aboriginal to modern to old world. The building itself is a work of art and encourages one to browse, take their time and absorb all there is to offer.

Love this place inside out!. As Sydneysider we are so lucky having quite many fantastic Art Gallery and Museum. Whenever I have visitors or even just myself this is a place I frequently visit. Beautiful art selection and the location will give extra walking enjoyment.

Australia's "call and response" to artistic movements. We spent four and a half focused hours at this museum (not including the satisfying scones and clotted cream pick-me-up in its cafe), discovering the richness with which Australian artists responded to and at times anticipated artistic trends we had only known through U.S. and European museums. Here a set of landscapes that called to mind the Hudson Valley School; there a Monet-like village; over there, a Manet-like portrait; onto symbolism and abstractions . . . . Plus of course the scenes so emblematic of aspects of Australian life, such as the sheep-sheering. I felt like I had won the lottery in coming across this previously unknown-to-me trove of artists and works!We also were excited to view works of aboriginal art, both historic and contemporary, and found many compelling pieces. However, I will say that the legends describing aboriginal art both at the Museum of Australia (primarily a science museum) and the smaller Discovery Museum (in the Rocks area) were more detailed, helping us to understand better the context and aims of the artists and the pieces themselves. A few more words of description or explanation would have enhanced our time in these galleries of the NSW Museum. But, I have to stress that the Australian holdings (settlers and aboriginal) were so strong that we only very briefly walked through the European galleries (just to see what they contained) and never did get to the Asian ones, an omission we made sadly.
Must do. Amazing art works! A must see in sydney. Perfect for a rainy day, families and solo visits are also fantastic.
yuk. It was completly boring. The most interesting part is the architecture of the building. Been twice and both times was bored to death.

Francis Bacon exhibition!. My husband and I went into the City to view the Francis Bacon exhibition which was in fact wonderful. However after we had paid our $20 admission fee each we were told that we couldn't have a catalogue as they had all run out :( Not really acceptable when there was still over a week of the exhibition to run and think I it was very bad planning on their part!

Small but selective collection. The building is not large by New York or London standards, but the collection is designed to reflect Australian art, and Asian (including modern artists). The museum shop is worth a long look, and the High Tea is the best in Sydney (but book for this). Excellent views from the floor to ceiling windows.

Create some time to visit NSW. This is a beautiful stop for art lovers.The aboriginal collection gives you a fair idea. The Francis Bacon exhibition was very informative and the film with the curator really wrapped it up.The cafe is very nice. I walked throuhgh the Botanical Garden until The Opera House and enjoyed every moment of my day.
Great Gallery. I spent an afternoon at the gallery and quite enjoyed it. I especially liked the availability of free guided tours of the exhibit (Francis Bacon).
I love this gallery... This time I visited the NSW Gallery specifically to see F Bacon exhibition and it was fantastic.. As with my other visits, I spent a bit of time in the modern art areas.. Nice!

Great tour on Aboriginal Art. I had read on tripadvisor that there was a free tour of aboriginal art at 10:00 a.m. at the museum. The tour was so interesting and gave me so much insight into the aboriginal art and how it is so different depending on the area from where the art form originates. We had lunch at the cafe in the museum. Very nice. We asked about free tours for the next day in case it rained. You could have spent the whole day doing free tours at the Gallery. We did not make it back the next day, but worth a call to the gallery to check on the day's tours. Sorry we did not have more time in Sydney.

amazing exhibitions. Really beautiful building just near the botanical gardens. They get great exhibitions and have a really nice, diverse permanent collection. Its nice to go at night on a Wednesday. The cafes are surprisingly nice and reasonably priced for a museum.

Wonderful art gallery. I visited here on the hottest day in Sydney's records. It was brilliant. A very good guide took us round the Australian Art for over an hour and was knowledgable and fascinating. I learnt a lot.

a good exhibition of 20th century work. my wife and i enjoyed our visit to the gallery, we had expected a larger display of aboriginal work we did enjoy the 20th Century art. it is a good gallery and the cafe was pleasant

Heidelberg School. I came to this Gallery specifically to see works by this group of painters whose work is so expressive of Australia and its beautiful nature - Arthur Streeton in particular seems very well represented here - a good visit all round and I enjoyed the other exhibits too.As the Francis Bacon exhibition was on I went - although I find his work quite disturbing and hideous although superb in its execution - he could paint the socks off a lot of his contemporaries.
Francis Bacon. The art gallery is always a good place to visit even if there is not an exhibition. I loved the Francis Bacon exhibition.

Must-see: Five Decades of Bacon! (Francis Bacon - You Didn't Really Think I Meant Food, Did You?). This is a must-visit for travelers and those domiciled in the Sydney area!I have visited the gallery at least 10 times, along with most of Sydney's museums and galleries. The Art Gallery of NSW is, without a doubt, my favorite. Their permanent collection is truly a treasure, a brilliant and robust display of many of the world's (arguably) finest and well-known artists, which features broad and notable displays of Impressionism, Abstraction, Contemporary and Indigenous/Aboriginal art, sculpture, Ancient and Asian art.***The special exhibition, in my opinion, is ALWAYS worth visiting. Currently, the gallery is featuring Francis Bacon's works until 23 Feb '13. Do NOT miss this, and be sure to take the free guided tour. The guides are exceptionally well-informed and will most definitely make your visit memorable with a wonderfully prepared narrative, which captures and contextualizes Bacon and his works in a unique light.***General admin. is free. Special exhibition is $20 for adults, $10 for children, and ***2-for-1 tix are avail 1 night only on 13 Feb from 5-9PM.*** Parking is easy. The Botanic Gardens are across the way from the gallery, with the CBD, Circular Quay, Opera House, many other points of interest, hotels and restaurants shortly beyond that. The gallery is very accessible, and an easy, worthwhile activity for anyone in the Sydney area.

The City's Finest Gallery. The Art Gallery of NSW is a must see for travellers and art lovers. Car Parking is available in the Domain underground car park for a reasonable set fee on a weekend and it will save you having to move the car around or try and find street parking in the Domain itself. The Gallery itself features multiple levels of exhibitions within a complex that embraces both postmodern and classical/gothic architectural surrounds and carries a wide range of art in its various forms. Regular collections on display incorporate painting, multimedia, sculpture, digital and a wide range of Asian and Indigenous art. Entry is free. Touring Exhibitions are a highlight, a personal fave being 2011's Manga exhibition. The annual HSC art exhibit - Art Escape - is also very worthwhile and is run in the first quarter of each new year. Most of the touring exhibitions attract an additional fee however it is usually reasonable given the cost of other art galleries globally and if you are a regular attendee, becoming a member of the Gallery will give you discounted tickets as well as access to free exhibitions. The Art Gallery's shop is comprehensive is providing a selection of prints and art resources as well as popular culture items so souvenir buying is not an issue. The cafe is also reasonable in offering a range of hot and cold items from hearty lunches to snacks and sweets. The Gallery also offers a range of workshops for budding artists and you'll find that there are often talka and musical performances on offer from students of the local Conservatorium and Australian Institute of Music to accompany select openings and exhibitions. In summry, the Art Gallery of NSW is definitely worth a visit whether it be to view a Gaugin, a Picasso or a Warhol. Lovers of edgy, contemporary sculpture will embrace many of the exhibits while lovers of colonial and classic art will find more than enough to entrance them.

An Art lovers must. I'm a regular that this gallery, in fact I'm a member. They have a selection of great exhibitions per year, as well as great permanent collections (old, contemporary, Asian the list goes on). You can dine there at the cafe or restaurant and can book their function space for an event (wedding reception etc). Do yourself a favour and take yourself along to the gallery.

good gallery. We only went (for free with voluntary donations) through the standard exhibits. It is not too far from the botanical gardens & Hyde Park & the Domain, so we started in those places & ended up enjoying a cool stroll through the exhibits. Big museum.
Inspirational gallery. Spacious, well lit, well curated exhibits; excellent collection of Aboriginal and modern Australian art.

Always enjoy a visit. Went specifically to see the Frances Bacon exhibition, which we enjoyed, but felt, after seeing the Bacon exhibition in Dublin, that this was was a bit clinical, and lacked insight into Bacon. We also spent time looking a the photographic exhibition also on display, showcasing some of the Gallery's works. So over all worthwhile.

Fantastic art. Incredible displays.... WE loved the art gallery. We always visit art galleries, and museums in the cities we visit. This was well worth the limited time we had to sight see....thanks a lot nsw!

Francis Bacon exposition. Fantastic Selection of Francis Bacon artworks!Masterfully organized. The only downside - initially staff instructed us that we can take pictures anywhere in the Gallery (except for aboriginal exposition). And then different staff members kept on chasing us for making photos....

Free and interesting art exhibition.. I thought this was very good and with free entry it does compliment a visit to the botanical gardens perfectly. Should take you around 2 hours depending on your interest. It is bigger than it appears from the entrance. Many works from classical to modern and sculpture as well as a South Asia exhibition. I enjoyed the pieces on the french revolutionary war and classical Rome. It is possible to get a bite to eat, they have a normal cafe and another white tablecloth affair which is pricier but has live classical music.  Some very alternative art downstairs which will get you thinking and discussing your point of view. Surroundings are very nice and it is possible to walk from circular quay to get here. Would highly recommend.
First class art gallery. The collection is large and extremely well presented in a lovely setting. We enjoyed the cafe after exploring the European, Australian and aboriginal art

Should be better. I went to this gallery with tickets for the Francis Bacon exhibition which was well set out but not my cup of tea. The rest of the gallery made the trip worthwhile, but only just. I was surprised that more of the collection was not on display.Best part is the iconic Australian paintings that would be recognised by anyone.Worst was that there must be some Whiteleys there but I couldn't find any.

interesting. it's a huge library and periodically updated with new arts. so if your visit to Sydney is long you might consider going there more than once if you enjoy Art. it has a timetable so it closes around 5pm most days. Entry is free, except for special events that might cost something as little as 15 to 20$

Lots to see!. Spent a couple hours, saw most of the art that was on display. Especially liked the "basement" exhibit, scarrrrry! Also really liked the distorted "Bugatti" automobile and the burnt gold log with the two pictures pre-burned. Added to my cultural experiences, worth the visit.
Frances Bacon. Excellent exhibition - a really unusual artist. Also good to revisit some of the Australian classics.

Great special exhibits and a free permanent collection. We visited the Art Gallery to view the Frances Bacon exhibit and were very impressed with the museum. Before arriving in Sydney, we were recommended to walk along the harbor, through the Royal Botanical Gardens, and visit the museum, and we spent a lovely morning doing just that! Anyone can view the permanent collection free of charge, but the special exhibits cost about $20. We were lucky enough to happen upon a curator talk of the Bacon exhibit that took guests through the works for about an hour. My husband is not very interested in art but stayed engaged in the talk-- it was really a treat. It would be worth looking at the website before a visit to see if you could benefit from the museum's educational programs.

strange building add ons, great art. From the classical facade to the ugly 1960's extension the AGNSW is Sydneys top art gallery. It's a wonderful place to visit. best part is that it's free for the standard collection.

Friendly and welcoming. Check your heavy bags at the front counter (free of charge) and join in one of the free tours that leave regularly. You will learn so much from the knowlegable guides. Ticketed events can be a bit crowded, but you can usually move through ahead of any big bunches of people and then come back through when it is a bit quieter.

Bacon at the Gallery. What I did know about Bacon's work could only be helped by a greater exposure and that is exactly what occurred.The very familiar gallery, beautiful position, elegant display design & good collection (I wonder what is not displayed, is there a chronicle of any gallery or museums full collections?)Bacon exhibition was educational and stimulated a followup of greater exposure i.e. dvds and reading. Always a wonderful place to visit.
Awesome.. Got a volunteer tour - one of the best times we had in Sydney. What a remarkable experience! Loved the art and the love that the lady gave it. I wish I remembered her name.

Always interesting. The fixed exibits are world class and the events are always intersting and well presented. The location of the gallery at the top of the Domain makes for an enjoyable walk from the city. The little cafe in the grounds of the Domain are perfect to recoup after walking around the gallery.

Great Museum, something for everyone. I was very pleased with the Art Gallery of NSW, very conveniently located near the Royal Botanical Gardens, it has a little something for everyone. My favorite part of the museum were the contemporary aboriginal paintings.

Great Place to Meet with Plenty to talk about. Loved the older art, paintings and so forth on the right hand side as you walk in. I don't think contemporary art is my cup of tea. A plain blue tile on a wall is not art regardless of what anyone says LOL.I did end up here twice in one week - slight overkill. My sister from regional interstate was needing some culture and later in the week my mother was keen to see Australia work by Tom Roberts and such.Place is well laid out. Cafe is expensive and I didn't have a pie but they looked and smelt much better than the sandwich and salad I ordered when I was there.Maybe not the first point of call for a tourist but certainly a place worth seeing for the locals wanting something different to do.

A World Class Museum. We spent about four hours at the Art Gallery of NSW, and still hadn't seen everything. But one's legs, at least at our age, have limits. Wonderful European art, a fabulous Australian collection that introduced us to some first-rate artists we were not familiar with, and a very thorough Aboriginal art collection as well. And the Asian galleries - including significant collections of Chinese, Japanese, and Indonesian art - were very impressive.

An oldie and a goodie. I've been here a few times, each trip spaced a year or so apart. Every time, it has been a no-nonsense, no-fuss wonderful time. Make sure you have a bit of extra time in your schedule to have a good look around, plus a bit of extra cash if it just so happens that there is a (pay to enter) traveling exhibition at the gallery you want to see.

Always a place to spend a couple of pleasant hours. I have visited the Art Gallery many times over many years and always enjoyed the experience. The permanent collections cover a wide range of works over a span of time, all housed in an attractive building with great facilities such as the reference library, the Gallery shop and the restaurant/cafe.
Good International exhibitions. Exhibition of Francis Bacon paintings plus the permanant collection make this an important cultural stop -
Amazing Gallery. Spend the afternoon here.It free and worth spending an afternoon.It airy and an amazing space... The cafe is over priced but has a great view

Room with a view. Loved the classic artists. They always make me sit and think and that is one things that I love about the gallery is that you can sit and view these works to contemplate their affect on your life. The modern art does not hold and enjoyment for me, but the contemporary Australian artists were fantastic. With free entry and free coat/bag check it was well worth the visit.
Art Gallery. An icon of Art that everyone iterested in culture must visit. We have some amazing peices and you must spend 2/3 hours here.

Wonderful, varied art collection. Although I went for the aboriginal and islander art exhibit (a gem), this is a terrific collection in a beautiful building, in an easily accessible area of downtown Sydney that has something for everyone. The large city park in which the gallery is located is itself worth the effort to explore, as are the surrounding downtown areas.

Stunning, plan to spend several hours!. Most of the gallery was free entry, and we spent about four hours exploring all the different exhibits. What a stunning building and beautiful exhibition spaces. So glad we took the time to see such an amazing place. Worth a visit.

Just wonderful. I've loved this gallery since I was a kid. I went back for the first time in years the other week and found it's just as good as I remember, possibly even better. For me, hands down the best part of the gallery is the contemporary artists section on the left as you walk in. The magnificent Indigenous artwork in the entrance gallery, makes the gallery worth a visit by itself - before you even get to the stunning Boyd and Whiteley works, and THAT'S just what you can find in the first two minutes inside the building!

A must for visitors. Check out what's on and head for the Art Gallery. It is located in an historic district and well laid out. A must for visitors staying in the CBD. We viewed the Paths to Abstraction exhibition and thoroughly enjoyed it.

Wonderful exhibits!. We spent three hours in this thought provoking museum. Excellent collection of contemporary art with an excellent perspective of the effect of the European arrival on the indigenous population. Highly recommend this venue....and it's excellent rooftop cafe with its waterfront location on the Quay.
Love the gallery. Spent hours in the gallery. Amazing paintings and contemporary art. Includes art from different cultures. Can't take photos for Aboriginal art. And it's free!
Great venue and great food. Exhibitions are always really well put together.Lunch in the fine dining restaurant is always memorable.Alternatively lunch in the cafe is always very easy with kids.
Picasso.. I saw the Picasso exhibition and was not disappointed! What a beautiful gallery - not only do they have amazing visiting collections, but the permanent display is not to be missed.

Francis Bacon show is Sensational. The Art Gallery of NSW is one of the highlights of Sydney for art lovers. At the moment the Francis Bacon show is a real treat. The permanent collections is pretty good and the Botanical gardens across the way are really nice.

Great gallery, easy to navigate.. The nsw gallery is a fantastic outing, recently went to Francis bacon which was a well thought out exhibition. The great thing is the galleries location, between the botanical gardens for a picnic before hand or woolloomooloo wharf for great restaurants.

A feast of Bacon. The Francis Bacon exhibition currently showing at AGNSW is brilliant and one of the best shows ever at this gallery. Sensitively curated and wonderfully hung these gems of 20th century art have to be seen to be believed. Highly recommended. Just don't bother with the expensive gallery cafe after the show!

such a great collection. first time we came, the afternoon was just not enough time to enjoy it all, so had to go back for more, it was such a refuge, great collection, can really wander at own pace, not crowded at all, will visit again for sure
Very good - great views. Loves the restaurant. Good modern cuisine. Stunning views. Highly recommended. Service was efficient. Menu for lunch was short but covered all bases. No problems.
Always something great to see. Don't aim to see everything - like all galleries of this size there is just so much to see. Afterwards have a picnic in the grounds!

Francis Bacon Exhibition - OUTSTANDING!!. We purchased early entry tickets to the exhibition and we had a FANTASTIC guide. She was able to tell us so much about the exhibition that even my 12 year old daughter is still talking about how amazing Francis Bacon was.
Thank you John Kaldor. For contemporary art lovers, this gallery is second to none. Also currently is the brilliant and disturbing Francis Bacon exhibition. Fascinating in its train-wreck appeal

Art Hub. A dynamic place for local and international exhibitions, Art-related movies, lectures, Aboriginal art. Have a break at the cafe overlooking the water. The perfect place to spend a rainy day! On a sunny one, enjoy a walk in the Botanical gardens afterwards, arrive at the Opera House, and from there if you're not Art-saturated, you could even go on to the MCA.

Great free activity. Nice selection of art, and entry is free of charge, what more could you ask for? There was a small fee for the featured show, Francis Bacon, but my dad is not a fan of his work and the rest of us are not that into art, so we looked at the many other rooms on various floors besides that one.
Francis Bacon exhibit. Fantastic exhibit, very well put together. Other exhibits great too, easy to spend best part of a day here.

French photography display. Reasonably priced entrance to the special displays and a very good special photograph display at the time of my visit. Nice views from the cafe. And picked up some cute gifts from the shop.

Good food at the Art Gallery of NSW. The view was great and the food was pretty good. It was a nice way to end a day at the Gallery. The Gallery in general is lovely, nicely laid out. We had great views of Sydney and were able to relax and eat a leisurely meal.

Great Day out. Well organised, nice cafe which is relaxing after or before a tour of the Museum and a good way to spend at morning or afternoon.
Tour guide was helpful and pleasant.

just go. We went to see the exhibition on Picasso, it was definitely worth it. There are a number of other (some permanent, some not) exhibitions that are worth visiting. And the gallery is right next to the botanical gardens - great place for a walk.

Wonderful aboriginal art & docent tours. The Art Gallery of NSW is in the Botanic Gardens, so firstly it is a pleasure to walk to. It was a 1900 ish building that has been modified for more contemporary use. There are many rooms of European art, which I think was the first item of interest for early Sydneysiders, but now there is a good aboriginal collection. And I went on a good (free) tour of the aboriginal art with a very informed guide. The museum is free and has interesting temporary exhibits. Nice Asian collection as well.

Upper floor restaurant is not a let down. Normally I avoid the restaurant in any art gallery, serving up, as they do luke warm food with luke warm service.Not at the upper level restaurant in the Art Gallery NSW. Spectacular views over Sydney Harbour flow into the glass walled space whose tables are far apart and offer dining privacy with lots of room to rubber neck the view. Food is contemporary Australian and well done. Prices are contemporary too with service friendly and professional with not a hint of attitude.My party of seven enjoyed the full menu and stayed long, pleasantly surprised at the quality of our experience. Dont dodge this place for fear of a bad time. A wonderful way to visit the gallery.

An Amazingly Diverse and Delightful Museum. This museum is a bit of a surprise. The front exterior is neoclassical and might appear to be rather dated. Will you be in for a surprise! The interior is quite modern and there is a addition on the rear of the museum that is anything but neoclassical. The museum has an excellent and diverse collection, to include a wonderful array of contemporary art. I am a former contemporary art museum docent and totally enjoyed the variety and quality of their contemporary art. I spent a full day here, leaving at closing!
What A Find. We thought oh no, just Aussie artists, but they had a fantastic selection of all eras. And very helpful staff too

Peaceful and something for everyone. A terrific selection of Australian art from colonisation through to today. The well known and the less famous. Great Asian galleries as well, sculptures abound, a choice between a simple cafe and a lovely fine dining restaurant (with the most spectacular views!), shop with a fabulous selection of gifts make this a real pleasure to visit. The building itself is lovely, airy, light and tranquil. There are always good exhibitions going on, tours, classes and talks.

Go by yourself. I always seem to have to negotiate with my kids/partner when I go here. So I've learned to do it on my own instead. From the parquet floors to the towering ceilings, the artworks take my breath away. I could sit for hours just gazing at what lies before me. Go on your own, take your time, love what you are doing... It's a complete pamper of your senses.

A beautiful gallery in beautiful surrounds. Set close to the gardens in one of the early settled parts of Sydney, it is a lovely way to spend a day - easy to walk to from the city and enjoy the parks and gardens on the way.A good variety of art and the exhibitions change regularly and are always worth seeing - at the moment, an outstanding exhibition of Francis Bacon: Five Decades and this will be a huge attraction.

So fun and free.. Nice art, wide variety. We paid extra for special exhibit but I can't remember what it was right now, though it was good. Dang. It sucks getting old. We ate in the cafe, was very good. Beautiful outside patio.
Beautiful Gallery and exhibits. Interesting exhibitions in beautiful surrounds. Restaurant very good, cafe so-so. Talks/ lectures etc. consistently excellent. Staff are helpful and attentive.

A lovely building with a wonderful collection.. This building is very impressive, it would be intersting to know a little more of its history but that was not easy to source. The collection is stunning, some great aboriginal works, and some very famous European masters. Highly recommended.

Treat yourself. My family and I always visit the Gallery when in Sydney and we have become quite familiar with it. There are always special exhibitions (last time we visited it was Dream Symbolism - before that, Picasso) and the permanent exhibits are well worth regular perusal. It doesn't compare well with Canberra's ANG, given the ANG's sculpture garden is superb and the Art Gallery of NSW seems to have just been plopped into it's environment without attempt at artistic integration... but, in every other way, it's a reliably energising experience.BTW, for film buffs there's a great selection of DVD's in the gallery's shop and I can never resist buying a few...
Lovely Sydney Gallery. Gorgeous Gallery, not quite got the collection that European galleries would have but still a superb collection and nicely laid out.
One of Australia's great galleries. We spent most of a day at the gallery looking at its extensive collection and enjoyed a fine lunch at the gallery cafe with a view over the harbour.
Love the place. its an amazing gallery, not quite European standard of artwork but interesting none the less, Always has great installations and visiting works

Art in Sydney is free. The Art Gallery of Sydney is very impressive! It's all the Famous Australians painters as well as many European painters and art from Asia. It's a very welcoming place and you can see art without having to pay at all. There is only one exhibition room where you have to pay to enter but the rest is all free! The Gallery is in a beautiful part of Sydney, next to the Botanical Gardens and The Domain. If you walk around to Mrs Macquarie Chair, you have the best view to the Opera House.

Afternoon of art. My partner and I do not usually go to museums or art galleries whilst on holiday but we had some time to kill one afternoon and what a lovely treat - the gallery is free and has a varied and large collection to suit all tastes!

Don't pass this by!. This is a beautiful, airy, roomy gallery with stunning views out over Wooloomooloo. Its collection is enthralling, with European, White and Aboriginal Australian work all well hung and displayed. I am always fascinated by the light the paintings shed on the history of the early settlers, and by the depictions of native flora and fauna. The gallery is right opposite the gate to the Botanic gardens so if you travel by train to St James you can walk down through the Domain, look round the gallery, walk through the Botanic Gardens and come out to the Opera House and Circular Quay. It's a very satisfying way to spend a day, or half a day if your time is limited. There is no admission fee either to the gallery or the gardens.

Art gallery and more. Wonderful free events Wednsdays from 5pm to 9pm
I enjoyed the French movies at Domain Theatre in the gallery
Also Old Paris exhibition very interesting.

THE museum to visit in Sydney. Set in the beautiful botanic gardens, the Art Gallery boasts a great collection and offers exciting temporary exhibits. Great for the first-time visit to Sydney....and free entry!

Art that's accessible to all. Apart from its superb collection of Old - and new - Masters, the setting is superb. The green swards of Sydney Domain on one side, and the expanses of Sydney Harbour on the other. The coffee shop and restaurant should NOT be missed for their views as much as for their fare.

Some interesting exhibitions. We were there a couple of weeks ago and saw some brilliant old B & W and sepia photos of "Old Paris" taken last Century. Check out its current visiting exhibitions - they can be quite innovative and exciting.

Great Gallery. I found the place by accident without prior plan, but it was amazing, enjoyable visit from the gallery which took 3 hours, lots of 18 and 19th centuries arts, don't lose your chance to visit the gallery if you are going to Sydney
Good collection of australian and asian art. Always a special collection on show. Good aboriginal section, good modern art and asian art as well as some good old european stuff

A must see for locals and visitors alike. It is wonderful that this gallery has free entry. The art works on display are world class and it is a privilege that anyone can go in and enjoy them at no cost. The location of the gallery, being set in the gardens is also wonderful and then the views over the harbour from the coffee shop makes each visit worthwhile. I love the gift shop. It is reasonably priced and has very interesting pieces that you won't find anywhere else. The special exhibits that are brought in are always fabulously curated and well worth the price of the ticket. The Art Gallery is often a place that only tourists go, but locals should see it too and be thrilled at this world class facility.

Ab-originals -and some modern classics. Great gallery, with an excellent aboriginal art collection. A great insight into native Australian culture. Also an excellent restaurant -try the beetroot salad! They're also open late on Wednesday evenings until 9pm, for an extra large dose of culture.

World class, free entry, surrounded by gardens and water. AGNSW sits in the domain parklands next to the Botanic Gardens and Harbour. It takes 10 mins to walk through the Domain from the CBD. In Summer the gallery stays open late at least 1 night a week so check the website. A decent gallery experience will take you between 2 and 3 hours depending on whether you also do one of the optional special exhibitions (of which there are usually 2 on concurrently) at a cost (well worth it). The gallery space is approx twice the size of SF's Legion of Honour Museum, and includes an excellent modern extension housing a good affordable restaurant with a north facing outdoor terrace offering harbour views and an enormous historic Moreton Bay Fig tree. I am Australian who takes Art holidays o/s and I am very proud of our AGNSW. It is unpretentious so don't be afraid of showing up "looking like a tourist with a back pack" as you can cloak your bags for free. The collection of contemporary Australian big name artists is extensive and impressive, and there is an equally worthy collection of international art (modern and period). The gift shop may be a bit of a dissapointment to those used to stores like the de young but that's a small criticism. Check out what is happenning in the Domain and the Botanical Gardens before you arrive so you can maximise your day, or walk a little further north past the entrance and turn right to take the stairs to the excellent bars and restauarants on the waterfront at the Woolloomoolloo Finger Wharf. This area is very safe for travellers.
A contemporary expeience. Saw the dynamism and variety of art and related works.As an art aficionado I truly replenished my vision and got back with appropriate amount of motivation.

Great gallery but neighbouring New Zealand missing. The Art Gallery of NSW is located in a beautiful location next to the Botanic Gardens and in an impressive building. A good mix of collections of Australian, European and Asian origin as well as appealing modern art. However, there was an obvious lack of art from one of Australia's nearest neighbours - New Zealand - and more recent work e.g. by Binney or prominent Maori painters or sculptors, or Maori cloaks would be a useful addition to the collection.

Outstanding!. The collection of indigenous, colonial and contemporary paintings was impressive, and eye opening for someone with no knowledge of Australian art. I wish there had been more decorative arts as well.

Atget's Paris until November. The gallery is fabulous. Lovely exhibitions, great gift shop and well positioned coffee shop with views of the garden, harbour and city so you can just sit and take it all in over a lovely cup of coffee or light lunch. Best as of now the magnificient Atget photo exhibition. Love Paris, delight in amazing photography? If so this exhibition is a must. Relatively small and simple but what an amazing collection. It probably won't come to Australia again soon . It is an inspiration for aspiring photographers and anyone thinking of visiting Paris. Afterwards just wander down through the gardens to the harbour, on to the Opera house and if you are there on Saturday onto the Rock's market. If you are hardened you can even head on to the Gallery of Modern Art which is also glorious. But don't miss taking a breath to enjoy the harbour, bridge, gardens and the opera house. Lucky you, picture taking heaven. Loads of places to stop and eat or drink or just sit and revel in the visual magnificence.

Let there be light!. As it had been many years since we last visited the gallery, we thought it would be a great day out with lunch included. What a disappointment! While there are some magnificent works housed there, none more so than the works of the early Australian artists... Condor, Streeton, Preston, Cossington Smith ET al, the lighting left a lot to be desired and did not do the paintings justice.Come on Sydney, you need to lift your game! Not only that but could do with some obvious shuttle transport fom railway station to the Gallery as is quite a walk from Town Hall on a hot day.Lunch at the cafe was also awful... the smoked salmon sandwich with so little filling and mostly bread....comprising a few lettuce leaves and a miniscule slice of salmon on heavy black rye bread cut so thick and so chewy and smeared with some tasteless dressing, it was impossible to eat, to be whed down with a bottled version of lemon lime and bitters so sickly sweet it resembled nothing like lemon lime and bitters! Very expensive at almost thirty dollars for two for a couple of sandwiches and small bottles of drink??" Won't be back!

A good permanent collection. The permanent collection includes Australian historical and Colonial works as well as more recent Australian and international work. there are frequent special exhibitions.

Great exhibitions and art for all tastes.. Whatever your taste in art, this gallery will surely have some surprises for you. There is generally special (paid) exhibitions on offer most of the year. Great artists to view, and plenty of free levels to enjoy. Cafe available for refreshments. Don't have to leave this for a "rainy" day... enjoy all year 'round.

dont miss this place. this is fantastic and a great day out. this has to be top of the visitor list when in Sydney team it with the opera house as well and give yourself a whole day to see the sights. Dont miss it

Picaso. I went to see the Picaso exhibit. Twice. I originally went in just to get out of the Sun. But even the standing collection is impressive. If they do all special showings this well, it's worth your time. They have a great place for an outdoor lunch. Mm.

Tremendous Collection. There was SO much to see we needed to afford way more time and see it on a day when we were not so tired. The collection is magnificent; modern and traditional. We joined a short tour that was very informative. A must see for any art lover.
exhibition. Well planned Japanese exhibition which was both exquisite and well researched. Lighting and presentation was excellent. A shame that not all prints were available in the book shop

Favourite spot. We visit the art gallery every time we come to Sydney and this time we found it to have the most satisfying collection of art... there seemed to be more on offer. Beautiful building, inspiring art...love it..

Excellent mix of art. Great museum, no entrance fee and a very wide collection. From aboriginal are to modern art. Paintings, sculptures and other installations. We spent about 2 hours wandering about.

Excellent exhibitions. Excellent free exhibitions. (NB you need to pay $10 to see the Atget, but it's worth every cent and is highly recommended.) The cafe in the building serves excellent quality food and coffee.

My Second Home when in Sydney. The Art Gallery of NSW is the best place in Sydney if you are an artist like me or just an admirer of fine art. Unlike most of the large international galleries (Louvre, Prado, Guggenheim etc) the AGNSW is never "over-busy". The cafe is excellent with views over the harbour and the collection of international and antipodean fine art is exceptional. I go there just to relax and get some quality down-time. AW (Tony) Scott

Wonderful Exhibitions. This is one of our favourite Art Galleries, it always has interesting exhibitions and challenges one's perceptions of what "Art" means. The traditional works are alongside really avant garde works and the contrasts are sometimes challenging, but always interesting. We visit this Gallery at least once a year and always enjoy it. The Gallery cafe is also a good place to eat lunch.

You must visit!. Have seen some wonderful exhibitions here. My favourite to date was Monet, but the Gallery never disappoints when you visit. So many beautiful pieces of art and I love the shop, always find gifts for birthdays and Christmas.

Interesting building in great location. The Art Gallery is just past the Botanic Gardens and has a nice cafe across the street. The building itself has some lovely rooms. Not being a connoisseur of Australian art I didn't think the collection compared to the Metropolitan in NY, the National Gallery in DC, the Louvre, or other great museums of the world.

Great way to spend a day. This museum has an average collection of 19th and 20th century paintings and the Aboriginal collection is limited but there are excellent contemporary exhibits with top notch video displays. Nice cafe for lunch. Take advantage of free WiFi too!
Time to reflect. The AGNSW is a great venue to view amazing artworks, quiet contemplation or admire amazing views of the harbour. It has something for everyone.

Great museum. This museum holds a very comprehensive collection of Australian art, both non-indigenous and indigenous. It also has an interesting Asian art collection. The number of special exhibitions throughout the year, including the Archibald Prize, Sulman Prize and Wynn Prize, student exhibitions etc makes this a museum worth frequent revisits.

Great way to spend a couple of hours. Interesting collections and a free entry to most of the Gallery. Good way to spend a couple of hours, especially if the weather is not good. Nice walk thru the Domain, just 10 minutes from the city centre.

Please visit the gallery if you are visting Sydney.
