If you are visiting Sydney I strongly recommend a visit to the gallery - especially for the 19th and 20th century Australian (including indigenous) art. There is also a good Asian collection. It's in a beautiful location near the Botanic Gardens. There are also a couple of nice, relaxing places to have lunch, a pleasant cafe and a slightly more formal restaurant.

Archibald!. We went when the 2012 Archibald was on. The Gallery is fantastic. The Archibald is always a key draw item when it's on, but their permanent exhibitions are spectacular and there is so much, it covers all tastes and genres in art.

art for gratis. Looking for something cultural to do that won't cost you an arm and a leg, have a browse through the Art Gallery of NSW. Entry is free and you only need pay if you want to view any of the special exhibitions that are visiting the gallery. Have a snack or light lunch in the cafe and gaze over the harbour and vista of Woolloomooloo.

Not to be missed!. This is one of the best Australian galleries. The extensive range of early to modern Australian art is excellent, and the indigenous art is not to be missed. The whole gallery is airy and easy to get around. For those who need a bite to eat the cafe is good, whilst the restaurant has one of the best views and locations in the city. Often, there are are exhibitions, which again are not to be missed. A highly recommended experience for both visitor and locals alike.

Take a look at the Australian Art Collectionis. Spent a few hours wandering in the galley. Watch for special exhibitions. Galley is free but any special events you have to pay. There are some very special Australian paintings for example ...that are great to see. Close to walk thru the Domain and the Royal Botanical Gardens.

Spacious & set in scenic surroundings. The interior conveys a sense of space, but the section on classical art seemed a lil crowded. I guess my tastes are more traditional, while much of this gallery is devoted to modern or aboriginal work.

Spend a day for free around art. I just visited the Art Gallery yesterday. Went in at 10:30 a.m. and wandered around the Biennale for 30 minutes before joining in the 11 a.m. Highlights tour. Did I mention the tour AND the entrance is free?!?!The Highlights tour was great, I wouldn't have known where to start on my own. Wendy, the tour guide, showed us all the interesting pieces and I went back on my own to revisit them. I took the $10 tour of the Atget "Old Paris" exhibit that also has a tour a few times a week. It's a good exhibit for those interested in seeing old Paris and photos that have been developed by the photographer himself that are about 100 years old. Other than that, if you are looking for amazing composition, you may want to look elsewhere. The artist was more documentary style, with an eye for detail, but not any "artistic" composition. After two tours, I went back to the 15th-19th century galleries and then hit up the contemporary side. I ended up spending 10:30 a.m. - 3:30 p.m. at the gallery, getting a sandwich at their cafe (a bit pricey at $11 for what is served, but I needed sustenance beyond my protein bar).It is definitely worth it. And the Botanic Garden is across the way with St. Mary's Cathedral not too far off either. If you're on a budget, or if you have even a few hours to spare, go to the Art Gallery of NSW.

I love Art. Like many people I love Art and what better than spending an afternoon at the Art Gallery. I like staring at any artwork and see what the artists saw a hundreeds years ago :-)We are lucky to have this amazing Gallery.
Always a joy. The Indigenous collection is good, the contemporary art is interesting, the site is convenient to get to and the staff are helpful.
Loved it!. Absolutely beautiful, went to see Picasso and ended up spending almost the entire day checking out the permanent displays...

Impressive. The Art Gallery of NSW is located within the beautiful park The Domain and a stones throw away of the Royal Botanic Gardens. It is home to a huge collection of Australian art from all times. The modern art sections were my favourites, specially the piece of a lying obese clown and that of a miniature older woman. Entry to the museum is free, and the staff was accessible and helpful. A must in Sydney!

Spiritually refreshing!. This Art Gallery, is not a static collection of works. Although the focus is on Australian artists, it is juxtaposed with collections of works from overseas artists including regular special exhibitions of significance. For example I can remember first seeing the Tutenkhaman collection at the Cairo Museum in Egypt, then again in London, then in Sydney at this Gallery. So most of the major collections that are touring come to Sydney. Because of Australia's location in the Asia Pacific Region there is also a significant Asian collection. The Art Gallery of NSW is really a vibrant community of art works, talks, performances, workshops, video and film. You can wander at leisure, or take a guided tour. The special visiting exhibits have self guided tours with recorded commentary and rentable earphones. There are two restaurants in the Gallery, one Bistro style and the other a la carte with one of the best panoramas of Sydney Harbour. Both are licenced. Across the road is the Botanic Gardens, a very special collection reflecting introduced species from early settlement and native species. A nice combination is to visit the Gallery and have lunch there, or to visit the Gallery and then to stroll through the Gardens and find one of several kiosks or restaurants therin for lunch. Or, take a picnic. The Gallery is within easy walk of Museum metro station or the CBD. Parking is metered and not really a problem if you want to drive. There is good provision of handicapped parking spots immediately outside the gallery, which itself is wheel chair friendly. Allow 4 hours for an Art Gallery visit with lunch and a stroll in its environs.

A grand building and lovely art. The NSW Art Gallery is a very grand building, with high ceilings, resplendent with archways and pillars. The artwork is extensive and diverse and a few hours in the Art Gallery are quite rewarding. Photography is permitted in most areas which was excellent.  Combine the Art Gallery with a walk around The Domain for beauty of man-made and natural kinds.
Picasso!. I like visiting this gallery even when there's no special exhibition around. Particularly like to see the Archibald prize and entrants.

Ever changing, always inspiring.. The gallery rotates it's permenant exhibitions as well as always having a number of special reature shows. Has an excellent collection of Australian art from the major artists of last century. Also a very good library downstairs.

vibrant and lively art museum. this art gallery has a wonderful collection of Australian art, shows interesting specialist exhibitions and has a rich and varied program of workshops and talks to engage their public
Worth to visit. Architecture, paintings- everything is really excellent. Exhibitions on modern Art or classics, a lot of events, a nice cafe.

Give yourself time for viewing & walking. Phenomenal art gallery with gorgeous artworks . Set near lovely botanical gardens you can walk through to opera house. Gallery is huge so be sure to allow yourself time to walk around and look at the different floors and works

Lovely gallery to spend time in!. This is a splendid gallery and has an excellent permanent and visiting exhibitions. The cafe is a pleasant place to take a rest, but nothing too terrific so don't spend on the food - just a cuppa is enough.

Cultural Tastings. Next to Sydney's Hyde park, take a stroll to the art gallery and feast your senses and feed your artistic mind to some great and fantastic painting and art pieces. I loved the pieces of "the disposition of Christ", "Mona Lisa" and the ones of Aboriginal art. A must-do if you have a thing for the arts!

A beautiful Art Gallery with a great Australian section. On our recent trip to Sydney we did a visit to the Art Gallery on a specific evening that we were told about. Its a Wednesday evening after 5pm and its called Art after hours. Whats really nice is that you are mixing with all the locals at this time and theres lots of other things going on like talks and bands playing. A great thing to do
Much better with special exhibitions. Art Gallery of NSW has a good permanent collection but it is worth visiting when there is a special exhibition as the combined visit is worthwhile

Large collections of art. There are a wide variety of collections, both Australian and International art. They are usually free of charge, but the special exhibitions are also worth it. A great place to spend a rainy day.

Australian masterpieces up close. It is a great spot on a cold winters day and you can see some Australian paintings that you will easily recognise. Great retail outlet with postcards of most of what is in the gallery

Something for everyone. Fine art, contemporary art, ancient pieces and many more... there's surely something for you at the Art Gallery. It's not a huge place but nevertheless, it has numerous wonderful pieces that one can appreciate. There's no entrance fee at the main gate though they charge to view special collections. We also witnessed some individuals standing on their own appleboxes orating on what they're passionate about on one of the paths outside the Gallery although I'm not too sure if that's a regular thing. It's always a good idea to visit the Art Gallery to spark some creative inspiration.Tip: Start your Royal Botanic Gardens expedition at this spot.
great art. beautiful space, some great art, good food and drinks, and its warm in winter and blissfully cool in summer, and almost all the art is free.

Always something interesting on!. I love the NSW art gallery! The new contemporary gallery downstairs is particularly good. It makes a great day out as can take in the Botanic Garden as well. Like the late Wednesday night - all galleries should do this
Great setting. The museum is very good and extremely well situated. I was disappointed that the aboriginal art section was closed, due to its position taken over for a temporary exhibit.

Surprising contemporary art. Visited AGNSW today to see the biennale and was pleasantly surprised. Some really interesting and beautiful paintings, photographs and installation pieces. Made a nice change from the wanky rubbish that is so much contemporary art
Great building. Saw the picasso exhibition, the rest of the gallery was great as well, activities for the kids whilst we were walking around. Great day out

It's free entry !!. A wonderufl place to visit a bit far out from the city centre but close enough to walk if you like to explore cities this way. Free entry into the main gallery means that you can wander at your leisure and choose to pay for special exhibitions.

Make time to see Japanese Design Exhibition & 18th Biennale of Sydney. If you're in Sydney you should make time to see the Kamisaka Sekka Japanese Design Exhibition (wonderful screen paintings - traditional and modern; fabulous textiles, laquerware and ceramics), also the 18th Biennale of Sydney - great works of art and absolutely fascinating Artist film screenings. Give yourself plenty of time to see both!The Cafe is ask good for casual food especially on Wednesday evenings, Art after Hours

Best things in life are free !. Beautiful gallery in the heart of beautiful Sydney. Surrounded by picturesque gardens, this gallery is a short stroll from the CBD and was FREE !!!!! Absolute pleasure to attend this fine gallery.

Great variety of Art. This art gallery has a wonderful collection of art from various periods over the world, which is great for Australia. The Australiania collection is fantastic, there is room to move around, view the paintings and place to sit to rest and or contemplate. With special exhibitions now, one buys a ticket with a time which is great so that it is not too crowded and one can get to view the work. Be good if they could do something to quieten the noise in the cafe area.

peaceful place to go. It was a good and peaceful place.The paintings were my favorite thing there was a lot of AMAZING paintings.You should also take your camera and walking shoes.I think it is an all-day thing.
Great exhibitions and cafes worth frequentling. Lovely day out and always something interesting to see at the gallery
always fabulous. Highly recommended for art lovers visiting Sydney.

A must see if you're a tourist or a local.. It is a beautiful building often housing famous art from all over this amazing globe of ours.A great place for a social catch-up with a friend. Stroll through the gallery then have a drink at their bar. It also has some amazing views.I've also performed here on several openings of exhibitions and the staff are just beautiful and friendly.

Art Gallery of NSW. Except for special "travelling" exhibitions, entry is free and a broad range of art is on display. Very pleasant way to spend several hours. Coffee shop/cafe is located inside the Gallery. Located opposite The Domain, the Gallery is walking distance (1-2 minutes) to the Botanic Gardens and Mrs Macquaries' Chair (10-15 minutes) where you can get one of the best views of Sydney Harbour, The Opera House, Fort Denison and the Sydney Harbour Bridge.

Worth a Visit. The Art Gallery is a beautiful building [ had some of my wedding photos on the steps] . The main parts of the Art Gallery are free to visit. My children always find something interesting to see each time we go. There are often extra exhibits that have a cover charge. There is a nice cafe , where you can sit outside if the weather permits. There is lots of parking within walking distance. It is nice to combine a visit witha walk through the Botanical Gardens which are located opposite the Gallery.

Always worth a visit.. Saw a fascinating Japanese exhibition "Kamiska Sekka, dawn of modern Japanese design". Interesting gallery spaces where you can view the external world juxtaposed with the art works.Great pea and ham soup at the cafe.

Symbolism. How wonderful to stand in front of Sydney Long's 'Pan' and not get a cricked neck... in this fun exhibition it is not high up and out of reach, but hung so you can see the textures . I enjoyed seeing it in context and wonder why there were so few visitors.I appreciate the gallery's enlightened 'photo with no flash' policy..most enlightened (sorry for the pun).

For People Who Love Art. This is one of the museum that you should visit if you come to Sydney especially if you love art.The building is quiet big, you can see a lot of paintings from famous artist.You also can find the Aboriginal art collection in the other section. There is an exhibition when I went there from a local artist and it's very interesting. For me it's a lovely place to enjoy the art and relax with your partner or friends.

Beautiful. It had been over 20 years since I had visited the NSW Art Gallery. I almost forgot where it was! Spent a wonderful morning going through the permanent collection, especially liked the range of Dobell's they have. The cafe also has great coffee.

Cramped on a rainy day. The Archibald Portrait exhibition was very cramped. It was a rainy Sunday when I visited and found that the cafe was packed and the food was rather bland.The exhibition was worth seeing but probably better to visit on a weekday when I expect there would be less people.
Art in the city. A well organized gallery. Uncrowded rooms with displays tastefully presented.

So much space so little art.... I've been to this gallery every year since my teenage years & what has prevented me from becoming a member is the fact that the gallery isn't able to properly utilise space. The centre of the gallery is so cavernous ie there's so much open space, that it hinders more works from being displayed. Why do this? There's an open area in The Louvre in Paris but that serves as a point where all the halls converge. And the AGNSW ain't The Louvre!The European & Australian masters area is wonderful, but the collection isn't as vast as that of the NGV's.Also I have been told in the past that I can't take photos of the newer (permanent) exhibits, despite the fact my camera wasn't in flash mode. And yet I can take photos with joyful abandon in various art galleries in Europe.All in all, the AGNSW is like a disappointing present: beautifully gift-wrapped but not much inside.

Representative of the community it serves. I probably prefer this gallery to the National Gallery in Canberra.It has a cosy feel. The heritage building in which it is located is exquisite. The location in the Botanic Gardens looking out over the Harbour is pretty well unbeatable.The highlights are:(1) the Aboriginal Art collection, which is arguably the best in the world;(2) Archibald prize season, when opinions run thick and fast and the whole community enters into the viewing and debating exercise;(3) the sometimes overlooked Australian colonial collection, which is first rate; and(4) lunch on the cafe terrace looking over the harbour.

Excellent collection. Really enjoyed this excellent collection. Particularly the paintings and the Asian art. It was a most welcome surprise after a stroll across the gardens opposite with the beautiful Ibis roaming around the park!
First class. Beautiful museum, excellent collection of Asian art. Great activities for children and children's guides. Fantastic gift shop with great collection of Australian books for kids.

There for the Picasso exhibition. Enjoyed the exhibition. There seemed to be more high quality work than some of the blockbuster exhibitions. Disappointed that the modern australian gallery wasn't available. Looking forward to seeing the new hanging in the next month or two.

Wonderful except for....... The Gallery was wonderful, we started with a really lovely lunch in the restaurant, quick and efficient with great food and very reasonably priced. We were exhausted trying to do so much, but we visited the aboriginal exhibition which was fascinating and the vibrant colours and images something significant and important to see as a visitor to sydney and the contemporary/modern art exhibition downstairs. this was really special as just when you felt I'll skip past this one, once up close you couldn't resist wanting to find our more. Some were very memorable some scary... Scary was the old lady, that looked like a baby asleep in her bed... thatt will live with me and if you have a phobia about clowns, just be careful as there's an inflated one lying on the floor in one of the rooms if my memory serves me right..... The point was solitude..... Do pop in to the gallery very light and airy, Thr shop had some nice pieces but as a tourist coming from Ireland found it a bit expensive to purchase much. My husband bought Anna Fundas book (probably spelt that wrong) new book which has just won an award, we saw her on the TV she was in England at the time of the announcement.
Good range of Australian artists. A nice place to see Aussie artists or an exhibition. Cafe is nice to have a relax in also.

Picasso Exhibition. Brilliant.. A brilliant exhibition of the great Picasso, for mine, far better than the GOMA show a few years previous. As always the rest of the collection was most interesting, representing a diverse range of Australian and overseas art from the naieve to absolute contempory.

I love this place. I often go to the art Gallery when I do a city visit . On a Sunday between 12.30 and 1.30 they have a concert in one of the galleries , is really beautiful . The art gallery really is a must when visiting Sydney.

A great art gallery and a nice place to come and reflect. I come to the art gallery often, not only to check out any current exhibits but to have a quiet time to myself. It's a fantastic place to just sit and reflect, in front of my favourite painting or at the gallery cafe. The staff at the gallery are friendly and approachable, and fantastic in telling you of all the events that are happening, or if there were a new art work that I have questions about.

Nice space close to the city. AGNSW has wonderful international exhibitions- check out their website to see whats coming up. I love the Artexpress show (finest selection of final High School students art work- seeing into the eyes of the teenagers is fascinating!) which I usually see at the same time as the Archibald exhibition(Australias greatest portrait prize show) in April. The museum is a nice walk from town across Hyde Park and the Domain). It also has a great Cafe and a very stylish restaurant, not to mention the best Art bookshop in Sydney!)
Walk over the skyline. At the end of a long avo, it was pretty cool to walk over a scale model of Sydney.

Symbolism at the AGNSW. I visited the Symbolism exhibition recently. As always it was well presented and thought through. It's hard not to enjoy this gallery which caters to all tastes without losing sight of what really matters - great art.

An Unexpected Bonus. Liked seeing the Archibald, Sulman and Wynne Prizes exhibitions as well as great Australian masters.
Disliked the short time I gave myself - you really need a whole day (not a sudden whim to see the exhibitions after lunch!)

Average compared to the Art Gallery in Vienna. There are nice old pieces though they didn't "Wow me as much" personally having seen the big great ones in Vienna's Art museum. Nevertheless, It is still a real nice Art museum with a nice exterior and interior! There is a good mix of old and modern art as well! Big plus : The cafe serves real Nice food at really good prices compared to the cafes elsewhere in Sydney! Would definitely be back again! p.S. : THe staff there were really helpful as well! Thumbs up!!!

Archibalds. Really enjoyed our visit to the Art Gallery to view the archibald paintings and some of the other exibitions, small tip find out if there are schools visiting as i think when we went there was every school from NSW there!!
Great collection. Some artists you have never heard of outside of Australia plus the 'big names in art.' Great location and a lovely building too.

Great Tours and Amazing Collections and Exhibits. I love the Art Gallery. I can't draw and can't paint but I look to see the talents of others. The Gallery offer free tours on different topics during the day, talk to the staff at the entrance to find out more information. There is also a cloak room so you are free to wonder without having to drag your belongings about. The collections are marvellous and some I had never even heard of. Great views of Sydney from this impressive buildings, and a short walk through the Botanic Gardens from it's front takes you to the harbour or to the city through the domain.

Great with kids, especially the evening program. A great place for an afternoon of art-browsing. The selection is vary varied, ranging from European masters to very modern. We just visited the John Kaldor exposition with the kids and they loved it as much as we did. Take the opportunity to attend the evening opening, a rather special experience altogether.

Very Good. The Gallery is great, - I went to see the Terracotta Worriers here and cannot complement to staff enough for the brilliant display and also the organization of the display as there were hundreds all trying to see the display and yet everyone got threw it in a timely manner. The cafe also was quite reasonable and the food great

One of my Fav Chillout Sunday spots. Catch the Speakers corner going off on a Sunday afternoon. then relax for a Latte in the Gallerys Cafe and watch the Harbour and its inner city digs above the onramp to the Harbour Bridge and Tunnel Lovely.

a place to visit with a family. Something for everyone to enjoy. We actually, went for Picasso exhibition and there were interactive workshops for kids, making abstract art - quite amazing experience for our teen. Big draw - one can take pictures (not at PIcasso, though) and on Saturday night it stayed open late until midnight. We also thoroughly enjoyed a concert of Monsieur Camamber - a very talented multinational band - played in the lobby, apparently such concerts are the norm there. The Gallery is adjacent to Botanic Gardens - so the passage from outside to inside and back was fantastic.
Loved it!. There was just so much to see it was ridiculous. I wish I'd had more time but unfortunately left this to my last day.Recommend allowing a good few hours - or a whole day - to explore.
Picasso exhibition. This was excellent and well worth the visit. A great faclility in a central location

Never miss!. The Sydney Art Gallery is not to be missed. I particularly enjoy the Australian section. I don't know a lot about art but a trip to this Gallery is a must when in Sydney. The location on the edge of the Harbour is superb as well. There are some lovely eating opportunities in the Gallery. On this occasion I saw a little McCubbin landscape which I have not seen before which made the trip worth it of itself. I was also thrilled to be able to have a look at the Archibald Prize submissions. Allow yourself the time to really enjoy the Gallery.Visited May 2012

Great Day Out. We dragged our teenage kids through here in the school holidays - what started off as whining and whinging ended up in "wow look at that". We stayed there for an afternoon of wandering - must see the lower floors for the kids - great fun!

Great views, stylish restaurant, casual cafe, music ... at the Art Gallery!. There's something for everyone at the Art Gallery, thanks in large part to former Director, Edmund Capon who, in his 33 year tenure transformed it into an accessible, sophisticated, friendly and rich repository for classic, Aboriginal & contemporary art.Locals love the Wednesday evening "Art after Hours", when the gallery is open until 9pm and there's an interesting talk or interview at 6:30, following a guided tour of specific works. Films, jazz and the opportunity for a snack & drink follow.http://www.artgallery.nsw.gov.au/art-after-hours/The restaurant has an excellent menu and is the ideal place for a leisurely or business lunch. It's also a very comfortable place for the solo diner. Service is good and the views of Woolloomooloo are an edgy alternative to the picture post card "Bridge & Opera House" vistas.The caffeteria is larger, has a good range of food and drinks and outdoor seating at a reasonable cost.I think the ideal route to the Art Gallery of NSW is via the Botanic Gardens - or walk back in the late afternoon and catch the Opera House with a sunset background.Entry to the gallery is free, 7 days a week. The only charge is for special exhibitions, which are usually about $10 for adults. Concessions are available for children, students, Australian Seniors and pensioners.The Art Gallery of NSW is a vibrant & integral part of Sydney and although this review will date my visit as "May 2012", I've visited at least once a month for the last 30 years & been a member for 25 + years. Always something interesting to see, love visiting my favourites, and discovering new works.The gift shop is a treasure trove and a wonderful source of birthday, Christmas and "just because" gifts. Sometimes, even for others!
Amazing. Beautiful gallery... Enjoyed walking around and viewing the paintings! It was a feast for both my eyes and mind!
Best in class?. Is this the nicest and best art gallery in Australia? Yes, probably it is. See for yourself!

Lovely art gallery with a good range of exhibits. This art gallery is genuinely interesting and has a good range of exhibits. I spent a very happy couple of hours here looking at works from Van Gogh, through Corot to Keifer. The gallery is well organised on all levels and I witnessed an excellent interactive session for schoolchildren while I was there.On a practical note for the visitor, there are excellent toilets available as well as a decent cafe.

Time out in the middle of hustle and bustle. Lovely building, took my wedding photos here, but it is good for any occasion. general exhibition is always great to view more than once, the facilities are thoughtfully placed, that you could spend the whole day here comfortably. Lunch at the restaurant also has an amazing view of the nearby waters.

Get a bit culture!. In addition to the permanent (and FREE) collections the Art Gallery of NSW hosts amazing exhibitions from other art galleries and musuems around the world. Previous exhibitions have included the Picasso exhibition and the China's Terracotta Warriors, as well as the Archibald prize!

One of Sydney's Best Kept Secrets. I just love the NSW. Brilliant collection of local works, with some of the best pieces from Olsen, Whitely, Grace Cossington, Michael Johnson, Lloyd Rees, Streeton and Roberts. Favorite for me is Streeton's Redfern Station, but the whole place is just the most fantastic chronicle of the development of Australia's (and specifically Sydney's) personality.It's free to get in, just and easy stroll from the CBD across the park, with some great places to sit and gaze across Wooli Pier and the eastern end of the harbour. Very hard to beat as a way to spend a couple of hours.I go back every 6 months or so, and seem to enjoy it more every time. Equal fav with Musee D'Orsay.
Great music, perfect evening. Wednesday night in the Cafe. M Carney Ensemble were playing. Dined with friends. Pleasant evening outing after a hard day at work.

Combine the art and natural beauty opposite if you have time. The Art Gallery of NSW is a favourite place to visit as it is well laid out and has the bonus of being situated opposite the leafy Domain parklands and a minute's walk to the sensational Bottanical Gardens. If you can combine the two experiences yo have heaven. Anyway back to the gallery. There is the classic section and the indigenous Australian section. TIP Do check online for what are the special collections showing when you are here. Recently we saw an amazing Picasso exhibition and the annual Archibald's (portraiture) is always a fave.The cafe is OK and a place to recharge.Enjoy it all.

A marvellous Gallery. Not The Tate, not the Met. But this is not a gallery to be overlooked. There is a wonderful Asian art section. Incredible Aboriginal artworks. A stellar display of great Australian artists and a fair representation of European Art. The cafe and restaurant here both have stunning views and it is an easy walk from the CBD
Some lovely old paintings.. On the rainy day we enjoyed our visit here for some culture and a nice lunch in their restaurant.

Still there after all these years. It doesn't take a blockbuster to get me through the door but the recent Picasso was worth a look. The standing collection still has plenty to offer and is worth a walk across from Macquarie Street if you have a spare hour. Even the parkland surrounds are enjoyable on their own.
Archibald Prize. I like modern Arts so try to visit the changing exhibitions there every year. Interesting also the yearly Archibald Prize Exhibition.
The aricbald. enjoybale place to meet friends for a light lunch and a bit of art

Wonderful collection of art in a lovely location. I walked to the Art Gallery from the city (an easy walk). It is a lovely light filled building with a diverse mixture of art - European as well as Australian and a easy stroll from there to the botanical gardens.

Australian art, so new yet so old. First time experiencing Australian Art, lucky I have a great mate who's an Art Advisor and explained it all, so surreal yet so real..really enjoyed Ned Kelly (Nolan).

Art Glorious Gallery. I went to see a wonderful exhibition here, however whatever there is on display is worthwhile. The bistro cafeteria is a wonderful place to sit outside and see the world walk by after a wonderful viewing
Something for everyone. Easy to spend hours exploring this gallery. Great variety in the collection.

Beautiful artworks but.... I found the Art Gallery to be too sterile & very big/empty. Yes, there are amazing pieces of art work but that's what you expect! The cafe needs a major wake up call as far as quality is concerned & prices... wow!!!!
Needs more disability parking too!

Always worth a visit. Visited the Archibald/Wynne/Sullman Prize exhibitions and was fortunate to arrive in time for a free guided tour. The volunteer guide was excellent providing just the right level of information.
Nice. Good but not great, if its nice outside do the outside sites as they are much better, if its raining, why not? There isn't too much to do in bad weather in Sydney
Some great Art, a good collection.. This is a very large Art Gallery and rivals that of the National of Victoria and those of our Nations capital. Some excellent Art and excellent collection.
Very good gallery. We liked the layout of the gallery, the quality of the artwork and the helpful staff. We found the signage less than clear.
free guided tour - great!. Loved the free guided tour about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander art. Really informative - excellent.

Picasso exhibition at Art Gallery of NSW. The art gallery has a good collection of Australian art, which is well arranged to provide an educational experience. The special exhibitions are ofte n outstanding, such as the Picasso exhibition. The Archibald prize is also a fascinating experience in audience involvement and is run annually. Seek out Brett Whitely and Dick Roughesy.

Some iconic paintings. I like the large 19th century Australian section as there are so many famous paintings on display. Most of Sidney Nolan's Ned Kelly series are also on display here. It's a 10 minute walk from Hyde Park without shelter so a bit of a pain if it's raining.

Good for Australian and modern Art. The Gallery is free, and that's an excellent start. I also love the fact that if you visit it on a Saturday, there are free copies of the Sydney Morning Herald (a bumper edition) that you can read in the café and then take away with you. The café is good, though more like a restaurant in that you can't see the food before you order it (I found myself wondering whether their sandwiches were small enough to warrant buying a cake to go with them). But that's a minor complaint; the sandwich was great.The gallery specialises, as I suppose one would expect, in 19th cent and Australian art (including an extensive collection of modern art) and I found that aspect of the gallery impressive. The least impressive collection was the display of Pacific Island Art which is tucked away in a kind of lobby at the bottom of a staircase. Maybe I was missing something, but if the half-dozen items on display represent the extent of the collection, and you want to see the art of the South Pacific, then you'd be better advised to visit the Auckland War Memorial Museum.There is a modest collection of Renaissance/Early Modern paintings, but they're well displayed and worth a look.
World class exhibits and free entry. Don't miss a visit to the Art Gallery when you're in Sydney. Right near the botanic gardens, perfect for a leisurely day of culture and coffee.
Great collection of art. Wonderful building in the Botanic Gardens. Great collection of art works, including the annual Archibald Prize for portraits. Always worth a visit
19th Century Australian Painters Gallery. To die for -- just brilliant. Coffee's good in the cafe too.

Serendipitous.. Go to the gallery of aboriginal art and talk to the curator/room steward. He is brilliant. He knows much more about the paintings than is written on the captions on the walls. Very moving.

Good collection, good exhibitions. It's one of the top attractions in Sydney.Much better and rewarding than Luna Park for sure,The permanent collection itself is worth visiting with quite a few master pieces hanging there,the exhibitions are good too. For example the Archibald Exhibition which is on now is really good.Fees is 10$ for archibald exhibition though entry to the permanent collection and the Gallery as such is free.

Archibald Prize Exhibition - don't miss it. The Archibald Prize is awarded for the best portrait. There are some great paintings in the 2012 exhibition. The remainder of the gallery also has great paintings.
Historic building. The art gallery is housed in a beautiful historic building. Within easy walking distance of the CBD, this is a wonderful place to visit.

winding down. Went into sydney for a drive just to get away from the norm.Stopped in at the Art gallery for a bit of a look and spent about 4 hours.The day just got away as there is so much to see,it was good to just walk around and see paintings from days of old that you would love to be there for your kids kids to see.A good day out if you were only sitting at home wondering what to do.
Wonderful experience. Indulge in old & new art before taking a stroll in the Royal Botanical Gardens just up ahead, makes for a very relaxing experience.

THE Museum/Gallery to Visit While in Sydney!. I have been to the Art Gallery several times. Every time I visit, I am reminded of their magnificent permanent collection. I've also taken great joy to see the impressive exhibitions, which locals and tourists of Sydney (and its environs) are able to enjoy. The exhibitions are always thought-provoking and truly profound, which always allows for great reflection and debate among fellow friends and visitors. For me, the Art Gallery of NSW is second to none in Sydney and a place you should really visit.

Easy access enjoyable visit. Even on a Sunday afternoon, the gallery was well staffed and queues went quickly. We enjoyed the 2012 Archibald exhibit and a few others on offer. The restaurant looked popular and it was lovely to just stroll around the open spaces.
Nice lunch. $9.50 for a delicious bowl of super or a tasty sandwich, can't be bad!

A gem. This gallery strives to be relevant and connect with both locals and tourists. For visitors I strongly recommend the Australian collections, especially the 20th century and the Koori (indigenous) works. The new Kaldor gallery (contemporary art) is without peer in Australia and should be on every ones to do list.

You will need a whole day.......if possible. just look look look and look it is great.....situated in a wonderful place for views and the coffee shop is good to have a small break in between all the art work you must see

Archibald and ArtExpress. I always go to the archibald each year and find it thoroughly moving, interesting, intriguing despite being a novice art buff. This year we were lucky to have our family visit coincide with the Artexpress works from the HSC students of 2011. My own daughter was a HSC student last year and whilst not an art student we were keen to see if the work of a friend was exhibited. Whilst it wasn't which was disappointing (they must rotate them?) we were thoroughly enthralled with the quality and diversity of what was displayed. Don't worry about the future of art in Australia - it is well covered if the talent of these students is anything to go by...deep, mind blowing, moving, clever - don't miss it. The two kids thought it more interesting than the archibald, sulman and wynne exhibitions!

Picasso Exhibition at the Art Gallery of New South Wales. The AGNSW does it again with another blockbuster exhibition. Picasso has been one of my favourite artists since childhood. This exhibition was both vast and high in quality. A great gallery, with the flow of people well managed.
Well set out Gallery. Well set out. Friendly staff. Excellent location opposite the Botanic Gardens.

Great overview of Australian Art...for novices and serious art critics alike!. We frequently return to the Art Gallery of NSW, it is a great place to take in an overview of classic Australian Art, and there are always great exhibitions coming and going to keep your interest. There is also a nice little cafe, and great book/gift shop.

OK but not awesome. I spent about 90 minutes here before closing one day. Enjoyed the Aborigine and Asian galleries and there were some nice paintings by lesser known European/Aussie artists sprinkled in the 1st floor galleries. I was turned off by the very modern art that appeared to make up the other galleries only to wonder what I had missed after I saw some lovely wood cuts as post cards in the gift shop. Had run out of time, so didn't get a chance to find the section they were in. I guess my word of advice then is to give yourself more than 90 minutes before closing :>.

Good galleries and free (save for special exhibits). I love art galleries in small doses. I want to spend no more than two hours in one at a time, and I found that I could visit nearly the whole place in that time. This gallery has a good mix of work by both Australian (native and other) and non-Australian artists.

Lazy place. I want, so much, to love this place, but it's lazy. the volounteer body is crap. i go into this place all the time . there are these cranky volunteers they have no idea what's going on and where . i go very regularly and find out subsequently, on the net, that they have this that and another stuff going on. guess what i'd like to know. so disappointing and doesnt have to be.

Main display if free and worth a look. Some great australian pieces are located here. Howard and Julian Ashton, Streeton, etc.. Great venue within the botanical gardens. Good displays. Special touring exhibitions are charged.
Our heritage. the Australian art on display shows off our history, great for students
Love the gallery parties!. if you can get into a function at the art gallery go. great food and entertainment and drinks, and being able to stroll around the gallery after hours, priceless!
Another great retrofit. Grand old building, with three sub floors of modern art in modern galleries, and a fine cafe.
Awesome. Recently saw The Picasso exhibition. The staff were so friendly and informative. The place itself so welcoming. The exhibtion, amazing.
Take a look. Some beautiful and interesting art work.. go and see.

Worth a visit.. We never tire of going to the Art Gallery. First it is in such a lovely area right near the Botanical Gardens and not far from Macquarie Street where there are lots of lovely old buildings. The Gallery always has some wonderful art on display and there is a lovely cafe and also a restaurant there. We particularly love the Australian Art.
Interesting collection. Interesting collection with variety and not too many didactic panels.
Interesting. Great building and a great variety of exhibits.PS lunch in the gallery restaurant delicious

Picasso Exhibition - Fantastic. If you were in Sydney while it was on I hope you didn't miss this exhibition! It was fantastic. In fact the gallery generally is worth a visit. Only a short walk from Museum station and free admission into the general collection displays. Of course you won't really see everything in one visit so you need to plan which collections to see.

Great collection of Australian Art. I enjoy the modern Australian work: mainly on the left of the large main hall. The earlier Aussie classics are on the right. Asian on the next floor down, as well as a lovely café for fresh, interesting lunches. Not many people know about the reference library downstairs... ask at the desk about this...You can take pictures of the art (except for the Aboriginal work.)If you arrive early enough, there is meter parking in front of the gallery. Otherwise, parking is nearly always available in the loop road next to the Botanical gardens. It is metered, so a bit of walking is required if you want to stay a while. Otherwise, the other parking stations nearby are under the Cathedral (enter from the back) or "The Domain Parking". These both require a walk.

The Picasso exhibition was wonderful. The masterpieces displayed in 10 rooms were fantastic. The Picasso exhibition included a wide range of artworks including sketches, paintings and sculptures. I was totally mesmerised by the wide range of stages Picasso went through in his development and exploration as an artist and across various media. He dabbled in both traditional and experimented with abstract work too. My only disappointment was there were no pieces of art that involved his paintings over pottery.
Saturday Night extended hours. Been with the family and there was lots of stuff going on, Flamenco, Italian music and a number of free and paid exhibitions, some of them of great quality (Picasso)

Made Picasso a pleasure. They handled the crowds for the popular exhibition really well and being able to pre-book your time online was great. The gallery is a fantastic place to enjoy all its works of art and the staff are extremely helpful.

Ticketing is frantic and crazy. Great gallery space at the entrance of the beautiful Botanical Gardens. Ticketing can be a nightmare though. If they have a big exhibition on you have to buy your tickets online so that the ticket line doesn't clog the foyer. Problem is the tickets are valid for entry for a single 30 MINUTE timeslot. I don't know about you, but if I'm enjoying a day in the city I would never set myself such a strict timeslot to be somewhere. Which of course means, you may miss you ticket entry time and either wait until much later in the day/evening or miss out on going in that day altogether.The National Gallery of Victoria and Australia both ticket at the event...you just line up and wait. I've been to the last day of exhibitions a few times in Victoria and it was manic...but I didnt wait more than 40 minutes to enter from the line and it didnt disrupt my day as I got then when I felt like it.You should defintely be able to refund or at swap to another time or day...they dont advertise this but we pursued them to give a missed timeslot ticket to go another day (because of the *cough* disgusting Sydney traffic).Rant over.

An uplifting feast for the eyes. The Art Gallery of NSW never fails to disappoint in any way, shape or form! From the moment you are outside the majestic building, you will feel an air of austerity and all your cares fall behind you as you enter the gorgeous timber-doored entrance. The classically elegant Art Gallery of NSW is one of Sydney’s most distinctive landmarks. The façade and old wing of the Gallery were built between 1896 and 1909 and since that time there have been a number of extensions and additions. From its more permanent collection on exhibition to visiting collections (such as the recent Picasso), the gallery has something for everyone's art interest; from the extremely modern through to the classics. If you're looking for a carefree and uplifting afternoon where you can admire artworks in the genre of your choice, either solo or with friends/family, this is a wonderful place to visit. The Art Gallery shop has a wonderful collection of books, gifts, gift cards and the like for those interested in a little retail therapy when you snap out of your dream-like state after you have viewed art until your heart's content. A must for visitors to Sydney and for Sydney-siders alike! ENJOY!
State gallery of NSW. Vibrant and interesting place, always full of people and changing exhibitions. A good cafe and a good restaurant.
Found it during a city stroll!. Even if you don't have enough time to spend inside the gallery, the Gallery Shop is a mini-museum of its own and fun fun fun to brouse!
Saturday night at the gallery. brilliant - great way to spend a saturday evening viewing some great art
A lovely collection of world renowned art. This art gallery attracts world class art displays because it is in Sydney. Do not hesitate to see what is currently on display!

World Class Gallery in Beautiful Surroundings. Local and International Exhibitions always of the highest quality and very diverse.So fortunate to have seen the latest.....Picasso! What a privilege!soon the annual Archibald....we look forward to this every year
Great facilities including the restaurant with delicious food and amazing view,excellent position.
Every experience here never disappoints!

Nice to browse through. Nicely set out and very informative with no entrance fee! Definitely worth a visit. Has some great indigenous art and I particularly enjoyed the modern photographic exhibits. Also has a great Cafe for lunch.
Great place to spend a rainy day in Sydney. I saw the Picasso exhibition there and it was very informative and well managed. You can easily while a day away in there.

Very enjoyable. We aren't big art gallery enthusiasts but we had to check out the Picasso exhibit that was there while we were. Free main entry and very reasonable exhibit fee...excellent presentation and layout, managed entry that was fair and reasonable (maximum number of people per hour). We visited some other permanent exhibits but didn't have time for many. overall, the gallery seemed very inviting.
Picasso. Great exhibition for both Picasso lovers and novices.

A Must Do in Sydney. I love this museum. It is free. It is open late on Wednesday nights. It always has good exhibitions. It is in The Domain which is a divine place to stroll through. There is a lovely cafe where you can sit outside and look out over the City.This is a must do in Sydney.

Great Gallery. Love love love the art galleryWe are frequent visitors to see the remarkable moving display of exhibits that they haveJust saw Picasso the other dayOf course it was crowded! Lots of people want to see a brilliant exhibition.love the gallery and fairly reasonably priced food

Lovely museum, especially the Aboriginal Display. We very much enjoyed the traditional art and especially liked the Aboriginal section. Some of the contemporary art, however, was just ridiculous (a Pamper's carton with holes cut in it??). We walked to the Museum from the Marriott. Quite a little hike in the rain, but Sydney is a fairly easy city to navigate on foot.

Great Exhibits of Australian and International Art. The building is located next to Hyde Park and is adjacent to the CBD. There are many public transport options to arrive here.The building is typical museum design. Columns and wide open spaces. There is a cafe here that serves decent food and is worth a lunch.The museum had an exhibition on Picasso at the time of writing. The exhibition gallery has timed entries depending on when you bought your ticket. The main galleries span from the traditional European to current modern mixed media. The chronological path takes you from the main floor and descending into the below ground floors. There is art of all types and media here. At the time of writing the Museum of Contemporary Art is closed for refurbishing and this is the best location for your dose of "mind expanding" art. Allow at least half a day.Tours are available and check the website for current times.There is a museum shop to take souvenirs home.

Iconic art gallery. The Art Gallery of NSW has a stunning permanent display of Australian art, and a great modern art collection downstairs. All free! The cafe serves great, reasonably priced food (this applies to most art galleries, which is handy to know for tourists). Special exhibitions are held throughout the year, and are good value. A great place to spend a day out of the sun or rain!
Great Gallery. We went to see yhe Picasso exhibition which was amazing. Afterwards we had a look around the gallery which included works by artists like Pissaro,Van Gogh,Carrick and so much more.
Well worth a visit.. Beautiful building, varied art collection - I especially enjoyed the aboriginal art gallery. Best to have the guided tour.

Not a bad little gallery!. OK, so it's not the Prado, Louvre or Uffizi, but it's not a bad little gallery in this far flung corner of the world. A good collection (one or two pieces by many famous artists) and nicely set out. Our little gallery is something for Sydney to be proud of.
Picasso amongst Aussie greats. Always a wonderdul day at the Gallery - but a little more crowded with Picasso there. The shop has some wonderful and reasonably priced souvenirs to please all ages.

Perfectly Picasso. Our normal place of residence is Brisbane, Queensland. We dashed down to Sydney for the weekend for a wedding and added a visit to the AGNSW as Masterpieces from the Musee National Picasso, Paris was still in the gallery. While it is something of a sprint to keep up with the crowd, which seems undiminished after 4 months, one nevertheless gets a sense of the breadth and depth of Picasso's enormous output - as well as his extraordinarily complex life. While the exhibition itself is very interesting, it is made even more enjoyable by spending a few hours comparing and contrasting his works with the balance of the gallery. If you are heading to Sydney before 25 March 2012, definitely add a visit to the AGNSW to your itinerary.
What's not to love. wonderful restaurants, artwork, shopping and views

Wonderful Place to see Australian Art. This place is the place to go if you want a fix of art regardless of your preferences... I have visited during the Picasso and Archibald exhibitions, which were fantastic... but what really takes my breath away every time I visit...is the classic 19th & 20th Century Australian Art and seeing it up close and personal!
Love it, Picasso exhibition fantastic. This gallery is always great to visit, there was a special exhibtion on featuring over 150 Picasso works which was awesome.
Nice gallery & good food in restaurant. Nice to visit & a good option for a rainy day. Restaurant was of a high quality & good choice of food.

The Picasso exhibit was amazing!. I've been to this museum before, and it is wonderful, but the Picasso exhibit was truly outstanding. Almost better than the Picasso museum itself!The museum has a wonderful variety of galleries that should appeal to almost everyone. If you have the time, stop at the restaurant for lunch or a glass of wine - very modern, airy and very good food.
A wondful way to spend the day. Excellent Aussie Art, Asian Gallery and new contemporary Gallery. Great a restaurant/cafe also
Picasso. The gallery provides great veiwing of Australian art but the special exhibit was fantastic

Art Gallery. We had recently seen many Picasso paintings in various places in Europe, so that being the special exhibition was less interesting for us, but the rest of the introduction to Australian artists was informative.
Picasso exhibition. Having just visited the MoMA and the Met in New York a month ago, sad to say, but we have a long way to go.....guess having a much smaller population doesn't help
Excellent Cultural Place. Great place to visit and see ^^ definitely have to try the meals theirs whilst visiting.

Visited the Picasso exhibition which was fabulous. The Gallery is in a beautiful setting near the Gardens and easy to get to from City. Wonderful cafe/food. The permanent exhibitions are also very good

Interesting collections, shows and building. Apart from the big name shows which are held here, the gallery has an interesting permanent collection which showcases Australian art as well as other iconic pieces from the rest of the world. The modern addition is also of great architectural interest and includes places to eat and a good bookshop.

Picasso down under. Took the opportunity while staying in Sydney to see the Picasso exhibit at the Art Gallery of NSW. it was a strange feeling to see some of the paintings that I had admired in Paris years ago, now exhibited so far from their home. They are well presented in several rooms according to the different periods. I love "Paul en Arlequin" (Picasso's son) and the huge portrait of Paul's mother as well. definitely worth the stop over also for the gallery's rich permanent collection which can be visited free of charge.

Dont miss the Indigenous collection hidden in the basement. For a country the size of Australia it has a good international collection of works by major international artists .The ANGSW has always been the poor cousin of its Canberra and Melbourne counterparts and is a mish mash of grand Victorian and 70's architecture .Visitors often miss the Yiribana Gallery located various escalator flights down and this is a real shame as the ground floor displays such as the Asian collection are not really representative of our country 's unique Indigenous heritage .

Fascinating. What a wonderful experience to find the work of so many talented people. Even more interesting is to wonder why some was actually made - still very inspiring. Everyone should go there at least once.
art at it best. the painting on show are great and the building it self is beautiful

Picasso Exhibition. This was so well planned out, you were given a time slot when you purchased the ticket so there was no queue. You weren't rushed through and could take as much time viewing the pictures as you liked.

Always something new, always something remembered.. Right now, the new is a major collection of works by Picasso culled from around the world. Always there is one of the most impressive and absorbing Asian Galleries anywhere in the world. Take the guided tour for memorable insights on the collection. One particular jewel: a lovely beach scene in the European galleries by Monet mentor, Eugene Boudin. Don't miss it!
History, Art, Style. Modern meets old.Fantastic permanent collection from Renaissance through to Modern.Dont miss the permanent Indigenous section downstairs.
Great permanent collection and Excellent Picasso Exhibition. I saw a great Picasso exhibition and many other interesting modern and indeginous australian authors

An absolute must!. This Art Gallery ranks amongst the best in the world as far as my wife and I are concerned. Although our recent vist was for the Picasso Exhibition, the whole experience is fantastic! If you arrive mid-morning, you can take a lunch break in the cafe or restaurant and enjoy quality food and then start exploring again after being refuelled and refreshed!

Very good contemporary art collection. The art gallery is situated near the Botanical Gardens and easy to find. We visited the main collection and thought the contemporary art collection was excellent. The entry is free for the main gallery but special exhibitions are expensive. Picasso was on when we visited and as we have seen most of this collection elsewhere we concentrated on the permanent collections which we thoroughly enjoyed.
Great - saw Picasso. Good exhibition, in the Botanical Gardens so combine with walk. The cafe service sucks but there is a little cafe in garden across road.

Picasso exhibition. The $25 entry fee to the Picasso collection is a very worthwhile investment and e xperience. Picasso's private collection from Paris is a welcome "temporary" addition to a wonderful gallery.

Picasso exhibition was great . . .. Probably the best exhibition (informatio-wise) that we have been to although at times the lighting wasn't that great - nice mix between paintings, sketchings and photos and the curator/producer really ensured they took people on the journey through the exhibition - staff were really helpful and the Australian painting exhibition is fantastic
A_great_free_activity!. on_the_lower_floor_it_had_a_great_contempary_art_section_that_was_fun_and_intresting.!!

Lose yourself for the day. Set in the beautiful gardens glimpsing the harbour, you can lose yourself for the day wandering around the huge rooms and soaking up the artworks. No where near as hectic as the European galleries, sometimes live music is on offer and free guided tours and lectures. Makes sure you take your time to enjoy all there is on offer.

Picasso exhibition. Go while you can, its breathtaking. I booked the lunch ticket and made an afternoon of it. The exhibition is well organised and beautifully put together. I loved it. Lunch was delicious.
Good cafe. Even if you're not interested in art, the Cafe inside (downstairs) is a good place to stop for a coffee.

The Picasso Exhibition is fantastic. what a coup to get the Masterpieces from the Musee National Picasso, Paris. Whilst I was annoyed to have to wait for a time slot, it was a good idea and well thought out. The information staff are friendly (so are the security) and the cafe and shop are good.

Picasso Exhibition Feb 2012 was just OK. We saw the Picasso exhibition at GoMA (Gallery of Modern Art) Brisbane in 2008 and loved it so thought this one, which was more expensive at $35/ticket would be much better but we were VERY underwhelmed... It was OK at best. If you like modern art, try MCA's one and only exhibition while under renovation/construction - we enjoyed it more than Picasso and it's free!
AGNSW. AGNSW is the centre of art and culture in Sydney. Things happening all the time - beautiful building - well located - well curated - a real pleasure to visit

Picasso Exhibit. Recently attended the Picasso Exhibit at the Art Gallery and was very impressed. Not being an experienced art lover, I appreciated the informative pamphlets handed out and the optional headsets to give more information about the pieces. Well set out, and definitely one to put on the to-do list.
Enjoyable. We visit the Art Gallery regularly. It's always worth a stop and especially when there are special exhibits on. They bring in fantastic works.

beautiful. Came here to see the Picasso exhibit, really enjoyed the rest of the museum too. Make sure to go upstairs and also downstairs. Then take a walk through the Royal Gardens, along the water, past the Opera House, to Circular Quay.
Well worth a visit. Something for everyone here. Although found the special Picaso exhibition was not our cup of tea.
Never boring. I have been to the Art Gallery of NSW a few times and look forward to going back. The building and artworks and artifacts are amazing.
Good enough reason to visit Sydney alone.. Always a great selection of art and objects to peruse, and that's just the shop! Get to Picasso before it's too late.
Very enjoyable. Large enough to spend at least half a day. They have a nice restaurant with outside seating which does decent food.
Art Adventure. Wonderful sculptures and a very good cafe with stunning views over Cockatoo Island and the Naval moorings.
Cool. If art's your thing, you'll like it. The Picasso exhibit will break your wallet but a great chance to see some great work.

Disappointing Exhibition Display. We visited the "Picasso" exhibition on a Sunday, and although they had timed entry to have an even flow of visitors it was still very crowded during the tour. Whilst the works were eye opening the displaying of the work was very low key. The information cards for each painting or work were very small and difficult to read as well as lacking in information. For a major exhibition it was disappointing, it gave the impression that it had been rushed rather than properly planned. The paintings however were very interesting and thought provoking.

A lovely gallery. Have just been to see Picasso at the Art Gallery of NSW. You can book on line to avoid a queue and we chose the time we wished to view. It's a very well laid out gallery and has a restaurant for lunch or snacks and afterwards its only a stroll back into Sydney or down to the harbour.

Near Botanical Gardens. Art Gallery has some great exhibits and best of all is free to enter.Well worth putting on your list of things to do.Easy to walk to from the centre of town just head to the Botanical Gardens.

Picasso Exhibition, Go for the early session if you can.. We went for the 9 am early session, and were in the 1st group that went in. Leaving the volunteer guide I wandered thru the rooms by myself for just on an hour. Each room has plenty of works, and covers the artists career. Having been to the Museum Picasso in Paris, we had high expectations, and were not disappointed.

Best gallery in Australia.. Fabulous permanent collection and good variety of other exhibitions. Gallery shop is excellent. Cafe is good, and lovely to sit outside. Mostly this gallery just works. The building has good energy and lots of natural light.

A place to come and relax the hussle and bustle of the city and enjoy the many works of art on display.. If you enjoy viewing fine artworks from around the world you will experience the finest that Australia has to offer.

Premier national gallery with the works. This gallery has some amazing collections. The various Australian period collections, including a brilliant indigenous collection are well worth the visit. The gallery also has numerous other special collections, old masters and the like .. And is always running some special exhibition. Keep an eye on what's on.
A Good Art Gallery. This art gallery has amassed a very good collection and is worth a visit if art is your thing..

Great for a rainy day. Although the art gallery isn't on par with the great museums that can be found internationally, it is great for a quiet day/afternoon to escape the rain or the heat. There is free entry to the permanent exhibits (and there will be a charge to enter the special exhibits). There is a reasonable Australian painters collection and an even smaller Aboriginal collection. There are free activities on Wednesday nights and Sunday afternoons usually relating to the special exhibits currently running. This will usually include talks, possible recital and a movie.
Wonderful gallery. I'm usually not a huge fan of art galleries, my husband is though. Its well organised, clean, the art is wonderful and you can have coffee and a snack there.

Always a favourite when in Sydney. One of the better galleries in Australia as it always have a few major exhibitions running.The best probably being in January, presenting the best works of just graduated year 12 students from all over NSW.
Picasso, he was smoking somthing. We went to see the Picasso exhibition, it was very good. Lunch in the restaurant was a great way to complete the visit.

An excellent way to pass a couple of hours. The art gallery is free (with the exception of temporary exhibitions such as the Picasso one) and has an extensive and varied collection of art, covering several floors. I've been twice now and would definitely go again, there's a lot to see and take in. There are some lovely things in the giftshop too.

Vibrant and so interesting.. This is a bright and spacious gallery with a great selection of Australian art works as well as some really good international exhibitions. When you have spent a couple of hours exploring the gallery the shop has some good quality souvenirs and also the cafe is good although it is a little pricy.
super!. temporary and permanent exhibitions covering a broad taste. I love to get in to see the HSC art displays 'Art Express'

A gallery for all - young and old. Now here is a place which really encourages the interest in art, in all its forms. It is friendly and casual, not pretentious at all and children are welcome. entrance is free unless you wish to see one of the many interestsing travelling exhibitions. There is a great cafe/restaurant where you can have a meal.
Don't miss it. Always a wonderful show on. Centrally located, beautiful architecture and good food. Why not?

Art with a view. I love this gallery. There is always an interesting temporary exhibition as well as the really good permanent displays. Some really good Australian art. Well designed spaces for viewing art.
Outstanding!. This place is amazing - the galleries are beautifully presented and the quality of works are quite astounding. Even if you are not that interested in art it is still worth a visit.

Dobell Drawing Exhibition a Winner. Visiting the Picasso exhibition was top of our list for a long weekend in Sydney, however it was the Dobell drawing prize that left us amazed. Attendance is free, as it was to the rest of the gallery - (other than the Picasso exhibit)-. We spent ages exploring each work. The technical skill, creativity and effort that went into many of the works was astounding. What a pity there wasn't a catalogue or book. We also enjoyed, Dragon, the Asian ceramic and other objects' exhibition in honour of the Chinese New Year.The Picasso exhibition was worth seeing for its scope, covering all of his major periods and taking ten different rooms to do so. Picasso was a seminal figure in the art world for most of the twentieth century. He was certainly one of its most prolific producers of art and no stranger to self promotion and marketing. Still I can never shake the feeling that he was completely self indulgent and just a bit reminiscent of the children's story - Emperor's New Clothes.The Art Gallery is next door to the Botanic Gardens. We travelled from Darling Harbour by water taxi and were shown Lloyd Rees and Brett Whiteley's Lavender Bay homes enroute. Disembarking at the Opera House we took a "choo choo" train across the gardens and alighted at stop two only two minutes from the gallery.We spent three hours there seeing the three temporary exhibits, some of the permanent collection, exploring the shop and having a sublime meal in the restaurant

A must do place for Art Lovers. You dont need to be a serious art lover or critic to enjoy this place. Entry is free, although the special exhibitions are usually ticketed at a very reasonable cost. The gallery is divided into sections depending on the type of art and the period and/or country it is from. There is a restaurant and cafe onsite that provide great coffee and food. A must see site in Sydney.
What a view. Very smart venue, great staff and inetresting menu, the view is amazing and makes for a memorable visit, then back to the galleries.

apart from a good permanent exhibition, you can always count on something special. this is the fifth time we've visited this gallery - always pleased. They manage to put on some interesting world class displays, but also represent traditional and modern Australian artists.
Great place to visit. They always have fabulous exhibitions and something for everyone
Worth a visit.. Something for everyone as there is large variety (Asian, European etc). Great for escaping the summer heat.
Great Gallery. Has great touring exhibitions too - Picasso, Monet etc

The Picasso Exhibition. Brilliant. Congratulations to the Gallery on obtaining the exhibition. Of course it is very popular but the gallery staff handled the crowds well and the limited number access ensured that those inside the exhibition had a decent viewing experience. Well Done.

This is a must whilst in Sydney!. Special exhibitions are provided - it is very interesting and many hours can be spent at the Gallery. After a foot tiring time a restaurant can be visited within the building - there are lasting memories forever

Not the Louvre, but some wonderful exhibits. The headline says it all---a good gift shp as well. You can walk up through the Botanical Gardens from the opera house and visit the Art Gallery if you want to make a day of it.

Picasso Exhibition. Go See it. Its a very big and popular exhibition. The gallery also has alot of free exhibiitons worthwhile going to see including the permanent Indigenous Art exhibition on the lower level and more! If you would like to see some amature art have a look at my site! http://michaelbanak.wordpress.com/
Outstanding exhibitions even for not-very-arty. Facbulous exhibitions - and all really well laid out. The AV was amazing and the staff helpful - mostly.
So much to see. This is one of my fave galleries. It has collections of lots of different genres and is in a pleasant location in the Domain.

Picasso. Went to see Picasso at 9am, Domain parking doesn't open till 9am Sunday. Was told to be there 15 minutes before exhibition time. Weren't allowed in till 9:55am. Lady on the door said we don't open till 10am. A gentleman waiting outside with the rest of us who had 9am tickets, said no you have a 9am exhibition this morning. Lady said, I will go check...... Had to race to toilets, they were being cleaned. Had to race down another level. Toilets we used were filthy. Picasso exhibition was well set out and very enjoyable. 9am time avoided main crush of people.

Picasso. The exhibition was great, they really did what they've promised, however I think they could do a little better with decoration and placing of some art, for example I can't really see the full impact of "The man with mandolin" painting until I went across the room..., and some of his painting are placed on white wall, which is cool, but they could do a little more to emphasis the experience

One of my favourite things about Sydney. This is a beautiful art museum with an impressive permanent collection and numerous, international temporary exhibitions, courses, tours, etc. Very recommended!

Picasso Exhibition is recommended. This exhibition is very impressive and I loved the catalogue that selected one work from each room to focus upon. It made the exhibition come alive and it was easier to see the development of the artist's work.

Picasso. We went there for the Picasso exhibition but we ended up spending more time inside than we planned to because there are just so many great masterpieces inside the Art Gallery of NSW to visually savour!
Great Gallery, Great Exhbition. Visit the Gallery for a Picaso exhbition- very nice setting for a gallery- great exhbition

Excellent. The Art Gallery of NSW houses a wonderful permanent exhibition as well as the annual Archibald and other exhibitions. Centrally located near Mrs Macquarie's Chair, the Domain, the State Library, and the Royal Botanical Gardens, the Art Gallery of NSW is easy to find.

Picasso a gogo. You had to buy timed tickets for the Picasso exhibition which was great because it limited the number of people you were competing with to see the paintings (unlike the entombed clay warrior exhibition which was hellish).The free guide was high quality and the children's guide was good too - if pitched a little high, probably suitable for 10+
picasso exhibition. the picasso exhibition was great, the modern art pieces were good, lots of crowds mainly for the picasso exhition. staff friendly and helpful.

Amazing - and it's free!. Not being art-snobs we just popped in to have a brief look on our way to the Botanic gardens but were very impressed. The Picasso exhibition was on, so there were large queues just inside the entry doors, but once you got past them it was really quiet & blissfully air-conditioned on a hot summers day.Had a brief wander at the "Old Master"-type sections which were exactly as you would imagine (massive gilt edged frames with formal portraits of largely unknown European aristocracy and whole walls of landscapes) , then ventured down to the Contemporary Art & Indigenous Art sections which I must confess I found the most interesting and thought provoking. Good mixture of sculptures, paintings and audio-visual displays.I can attest to their excellent security, managing to set off a laser proximity sensor when I leaned too far forward to check out the intricate pencil work on a large abstract piece - the security guard was very friendly, realised I wasn't trying to damage anything and let me off with a gentle rebuke. Well worth a look and sure to have something to please almost everyone.
love Picasso. the Picasso exhibition this summer has been excellent.....it is well designed and gives a real feel for the development as an artist.....well worth the trip

Nice place to spend the day. Spent 3 hours here. There was the Picasso exhibition whilst I was there which was great. Did not see the whole thing as have been to Paris to see the paintings but there were some works and exhibitions which did not require payment.The Australian art section was closed this time but other segments were open. There were some new Chinese art purchases.A pleasant gallery which was not to big nor to small. Can be finished earlier. Wi-fi available!
Excellent time at the Picasso exhibition. Wow! Some of Picasso's best works and no need to travel to France. Really enjoyed it, and the timed entry system seemed to be good at controlling the crowds.
Picasso. Went to the Picasso exhibition was great a real coup to get this collection while the museum in Paris is being renovated. Food also great at the Museum cafe.

Picasso Exhibit worth a visit. The Picasso exhibition currently on at the Art Gallery of NSW (12 Nov 2011 – 25 Mar 2012) is worth a visit. Containing over 150 drawings, paintings, sculptures and sketches imported from the Musee National du Picasso in Paris, the exhibit explores Picasso's work in chronological order from his early days through later life. There are a few well-known pieces on display. The exhibit is very popular and each room is packed with visitors. It has timed tickets so best to book online for the time you want, especially if you have limited time. For example, I arrived when the gallery opened at 10am without a pre-ordered ticket and the earliest I could get in to the exhibit was 11.30am. But there is plenty to see elsewhere in the gallery while waiting to get in. The Kaldor Collection is an interesting display of contemporary art featuring works by Christo, Jeff Koons and many more.

Wonderful relief from the bustle or the heat. This is free to get into (except the large, special exhibitions they sometimes have), so it's a great place to rest your mind, or your feet, after a day sight-seeing. It's also nice and cool on a hot summer's day. Wander around the old paintings and see vistas of Sydney as it once was. Go to the basement and see the aboriginal collection. The cafe down on the middle level is very nice and it's lovely to sit outside and look down into Woolloomooloo.

A small collection of good and average artworks. Visited the Picasso exhibition, and took the time to look around the rest of the gallery. The Picasso exhibition had only a few good peices, the rest were second rate at best. Havign visited the Musee de Picasso in Paris, I recognised a couple of pieces, but it was obvious the best pieces stayed in France. A few good pieces of Australian art on display in the permanent collection. Not a patch on the Canberra Gallery or the NGV in Melbourne.
Magnificent. A must see. Regular artwork by the masters or see one of the many exhibits that change regularly. If you enjoy art .... you have got to see this place.

Picasso exhibition. I came to see the Picasso exhibition and wasn't disappointed - the gallery is largely free unless you specifically pay to see an exhibition (such as the Picasso one), it is well laid out and worth a few hours to immerse yourself and relax
Picasso Exhibition. Great exhibition and well presented. Loved it. Had lunch afterwards in the gallery which was lovely and topped off with my fav ice cream...Ben & Jerry's! Yummy
It's Free.... Want some culture, and for Free. Combine it with the Botanic Gardens...
Picasso in the Botanic Gardens - Sublime!. The setting for our State Gallery is unsurpassed as was the Picasso exhibition. Regardless of why you visit, it should not be missed.

Another Sydney must. Of course as everybody is at the beach, you can tour the museum in excellent conditions, no rush and no queuing. First the building is settled into the park so it is delightful walk, then the building is convenient for all, and difficult access is gently eased by the staff (not like everywhere in the world). Sydney people do mind disabled and prams that is such a caring atmosphere almost everywhere. So, the collection : when you have toured international museums, well you can go directly to the restaurant for the view or the tastes of new food. That is a lovely place to hang around on a rainy or warm day.
