Perfect Picasso. The Picasso exhibition is absolutely excellent, complemented by an excellent brochure. What a genius of a man he was!

Came away with a better understanding of Picasso's art. I am strictly an Impressionist gal. Monet is my hero and Giverny my favourite place on the planet. However, when the Musee National Picasso in Paris decided to lend major works to the Art Gallery of NSW for the summer 2011 - 2012, I decided to go along and try to get a better understanding of this artist's work. The works are well hung, but I was surprised that all the paintings are behind glass. This allowed people to get really close up and personal (though often making it difficult for others to see) but there was very little glare or reflected light getting in the way of the viewing experience. The sculptures are terrific and it was great to be able to see them from many angles. The biggest surprise of the day for me was the first room where his early work is displayed - these I could understand and his 'classical' artistic training was evident to me (who struggles with his later works). The exhibition follows a developmental timeline so the progression from his early, fairly conventional student days through his blue and rose periods to his late works charts these changes - I found this helpful.Entry to the exhibition is staggered at 30 minute intervals, and buying tickets online through Ticketek is a great option - there was still a queue to enter the actual exhibition but it moved quickly. Sydneysiders turned out in force on the day of our visit and while it would be nicer to have the gallery less crowded, it was still wonderful to see so many people of all ages enjoying the experience. Children are included, being given notebooks, pencils and a big picture to colour in, a la the painter's style.The cafeteria was busy - the quality is good, if fairly expensive. Limited parking is available at the door, or The Domain carpark would be best if a walk across grass is not a problem, There is also the 441 bus from the CBD.
Wonderful paintings and exhibits. This is a great way to spend half day. Lots of interesting artwork and always some exhibit on.Nice cafe to eat at & rest after browsing gallery.
Some excellent art is exhibited here. A must for art lovers. Worth a trip to sydney, to combine art and great food at some of the waterside cafes and restaurants.

A must see at least once Art Gallery NSW. The Gallery is Huge and there is not a charge to enter there are charges for special event showings such as the art of Pablo Picasso which started after we had visited the Gallery this year but we will go back to see this great mans workThere is more than one level in the Gallery each showing different aspects of art sculptures very modern art pieces as well as the older traditional paintings such as Hans Heysen's work they do change the paintings around often so never sure what will be on display the day you go Photos of any of the paintings in normal part of the gallery are allowed but probably not of featured artists work no flashes on cameras can be usedThere are plenty of toilets and also a gift shop where many of the paintings displayed can be bought in a print books on artists and there paintings are availableThe Gallery has eating venues we have tried both the restaurant and coffee lounge both were fineLarger bags are asked to be left at the front counter and smaller ones are inspected before entering There is a very small amount of parking outside the Gallery but following the road straight ahead goes past the gates to the botanical gardens there is plenty of meter parking here At the bottom of this street you will find probably the best view in Sydney for taking a photo of the Opera house and Harbour Bridge
Excellent location for lunch to top off a visit to the Gallery. Excellent service with innovative modern Australian cuisine in a location with views.
Mostly Contemporary arts.. I am not so much of contemporary arts fun - so the visit only took about an hour. I like the fact that it is free, and the lobby offers free WiFi.

Must See. The new Contemporrary Gallery is a must see and lots of fun. We also saw the Picasso exhibition. They have brilliant shows here. Walk across the park from the city...a great oasis in the bustle.

a relaxing hour. The building and surrounding gardens are beautiful but the well-travelled art lover will be disappointed. There are so few paintings but the ones that are there are interesting. The entrance is free and so an hour is enough to see it all.

A super place to pop into for an hour or two. Liked : a wide range of art from classical to modern. Not too much of anything - just a good sample of everything. Spacious, cool and attractive gallery. FREE !!!

One of my favourite places in Sydney. Located in midst of lush greenery, the gallery is so inviting. They generally have very interesting exhibitions from all over the world. Its open till late on Wednesdays and they have free film screenings in the cinema. I have spend many a wonderful Sunday afternoon in the gallery and then walking through the botanical gardens to end up at Circular Quay.

Needs some love. The arts are a very poor second cousin in this sports mad land and this is reflected in the gallery. The building is very impressive on the outside but don't expect world class within.

A city of 4 million deserves a larger & better museum. This museum is smaller than I would expect in a city this size. The European collection was not even mediocre - they admit that many of their paintings were rejected by the British Museum first. There is an Asian collection - but the exhibit of the 100 newest acquisitions was a hodge podge with no rhyme or reason to the arrangement. There are several rooms of Australian art - the aboriginal collection is better in the museum in Darwin. It's a good place to go on a rainy day, and adjacency to the Botanical Gardens. Altogether I expected more from Australia's largest city (& this is it, folks).
Big and beautiful. This is a great gallery, the Picasso exhibition was very well done. But the modern art works are also worth spending some time over.
Brilliant.. Great exhibitions, love the early 20th century landscape artists, especially John Glover.
picasso. visited the picasso exhibition and was blown away by the diverse forms of his art that was on display. the other displays are exceptional particularly the australian masters.
picasso exhibition. You have until end of march 2012 to catch this amazing opportunity.

A good afternoon experience. I've been a visitor to the Art Gallery of NSW several times and really enjoy the gallery. It has a well thought out collection located in a number of predominately medium sized rooms and galleries. Unlike other capital city galleries, the Art Gallery of NSW isn't overwhelming in terms of size, and offers a level of intimacy that is lost in larger galleries. With this in mind, the curators do a great job at ensuring they have a well selected range and depth of artwork on display at any given point in time.Entry to the main parts of the gallery is free. Exhibitions are at a cost, but discounts are normally offered under reciprocal rights arrangements with state, national and major international art galleries.Given it's size, the whole gallery can viewed comfortable over the course of half a day. Or for a more leisurely experience, consider a morning tour and lunch at the gallery cafe followed by an afternoon visiting select wings in more detail.For kids, exhibitions tend to have child oriented activities to keep them entertained and engaged. You can also find child based podcasts available for some exhibitions on the gallery's website. Kids audio tours and gallery trails are also available. Visit the gallery's kids webpage for more info. http://www.artgallery.nsw.gov.au/discover-art/gallery-kids/
Picasso exhibit. A great gallery, went to Picasso exhibit which was 9 rooms of fascinating insight into Picassos life
Picasso!. Lovely walk through the Domain to view the Picasso exhibition. Perfect.

Just the place for a rainy day. It just what you do when it rains in Sydney on a Sunday - go to the Art Gallery! Parking is a shocking so take the bus or walk. The collection is good, and the restaurant is great.

Go see Picasso while you can. I didn't have time to go through the whole gallery, but went to see the Picasso exhibition. This is a must-do for everyone - once in a lifetime event. They have it laid out in date order and it gives a great sense of how his art evolved over his lifetime.

Lots put away this time because of the forthcoming Picasso exhibition. Love this gallery but shame so much was not on view. On checking further they have so much stuff they seem to hide away of their regular exhibits.

Good location next to the gardens plus lovely artworks. It was a good 3 hours we had to browse the lovely paintings. They also have a nice restaurant and it is next to the Sydney botanic gardens which all made for a nice day out.
The gallery is a nice old building.
A great gallery. such a nice big galley, old on the outside but new on the inside, the staff are very helpfull and ready to answer all the questions. The artworks in thier are always intresting

Free admission to an eclectic mix of art, with a large contemporary collection. The Art Gallery of New South Wales has a delightful mix of works, from Renaissance European paintings to Asian religious statues to contemporary installation art. It's much larger than it looks from the front because most of the floors are underground, and admission is free (with the exception of certain special exhibits within the museum, such as the current Picasso show). I was especially impressed by the large collection of contemporary art, which occupies the largest floor; I spent about two hours in that collection alone. Best of all, because admission is free, you don't need to see it all at once, if you start to feel museum-ed out; I visited here twice in the course of a week-long visit to Sydney, spending about 4-5 hours total.You won't find too many top-tier names here, some of the better-known artists being Giacometti, Marini, and LeWitt. But the quality of the works is generally excellent, with the exception of the small exhibit of Australian aboriginal works, all of which I found rather unengaging. Toward the southeast corner of the ground floor, there's a new collection of East Asian and South Asian art; don't overlook it because the entrance to that wing isn't immediately obvious, lying beyond, and to the right of, the downward escalators. The museum has free public restrooms, and there's a cafe with a wider menu than you'd expect. There's also a small gift shop.The Art Gallery is located on a quiet road in the Domain, which is essentially the southern extension of the Royal Botanic Gardens. You'll immediately recognize the Gallery because its pillared facade and neoclassical look are typical of art museums everywhere; moreover, the frieze around the museum bears the names of many artists, mostly famous but some forgotten. In the immediate vicinity of the Art Gallery you'll also find a charming statue of the poet Robert Burns, as well as the memorial to New South Wales police officers killed in the line of duty. The nearest train station is St. James, located about 8 minutes' walk southwest of the museum.
Well worth it. I went to see the Picasso exhibit, but would definitely return again to check out the rest of the gallery. Great location, helpful staff and a nice ambiance.
Worth the visit. Some awesome works from all over the world and best place to see Oz artist work. Close to domain and botanic gardens, great view nearby of the harbour and opera house.

Enjoyed the Picasso exhibition!. We really enjoyed the Picasso exhibition. The kids workbook worked a treat and really had our eight year old following the art pieces and also helped Dad learn about some of the art pieces

Book AGNSW Tikatek package but stand firm on what you paid for. Friday of last week, we visited the Picasso Exhibition at the AGNSW. We were told that there would be timed bookings so as not to overcrowd the space. We booked the lunch package - main course, dessert and a glass of wine - in conjunction with the Exhibition and were pleasantly surprised that we could enter the exhibition any time before or after lunch (no passouts, so entry only once). We duly had a delightfully unhindered two hours enjoying the extraordinary works on show then headed for the restaurant. However, when the waiter handed us the menu (which had been published on the website) Tikatek diners were offered an entree (we three did not like any of those offered) and a main with dessert being an added $15. I stated firmly that this was not what we had paid for and the waiter, whilst telling us that it was not his rule, agreed that we should be provided with the published courses. The wine and delicious meal (with included dessert) took away the slightly off taste in our mouths and we left happy.
Picasso Exhibition. Don't miss the Picasso Exhibition- and use the podcast on the gallery website!

Great atmosphere and value. A pleasant place for lunch/brunch with excellent food and service and a very welcoming atmosphere. I have been here several times and believe that this adds to my visits to the gallery, but would also go there to eat without touring the galleries. A good place to meet friends.

Fantastic art gallery on the harbour. We've made multiple visits to this great art gallery and each time is fantastic. Special exhibitions such as Picasso are worth the entry free or just browse through the fabulous Australian art in the free gallerys. And when you need a break, there's a lovely restaurant with views of the city and harbour.

Great PICASSO exhibition. The NSW Art Gallery is currently holding a visiting exhibiton of PICASSO from the Picasso Musuem in Paris (which is currently under renovation), so for of us who need/want a good fix of art whilst in Sydney, this is a great thing. The gallery is always a pleasure to visit, and in particular on a beautiful day, when you walk either through the Domain or the Botanical Gardens to get there, a real Sydney treat. It has a great cofee shop with an outdoor area, s well as a more formal restaurant. The building is a beautiful blend of old and new. From the gallery it is a short walk to the Finger Wharf and its restaurants in Wooloomooloo. The gallery is free but there is a charge for the visiting exhibition.

Australia's Best. This is one of those places in Australia that I just have to visit multiple times whenever I am there. Excellent exhibits -- temporary and otherwise.I also love going to the "Art After Hours".Next time, I'll try to bring my camera and will take a picture of it at night with those gorgeous columns and architecture. Simply amazing.

1pm tours excellent. In 4 days we visited the gallery twice as it was so pleasant. Joined the contemporary and aborigine tours given by very informative volunteers. Gallery well laid out and interesting with a great variety of european and australian artists

Great new exhibition areas. Since I last visited the gallery, there have been new exhibition areas added to accommodate the John Kaldor collection of contemporary art. This has some stunning and thought-provoking work from a range of international and Australian artists. This collection was the highlight of my visit.There was also an exhibition of German expressionist work, which I enjoyed, but was quite expensive to see at $20. I felt some of the works were crowded together which didn't allow for the best viewing experience. With the gallery shop right outside, I wondered if this was intended to be more of a money maker for the gallery than a cultural event.I had a look at some of the recent acquisitions in the Asian art collection, and enjoyed this, although I'm not very familiar with this sort of art.

Excellent gallery. This is just opposite Botanical Gardens. It is a lovely place as the Museuem of Contemprary atr is closed at moment. This is open from 10 am to 5 pm. There are free guided tours on various things like aboriginal art, Collection highlaights, Comtemparary art from 11 am to 2 pm. These are free and the guides are excellent -- they work as Volunteers.

Exciting new contempory galleries. Visited the new John Kaldor contemporary galleries at AGNSW and blown away by the exciting, dynamic, fascinating art, sculpture and video installations. Much contemporary art appears pretencious and dull but this collection is well worth a visit. Highly recommended.

Inspirational and thought provoking collection. When in Sydney I recently I went with a friend to see the new Contemporary Collection at the AGNSW. This new collection has been donated by John Kaldor and is an interesting and eclectic mix of contemporary art from his private collection over the past few decades.Some of the art is brilliant, some is really interesting to sit and ponder and some is not as approachable. But overall it is a fantastic addition to the galleries collections. And if you can view it with a gallery volunteer guide, then it makes it even better.

Trying but failing. This gallery gives the impression of a greatness but in reality it wasn't very good at all.Many exhibitions are NOT free (around $10). The majority of the gallery is mediocre Australian painting - I admit this is not a favourite area of mine.I felt a distint air of pomposity from the staff that created an unfriendly atmosphere throughout.Though there were some good pieces, I wouldn't return.

Perfect Size. As I was in Sydney during their winter (July), made sure to put a few indoor venues on my itinerary, including the Art Gallery. I was quite worried when I arrived at opening to find several school busloads of children pouring into the building, but I needn't have. They broke the kids into small groups of 6 to 10 kids and the docents were brilliant with them. The children were being so entertained and educated that they didn't have time to get noisy or obnoxious. There were practically no artists names I recognized, but that didn't keep me from having a wonderful time. They have a good assortment of European artists and locals, indigenous peoples and Asian art, from classic to modern art. Keep your eyes open for what you can and cannot photograph. The general rule is no Aboriginal art or the main hall pictures. But I asked the docent/security guard about certain pieces and he gave me the go ahead, and some interesting tidbits of knowledge as well. I was prepared to spend money to go in to see the temporary exhibits, but found the free areas to be more than enough for a wintry morning. Found some new artists to research and had a great time.

Always something new to see and do. The Art Gallery of NSW is a very comprehensive art gallery in Sydney, Australia. With galleries devoted to Australian art (18th to 20th C), Aboriginal art, Asian art, contemporary art and European art, in which the artworks being exhibited are regularly updated from the vast collection, plus regular special exhibitions (the yearly Archibald prize is always popular, plus the recent Monet exhibition was also very popular), there is always something new to look at for regular visitors. (Tip: As most major international exhibits only visit one Australian city, interstate art lovers should regularly check out the website for major exhibits that you may want to travel to Sydney to see.)There is also an extensive program of free activities (such as movies related to the current exhibitions, guided tours, kids activities), an excellent café that is not too expensive, a restaurant with wonderful views, and a delightful shop to visit, meaning that you can easily spend a large stretch of time here.One of my favourite features of the gallery is the Art After Hours extended opening hours on every Wednesday (the gallery is open to 9pm instead of the usual 5pm, with, you guessed it, more special talks and tours!) After coming across galleries in Europe that are open at least one evening a week, it was great for the AGNSW to introduce this - the only large gallery or museum in Sydney to do so. For visitors to Sydney who are disheartened by the deadness of the city on weekday evenings, I thoroughly recommend the gallery for an entertaining Wednesday evening.

Art Gallery NSW - what's happening to exhibitions?. Visited the Art Gallery of NSW this afternoon. Nice stroll from the Rocks passing the weekend markets, then down along the Circular Quay listening to the sounds of a guitar playyed by basking artsist, then a quiet jog through the park that starts at the steps of the Opera House. There are 2 equestrian statues outside the Gallery by Gilbert Bayes - The Offerings of War and The Offerings of Peace. These two statues are by the English sculptor Gilbert Bayes [1872-1953]. They were commissioned in 1916 from 18 inch bronzed plaster models, submitted in 1915. Cast in London, dated 1923, they were finally erected in 1926, but only after considerable deliberation as to the most suitable position for them. They were initially intended for the two edges of the Gallery front stairway and these stairs still bear traces of their earlier bases. The one of the left of the Gallery entrance is titled The Offerings of War, and the one on the right The Offerings of Peace. The inscription beneath The Offerings of War reads 'That our house may stand forever / and that justice and mercy grow.' War holds a staff topped by a figure of Winged Victory. He also holds a bundle of swords and broken spear shafts. The inscription beneath The Offerings of Peace reads 'The real and lasting victories / are those of peace and not of war.' Peace offers the Arts and PlentyToday both sculptures were covered with wooden struts so you can hardly see the sculptures themselves. Talking to the Gallery guides I was told that these are not renovations but a new contemporary exhibition preparation for Tatzu Nishi. Tatzu Nishi settled in Germany about twenty years ago. His work focuses on all objects which make up our towns: public benches, lampposts, bus stops and especially monuments and statues. Diverting them from their first use, putting them in unexpected and incongruous situations, he introduces them in a different, funny and poetic light. Since 2001, he has been developing this more ambitious work around big classic sculptures that can be found in any city. The first time Tatzu Nishi exhibited in France he used Nantes Place Royale.According to the Art Gallery NSW deputy director Anne Flanagan Tatzu Nishi is working on War and Peace and In Between, commissioned by Kaldor Public Art Projects, installing his own visions and constructions around the 2 Gallery Sculptures. The work will be open to the public from 2 October through to February 2010. Let's hope it's worth the wait!Downstairs opposite the Gallery Members' Lounge on Lower Level 3 there is an interesting exhibition by Yiribana Aboriginal & Torres Strait Art which will run till 18 December 2009. The exhibition is called The Dreamers. This exhibition celebrates the lives and work of eight distinguished Aboriginal artists who have contributed significantly to Australia’s cultural landscape. Profiling major bodies of work by Kutuwulumi Purawarrumpatu (Kitty Kantilla), Ronnie Tjampitjinpa, Rusty Peters, Dr David Malangi, John Mawurndjul, Ginger Riley Munduwalawala, Judy Watson and Munggurrawuy Yunupingu.Whilst it is popular between overseas visitors, I personally found the exhibits rather disappointing. Too many works on barks and carvings present more of the traditional mediums yet limited works on canvas are present. New mediums such as acrylic paints and canvas have added a new dimension for artists to explore and express themselves.Art forms such as ceramics, pottery and silk paintings have influenced and been incorporated into traditional Aboriginal art.The use of modern styles still allows for the passing on traditional tribal knowledge.I was disappointed not to see works by Tjapaltjarri, brothers who were part of a group known as the 'last of the nomads' and wandered from the desert to encounter white people for the first time in 1984 as their art forms are absolutely, 100 per cent not influenced by European art in any way.Instead of Tjapaltjarri's Tingari the room was filled with Ronnie's works. Seeking the contemporary works in orche the exhibition is rather limited to Rusty Peters. If you want a better experience of aboriginal art, you need to go upstairs to the information desk where on the wall behind you will find a diptich by Freddie Timms and a large Emily Kngwarreye. Hetti Perkins is a gallery's aboriginal art curator and rejected my proposal to add new items to the exhibition. I offered 150 artworks that typically exhibit in British Museum in London, Musée du Quai Branly in Paris and trendy art galleries in NY suggesting they can have them for free and I was surprised to hear that the present works apparently "represent the best of aboriginal art and the gallery does not need any help or suggestions". The other exhibition worth mentioning is Silk Ikats of Central Asia from the collection of the Islamic Arts Museum Malaysia (running for another 7 weeks till 11 October 2009). I enjoyed it endulging into the worlds of ancient history and fashion at the same time. Silk Ikats of Central Asia will display 50 exotic and colourful robes and textiles, wall coverings and jewellery, mainly from Uzbekistan, a land of nearly 30 million people. Central Asian ikats were almost unknown to the rest of the world until as recently as 20 years ago. While often the term ikat, derived from the Malay word for ‘to tie’ or ‘to bind’, is used to refer to the actual process, in Central Asia the Persian term abrbandi - literally cloud (abr) tying (band) is used. The dyeing and binding processes used to create ikats are complex, so the more colours and the more complex the patterns, the more admired the ikat. The rich colours are obtained from natural resources: yellow comes from saffron, black from the skins of pomegranates; red from crushed cochineal insects, and indigo from the indigo plant imported from India. While the origin of the technique of ikat dyeing is uncertain, we know it was practised in China, India, and Eygpt by at least the 7th century. Central Asia has always played a crucial role in east-west exchange because of the famous Silk Road that passed through its numerous cities. Silk Road trade brought great wealth to Central Asia, with textile production a major industry. The people of Central Asia have lived a turbulent history: in the 8th century they were conquered by Arabs who brought with them Islam which has been the major religion ever since. Later in the 13th and 14th century the Mongols came, and then from the mid 19th century it was Russia.Central Asian ikats became more widespread from the early 19th century until the first decade of the 20th century with Bukhara, one of the most ancient cities of Uzbekistan, the centre for the various workshops for weavers, dyers, designers, as well as a wealthy upper class who could afford the textiles. Bright patches of ikat weaving were also used as wall hangings to ornament private homes. Ikats continue to be admired; inspiring contemporary designers such as Oscar de la Renta.The Art Gallery of New South Wales is the leading museum of art in New South Wales and Sydney, and one of Australia's foremost cultural institutions. It holds significant collections of Australian, European and Asian art, and presents about 35-40 exhibitions annually.It's open every day except Good Friday and Christmas Day: 10am - 5pmOn Wednesday it closes late - 9pm as it holds Art After Hours weekly program. The late Wednesday night opening features a free events program with films, talks, performances, food and wine, alongside the exhibitions. The typical Wednesday curriculum is:5.30pm Exhibition Talk6.30pm Celebrity Talk7.15pm Free Art Film (presently running Silk Ikats Along the Silk Road ,The Cave of the yellow dog , Dir Byambasuren Davaa 2008) The best place to park is at The Domain Carpark that is open until 9pm. Parking is also available along Art Gallery Road (takes credit cards and coins, $2.20 per hour). The Gallery offers a complimentary Shuttle Bus to Martin Place every 15 minutes, from 7.15pm until after the last film, and you can take a train from there if needed.The first home for Sydney's art collection was at Clark's Assembly Hall in Elizabeth Street. This building, which had at one time been used for dancing classes, was rented between 1875 and 1879. It was open to the public on Friday and Saturday afternoons. The International Exhibition of 1879 provided an opportunity for the national collection to be re-housed more suitably. Space was initially allocated in the main hall of the Garden Palace, but as lighting and display possibilities were not considered adequate, the Government allowed William Wardell to construct a 'Fine Arts Annexe' of nine rooms near the entrance to the Botanic Gardens. This building was located roughly where the Glass Pyramid now stands. Concerns for the security and care of artworks, particularly after the fire which destroyed the Garden Palace in 1882, ruled out the Annexe as a permanent home for the collection. In December 1885 the collections were moved to a building of six rooms at the present site in the Domain.Early deliberations favoured a site for the Art Gallery on William Street, opposite the Australian Museum, where the recently built Cook and Phillip Park Recreation Centre now stands. Henry Copeland, Member for East Sydney, denounced the Trustees’ preference for a site overlooking Woolloomooloo Bay as the worst possible choice after ‘Fort Macquarie or Shark Island.’The façade and old wing of the Gallery were built between 1896 and 1909. Architecturally, Sydney's Art Gallery reflects nineteenth century ideas about the cultural role of a gallery as a temple to art and civilising values. Yet early designs for the gallery were less confident about the institution's role and image. The present building is the work of Government Architect Walter Liberty Vernon, who secured the prestigious commission over the less conventional architect Horbury Hunt. Hunt had originally been employed by the Gallery when it was decided to move from a temporary wooden structure in the Botanic Gardens to the present site. He erected a building which was nothing more than a series of thick walls with a saw-tooth roof, planned to be the foundation of a more substantial building when funds became available. After ten years of design and funding disputes, Hunt was finally denied the opportunity of completing the gallery. His rejected designs are wildly varied. Stylistic eclecticism characterised much of Hunt's work. It exposed him to severe criticism, but also allowed genuine innovation and creativity. His rejected designs for the Art Gallery of New South Wales include a heavy Gothic structure with a blind arcade of pointed arches winding around the building, even a Byzantine/Islamic hybrid with Moorish arches and a series of domes. Some might agree with Hunt's biographer that he would have provided Sydney with one of its 'finest as well as most hilarious buildings' had he been given the opportunity. Hunt's designs, however, were rejected in favour of Vernon's present chaste, classical building. When Vernon's building was officially completed in February 1909, the press was full of praise. It was felt that the city at last had a public gallery worthy of Australia's Mother Colony and one which, as an added bonus, rivalled Melbourne's multi-purpose Museum, Library and Gallery. It was also viewed as a happy coincidence that the completion of the Sydney gallery coincided with the opening of Sir Aston Webb's grand additions to the Victoria and Albert Museum in London. Comparisons didn't go much further. Webb's rather strange pastiche of Renaissance styles, with pavilion domes, campaniles and a column-tiered tower is far removed from Walter Liberty Vernon's low-lying, simple classic gallery. Yet if Vernon had been left entirely to himself to design the Sydney gallery, we may have had a building more akin to Webb's museum than the present structure. Vernon's first design for the gallery included a dome, along with turrets and pinnacles. He was not an entirely conventional architect, as buildings like the Jacobean-style Challis House on Martin Place testify. Neither was he convinced of the superiority of a classic architectural vocabulary for public buildings. Indeed, throughout his career he tended to favour an adapted Gothic style, believing it admitted greater individuality and richness 'not obtainable in the colder and unbending lines of Pagan Classic.' In many ways, the Art Gallery of New South Wales is a departure from the style he was pursuing in the 1890s. He had abandoned the grand classical manner of his predecessor as Government Architect James Barnet, erecting more modest buildings in brick with stone dressing, incorporating Gothic and many other decorative elements. When one compares the Art Gallery of New South Wales with the former Premier's Office on Macquarie Street [1896], the Tudoresque Land Titles Office [1908] or the elaborate Perpendicular MacLaurin Hall at Sydney University [1902-9], it appears uncharacteristically chaste. The portico is hexastyle in design, with six Grecian Ionic columns supporting a pediment, the tympanum of which was left rough for future carving or decoration. The two end columns are coupled with similar columns behind them. The back portion of the portico encloses a lobby, used then and today as a coat check. This leads into a grand oval vestibule, considered to be Vernon's masterpiece. Its intimate proportions, detailing and use of marble and mosaic give it a sumptuous tone. It consists of two internal bays with apsidal ends. The two central bays are designed with coupled Ionic columns carrying arches which support domes, the central portion of which is glazed to provide lighting to the space. The apsidal ends have a colonnade of similar columns, between which are ornamental niches for statues and which support richly coffered semi-domes. The whole vestibule is of rubbed stone, with column shafts of polished Kempsey marble. Although facade and vestibule were completed in 1902, they were not made available to the public until the floor of the Main Hall was raised to the level of the new entrance. This took over four years to be achieved and generated a stream of acrimonious correspondence to the press about the spending of public monies on projects closed to public use. While this was being done, a basement gallery was opened on 31 October 1904, intended for the display of applied arts and for the gallery's collection of plaster casts and replicas. Today its staircase of Rockley, Fernbrook, Borenore and Molong marble makes an impressive entrance to the Art Gallery Research Library and Archive.On 20 February 1909 the entire façade of the gallery was completed. A circular loggia at the end of the north-west wing differentiated it slightly from the one completed in 1897. As a concluding flourish, names of painters, sculptors and architects were lettered in bronze below the entablature of the building. Forty-four names were intended, thirty-two are to be found on the existing elevation. Painters' names appear on the southern half of the front elevation and on the adjoining side elevation to the south. Sculptors appear on the northern half of the front and were intended for the adjoining side elevation. Architects appear on the rear elevation. It was a peculiar selection of artists, partly representing Victorian tastes and partly the idiosyncratic choice of Eccleston du Faur.When in Sydney, make sure you drop in!

More than just art. Apart from the collections housed at the gallery and visiting collections, there are often small shows aimed at kids, particularly on Sundays or during the school holidays. There are also free movies on Wednesdays as well as talks by different interesting people.
It's Free & Wonderful. Located in the middle of fabulous gardens and very close to the water, this museum has an extensive art collection. A perfect place to visit even on a sunny day.
